HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Incumbent;
Bush Turns to November, Feeling Buchanan's Challenge Has Been Defeated

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Apparently convinced that he has quelled the renegade candidacy of Patrick J. Buchanan, President Bush today began to shift his political energy away from a revolt by his conservative supporters and toward the more formidable job of rebuilding his standing among voters of all stripes.
The President signaled what amounts to the beginning of his campaign for the November election at a White House news conference. He declared that he has "responsibilities that no other candidate has for leading this country and for being the President," and that he will pare his political travel to tend to the nation's problems. 
Mr. Bush also implicitly invited Mr. Buchanan to end his candidacy, asserting that most Buchanan supporters will vote for him in November and that Mr. Buchanan himself would be welcomed should he decide to rejoin the ranks of the President's backers.
The President's political advisers said Mr. Bush would now concentrate on convincing voters that he has a workable plan to restore the nation's economic and moral strength and, equally important, that his Democratic rivals do not. That effort will begin in earnest on March 20, the deadline Mr. Bush set in his State of the Union speech for Congress to enact legislation that he has proposed to stimulate the economy but which congressional Democrats already have rejected.
 
Defections Stemmed

 
 Mr. Bush's strategists plan to highlight the passing of the deadline with a carefully staged event, like an Oval Office speech, a prime-time televised news conference or an address to Congress. None has been chosen, although aides are leaning away from a nighttime speech, one White House official said today. Networks have not carried some such speeches before.
This campaign will continue throughout the spring, when Mr. Bush will deliver a series of speeches outlining his view of the issues in the November election, veto any Democratic economic package that does not conform to his plan, and take action to stimulate the economy that does not need Congress's approval.
The shift from conservative stump-speaker back to Rose Garden leader has actually been in the works for several weeks, Mr. Bush's strategists said. It is driven by a lull in the primary season between next Tuesday's contests in Illinois and Michigan and early May.
But it has been made possible only by the voting in this week's Super Tuesday primaries, in which Mr. Buchanan largely failed to widen the defection of disaffected voters from Mr. Bush's camp, and the President scored several compelling victories. Mr. Bush's advisers also concede that the quarter or so of Republican voters who have consistently backed Mr. Buchahanan are unlikely to return to the fold during the remaining prmaries unless the economy improves.
"If we'd had the luxury of not having to run a primary campaign, we'd already have begun to lay out the facts of George Bush's vision of America," James Lake, a senior issues adviser to Mr. Bush's campaign, said today. "As of today, that campaign, for all practical purposes, is over."
While the President will make other ostensibly nonpolitical trips in coming months to promote his economic-growth legislation, aides said, there will be little of the campaign barnstorming that has characterized his travels since last month's New Hampshire primary election.
 
Getting Beyond a Slogan

 
 In the 20 days that ended on Saturday, the President traveled to 22 cities in 11 states. The crusade amounted to a furious courtship of Republicans who were flocking to Mr. Buchanan, largely out of disaffection with Mr. Bush's attention to the conservative right and his handling of the economy.
In the two weeks that began on Sunday, Mr. Bush plans but two day trips to the Midwest, where primary elections are being held next Tuesday.
Mr. Bush's campaign manager, Robert M. Teeter, said in an interview last week that the White House hopes in the next month to start the process of fleshing out a re-election platform that so far is little more than the political slogan, "Jobs, family, peace." Mr.
"In the next six months, we're going to stress a lot about the job the President has done on a lot of very difficult issues, where he has led this country and the world through some remarkable changes," Mr. Teeter said.
Mr. Bush may even return foreign affairs to his White House agenda for the first time since his politically disastrous journey last January to Japan and three other Pacific nations. The White House is reconsidering the decision not to send Mr. Bush to a global environmental summit in Rio de Janiero in June. Officials also continue to study the options for action against Iraq and Libya, which are flouting United Nations mandates.

HEADLINE: New York Threatens Penalties Against Bond Underwriter

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
New York City officials said yesterday that they plan to withhold $250,000 of $1 million to $2 million in fees from the city's main underwriter of bonds, the First Boston Corporation, as a penalty for the investment bank's failure to disclose its purchase of city bonds that could have yielded a profit at the city's expense.
First Boston, which is currently underwriting more than $1 billion in city debt, will also pay for the city's investigation into the matter, which is being conducted by the city's counsel on bond disclosure, Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith. 
 While city officials said that it was too early to determine the total cost of the investigation, lawyers familiar with such inquiries estimated that the city would incur more than $100,000 in legal fees.
City officials said the penalties are intended to send a strong message to First Boston that they are agitated about First Boston's handling of the bond transaction.
The city hired First Boston to underwrite $1 billion of low-interest bonds, the proceeds from which would be used to repurchase $84 million worth of bonds at a higher interest rate. In February, First Boston bought $13 million of the $84 million of bonds the city planned to repurchase.
First Boston did not notify the city of its purchase. The city discovered the transaction on March 3 and began an investigation.
The city's Corporation Counsel, F. Peter Sherwood, said yesterday that the $250,000 in fees would be withheld from First Boston to reimburse the city for the investigation.
Still, the city has retained First Boston as its main underwriter of the deal, and the investment bank stands to gain the bulk of the $1 million and $2 million that it was to receive for handling the bond offering.
Details of the city's plan to withhold $250,000 in fees from First Boston were first reported in the The Bond Buyer newsletter on Tuesday.
Archibald Cox Jr., president and chief executive of First Boston, said the bank had agreed to pay the $250,000 and legal fees to keep its client happy. "I would hate for people to think that we have admitted to any culpability just because we have agreed to pay this," he said.

HEADLINE: Republicans' Tax Plan Is Rejected by Senate

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Voting almost entirely along party lines, the Senate tonight rejected, 60 to 37, a Republican tax measure. The defeat surprised no one, least of all the Senate's Republican leaders, who had introduced it not because they thought the measure would pass but because they wanted their own position to defend.
The Democrats, meanwhile, rushed to adjust their plan, to protect it against challenge because it would increase the budget deficit, eliminating $3.5 billion in tax credits for middle-class parents. 
 The Senate took up the Republican plan, a modified version of President Bush's seven-point tax proposal, as the second of a number of amendments to the Democratic bill, which is expected to be approved by the end of the week. The first, which would have linked pharmaceutical companies' tax credits to drug prices to hold down health-care costs, was defeated 61 to 36.
 
Urging Fairness
 Like President Bush, the Republicans leaders would have cut corporate taxes by accelerating depreciation, reduced the capital gains tax to 15.4 percent and provided tax breaks for home buyers and real estate investors. And like Mr. Bush, they stumbled over a tax cut for families. The Democrats have been touting their measure, which centers on tax cuts for the middle class and increases for the well off, as one that would make the tax code fairer.
Under the changes introduced tonight by the majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the middle-class tax break would now apply only to families earning up to $40,000, and would phase out at $50,000. The original Democratic proposal was for a $300 tax credit to families earning up to $50,000, but phased out for families earning up to $70,000.
On the Republican side, some senators had wanted to include a $500 increase in the personal exemption for each child, paid for by cuts in military spending; others backed off, saying it would promote consumption rather than economic growth and would hurt the party's image of concern about the Federal budget deficit.
Mr. Bush proposed such a change in January but did not include it in the seven-point list he said he wanted passed by March 20, an omission that his Republican challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, stressed to New Hampshire primary voters as a sign that the President was not concerned about their interests.
The principal difference between the White House and the Senate Republican plans came in how to pay for them. Instead of making accounting changes in long-term Federal programs and claiming them in the coming fiscal year, as the President proposed, the Senate Republican plan would rely on small spending cuts and the sale over five years of $3 billion in minerals in Defense Department stockpiles.
"It's important for a lot of people to be for something, and it's clear that's why the leadership package is being offered," said Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, before the debate.
Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, said that doing without any Republican measure "would be fine." A certain Presidential veto of the Democratic bill made the current round of tax legislation "a dry run," he added.
In a news conference, President Bush vowed again today to veto the Democratic bill because it included tax increases. "I'm going to veto this tax bill; we've got too many," he said. "This would be the worst time to raise taxes. No time is good, but this would be the worst."
The middle-class tax cut that Republican moderates rejected had been backed by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and other conservative Republicans.
After a day of negotiations among Republican senators, Mr. Gramm agreed to support the leadership's proposal while reserving the right to introduce his own measure later that would also include the tax credit.
The Senate spent the morning and most of the afternoon debating the other amendment it later defeated. Sponsored by Senator David H. Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, it would have curbed the tax credits of pharmaceutical companies that raise their prices faster than the inflation rate.
Mr. Pryor said that pharmaceutical companies had tripled the profit margins of the average large industrial corporation because of "outright price gouging" at the expense of the old and the sick.
But Senators Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg, both Democrats of New Jersey, a home to large drug companies, said that pharmaceutical companies needed the ability to raise prices as needed to pay for research. Prescription drug purchases account for only 7 percent of the nation's health care spending, Mr. Bradley said.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Climbs

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 11

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus soared to an all-time high in February as exports, especially to Asia, jumped while a slowing domestic economy and lower oil prices trimmed imports, economists said today.
The Ministry of Finance said the surplus, without being adjusted for seasonal factors, more than doubled, to a record $10.23 billion, from $5.06 billion in February 1991. 
 Japan has been trying to fend off foreign criticism, particularly from Washington, over the size of its enormous trade surplus by decreasing the volume of exports and increasing imports.
But in February exports increased 12.4 percent, to $28.08 billion, and imports fell 10.3 percent from a year earlier, to $17.86 billion.
"Today's figures were a sign that the Japanese economy is starting to depend more on exports than domestic demand," said Hiroaki Hashiguchi, an economist at Tokai Bank.
Exports to Asian nations posted a larger increase compared with those to the United States and Europe, where economies are sluggish and the stance against trade imbalances with Japan is tougher, economists said.

HEADLINE: Casino Developer Tries One Hard Sell: Hartford

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 11

 BODY:
In this old city of insurance companies and banks, the buttoned-down culture seems as ingrained as the methods of actuarial accounting. There are few showgirls, and neon is mostly considered an inert gas. Want some time alone? Go downtown at 9 P.M.
Mirage Resorts wants to build a $350 million resort casino and convention center in the middle of all that. 
 "If you build it, they will come," Stephen A. Wynn, Mirage's president and chairman, told a joint committee of the General Assembly today, quoting from the movie "Field of Dreams," which starred Kevin Costner, whom Mr. Wynn described as a close personal friend.
Mr. Wynn is no idle dreamer or crank. He represents a company that he said made more than $200 million in operating profit last year from one Las Vegas property alone, or as Mr. Wynn put it, twice the profits of the entire Sheraton Hotel chain. Besides the Mirage Casino Hotel, Mr. Wynn's company also owns two Golden Nugget casinos in Las Vegas.
 
Gray Flannel and Green Felt
 Tanned and polished, he swept into Connecticut's Capitol like a foreign potentate, ready, he said, to stake his personal fortune and reputation on the notion that Hartford's gray corporate flannel and Nevada's green casino felt could coexist to the enrichment of all.
Flanked by sleek aides, Mr. Wynn dropped names by the handful (Jimmy Carter has stayed at the Mirage; Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers treat it like a second home), belittled Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and flattered his hosts about their intelligence in considering his proposals, which he said would employ 5,000 people and pump $500,000 to $1 million a week into the local economy in supply purchases alone.
But the smooth-as-glass presentation, and even the news that Mr. Wynn likes dolphins so much that he swims with them "three or four times a week" still seemed to some lawmakers to overlook the almost Zen-like question raised by Mr. Wynn's assessment and remedy for the capital city: Is Hartford boring because its economy is depressed and its nightlife is minimal, as he contends, or because its very identity is boring?
Like a fragile ecosystem that could be shattered from undue stress, would a more exciting Hartford really be Hartford?
 
Few Have the Vision
 "I can't think of too many places that are as different from Las Vegas as Connecticut," said Representative Irving J. Stolberg, a Democrat from New Haven. "A lot of people don't want to lose that."
There seems little chance that Hartford will get a casino soon. Mr. Weicker has vowed to veto any casino bill, and Hartford's Mayor, Carrie Saxon Perry, has also announced her opposition. Even the main proponent, Senator William A. DiBella, a Democrat from Hartford who said today that Mr. Wynn's plan makes "infinite sense for this city and this region," concedes that many lawmakers lack his "vision."
Although Connecticut does have one casino, which opened last month at the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation in Ledyard, state laws prohibit gambling for profit off the reservation. Mr. DiBella and other supporters say that that will change eventually across the Northeast and the cities that don't act soon could lose out.
Mr. Wynn said that he and Jon Adams Jerde, an architect whose credits include planning for Euro Disney in Paris, would construct a "synergy" of entertainment, hotel and convention center space that would revitalize Hartford's downtown, bring in millions of new tourists and convention visitors and employ thousands of poor city residents.
 
Gambling for Conventions
 Gambling, he said, would only be a means to an end. The casino's revenues would subsidize the convention center, allowing the center to charge lower rates that would in turn capture more convention business for the city and, to complete the circle, more gambling revenues for Mr. Wynn.
Without gambling, the standard convention center that Hartford wants to build in the next decade will have to compete by price alone, dooming both the city and state to long-term subsidies and cutthroat competition without guarantee of success, Mr. Wynn argued. Gambling might not be ideal, he conceded, but the world has changed.
"If you can get a steel mill to come to Hartford, I say do it right away," he said.

HEADLINE: Reebok Fights to Be No. 1 Again

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
Most days, weather permitting, several Reebok executives spend their lunchtime playing pickup basketball on the asphalt court at the edge of the company's parking lot near Boston. The game is friendly, but serious, as the men and women players join in for the exercise and to promote corporate camaraderie.
But most of all, it is a practical training ground in the competitive spirit driving the company these days: Reebok wants to be a winner again. 
 Ever since Nike took away its title in 1989 as the nation's No. 1 seller of athletic shoes, Reebok has been waging a fierce marketing battle to win back the prestige and sales appropriated by its rival.
It is continuing the fight this year with a new ad campaign called "Life Is Short. Play Hard," and it is gambling that a steady stream of new shoe designs and gimmicks will catapult it back into first place.
"We hadn't been hitting on all cylinders during the last few years," said Angel Martinez, Reebok's corporate vice president for new business development. "But we are starting to now."
In the last two years, Reebok International Ltd., based in Stoughton, Mass., has increased its share of the domestic market to 24 percent from 22 percent. Nike Inc.'s share, meanwhile, has held steady at 30 percent of the $5.82 billion athletic shoe market.
"Reebok is getting closer and closer to Nike by beating up the other players in the marketplace," said John Horan, editor and publisher of the Sporting Goods Intelligence Management News, an industry publication. "Reebok has a huge advantage because it can afford expensive promotional campaigns."
Reebok's current campaign is tied to the coming Summer Olympics. Like much of Reebok's past offbeat advertising, the new commercials feature a humorous competition between two members of the United States Olympic team, the decathletes Dave Johnson and Don O'Brien, both of whom boast they are the world's best athletes. And as with some of Reebok's past campaigns, this one has also been criticized as not being focused enough on the shoes.
Although Nike is a sponsor of the Summer Olympics, Reebok will be the exclusive athletic shoe and active-wear advertiser during Olympic broadcasts. In addition, the company has designed the uniform that American winners will wear when they step up to accept their medals.
 
Battle of Inflatable Shoes
 Nike's Air series of shoes with pre-filled air cushions helped the company move into first place. In turn, Reebok began to revitalize its sagging image with the Pump inflatable shoe, which allows for a more custom-fit by pumping air into inflatable chambers in the shoe.
But company executives know the popular Pump cannot do the job alone. Since its introduction, the Pump has accounted for about 16 percent of Reebok's annual sales. So far, some six million pairs of Pump shoes have been sold for a total of $750 million.
The Pump's popularity has helped to give the company bottom line a healthy boost. Last year, Reebok's worldwide sales increased by 26.6 percent, to $2.7 billion. Profits also jumped to $234.7 million in 1991, compared with $176.6 million the previous year.
As the market for the Pump matures, sales are expected to drop by as much as 30 percent this year. "The Pump got the energy flowing again at Reebok," said Bob Meers, president of United States operations. "But it's only part of Reebok, it has to evolve."
 
$220 Million for Ads
 To help offset that decline, Paul Fireman, Reebok's chairman, said the company would spend about $220 million on advertising this year, substantially more than the $140 million it allocated in 1991. Some analysts said that level of spending might help Reebok slow the Nike juggernaut a little. This year, Nike plans to spend about $150 million.
To keep customers' interest, especially prime ones in the 12-to-18-year-old group who continually change their taste in shoes, Reebok last year introduced several redesigned shoes. Among them is a double-pump version with two inflation gadgets to pump air into more areas of the shoe. Another is a sturdier shoe called the Blacktop, which the company says is made for playing basketball on the rough surfaces of outdoor courts.
In January, at a trade show for sporting-goods manufacturers and retailers in Atlanta, Reebok introduced an advanced version of the Pump that makes it easier to inflate the interior of the shoe around the foot. The Insta-Pump, which is inflated using a small canister of carbon dioxide, instead of manually, is intended to give greater support for runners and tennis players. If the Insta-Pump proves to be popular, Reebok plans to use the technology in all of its athletic shoes eventually.
With the Insta-Pump, some analysts say Reebok may have taken the lead in technology. "The Insta-Pump is on the cutting edge in athletic shoe technology," Mr. Horan of Sporting Goods Intelligence said. "Reebok has demonstated that it can make a better shoe. The other brands will be forced to follow suit."
But making headway in the women's market will not be easy for Nike. Reebok first made its reputation with hot-selling aerobics shoes mainly aimed at women. Reebok still dominates the women's athletic shoe market with a 49 percent share, company executives said, and its Step Aerobics, a new exercise program intended to replace the more old-fashioned jump-and-kick aerobics, is helping it to keep market share.
Not coincidentally, Reebok sells Step aerobics shoes and also markets the portable plastic steps that exercisers sometimes stack up three or four at a time.
The company has also begun to branch out into other areas of athletic wear that it hopes will be as rich as footwear has been. The company has put a greater emphasis on its apparel division, which includes casual and athletic wear for adults under the Reebok, Allesse and Rockport brands, as well as Weebok, a new line of clothes and shoes for children.
"In the past, we had not made apparel a serious business," said Marilyn Tam, president of the apparel products group. "Now we have some of the top people in the business."
 
Chief Executive's Role
 Many Reebok executives attribute the company's revival to John Duerden, who became the president and chief executive of the company in 1990. A former Xerox executive, Mr. Duerden has used his buttoned-down corporate style to temper Reebok's entrepreneurial zeal. "This was a big company that needed some discipline," he said. "You can't just make shoes at random."
Mr. Duerden streamlined the company's management so that only 12 executives report to him. Now, the company feels it can move more quickly to accommodate the company's core of fickle customers, who love new types of shoes. "To keep up with the marketplace, we now have to change one-third of the products we produce two times each year," Mr. Duerdan said.
He has also mandated that pleasing customers is as important as designing shoes. Reebok now keeps closer tabs on whether retailers are getting enough of the right merchandise on time. Even Mr. Duerdan calls 10 retailers each week to listen to their complaints or bask in their praise.
In a sort of marketing show-and-tell, Reebok has begun to open its own stores that company executives say are intended to demonstrate to retailers the best way to sell Reebok shoes, clothing and other athletic gear. The first Reebok Concept store opened in Boston last year and the next one is scheduled to be completed in May in Manhattan. "These shops are not intended to compete with other retailers," Mr. Meers said. "These are living merchandising laboratories." Nike has opened similar stores.
 
Some Traditions Survive
 But Mr. Duerdan did not tamper with some Reebok traditions. On his first day at Reebok's headquarters, an unsuspecting Mr. Duerdan walked into the third-floor conference room to sit in on what he thought would be a run-of-the-mill meeting about new products. The room was jammed with employees from every level of the company. The scene was chaotic as executives shouted at co-workers, waving new shoes and sometimes hurling them at each other to make a particular point. One designer had been reduced to tears by a particularly scathing review.
"I couldn't believe it," Mr. Duerdan said. "I tried to put limitations on these meetings, but I realized I couldn't because they were too much a part of the company's culture."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reebok's president and chief executive, John Duerden, involves himself in nearly every aspect of the company's operations. He recently met with a group of Reebok shoe designers to discuss new styles. From left were Paul Brown, the vice president for design; Mr. Duerdan; Rob Purvy and Dave Preskar. HEADLINE: Court Halts Projects Planned for Pine Barrens

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLANDIA, L.I., March 11

 BODY:
A divided State Appellate Court has ordered a sweeping environmental review of the last large tracts of undeveloped pine forest on Long Island, overturning hundreds of zoning decisions by local governments.
In the decision, the State Appellate Division in Brooklyn barred any development in the environmentally sensitive Pine Barrens, an area of almost 200 square miles, until a study has examined the cumulative effects of hundreds of developments planned there. 
 Environmentalists said the decision would force the creation of a master plan that would save much of the unusual woodland, with its rare species of plant and animal life, and preserve some of the purest water in the region, which lies thousands of feet beneath the Pine Barrens. The vote, which overturned a lower court decision, was 3 to 2.
 
Tool for Environmentalists
 The suit, if upheld on a probable appeal to the state's higest court, the Court of Appeals, could give environmentalists a new tool that could be used to require comprehensive planning before projects could be approved in other environmentally sensitive regions on Long Island and across the state.
"The same theory would apply to the Adirondacks, the Catskills, the Great Lakes and along the Hudson River," said Michael B. Gerrard, a lawyer with Berle, Kass & Case, who represented the Long Island Pine Barrens Society in the suit. "This is one of the most important environmental decisions handed down by the state courts in the past decade."
The decision could delay for years as many as 250 projects proposed by private developers across the region, from small housing developments to a huge development project with a 150-acre mall and 12,000 homes planned near the Long Island Expressway in Yaphank. The projects were valued by developers at as much as $11 billion.
 
Stalled by Recession
 But most of the projects have already been stalled by the recession and uncertainty over the Pine Barrens lawsuit that has been wending its way through the courts since 1989.
"There are many developers hanging on by their eyelids," said Edwin M. Schwenk, executive director of the Long Island Builders Insittute, which represents residential developers. "With this decision, the right of towns to effectively plan their own destiny has been superseded."
Patricia C. Moore, the Riverhead Town Attorney, called the decision a "nightmare" of clashing jurisdictions between three different town zoning bodies and a variety of state agencies. She said that she would recommend that the town appeal the decision.
But in Southampton, the Town Supervisor, Fred Thielle, said he would probably recommend to the Town Board that it drop out of the case. "Rather than spending town funds on lawyers -- in what is essentially a battle between environmentalists and developers -- I would prefer to spend it on planning," he said, "deciding where to build and where not to build."
The Pine Barrens -- harsh forests dominated by pitch pines that took root in the sandy soil -- once covered much of Long Island, but were cut down and replaced by tract houses and strip malls.
Rainfall on the pine barrens percolates down through thousands of feet of sand and gravel to deep aquifers that are Long Island's only water supply. Water from the aquifer is so pure that the Suffolk County Water Authority is considering marketing it in bottles across the country.
In 1987, the State Legislature designated the Central Pine Barrens and seven other Long Island sites "special ground-water protection areas" and called for a study of the level of development that could be permitted without polluting the underground water. The study was not binding on town governments.
In its decision announced today, the Appellate Court ruled that the action of the Legislature in setting up a ground-water protection area triggered a higher level of review under the state environmental quality review law and required a detailed comprehensive impact statement covering the entire area.
The decision covered projects 30 miles or more apart, including those in virgin woods as well as projects, especially in western Suffolk County, in already developed areas. It would also probably have an impact on a proposal, opposed by environmentalists, to convert an airfield used by Grumman into an international freight airport.
"The various projects -- although functionally unrelated -- are similarly linked by virtue of their potential to adversely affect an irreplaceable natural resource located within a discrete geographic area," said Justice William C. Thompson, in the majority decision. He was joined by Justices Geraldine T. Eiber and Sondra Miller.
 
Albany Case
 Though the outcome of the case on appeal is uncertain, the Appellate Court decision is grounded in a prior decision by the Court of Appeals in a case involving a specially designated Pine Bush preservation area in Albany.
In that case, the court ruled that once the city had set up special environmental rules, any project had to take into account the cumulative impact of all development in the areas.
In a dissent, Justice Thomas R. Sullivan said that the Legislature in designating special groundwater protection areas made sweeping policy statements but adopted no guidelines or standards. He was joined in the dissent by Justice John Copertino.
A draft water-protection-area study, carried out at the behest of the Legislature, called for Suffolk County to buy some environmentally sensitive land and for five-acre zoning in much of the Pine Barrens to protect the underground water supply.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Control Data Official To Be Chief at Quantum

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Quantum Corporation, a leading disk drive manufacturer, said yesterday that William J. Miller would join the company as chief executive. Mr. Miller joins Quantum after 11 years with the Control Data Corporation, where he was most recently executive vice president, as well as president of information services.
As chief executive, Mr. Miller, who is 46, succeeds Stephen M. Berkley, 48, who will remain actively involved as chairman, the company said. Quantum, based in Milpitas, Calif., does not have a president. 
 "Bill brings to Quantum a unique combination of hard-disk-drive industry experience, leadership and proven ability to grow a business," Mr. Berkley said in a statement. "These are all qualities that will be important for us as we put the strategies in place to continue building our business."
Founded in 1980, Quantum is a leading manufacturer of hard disk drives for personal computers. Its largest customer is Apple Computer Inc. Analysts say Quantum has been performing well and that the executive change came as a surprise.
"Steve Berkley is a vital guy and has done a great job boot-strapping Quantum," said John Rossi, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company in San Franicisco. "He has driven them through a heavy growth stage in the last two years," he said. On the other hand, he added, "Bill Miller has a good reputation in the industry and is probably a good choice."
At Control Data, Mr. Miller was previously president and chief executive of Imprimis Technology, a wholly owned subsidiary at the time. He was credited with the turnaround of Imprimis, a billion-dollar company specializing in hard disk drives for larger computers, before it was acquired by Seagate Technology in 1990.
Before that, Mr. Miller led the small-disk division of Control Data's data-storage products group, the predecessor of Imprimis. Earlier, he held senior management positions in marketing and legal support.
Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview that he relished the chance to run a disk drive company again after his favorable experience with Imprimis. "Quantum's a terrific company, on a course that's real compatible with what I believe in," he said.
He received his B.S. in economics and his law degree from the University of Minnesota.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt and Taxable Yields Slip a Bit

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The yields on tax-exempt funds moved down a little more for the week ended Monday, while the taxables moved down slightly for the week ended Tuesday, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
"Despite the lower rates the assets of the tax-free funds remained close to recent highs," said Walter Frank, economist for Donoghue's. The average tax-exempt yields, he pointed out, were competitive with taxable yields for the high-bracket taxpayer, which might explain the steadiness in the assets of the tax exempts. 
 Mr. Frank said the yields on taxable funds were still declining, "but since open-market rates have moved up slightly in recent weeks, we should see that reflected very shortly in the yields of the money funds."
The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempts was down 7 basis points, to 2.50 percent, from the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield dropped to 2.47, also down 7 basis points. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
In the same period, the 30-day compounded yield was 2.61, off 10 basis points; the simple yield was down 9 basis points, to 2.58.
 
Top Performers
 The top Connecticut fund again was the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compounded yield of 2.91, down 3 basis points.
In New Jersey, the top fund again was the Fidelity Spartan N.J. Municipal Money Market Portfolio, with a yield that dropped to 2.83 percent, down 22 basis points.
In New York, the top fund again was the Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market. It had a seven-day compounded yield of 3.36, down 12 basis points.
Assets of the tax-exempt funds, rose by $901 million, to $98.9 billion. Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios remained unchanged at 52.
Of the funds monitored by Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund of Milwaukee continued to lead with a seven-day compounded yield of 3.38, down 12 basis points from the previous week.
 
Taxable Funds
 The assets of the taxable funds rose by $4.1 billion, to $499 billion. Mr. Frank said the increase was from institutional buying because there was a small outflow by small investors.
Mr. Frank said the average days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds held steady at 57.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield dropped 4 basis points, to 3.79 percent, from the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield declined 3 basis points, to 3.72.
The 30-day compounded yield on the taxables declined 3 basis points, to 3.84 percent, from the previous week, and the 30-day simple yield dropped to 3.77, also off 3 basis points.
The Fidelity Spartan Money Market Fund led the way as the taxable fund with the highest yield -- 4.45 percent.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.68 percent, off 2 basis points, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Small Business Aid Backed By House Panel and S.E.C.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1

 BODY:
A House panel, with its Republican members on board, recommended increases in Government-backed loans to small businesses today.
Meanwhile, the Securities and Exchange Commission, as expected, proposed changes in regulating mutual funds to make it easier for small businesses to raise money through the stock market. 
 The House Small Business Committee unanimously said the Government should guarantee $18 billion in private loans to credit-pressed small businesses between now and 1994.
The approved measure contrasts with more modest requests by the Bush Administration, which originally sought to guarantee about $11 billion in loans between now and late 1994 and only recently asked Congress for more.
 
Soaring Loan Demand
 Under the program, the Small Business Administration acts as a guarantor for small business loans that might not otherwise have been granted. Demand for the loan guarantees has soared during the recession.
Because the Government must set aside only a fraction of the amount in loans it guarantees, the $18 billion in loan guarantee authority recommended by the committee would actually cost the Government about $1 billion.
But many obstacles stand between today's action and an actual increase in Government-backed lending. Because of budget constraints, Congress must cut money from other domestic programs to clear the way for the additional guarantees.
In proposing changes in regulating mutual funds, the S.E.C. is taking up the proposals of its chairman, Richard C. Breeden, for easing the regulatory burden on small companies, which are having problems raising money just as banks are lending less.
The commission agreed to propose a plan that allows mutual funds to increase their stake in small companies, which cannot sell their securities as easily as big companies can. The panel also proposed legislation that would create a new class of less-regulated mutual fund geared to supplying venture capital.
But the expected highlights of Mr. Breeden's plan are proposals for cutting the red tape that often makes it too expensive for small companies to register their securities with the S.E.C. before selling them.
 
Simplifying the Process
 The proposals would simplify the disclosure forms that companies must fill out and lower the standards for qualifying to use the easier, and cheaper, disclosure documents.
The S.E.C. was expected to seek public comment on the proposals before a final decision to be made sometime in the future.
Mr. Breeden's proposed changes would reduce the amount of information some companies have to supply investors, opening him up to criticism that he is sacrificing investor protection for short-term aid to the economy -- and possibly a political gain for his former boss, President Bush, in an election year.

HEADLINE: Record Orders For U.S. Chips

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 11

 BODY:
Orders for semiconductors in the United States set a record in February, the Semiconductor Industry Association reported today.
The data suggest that despite the recession, computer companies and other makers of electronic gear seem to be ordering components, perhaps in anticipation of greater sales. 
 The trade group also reported that the book-to-bill ratio, an important index of the industry's health, rose to 1.12 for the three months ended in February, compared with 1.09 for the three months ended in January. A ratio of 1.12 means that for every $100 worth of products shipped, $112 of orders were received, a sign that sales should increase.
Daniel Klesken, semiconductor analyst at Robertson Stephens & Company in San Francisco, said he thought there were strong shipments of particular chips, not strength industrywide. He added that the industry ratio always tended to rise in the spring.
The industry group said the February figure for bookings, or orders, was $1.52 billion, up 4.9 percent from January. The figure for billings, or shipments, was $1.36 billion, up 2.6 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off After Intervention By Switzerland and Japan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower against other major currencies yesterday after the Swiss and Japanese central banks entered the market.
Analysts said the dollar ran into resistance after the Swiss National Bank intervened to support the weakening franc and the German mark. Traders used the intervention as an excuse to liquidate large dollar holdings. 
 The Swiss bank's actions worked, as the dollar fell to 1.5075 francs, from 1.5165 late Tuesday in New York. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.5085 francs, from 1.5170.
The dollar also fell to 1.6635 marks, down from 1.6705, in New York, and to 1.6650 marks, down from 1.6715, in Europe.
 
Yen Declines Anyway
 The Bank of Japan, however, was unsuccessful in its attempt to prop up the yen, which has been battered by the weakening Japanese economy and the falling Tokyo stock market. Although the Japanese central bank sold dollars, the United States currency still ended the day with a gain against the yen.
The dollar rose to 133.40 yen in New York, from late Tuesday's 132.90. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 133.70 yen, up 1.70 yen. In London, it was quoted at 133.55 yen.
John McCarthy, chief foreign exchange dealer with ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. in New York, said central banks were the main sellers. He said other players selling dollars were motivated more by technical factors than by a belief the dollar was fundamentally weak.
The British pound advanced against the dollar, closing at $1.7260 in New York, up from $1.7175. In London, the pound rose to $1.7250, from $1.7160 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 5.6485 French francs, down from 5.6725; 1,246.50 Italian lire, down from 1,251.00, and 1.19585 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19725.
In the precious metals market, gold rose $1.70 an ounce, to $350.70, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $349.95, up $1.15.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $349.25 an ounce, from $348.65. In Zurich, the metal was unchanged at a bid of 348.75. In Hong Kong, gold fell 43 cents an ounce, to a bid of $349.74.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Miracle Saves The Toolworks

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
THE Software Toolworks Inc. used to be a struggling producer of games and educational programs, mired in losses and shareholder suits, abandoned by securities analysts. Then came the Miracle.
The Miracle Piano Teaching System is an electronic keyboard with teach-yourself-to-play software that runs on the Nintendo game systems and I.B.M.-compatible, Apple Macintosh, or Amiga personal computers. Pushed by $1 million a week in advertising, the Miracle sold about 40,000 units during the December quarter at prices from $379 to $479, suggested retail, and has sold slowly but steadily since then. 
 The two analysts who follow Software Toolworks say that while the Miracle accounts for only 25 percent of revenues, it has helped redefine the company. Software Toolworks has made strides in other product areas, and now warrants investors' attention again, they say.
But they caution that Software Toolworks is in the middle of, rather than through with, a turnaround, and that shares in the company remain a speculative purchase. The stock, which traded as low as $2 last year, peaked at $8.50 in November before settling a little over $6. It closed yesterday at $6.0625 , down 6.25 cents, in over-the-counter trading. The company, which is based in Novato, Calif., has been modestly profitable in the first nine months of its 1992 fiscal year, which ends March 31.
"We are very encouraged by the progress management has made," said Robert F. Kleiber, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. He rates the stock a speculative buy. "They are not perfect, but they have put some product out that makes sense," he said. "The Miracle indicates a high level of creativity; it's a very nice product that does exactly what they say it does."
In addition to the Miracle, which numerous reviewers have said really can teach the user to play, Software Toolworks has a very successful program that teaches typing, "Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing!" that has sold more than 1.5 million copies since 1986, and a chess tutorial program, the Chessmaster 3000, Mr. Kleiber said. The company recently introduced versions of these for the Windows operating system, as well as atlas and reference programs that work with Windows.
Mr. Kleiber gives much credit for Software Toolworks' improvement to Robert Lloyd, a former All-American basketball player at Rutgers, who joined the company as president and chief executive in October 1990. "He's done a great job of cleaning up," Mr. Kleiber said, adding that the company's "balance sheet is still not a pretty sight."
Software Toolworks "is not out of the woods yet, but the last few trees are clearly in sight," he said.
Lee S. Isgur, an analyst with Volpe, Welty & Company in San Francisco, is also recommending purchase of Software Toolworks but acknowledges that the company's turnaround is progessing more slowly than he anticipated. "The bad news is that the improvement is not occurring at a faster pace, but given the current economic situation, it may be unrealistic to ask for more," he said. "The good news is that the turnaround that began last summer continues."
The Miracle has established a new product category, and is an even stronger product on personal computers than it was on Nintendo, Mr. Isgur said. The success of the product at Christmas helped persuade retailers that Software Toolworks was a viable supplier, he said, adding that major chains, like Radio Shack and Target, that carried the Miracle only at limited locations last year, will carry it throughout their stores in 1992.
One problem with the Miracle, Mr. Isgur said, is that it currently accounts for a disproportionate share of the company's $28.2 million in inventory, more than half. This is because Software Toolworks committed to buying components in large volume in order to hold prices down, he said. "They have to sell enough Miracles to free up capital," he said, predicting that this is unlikely before next Christmas.
Mr. Isgur also likes the company's other product lines, noting that Software Toolworks is "probably the largest and most diversified manufacturer of CD-ROM product," referring to atlases and other reference software that run on compact disk drives for personal computers. In the educational market, he is particularly enthusiastic about the company's recent license to develop a geography program featuring Mario, the hero of Nintendo's most popular games.
Software Toolworks "had a profit this quarter, which will give them a modest profit for the year," Mr. Isgur said, adding: "Next year, they will have a much bigger profit, maybe 50 or 60 cents a share. If they do 60 cents, the stock is a screaming buy; if they only do 35 cents, maybe it's a little ahead of itself. That's the tough call."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Scrawny Economy but Tables Are Lush

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
THIS year may be one of fiscal restraint, but not necessarily at the table. Table settings are currently baroque, and excess of a sort is cherished.
"In the 80's, tables were simple and utilitarian and, after a while, the plain table got boring," said Peri Wolfman, co-author of "The Perfect Setting (Harry N. Abrams, 1986), which has just been reprinted. "Now people are setting more opulent, more abundant tables." 
 Ms. Wolfman is a co-owner of Wolfman-Gold and Good Company, a housewares store in Manhattan's SoHo district.
Jewelry designers, like Stephen Dweck in Manhattan and Pierre Casenove in Salins, France, are getting in on the act, and it comes as no surprise that their serving pieces and candelabra are as jewel-like as they are functional.
This decade, then, is the moment for Michael L. Cipriano. Some people are to the manor born. Mr. Cipriano, a 31-year-old interior designer, is to the table born.
From 1985 to 1990, he was display manager for Chelsea Passage, the gift area at Barneys New York. Since 1990, he has been a consultant to the Manhattan store, and sets the tables there twice each week. For this article, he was invited to set the table shown above, one that he describes as luxurious but not in a formulated way.
At night, Mr. Cipriano reads up on the 1920's, a time he calls the golden era of the tabletop ornament. "People put little glass birds, seashells and little Murano glass figurines on the tables," Mr. Cipriano said. "Now they're called tchotchkes."
On weekends, he haunts flea markets and antique shows for, well, table accessories. It was his passion for collecting that led him into designing tables.
He is one of the few people who can recognize a bonbon spoon from a dessert spoon.
"Now you'd take a bonbon with your fingers, but if you had a bonbon in the 20's, you'd take it on a spoon, and then with your fingers," Mr. Cipriano said. "A bonbon spoon is a quirky little nicety."
In his Gramercy Park apartment, he has dozens and dozens of Victorian porcelain cake dishes, tea cups and saucers, 19th-century English and American sterling silver sugar spoons, petit four shovels and trowels.
"In the 19th century, silversmiths combined materials: silver and gold, silver and copper, and silver and enamel," Mr. Cipriano said.
It is possible to overdress and overeat. But it is nearly impossible to overdo a table setting.
"You don't have to have Baccarat or Waterford," Mr. Cipriano said. "Crystal can be some little flea market find, or your mother's or grandmother's, or made by an artisan you come across. You can fall in love with one plate and buy it as a set of dinner plates, and fall in love with another plate and buy that as a set of salad plates.
"It's luxury in little pieces."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bonilla's Seasoning Spices His Career

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 11

 BODY:
Throughout his childhood in the Bronx, the constraints of climate and economics left Bobby Bonilla wildly hungry for more baseball. And so it was more just the desire to play than to succeed spectacularly that Bonilla's start in professional baseball, late and unremarkable as it was, satisfied most.
"I'd had potential, had talent as a kid," said Bonilla, the $29 million right fielder for the Mets. "But I didn't have the opportunity to play enough. So when I was signed by the Pirates, I was crazy just to play. I loved it. But there was some serious seasoning to be done." 
 The refinement of Bonilla at the plate has now stretched over a decade of professional experience, and the developmental chart that has resulted is an intriguing mix of variation, consistency and curiosity.
He has, after all, hit 32 home runs one year, 18 the next. A natural right-handed hitter, the switch-hitting Bonilla has batted .268 for his career from the right side, .286 from the left. He walked 45 times and struck out 103 times in 1990, then walked 90 times and struck out 67 times in 1991. He hit .300 in his first full season as a regular in 1987 and .302 in his most recent season while never posting an average better than .281 in the three seasons in between.
 
'So Many Different Labels'
 "There have always been so many different labels," said Bonilla. "At the start, it was hard for me to tell which one was me."
Bonilla, imposing with enormous hands and powerful legs, was a slight kid through his first threee years at Lehman High School.
"I didn't shoot up until the 12th grade," said Bonilla. "But I'd always hit a couple out, no question about that."
The early suspicion, then, was that Bonilla could be a power bat, and that was how he was typecast when Pittsburgh signed him as a nondrafted free agent in 1981. But from his first seasons in rookie ball through several undistinguished seasons in the low minors, Bonilla never hit many home runs, his 11 in 136 games for Nashua at the Class AA level his highest total. And his .264 batting average during that 1984 season in Nashua was his best in the minors.
"I was supposed to a guy with pop from both sides, but I never, ever did much in the minors," said Bonilla, who began to bat from both sides in the 10th grade. "So, sure, there were holes, and plain experience was the biggest one. Then, in 1985, I broke my leg and I spent four months watching. And nothing more than watching turned out to be a great learning experience for me."
A season later, Bonilla, having been lost in a special draft after he was left unprotected by the Pirates, was playing in the majors for the White Sox and then later in the season with the Pirates after a trade returned him to Pittsburgh. He wound up with a combined .255 average and 3 homers.
 
Startling Breakthrough
 But in a startling breakthrough, Bonilla hit .300 in 1987 for the Pirates and by the end of the season he was the regular in the cleanup spot. He hit 15 homers and drove in 77 runs.
"That season, I realized I could play in the majors," said Bonilla. "And in 1988, I realized that not only could I just be someone up at the plate, but that I could be someone who could make a difference."
Bonilla hit 24 homers and collected 100 r.b.i. in 1988. He followed that in 1989, what he calls his most gratifying year at the plate given the injuries that savaged the Pirates and often left him naked in the order, with 24 homers and 86 runs driven in. And then, with the full explosion of the once unprocessed talent, Bonilla smashed 32 homers and drove in 120 runs in 1990, more than any other Pirate since Willie Stargell in 1971.
 
Every Year Is Different
 "For me, every year has been different, and I haven't been able to predict what was coming or explain it after it came," said Bonilla. "In 1990, everything I hit hard went out. It was pretty wonderful."
But Bonilla nevertheless thought he might have been too aggressive. He didn't like his strikeout total of 103 or his extremely modest mark of 45 walks for a run producer of his caliber. And so last year, Bonilla compiled his most disciplined season at the plate ever.
He hit only 18 homers, but his average was .302 and he drove in 100 runs. His 44 doubles led the league and his 68 extra-base hits ranked third.
"I cut down on my swing, determined that I wasn't going to be swinging from my rear end trying to do what I couldn't do," said Bonilla. "The greatest stat is runs produced, and so there ain't nothing wrong with 44 doubles, 18 homers and 100 r.b.i."
"I haven't had a year, yet I've been satisfied with," Bonilla said.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Mets collected 10 hits and DAVID CONE gave up two runs over four innings in a 4-2 triumph over the Houston Astros at Kissimmee. PAUL GIBSON, JEFF INNIS and JULIAN VASQUEZcombined to pitch five innings of scoreless relief. VINCE COLEMAN went 2 for 3 with a run-scoring triple.

HEADLINE: A Great-Tasting Budget Bill

 BODY:
Tastes great / Less filling. That false dichotomy sold a lot of beer. Today, the House of Representatives will vote on a similar dichotomy: Reduce the deficit / Increase domestic spending. Logic argues for a "yes" vote. Those goals may seem contradictory but in budgets as in beer, there's no reason the nation can't have both.
The vote will come on a bill sponsored by John Conyers, the Michigan Democrat, to remove firewalls in the 1990 budget law. Those barriers forbid Congress to switch money from defense to domestic programs. Once those barriers are down, Mr. Conyers and the Democratic leadership propose splitting the peace dividend saved from declining military budgets between deficit reduction and public investment. 
 In opposition, President Bush and Republican leaders argue that the only acceptable way to use the money is to reduce the deficit. They say only deficit reduction can spur growth and, besides, firewalls are needed for fiscal discipline. Mr. Bush and his allies are doubly mistaken.
Public investment is every bit as important to growth as private investment. And the Conyers bill would only shift spending among programs; it wouldn't raise the deficit a dime or erode discipline.
The 1990 budget law was designed to reduce the deficit by about $500 billion over five years through modest spending cutbacks and tax hikes. Without debate, Congress agreed to separate caps on domestic, international and defense programs. The amendment defaced an otherwise laudable bill, blocking Congress from doing what it's elected to do: make choices.
What was politically perverse in 1990 has now become fiscally irresponsible. The demise of the Soviet Union now makes frivolous tens of billions in proposed defense spending. But Congress has precious little incentive to capitalize on the golden opportunity. It can cut military spending but the entire saving must go to deficit reduction. Congress isn't likely to undertake painful tasks like closing bases on behalf of the grand abstraction of deficit reduction.
Besides, deficit reduction alone performs no magic. Smaller deficits help the economy because they mean the Government siphons less out of private capital markets. That leaves more money for entrepreneurs, leading to faster growth in investment, productivity and wages.
But there's another key to economic growth: Public investment in telecommunications networks, water treatment, education, training, research. These have been slighted in the Reagan-Bush years, yet study after study shows that such public investments produce returns as high as, or higher than, private investment.
Mr. Bush threatens to veto the Conyers bill because he assumes Congress will throw away the peace dividend on wasteful expenditures. That's a legitimate worry. But the remedy is not to veto Congress's capacity to choose; it is to veto wrong choices it might later make.
Deficit reduction; increased public investment. The economy needs both. Both taste great.

HEADLINE: Who's Presidential?;
No Candidate Is Better Than Bush

BYLINE: By Thomas H. Kean; Thomas H. Kean, New Jersey's Governor from 1982 to 1990, is president of Drew University and chairman of the state's Bush-Quayle campaign.

DATELINE: MADISON, N.J.

 BODY:
Presidential elections grant Americans a rare opportunity to examine issues and candidates. The problem is that campaigns also open a season of political negativism that usually exaggerates America's difficulties and overlooks our successes.
This climate is victimizing George Bush. His critics pound relentlessly on his perceived failures, especially his handling of the economy. Yet, these critics largely ignore many remarkable successes of the past four years -- and the great promise of the next four years. 
 Mr. Bush (and Ronald Reagan) have presided over some of the greatest victories in this country's history. Long after the current recession has faded from memory, Americans will be reaping the dividends of the peaceful collapse of Soviet Communism; the liberation of Kuwait and Panama; the largely unexpected advance of democracy in Africa, Asia and Latin America, and the free trade agreements with Canada and other nations.
Conversely, the President's challenger, Pat Buchanan, and the Democratic candidates seem to lack any solid vision for how to deal with foreign policy and security demands. The Democrats' only major plank -- cutting the defense budget even deeper than Mr. Bush has proposed -- ignores threats America may need to counter in coming years.
This lack of vision leaves many questions unanswered. After disarming America, how would Jerry Brown, Bill Clinton or Paul Tsongas respond to a regional nuclear threat from Iraq or North Korea? Would they know how to counter the emergence of a new authoritarian regime in the former Soviet Union that is armed with nuclear warheads? Could any of these contenders muster the will to commit American forces intelligently and prudently if a threat to our interests emerged? We know that the Democrats shun the Strategic Defense Initiative, so how would they insure America's defense against an accidental or orchestrated nuclear attack? Absent a realistic Democratic response, Americans must be skeptical of Mr. Bush's challengers. His demonstrated skills in foreign policy are not abstract; they are a fundamental requirement of the job.
Mr. Bush's foreign policy victories are not his only successes that are being overlooked. In education, for example, he has introduced one of the most promising reform plans in decades. His America 2000 program includes greater community and business involvement, greater choice for parents in selecting their children's schools and the introduction of promising experimental schools. At the root of his reforms is an acute understanding that tinkering with the American educational system has failed to yield major improvements.
Instead of embracing America 2000, Congressional Democrats have sought to dilute and destroy it. Their suggested remedies rest not on real change but on the failed approaches of the past: more and more spending without accountability.
Similar foot-dragging hampers Mr. Bush's economic reforms. Congressional Democrats contended that he lacked a program, yet when he put forward a constructive blueprint in his State of the Union Message and requested prompt action, what he got was procrastination and maneuvering. And now the Democratic leaders are busy pushing an alternative plan that lacks most of the pro-growth policies Mr. Bush has advocated.
Americans should view the economy in its proper historical perspective. Standing with Jimmy Carter several weeks back, Paul Tsongas should have refocused the minds of Americans on something: The last time Democrats controlled both the White House and Congress, people were waiting in gas lines, burdened with 21 percent interest rates and suffering under the dual swords of double-digit inflation and unemployment.
The political season may be a time for negativism. But it should also be a time for remembering that there is a lot to be proud of -- and even more reason for hope.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The New Despotism

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
All the political munchkins had persuaded their principals that, in a recession, foreign policy was a no-no. Foreign aid? Kiss of death.
Along came Richard Nixon this week to give all the candidates and their lockstep pollsters a swift kick in the teeth. 
 He reminded a foolishly intimidated Establishment what leadership was about: "Not simply to support what is popular but to make what is unpopular popular if that serves America's interest."
To wake up a world traumatized by conventional wisdom, our only thinking ex-President used a new medium and an old device.
He rejected the mass media, who tend to paint their tails white and run with the antelopes. He chose not to go the op-ed route, overused by purveyors of opinion.
Instead, drawing on the Lazarsfeld Theory of Two-Step Communication, Mr. Nixon wrote a memorandum and sent it, with a personal cover note, to the 50 people interested in foreign affairs that he believed most capable of affecting public policy.
It is the most prestigious list to be on since the "enemies list" of 20 years ago. A former national security adviser called me to say "Did you see what Nixon is saying?" In the steam room of the Army-Navy Club, a longtime policy maker wondered whether Nixon's tight-circulation blast at the West's "pathetically inadequate" response to the needs of Russian reformers would get through.
James Baker, whose phony photo-op Russian-aid conference was scorned in the Nixon memo, is not on the list. But Brent Scowcroft at the White House is, and brought it to the attention of President Bush, who discussed it with ex-President Nixon early this week.
The non-secret memo made its way into the hands of Daniel Schorr, writing an Op-Ed piece for The New York Times, and Times news editors immediately saw its news value as implicit criticism of Mr. Bush. Tom Friedman's front-page news story and next-day analysis not only exposed White House timidity but the shallowness of the position of Candidates Clinton and Tsongas.
The memo formed the basis of a speech delivered at a two-day policy conference in Washington sponsored by the Nixon Library. CNN telecast the speech worldwide live, and excerpts are on the nightly newscasts. The memo got around.
It cannot be ignored. But President Bush says only, "I don't have a blank check for all of that."
The new medium works, but what gave the memo force is not the repetition of Nixon's frequent calls to help Mr. Yeltsin, nor even his criticism of Western leaders and candidates for failure to heed that call.
Nixon goes against the grain of timidity and challenges the isolationists on political grounds. The man whose career began in the era of "Who Lost China?" now raises the specter of "Who Lost Russia?" To be timid now will cost a political leader dearly later.
He understands the vacuum sucking the life out of politics today: the absence of a global villain. For voters who need to be against something, Nixon supplies "the New Despotism." And it's no chimera; the danger, when you think about it, is real.
"If a new despotism prevails," warns Nixon, "everything gained in the great peaceful revolution of 1991 will be lost. War could break out as the new despots use force. . . . China's totalitarians [!] would breathe a sigh of relief. . . . A new Russian despotism . . . would be even more dangerous than Soviet totalitarianism."
If he's wrong, and the West spends $20 billion a year extending freedom, no harm done; but if he's right, and the New Despotism arrives, the U.S. alone would be spending 20 times that every year; no peace dividend; and our children would live in fear of nuclear destruction. Woe betide the politician on the wrong side of that.
Two decades ago, I went to furtive gatherings of Nixon hands; we called ourselves "the February group" and avoided notice. At the bipartisan, star-studded conference this week, with Nixon in his final comeback urging the assembled leaders to reaffirm national purpose, it was good to see many of those faces looking proud again.
My favorite Nixon, Julie Eisenhower, caught the wonderment: "We couldn't be sure this day would come. But I never stopped believing."

HEADLINE: Highlands Proposal Came as No Surprise at All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Feb. 22 report that plans for a huge preservation area in the New York-New Jersey Highlands, an area where the states border, have surprised and angered residents is highly misleading. The New York-New Jersey Highlands regional study by the Forest Service is certainly no secret, and its recommendations are not intended to bar future economic development of the Highlands area. 
 Over the last year the Forest Service held more than a dozen public meetings in Highland communities. These hearings, sponsored by nine county governments, attracted more than 1,000 people -- including farmers, developers and landowners -- who came and testified on the work of the Forest Service and the content of the draft study report. Notices of these meetings went to more than 2,000 residents. There were articles in newspapers that serve the Highlands area before these public hearings.
The report presented the opinions of the vast majority of citizens and elected representatives who chose to testify. These people support Forest Service recommendations for conservation measures to increase local prosperity while protecting a landscape that provides 3.7 million northern New Jersey residents with drinking water and attracts more than eight million recreational visitors a year -- more than twice as many as visit Yellowstone National Park.
Meeting that challenge is the real story of the Highlands, and one that should be of concern to all who care about the New York-New Jersey area's economic future and quality of life.
 
RICHARD T. ANDERSON
President, Regional Plan Association
New York, Feb. 27, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 196 words

HEADLINE: National Health Plan Anticipated by Truman

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "California's Medical Model" (editorial, Feb. 17), you cite the medical plan put forth by John Garamendi, California's Insurance Commissioner, and say that it offers a model for every state. 
 On Nov. 19, 1945, President Harry S. Truman sent to Congress his medical health plan: "A request for adoption of a national health program" (H.R. 380-79th Congress, 1st Session).
In his 11-page request for legislation, President Truman emphasized that medical services are personal and that the nationwide system must be highly decentralized in administration and that the people remain free to choose their own physicians and hospitals.
His five-point plan included all citizens because all Americans ought to be assured, the proposal stated, "the right to adequate medical care and the opportunity to achieve and enjoy good health as well as the right to adequate protection from economic fears," such as sickness.
It seems to me that the plan coming out of California must just be the one President Harry S. Truman sent to committee almost 50 years ago. The buck has finally stopped -- I hope.
 
RUTH GOODMAN
Westwood, N.J., Feb. 24, 1992

HEADLINE: BUSH CITES LIMITS ON AID TO RUSSIA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11

 BODY:
Responding to criticism by former President Richard M. Nixon that he has not done enough to support democratic reforms in the former Soviet Union, President Bush said today that his Administration does not have a "blank check" to finance extensive aid programs.
 Mr. Bush did say that his Administration was now considering contributing to a multibillion-dollar international fund to stabilize the ruble, a key ingredient for economic reform in Russia. While other Administration officials have said United States support for such a fund was under consideration, this was the first time Mr. Bush himself had expressed his interest. 

 
Bush Response
 Nevertheless, when asked about Mr. Nixon's criticism at a White House news conference, Mr. Bush said: "Where we might have a difference, is we're living in a time of constrained resources. There isn't a lot of money around. We are spending too much as it already is. So to do the things I would really like to do, I don't have a blank check for all that. I think the question should be addressed to President Nixon."
 Mr. Bush's White House news conference was held in the morning, just a few hours before President Nixon, in an address to a foreign affairs conference across town, repeated his criticism of the American and Western response to the collapse of Communism and the breakup of the Soviet Union.
 The foreign affairs conference, sponsored by the Nixon Library in California, served as the occasion for the former President to make one of his most high-profile visits to Washington since he resigned the Presidency in disgrace in 1974 following the Watergate scandal. Mr. Nixon addressed the gathering of prominent foreign policy experts, foreign ambassadors and former Nixon Administration cabinet members at lunch. Then, President Bush addressed the conference himself in the evening.
 In his evening address, Mr. Bush, making no mention of the financial constraints he spoke about at his morning news conference, told the Nixon gathering that "turning our back on the world is no answer."
 "We invested so much to win the cold war," Mr. Bush said. "We must invest what is necessary to win the peace. If we fail, we will create new and profound problems for our security and that of Europe and Asia. We must support reform, not only in Russia, but throughout the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe."
But Mr. Bush, who hailed Mr. Nixon as "one of the greatest statesmen of the 20th century," confined his remarks to generalities and outlined no new initiatives or spending plans to translate his declarations into action.
 
Recalling Harry Truman
 The 79-year-old Mr. Nixon, for his part, spoke for 30 minutes without notes or a lectern, and appealed to President Bush and Congress to join together in a bipartisan effort to transform the former Soviet republics into democracies. He said they should employ the same vision and energy that President Harry S. Truman used to persuade Mr. Nixon and John F. Kennedy, when they were both young Congressmen, to support the beginnings of the Marshall Plan 45 years ago.
 "All of the pollsters are telling their candidates, don't tackle foreign policy, and particularly not foreign aid, because foreign aid is poison as a political issue," Mr. Nixon said. "They're wrong and history proves it. In 1947, I recall vividly as if it were yesterday what Harry Truman did."
 In that year, Mr. Nixon said, President Truman's approval rating was 35 percent, and the Congress was overwhelmingly Republican controlled.
 "And yet, I remember Harry Truman -- jaunty, some said a little cocky -- coming down before a joint session of the Congress and asking for millions of dollars in aid to Greece and Turkey to prevent Communist subversion and possibly Communist aggression. It was a very tough vote for two very young and both, as history later indicated, rather ambitious young Congressmen."
 
Kennedy and Nixon Together
 The liberal Democrats in Mr. Kennedy's Massachusetts district were against military foreign aid, said Mr. Nixon. And the conservative Republicans in his own California district were against all foreign aid.
 "Under the circumstances, however, after considering it, we both voted for it," he said, "and a majority in that Republican House and the Senate voted for that program and that was the program which later was developed into the Marshall Plan and later into NATO, which not only contained Communism but bought the time that was essential for Communism to fail."
 The next year, recalled Mr. Nixon, Harry Truman won the election for President. What is more important, he added, is that that action by a Democratic President was supported by a Republican Congress.
 "And then you have a situation at the present time, where we have a Republican President with a Democratic Congress with the opportunity to take action which would provide aid to Russia and the other countries that we have mentioned here which would assure the victory of freedom," said Mr. Nixon. "That is the question, then, that Americans must face today, political Americans, all Americans, and I think we know what the answer should be."
 
Warning of 'New Despotism'
 The brunt of Mr. Nixon's argument today tracked closely with a memo he had circulated to friends and foreign policy experts in recent weeks, in which he stated that the United States and the West were missing a great opportunity to transform Russia and its neighbors to democracy by providing enough aid to insure the success of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. Without such help, said Mr. Nixon, "a new despotism" will take hold where the Communists once ruled.
 The several hundred foreign policy experts gathered for the Nixon speech gave him a standing ovation. Mr. Nixon, though, did not take any questions, and therefore did not give any details on how he proposed the Government would pay for the aid he is talking about.
 Yet his appeal found admirers. Max Kampelman, a former Reagan Administration arms control negotiator, said of Mr. Nixon's speech, "It was the clearest voice we have heard from any political figure of either party during this period."
 Because of the attention Mr. Nixon's criticism has received, however, it may break the virtual silence that both Republicans and Democrats have kept on foreign policy issues thus far in the Presidential primary campaigns. Whether or not it changes the Administration's behavior, Mr. Nixon has forced has forced Mr. Bush to address the Russian aid question, which the White House has been avoiding for some time.
 "One thing Nixon is doing is giving the President the political cover with the Republican conservatives to go ahead with more aid -- if he wants it," said William Hyland, editor of Foreign Affairs Magazine. "The question is what will Bush do with it."
