HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democratic Voters;
Polling Shows Top Candidates Are Vulnerable

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 11

 BODY:
Both Bill Clinton and Paul E. Tsongas have significant weaknesses among Democratic voters even in the states where they won primaries on Tuesday, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls.
About 20 percent of the voters surveyed, not only in the South but also in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, said they planned to vote for George Bush in the general election. 
 Moreover, a third of the Democratic voters in the two New England states and a fifth in the five Southern states that held primaries on Super Tuesday said they thought less favorably of Mr. Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, because he managed to avoid being drafted in the Vietnam War. Mr. Tsongas picked up a disproportionate share of the voters who said they felt that way, indicating the issue might be a fertile one for Republicans should Mr. Clinton win the Democratic nomination.
 
Cancer Worries Cited
 As for Mr. Tsongas, a significant number of Democrats said they were worried that his battle with cancer might make him unable to serve effectively. Mr. Tsongas, a United States Senator from Massachusetts from 1979 to 1985, retired at the end of his term because he had lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system. He and his doctor now say he has been cured.
About an eighth of the Democratic voters in Massachusetts and a tenth in Rhode Island said they were concerned about the cancer, as did about one-fifth in the South. Fewer than 40 percent of such voters in New England, and only a small fraction of such voters in the South, voted for Mr. Tsongas.
There is often a big difference between what voters say in the spring and what they do in November. So voting patterns in the primaries are often not as relevant to the probable outcome of the general election as they might appear. About a third of the voters in Tuesday's Democratic primaries in the South and about a quarter of those in Massachusetts and Rhode Island said they voted for Mr. Bush over Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, in 1988.
One surprise in the voting patterns was the strength of Edmund G. Brown Jr. among voters who decided on whom to vote for in the last few days before the election. For example, in Massachusetts, Mr. Brown won only 15 percent of the overall Democratic vote, but he won 18 percent of those who decided how they would vote on Election Day and 30 percent of those who decided in the last three days.
 
Threat to Front-Runners
 Mr. Brown seems to have drained strength away from the front-runners -- Mr. Tsongas in New England and Mr. Clinton in the South. The capacity of the former California Governor to win over those who decide at the eleventh hour could prove important in Illinois and Michigan next week. Preliminary polls in those states last weekend showed about a third of the voters still undecided.
As has been the case throughout the primary season, Mr. Tsongas ran strongly among highly educated, affluent white voters, but was generally unable to cut into Mr. Clinton's support among all other Democrats.
Mr. Clinton won three-quarters of the black vote in Florida and about 80 percent elsewhere in the South. Outside of New England, he ran especially well among voters who said their own financial situation was worse than it was four years ago.
In Florida, the closest of Tuesday's contests, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas more or less split the Jewish and white Roman Catholic vote, but Mr. Clinton won solidly among white Protestants.
Mr. Tsongas did relatively poorly among blue-collar voters even in Massachusetts. He won only 52 percent of their vote, the exit polls showed, as against 67 percent of the overall vote.
The economy was the overriding issue in voters' minds. Given a list of issues, 48 percent of the Democratic voters in the South and more than half in New England said the economy was among the one or two issues that mattered most to them. Medical care, the next most important issue, was mentioned by about 3 voters in 10.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The Election Day exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters Tuesday as they left voting stations throughout eight states: Florida, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, Tennessee and Texas.
The polls were conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, and NBC News.
In Florida, results are based on 1,794 Democratic primary voters and 1,509 Republican primary voters leaving 60 polling places throughout the state; in Louisiana, 1,086 Democratic voters and 811 Republican voters in 40 polling places; in Massachusetts, 1,359 Democratic voters and 963 Republican voters in 40 polling places; in Mississippi, 1,074 Democratic voters and 783 Republican voters leaving 30 polling places; in Oklahoma, 1,206 Democratic voters and 650 Republican voters in 25 polling places; in Rhode Island, 1,020 Democratic voters and 376 Republican voters in 19 polling places; in Tennessee, 1,021 Democratic voters and 895 Republican voters in 30 polling places. And in Texas, results are based on 1,847 Democratic primary voters leaving 60 polling places and 1,504 Republican primary voters leaving 47 polling places throughout the state.
In the Democratic primaries, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus three to four percentage points.
In the Republican primaries, the margin of sampling error was plus or minus three to five percentage points except in Rhode Island, where it was seven percentage points.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such polls should differ by only a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all primary election voters who turned out. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 882 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republican Voters;
Fault Lines in Bush's Base of Support

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 11

 BODY:
Despite President Bush's decisive victory over Patrick J. Buchanan in Tuesday's primaries, surveys of voters in eight states reveal several potential problems that could work against him in the fall.
Interviews with voters leaving the polls indicated that Mr. Bush's ratings were tied to the health of the economy; that his approval ratings fell in the states outside the South or with fewer voters born in the South, and that there was a continuing gulf in the voting choices of women and men. 
 As in past primaries, the findings, by Voter Research and Surveys, showed that Mr. Bush's ratings largely reflected voters' views of the economy and its impact on them.
That pattern held true again Tuesday as voters in the three states that have seen perhaps the most significant economic reversals in recent years, Florida, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, registered the highest disapproval ratings for Mr. Bush's performance.
 
Strong in Mississippi
 Almost two in five voters in all three states said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's performance. On the other hand, almost seven in 10 voters in Mississippi, a state whose economic fortunes never boomed and never busted, said they approved of Mr. Bush's performance.
The surveys showed a bleak view of the economy from Florida to New England. In Massachusetts, where the most pessimistic view of the economy was expressed, 85 percent of Republican primary voters rated the economy poor or not good. In Rhode Island, 82 percent of voters had the same assessment.
But even in the states with the brightest assessment of the economy, Mississippi and Tennessee, 72 percent of Republican voters described the economy as poor or not good. Voters with the bleakest view of the economy were consistently the most dissatisfied with Mr. Bush's performance.
In Massachusetts and Rhode Island, 57 and 56 percent of Republican primary voters, respectively, gave him a positive rating.
His highest approval ratings came in Mississippi, where 69 percent of Republican voters gave him a positive job rating, and in Tennessee, where 66 percent did so.
It is likely that cultural and regional factors, as well as economic ones, played a role in the vote.
Some political analysts said Southern Republican voters tend to be less likely than voters elsewhere to turn against a sitting President.
There is no way to be certain how much a role was played by economics and how much was due to cultural factors. But it is striking that the percentage of Republican primary voters saying they would vote for a Democrat, or not vote at all, in the fall was highest in the states farthest removed from the South or the least Southern in nature. Thus, 23 percent of Republican voters in Massachusetts, 19 percent in Florida and 18 percent in Rhode Island indicated that they did not expect to vote for President Bush.
 
On to the Midwest
 But in Texas and Tennessee only 12 percent of Republican primary voters said they would not support the President. In Mississippi, the figure was 13 percent. Analysts will be closely watching the readings in Michigan and Illinois next week to see if Mr. Bush's support is as strong outside the South.
Once again, the poll results showed a striking gap between male and female voters in the Republican primaries. Tuesday, it worked in favor of Mr. Bush. In the eight states that voted, his vote among women exceeded Mr. Buchanan's by margins ranging from 9 percentage points in Rhode Island to 16 in Massachusetts.
But men also made up a disproportionate share of the Republican electorate. They accounted for 53 percent of the Republian electorate in the five Southern states of Florida, Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee and Texas.
In Massachusetts, men made up 60 percent of the electorate. In Rhode Island, they made up 59 percent.
 
Duke Is Big Loser
 It is possible that Mr. Buchanan's harsh style and message accounted for most of the difference between him and Mr. Bush. But both the difference between men and women in the Republican electorate and the huge gap in their voting pattern could pose problems for Mr. Bush in the fall, particularly if he moves farther to the right in response to Mr. Buchanan's campaign.
The day's biggest loser in the Republican contests clearly was David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klansman and Louisiana state representative whose candidacy fizzled to insignificance on what he had hoped would be his day in the sun in his home region.
His performance may have helped put in perspective his two well-publicized races for Governor and United States Senator in Louisiana. In those earlier contests, many said they were voting for him, despite his past, either as a protest, as an endorsement of some of his ideas or as a vote against his opponents, particularly in his race for Governor against Edwin W. Edwards.
Many of his supporters in the earlier contests were Democrats, not Republicans, but poll results in the Republican primary tended to back the idea that Mr. Duke's support in the past was not wholehearted.
In Louisiana on Tuesday, Mr. Duke got the votes of only 23 percent of Republican voters who said they had voted for him for Governor last November. Mr. Buchanan got 36 percent of Mr. Duke's earlier supporters while Mr. Bush got 41 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Move Upward

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Comments by President Bush helped to push up long-term interest rates during slow trading in the credit markets yesterday.
At a news conference, Mr. Bush told reporters he was more concerned about the health of the economy than in keeping long-term interest rates low. 
 Treasury bond prices, marginally lower during early trading, slumped after the President made his remarks.
"The market interpreted that remark to mean that the Administration will keep the heat on the Fed to push short-term rates lower and push for a tax-cut package," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "And, with so little going on, the comments got an exaggerated response."
Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that "with rumors floating around that the February retail sales numbers are going to be strong, it was not a good thing for Mr. Bush to say." He added: "You get the sense that the market is still jumpy about the notion the economy is recovering."
 
Retail Sales Rise Expected
 Most Wall Street economists do expect that the retail sales report, which is due out today, will show that sales were healthy last month. But the analysts said the figures may exaggerate the strength because there were five Saturdays in February, the day when most consumers do the bulk of their shopping.
As prices of bonds and intermediate securities fell, prices of short-term securities firmed somewhat. Traders said there were rumors that an investor leaving the stock market had bought as much as $1.5 billion worth of two-year notes.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 10015/32 , down 22/32 , to yield 7.95 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 9931/32 late yesterday, down 1/2 a point, to yield 7.50 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes dipped by 10/32 , to 9915/32 , to yield 6.87 percent. But prices of the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes rose by 1/32 , to 9921/32 , to yield 5.56 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.99 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a like amount, to a late offered rate of 4.14 percent.
Issuance of new investment-grade corporate bonds was strong again yesterday, as more than $1 billion worth of new securities were priced.
Among the issuers was the BankAmerica Corporation, which offered $350 million worth of five-year, non-callable notes through an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The 7.5 percent notes were priced at $99.351, to yield 7.659 percent, 82 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Delta Airlines offered a total of $300 million worth of notes and debentures through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The $100 million worth of 10-year notes were sold as 8.50 percent securities and were priced at $99.627 to yield 8.556 percent, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
 
30-Year Debentures Priced
 The remaining $200 million worth of 9.25 percent 30-year debentures were priced at $99.56, to yield 9.294 percent, 1.37 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the state of South Carolina sold roughly $200 million worth of bonds in a two-part competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Goldman, Sachs won $114 million worth of securities, which were then reoffered to investors with yields from 3.10 percent in 1003 to 6.25 percent on securities maturing in 2005.
J. P. Morgan Securities won the remaining $85 million worth of bonds, and reoffered these securities to investors at yields from 3.20 percent in 1993 to 6.40 percent in 2008.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted bonds fell by about 1/4 of a point.

HEADLINE: New York Region Concludes: Don't Expand Transit; Fix It

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The $1.46 billion highway and mass transit rebuilding program announced in New Jersey last week is part of a regional attack on congestion and delays, which officials believe are undermining the economic future of the metropolitan area.
The theme of this effort is that the region's network of roads, railroads, bridges and tunnels is essentially complete. The challenge to transportation planners in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is no longer what it has been for the last 200 years, building new routes across an ever-expanding megalopolis. Now, officials in Albany, Trenton and Hartford say, the task is to build more efficiency into what already exists. 
 Several factors have led to the shift in emphasis. Tightened land-use rules, particularly in New Jersey, are making it harder for development to sprawl at will with the expectation that roads will follow. The Federal Government's stringent Clean Air Act will start forcing drivers out of their cars by the middle of the decade unless pollution-generating traffic jams are reduced. And state economic development officials say the region is losing out to other, newer cities whose transportation networks are quicker and more efficient.
"Fiscal constraints, recent mandates from Washington and common sense demand new solutions in how we move people and goods," said Thomas M. Downs, the New Jersey Transportation Commissioner, in announcing the state's huge rehabilitation plan on March 4. "We can no longer build our way out of traffic congestion. We must instead repair, modernize and better manage our existing system."
 
Competing With South
 Mr. Downs was speaking for New Jersey, but he was echoing sentiments that have been expressed for months in other state capitals in the region.
"We have a lot of work to do," said Michael T. Saunders, deputy commissioner of the Connecticut Department of Transportation for policy and planning. "The overall competitive posture of the Northeast is dependent on its infrastructure, and ours is older, and it is subject to much more difficult weather, than our competition in the South and Southwest, and we are losing a lot because of it."
That means an emphasis on refining and restoring systems to enhance mobility.
"Mobility is the word we're all talking about," said David Murray, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Transportation. "That means thinking about moving people and goods, not just cars and trucks. That means park-and-ride, mass transit, high-occupancy vehicles. And improving what we have instead of trying to put down more pavement."
 
Cutting Friction in System
 Mr. Downs said in an interview before his new plan was announced, "I think of it as taking the friction out of the system we have."
The New Jersey program includes $282 million to repair badly deteriorated roads, including $55 million for Route 17 and Interstate 80 in Bergen County; $115 million to smooth traffic flow by synchronizing traffic lights on important local roads and to install automatic toll machines on the New Jersey Turnpike, Garden State Parkway and Atlantic City Expressway, $190 million to upgrade New Jersey Transit and about $40 million in recreational, tourist and freight projects, mostly to improve access to the New Jersey Shore.
Much of the money for these efforts will come from the recently enacted Federal Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, which will pump more than $20 billion into the ailing system of roads, bridges and rails in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut over the next five years.
The money comes as the region's roads and bridges show the effects of long neglect during the years of official emphasis on building anew instead of maintaining what exists.
 
Huge Percent Needs Work
 Of New York State's 36,148 miles of primary and secondary roads in 1990, 41 percent, or 14,829 miles, were poor or fair, engineering categories for roads needing repair, resurfacing or rebuilding.
In New Jersey, 58.1 percent of the primary and secondary roads, or 6,241 miles out of 10,739, were deficient, while in Connecticut 44.3 percent, or 3,056 miles out of 6,895, were deficient. The figures come from the Federal Highway Administration.
Nationwide, the highway administration estimates that 57.3 percent of 1.07 million miles of primary and secondary roads are deficient.
In Connecticut, Interstate 95 between the New York State line and New Haven is at an "F" level of traffic flow, the worst on a congestion scale, during much of the day, state officials said.
 
An Antique Bottleneck
 In New Jersey, cargo moving between Newark Airport and Port Elizabeth, which form the hub of an emerging international trans-shipment center, is choked to a trickle at the two antique lanes of the Doremus Avenue bridge, a constant headache for drivers and transportation officials that will be alleviated somewhat under the new construction program.
In New York State in 1991, according to the Federal Highway Administration, 12,201 out of 17,304 highway bridges, or 70.5 percent, were structurally deficient, which usually means that they are posted to carry limited weight, or obsolete, meaning that they are sound but too narrow or too light to handle the traffic intended for the roads they serve.
In New Jersey, 3,066 of 6,041 bridges, or 50.8 percent, were deficient, and in Connecticut 1,878 out of 3,863 bridges, or 48.6 percent, were in need of repair or replacement. Nationally, the highway administration said, 39.1 percent of the more than half a million highway bridges were below standard.
New York and Connecticut have suffered notorious bridge catastrophes in the last decade. The Schoharie Creek bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway near Amsterdam, N.Y., collapsed in 1987, killing 10 people, and 3 people died in the 1983 collapse of the Mianus River Bridge on Interstate 95 in Greenwich, Conn. In both cases, poor maintenance and inspections were blamed.
 
Disaster Spurred Connecticut
 The Mianus collapse galvanized Connecticut into embarking on a $7.2 billion, 10-year highway and bridge reconstruction program that will be aided by the $2 billion in highway funds the state will receive under the new Federal transportation bill.
Since his election last year, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has directed that special attention go to the state's crowded southwestern corridor, the I-95, Federal Highway 1 and Merritt Parkway network between Greenwich and New Haven.
Part of this effort will be to get local residents to break a bad habit they developed during the years of rapid growth and congestion: using the interstate for local trips.
"The situation right now is that I-95 in the southwest corridor has become like Main Street," Mr. Saunders said. "People who are only going one or two miles are getting on it and fighting for space with people who are driving from Florida to Maine. To the extent that we can, we'd like to provide an alternative for local traffic and leave I-95 for the long-distance drivers."
"Over 40 percent of our $2 billion Federal highway money, about $800 million, is in the bridge program," Mr. Saunders added. "So while we have tremendous needs on the bridge side, we will have the funds to make a strong attack on them."
In New York State, traffic in the Hudson River Valley north of New York City doubled during the last decade, and although it has just 11 percent of the state's population, or 2 million people, it experiences a quarter of the state's traffic congestion, state officials said.
 
Coordinating Hudson Valley
 Last year, Franklin E. White, the New York State Transportation Commissioner, created a pilot program for the Hudson Valley's seven counties -- Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Orange, Dutchess, Ulster and Columbia -- to unify state transportation planning and spending there, so that no decision is made on, say, road-widening without considering its impact on mass transportation and even environmental protection. If the approach works, it will be applied to the rest of the state.
Under the program, there will be some money for traditional road widening, said Alan N. Bloom, the regional director, to channel traffic onto main arteries and away from the secondary roads that now take the overflow. The Taconic State and Hutchinson River Parkways and the Cross Westchester Expressway are among the major routes that are scheduled for added capacity.
"But we can't just build our way out of the problem," Mr. Bloom said in an interview. "The days of trying that are over." Instead, there will be new park-and-ride lots for commuters; better parking at train stations, including expensive but necessary rail-side parking decks; and lanes reserved for cars with at least two or three passengers on the Tappan Zee Bridge and on some major roads.
 
Infrastructure With Sense
 Finally, Mr. Bloom has been ordered to dip his administrative toe gingerly into local land-use rules, a touchy issue for municipalities empowered by the state constitution to govern who builds what and where.
"We know land use is controlled by the locality," Mr. Bloom said. "So we are trying to do what they have already done in Florida, in New Jersey, Vermont, Maine, in Maryland. We're trying to encourage development where you can put the infrastructure, and that means planning to provide infrastructure where it makes sense and not just in a haphazard way, because someone put a shopping center there or an office there."
The New Jersey state plan, which is to be published in its final form this summer, similarly gives state priority to local efforts to control growth. The plan would enable state agencies to withhold the needed roads, bridges, sewers and permits for any proposed development that violates the state's guidelines of clustering growth in in already developed areas.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

THE TRANSPORTATION CHALLENGE
The $1.46 billion highway and mass transit rebuilding program announced in New Jersey last week is part of a regional attack on congestion and delays, which officials believe are undermining the economic future of the metropolitan area. The theme of this effort is that the region's network of roads, railroads, bridges and tunnels is essentially complete. Now the challenge for planners is to build more efficiency into this vast transportation system. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
THE DEATH OF AN EDITOR
In his years as editor of El Diario, Manuel de Dios Unanue had become the subject of a kind of running joke among his colleagues about the many threats he had received from anti-Castro Cuban groups, drug dealers and others he had angered. Mr. de Dios was on the front page again yesterday -- in a bold red headline that said "Sangre de Periodista," "A Journalist's Blood." His slaying Wednesday night followed the lethal pattern that Colombian cocaine traffickers have repeatedly used to silence critics in South America, the New York City police and Latin American journalists said. A1 and B2.
 
'A GOOD, LOYAL SOLDIER'
Salvatore Gravano insisted under cross-examination yesterday that he had been "a good, loyal soldier" for John Gotti and followed orders when it came to killing people. In eight days on the stand, Mr. Gravano has been a canny, if somewhat elusive, witness for the prosecution in the racketeering case against Mr. Gotti. B3.
 
THE VERDICT ON DIVORCE COURT
Describing horror stories that make Arnie Becker, the sleazy divorce lawyer on television's "L.A. Law," look like a nice guy, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs found the state's divorce system guilty of being "an expensive and costly failure." B3.
 
COUNCIL MOVES AGAINST HERTZ
Asserting that businesses cannot discriminate against New York City residents based on where they live, the City Council has barred Hertz from imposing surcharges on car renters who live in areas that have a high rate of accidents. B3.

THE LATEST PLAN ON SCHOOL AID
New Jersey Assembly Republicans unveiled another in a bewildering series of school-aid revisions, this one cutting $127 million from the figures proposed by the Florio administration in January. HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Executives are seeing signs that the sluggish economy is at last turning the corner. Nearly half of 490 business executives surveyed in a poll see some inklings of improvement. This guarded optimism appears to be a recent sentiment. [Page A1.] 
 Retail sales surged 1.3 percent in February, and grew 2.1 percent in January, far higher than first estimated, the Commerce Dept. said. The report showed the first back-to-back gains exceeding 1 percent since 1985. [D1.]
The Senate struggled to clear obstacles to passing its election-year tax bill after unexpected difficulty in killing a bipartisan attempt to strip a $300 tax credit for children. [D1.]
The F.C.C. more than doubled the number of radio stations a single company may own and allowed a single owner to have as many as three AM and three FM station in a single city. [D1.]
First-time claims for unemployment benefits rose to the highest level in more than a month. [D4.]
Criminal sanctions for promoters of phony group health schemes were urged by a Senate panel. [D16.]
One of the oldest ideas in social policy is getting talked up as the newest solution: the Works Progress Administration. [A14.]
 
Companies
Silicon Graphics said it was buying MIPS Computer Systems in a stock swap valued at about $406 million. The merger will unite two of Silicon Valley's leading electronics companies to create an enterprise with revenues approaching $1 billion. [D1.]
I.B.M. has quietly invited Sun Microsystems to join its alliance with Apple. The alliance, Taligent, aims to set the course of the desktop computer industry. [D1.]
Dow Jones and Bell South said they planned to test-market an information service. It is an unusual pairing, since such services are pitching publishers against telephone companies. [D1.]
Ford will offer one price, no haggling, on the Escort LX, in a marketing program it is expanding nationwide. The pricing strategy has increased sales in a regional test. [D2.]
Dayton Hudson reported sharply lower quarterly earnings, saying the results reflected weak Christmas sales, stiff competition and a recessionary economy in California. [D3.]
Black & Decker said it planned to sell 18 million common shares, as well as stock in its information services unit. [D3.]
Paramount Communications executives have held discussions with George Steinbrenner about buying the Yankees. [B7.]
A heart valve made by Shiley, a Pfizer subsidiary, has a far higher failure rate than previously believed, the F.D.A. said. [A1.]
 
International
GATT accused the U.S. of practicing a greater level of protectionism through measures aimed at halting imports. [D16.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks held steady, but prices slipped on the broader market. The Dow ended precisely where it began: 3,208.63. [D6.]
Yields on long-term Treasury bonds rose above 8 percent for the first time since early November. [D13.]
The dollar rallied after the release of better-than-expected consumer spending figures. [D14.] Gold futures sagged. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
Bush is struggling to get out of a crossfire: Nixon urging support for Russian democracy, and Buchanan insisting on putting America first. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
The Chicago Board of Trade is trying to revive the idea of electronic trading of Government securities. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
McCaffrey & McCall will complete an overhaul of top management by importing to New York a president and chief operating officer from Leo Burnett. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Effort to Gut Tax Bill Fails In the Senate

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Senate struggled tonight to clear obstacles to passing its election-year tax bill after confronting unexpected difficulty in killing a bipartisan attempt to strip the heart of the measure, a $300 tax credit for children. Senators agreed to try to complete action on the bill on Friday.
Two Democrats, Carl M. Levin of Michigan and Bob Graham of Florida, proposed eliminating the tax credits and spending the $28 billion designated for the credits on deficit reduction and public works instead. 
 Mr. Levin argued that the tax cut, which would benefit 17.8 million families, would omit three-fourths of middle-income families and that if Congress really wanted to help the nation's children it would reduce the national debt. Under his proposal, three-fourths of the $28 billion would have gone to deficit reduction. More middle-class Americans, he said, "say they want us to cut the deficit to get our economic house in order than are saying, 'Provide me a tax cut.' "
 
Long Wait for Roll-Call
 Although the rules call for 15-minute roll-calls, the Democratic leaders took an hour and three minutes to assemble the votes to kill the measure. Several Democrats were persuaded to change their votes, and the eventual tally was 57 to 39 to kill the proposal.
Earlier, the motion to kill the proposal had been behind, 50 to 46, as Republicans almost solidly supported the dissident Democrats, successfully spreading disarray in the rival camp.
This flurry was symptomatic of the tired politics surrounding the bill, which Democrats are using to argue that they care about the middle class while Republicans favor the rich.
The bill itself would pay for the $300 credits for children under 16 with increased taxes on about 800,000 well-off taxpayers, raising the top bracket from 31 to 36 percent on individuals with taxable incomes of more than $150,000 and couples with incomes over $175,000. It would also impose a 10 percent surtax on taxes attributed to incomes of more than $1 million.
It is these tax-increase proposals that have led President Bush to say he will veto the bill, just as he has threatened to veto a somewhat different set of proposals for tax increases and middle-class tax cuts in a companion House bill. No one in either house of either party believes a veto can be overridden.
 
Little Defense of Bush Plan
 But while Republicans scorned the Democratic measure, they offered little defense of President Bush's own program, the seven-point proposal of capital-gains cuts, accelerated depreciation allowances and incentives for the real estate industry.
Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, assailed the Democratic bill as a "purely political proposal, the only purpose of which is to try to accentuate class divisions and portray Republicans who oppose it for sound economic reasons as being the party of the rich."
But he said the Bush proposal, while including some "more carefully targeted tax cuts" with some "prospect for stimulating the economy," was also defective. "The Administration's proposal loses all beneficial value by their refusal to pay for it," he continued, adding that it was based on an "accounting gimmick" and "fictitious savings."
"The two proposals are worse than doing nothing," he added. "If we do nothing, economic experts agree that the economy will, albeit slowly, work itself out of the recession. Doing nothing, at least, has the virtue of not making things worse in an effort to score political points and show the American people that we care."
 
Several Amendments Passed
 In the evening the Senate passed several amendments to the bill, some of which were plainly destined for quick discard in conference.
One such change was a proposal by Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, who proposed allowing penalty-free withdrawals of up to $10,000 from Individual Retirement Accounts for the purchase of new cars. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, called it "bad tax policy" but accepted it for consideration to save time.
Another such proposal, accepted on a voice vote, was an effort by Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, to prohibit states from taxing pensions received by persons who do not reside in the taxing state.
But Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum won acceptance for a proposal, already in the House bill and backed by the Bush Administration, that would require purchasers of assets of defunct savings and loan institutions to account for assistance from the Federal Government, which is tax-free, when calculating gains or losses on sales of those assets.
That proposal would raise $500 million over the next five years, and Mr. Bentsen quickly moved to use that money and more by proposing to increase, to 100 percent, the deductibility of health insurance premiums paid by owners of small businesses. Only 25 percent is now deductible.
 
Wrangling About House Bank
 That spate of activity followed a slow afternoon. After Mr. Rudman's speech and the Levin-Graham effort, the Senate avoided action for more than two hours by wrangling about the House Bank and the bad checks written on it.
Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said the "scandal in the House of Representatives is a dead cat also lying on the doorstep of the United States Senate" because many Americans do not distinguish between the two houses of Congress.
After repeated complaints that his attack violated Senate procedures by disparaging the House, Mr. Helms settled for a resolution, adopted without dissent, that no similar Senate bank should ever be established.
With no House-Senate conference on the bill planned before next Wednesday, the only real urgency for Senate action derived from senators' personal schedules. Mr. Bentsen The general expectation was that a House-Senate conference would go quickly, even though the two bills contain many major differences.
Democrats in both Houses want to get the bill to Mr. Bush so that he cannot complain that they took no action by his March 20 deadline, even if he dislikes the actions they took.
 
Major Differences in Bills
 But the Senate bill contains two major elements not touched on in the House bill. One is a Bentsen proposal designed to make it easier for small businesses to get health insurance coverage and to limit rate differentials and increase the portability of insurance policies for people who change jobs. Another is also a Bentsen plan, to make contributions to individual retirement accounts again tax-deductible and to create a new kind of I.R.A. whose income would be tax-free after five years.
Even on the basic stuff of the bills there are significant differences.
For example, the Senate's $300 credit, available in whole or part to families with incomes of $60,000 or less, would be permanent. The House has a temporary, two-year credit for one-fifth of Social Security and Medicare taxes paid by a worker, up to $200 for an individual or $400 for a working couple. And the House tax increases go to 35 percent, not 36 percent, but take effect at lower levels, starting at $85,000 of taxable income for an individual and $145,000 for a couple.
 
Problem on Capital Gains
 The bills also differ on how to reduce taxes on capital gains, though neither would go so far as the Bush proposal, which would reduce the maximum rate from 28 percent to 15.4 percent.
The Senate has a progressive rate, which cuts taxes on moderate-income taxpayers from 15 percent to 5 percent, while leaving a top rate of 28 percent for the better off.
The House would index capital gains against inflation. Under its approach, if someone bought stock for $1,000 and sold it for $1,500 after the cost of living had gone up by 25 percent, only the real profit of $250 would be subject to tax and not the $250 attributable to inflation.
Both House and Senate bills include provisions that would reduce to an effective 14 percent rate the taxes on new investments in small businesses if they were held five years.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Highlights of Competing Tax Proposals"
 
TAX CUTS
 SENATE: Create a permanent, non refundable $300 tax credit for children under 16, available to families with adjusted gross incomes under $47,500, and phase it out between $47,500 and $60,000. After $60,000, the credit would not apply.
 
Estimated cost over five years: $28 billion
 HOUSE: Create a two-year, refundable tax credit for one-fifth of Social Security and Medicare taxes paid by workers, up to $200 a year for individuals and $400 for couuples.
 
Estimated cost over five years: $45.9 billion
BUSH: Increase the personal exemption for children under 18 from $2,300 to $2,800.
 
Estimated cost over five years: $18.5 billion
 
TAX INCREASES
 SENATE: Increase top income tax rate to 36 percent, from 31 percent, beginning at taxable income of $150,000 for single taxpayers and $175,000 for joint taxpayers.
 
Estimated revenue: $43.0 billion
 HOUSE: Increase top rate to 35 percent, beginning at taxable income of $85,000 for individuals and $145,000 for joint. Also, increase the alternative minimum tax rate to 25 percent from 24 percent.
 
Estimated revenue: $43.2 billion
 BUSH: No comparable provisions.
 
TAX SURCHARGE
 SENATE: Impose a 10 percent surcharge on tax attributable to taxable income in excess of $1 million.
 
Estimated revenue: $8.5 billion
 HOUSE: Same.
 BUSH: No provision.
 
CAPITAL GAINS
 SENATE: Cut tax rates on capital gains to a range of 5 percent for those with lowest incomes to 28 percent, from 15 percent to 28 percent now. Assets would have to be held two years.
 
Estimated cost over five years: $7.7 billion
 HOUSE: Index gains on assets acquired after Jan. 31, 1992, for inflation. Like Senate, add incentives for small business investments.
 
Estimated cost over five years: $1.1 billion
 BUSH: Reduce maximum rate on capital gains to 15.4 percent. Retain one year holding period.
 
Estimated cost over five years: $10.2 billion
 
(Source: Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation)

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Brown Draws Some Blue-Collar Support and a Campus Crowd

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., March 12

 BODY:
Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California whose insurgent campaign has been reeling around the nation in search of supporters, appeared to have found some fertile ground in this state among union members and college students, particularly in economically distressed cities like this one.
Mr. Brown picked up endorsements today from Arthur B. Blackwell 2d, chairman of the Wayne County Commission, and from two of 15 other commission members. 
 Mr. Brown, who has taken to wearing a blue jacket given to him by a U.A.W. local in the state, today spoke to about 300 students, supporters and unemployed workers at the University of Michigan branch campus here, reiterating the anti-establishment, anti-big-money message of his "take back America" campaign.
 
Goodbye Jobs?
 Mr. Brown stressed his opposition to the United States-Mexico trade agreement. He said the agreement was a way to get cheap foreign labor and export American workers' jobs.
It is a message that resonates among union workers.
Mr. Brown said the International Union of Electrical Workers had encouraged him to remain the race. And Edward J. Carlough, president of the Sheet Metal Workers' International Association, has sent out videotapes to members of his his union saying that he supports Mr. Brown.
The Brown campaign in Detroit operates out of a Sheet Metal Workers office.
 
The Right Message
 Mr. Brown also railed against the politicians who he said had been co-opted by "the thousand-dollar campaign contribution" of the "moneyed interests" who cared little about the jobs, health and safety concerns of his audience. He attacked both his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts, as "more of the same."
It was just the message that Julie Harrington, 35 years old, and two friends who drove from Petoskey, 300 miles north of here, wanted to hear.
"This sign says it all," said Ms. Harrington, who held a hand-painted placard with the word "greed" in a circle with a slash through it.
"I want reform, and he's the only candidate talking it," said Ms. Harrington, who described herself as a waitperson and whose husband, Fred, is an electrical worker.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the senior Democrat from Michigan, introduced Mr. Brown at today's gathering, prompting Mr. Brown to quip, "The establishment may be joining our insurgent campaign."
But Mr. Riegle, who was in the city to visit his ailing father, was neither campaigning for Mr. Brown nor endorsing him.
"I certainly endorse some of his ideas, though," Mr. Riegle said. His district includes this depressed car-manufacturing city.
 
Toward Main Street?
 Mr. Brown also had a private meeting with Mayor Woodrow Stanley of Flint. Though not endorsing Mr. Brown, Mr. Stanley said that he, too, was intrigued by some of Mr. Brown's ideas.
"Those ideas have to find themselves into the main street," said Mr. Stanley, who noted that his city had an unemployment rate of 27 percent. "I've heard far too much about a middle-class tax cut and not enough about how that will help the cities. I want a vision that restores."
Mr. Stanley said that he expected to meet with the two other candidates in the next couple of days and would then make an endorsement.
In endorsing Mr. Brown, Mr. Blackwell said: "Speaking as an African-American and an elected official, Brown's message is very strong, very succinct, and it means a lot to us, particularly his emphasis on jobs."
 
Message Is Heard
 On Wednesday, Mr. Brown traveled to Marquette in Michigan's sparsely populated Upper Peninsula.
"We're making Michigan a major focus," Mr. Brown said. "We're here to bring the message to everyone. This is not the same old thing."
The strategy is apparently having some success. Mr. Brown was met at the airport by 150 enthusiastic people, organized with one day's notice in the wake of two major snow storms.
"He's fresh," said Jere DeFant, who organized the event. She said the turnout was exceptionally large given the area's population.
"He's talking about the things we're interested in: the environment, radically revising the tax system and a universal health system," she said, adding that Mr. Brown's message was hitting the right notes with mine and timber workers.
Mr. Brown ended the day in Chicago speaking to 600 students at Loyola University.
He returns to Michigan over the weekend, working hard for a victory or a strong showing in the Michigan and Illinois primaries on Tuesday that he said would "shock the daylights out of the Washington political establishment."
As he told a cheering audience of 1,400 students at Western Michigan State University Wednesday night: "From a nuisance, we've become a wild card. Next week we'll become a movement and change the nature of politics in this country."

HEADLINE: Kinnock Alters Course, Raising Question: Where's He Now?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 12

 BODY:
Neil Kinnock, the leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party, had his last joust in the House of Commons today before the April 9 elections.
Why, Mr. Kinnock, looking very prime ministerial in a dark blue suit, wanted to know, wouldn't Prime Minister John Major join him and the Liberal Democratic leader, Paddy Ashdown, in a televised campaign debate? 
 Mr. Kinnock was trying "to whip a little fervor into this chestnut," Mr. Major contended. Besides, he and Mr. Ashdown would be lucky to get a word in edgewise with the eloquent but wordy Labor leader.
"Whipped chestnuts is a new one on me," Mr. Kinnock said, charging Mr. Major with being afraid to debate the real issues raised by a prolonged recession. What the Prime Minister had said, in rejecting the debate proposal, was this, "Every party politician that expects to lose tries that trick, and every politician who expects to win says no."
 
Voters Have Reservations
 For the first time in more than a decade, Labor has a chance of winning a British general election, according to all the polls. But they also show that when they cast their ballots April 9, many voters will have reservations whether Labor's leader, Neil Kinnock, would make a good Prime Minister.
The paradox that Mr. Kinnock, whose 50th birthday is March 28, faces is this: He transformed his party and its positions, after a decade in the left-wing wilderness, so thoroughly that many people now wonder what he really stands for. Personally, all polls show that he is the least popular of the three main national party leaders, far behind the Conservative Prime Minister, John Major.
A Gallup survey published in The Daily Telegraph last Friday, for example, showed that the proportion of voters who thought Mr. Major would "make the best Prime Minister" was 41 percent, compared with only 25 percent who thought Mr. Kinnock would. The poll was based on 10,405 interviews conducted through month of February.
Mr. Kinnock predicted Labor that would win the election with a 20-seat majority in the House of Commons, which would require an unprecedented gain of 127 seats over what the party has now. But win or lose on April 9, the short, balding Welshman with the mellifluous voice will get all the credit or take all the blame. Which it will be is, at the moment, impossible to tell, with the public opinion polls early in the campaign showing Labor and Conservatives running neck and neck.
 
A Marked Change in Views
 He himself makes no bones about how much his views have evolved since his own student days, or even since the early 1980's. At University College in Cardiff, Wales, in the 1960's, and right up the beginning of this decade, both Mr. Kinnock and his wife, Glenys, were members of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament. The last time he ran for Prime Minister, in 1987, Mr. Kinnock still supported unilateral British nuclear disarmament, to the dismay of the Reagan Administration, and Labor lost decisively.
Mr. Kinnock got his party to drop its commitment to unilateral disarmament in early 1989, just before the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. The Kinnocks also let their membership in the anti-nuclear campaign lapse in 1991.
Mr. Kinnock would probably include British nuclear weapons in future disarmament talks, a position Mr. Major has not yet espoused, and Labor's past positions are no longer of much concern since the disintegration of the Soviet Union last year.
Things were very different when Mr. Kinnock took over the party leadership in 1983, after Labor's second consecutive defeat at the hands of Margaret Thatcher. Mr. Kinnock, then 41, had been parliamentary private secretary to his mentor, Michael Foot, an erudite left-wing Laborite who had lost the election after Mrs. Thatcher's victory in the Falklands Islands.
But the militantly Socialist positions of the day had cost Labor in other ways as well. A 10th of Labor's Members of Parliament deserted the party to form the Social Democratic Party, with such distinguished former Labor leaders as Roy Jenkins, David Owen and Shirley Williams among the defectors.
 
Youth Shaped by Hardship
 The new party faded away after Mr. Kinnock began making his changes. But when he began, little in his background suggested that he would be the man to force the changes. Born in Tredegar, in Wales, into a miner's family in 1942, Mr. Kinnock's youth was shaped by hardship and what he himself called "proletarian politics."
At his university, he took a degree in industrial relations and history, and met Glenys while he was chairman of the Socialist Society and she was campaigning against the bomb.
As late as 1983, he was saying that Labor could never accomplish the social and political change it sought without "a major extension of public ownership and control."
But by 1990 he was telling BBC Television that nationalization of British industry was "simply not something that's on offer." Instead, a party platform published that year promised a moderate policy in which its government would do more than the Conservatives had supposedly done to foster a climate in which private enterprise could flourish.
Mr. Kinnock's Labor Party pledges itself to prudent low-inflation economic policies. "We will not spend, nor will we promise to spend, more than Britain can afford," it says, adding that it is firmly committed to enthusiastic British membership in the European Community and in its monetary system. The party's election manifesto will be published next week.
The American Ambassador, Raymond G. H. Seitz, gave a dinner for the Kinnocks last week and paid tribute to the Labor leader's transformation of his party. Mr. Kinnock, who has been to the United States only twice since 1987, sidestepped a question today about President Bush's comment Wednesday that his respect for Mr. Major knew no bounds. President Bush, Mr. Kinnock said, had "made an honest, measured and reasonable response" to the question he had been asked at a White House news conference.
Mrs. Kinnock, like her husband, is confident about who will win. She said the family expected to move into 10 Downing Street in April, but will keep the house with the red door in Ealing for their two children, Rachel and Stephen, both at college.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Journal;
For New Ideas, It's a Week That Isn't

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 12

 BODY:
As sanctimonious as ever, the Democratic Presidential candidates are all on television here, attacking traditional politicians and promising radical reforms. But viewers may be wondering what exactly makes these enlightened rebels so different.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who likes to calls himself an "agent of change" against the "brain-dead politics" of the past, arrived here to pose for the cameras and effusively praise Chicago's Mayor, Richard M. Daley, the heir and namesake of America's most famous machine politician. Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton's television advertising is lambasting one of his opponents in next Tuesday's primaries in Illinois and Michigan, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, for daring to even mention some new ideas. 
 Mr. Tsongas, who likes to stress his devotion to the issues and his abhorrence of attack advertising, is running commercials that essentially call Mr. Clinton a liar without offering any evidence.
And former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who promises to save politics from the evils of moneyed contributors and lobbyists, is now suiting up in the uniform of one of Washington's more powerful special-interest groups.
 
Fashionable Jackets
 Mr. Brown's fashion statement, on display at factory gates and in front of microphones, consists of his trademark white turtleneck under a shiny blue warmup jacket with the logo of the United Automobile Workers. He does not seem to have taken off the jacket since he unveiled it to prime-time television audiences on Tuesday night in interviews that he conducted with network anchors from the U.A.W. union hall in Romulus, Mich.
"These people have been ripped off," Mr. Brown repeated in the interviews as he stressed his opposition to a free-trade pact with Mexico. "Jobs are being exported to Mexico and everywhere else, and these people feel it. They're angry and they know that neither Bush nor even the leadership of their own party care about what's happening in their families and their neighborhoods."
Mr. Brown looked pleased when David Brinkley of ABC News quoted the candidate's promise to "challenge the corrupt political system dominated by the Washington elites." But Mr. Brown did not seem to include the auto workers' union among these elites, even though it is a well-established presence in Washington and has its share of critics.
"If Jerry Brown wants to talk about who's ripping off working people, the U.A.W. would be a good place to start," said James Bovard, the author of a book on protectionism, "The Fair Trade Fraud" (1991, St. Martin's Press ). He faults the union for supporting restrictions and tariffs on imports of foreign cars.
 
'It's Highway Robbery'
 "Brown is pandering to a union that gives hundreds of thousands of dollars a year to Congressmen to keep restrictions on imports," Mr. Bovard said. "Those restrictions added $1,600 to the cost of the average new car during the mid-1980's. It's highway robbery to make an American car buyer, who on the average makes a lot less money than than an auto worker, pay an extra $1,600 to bankroll the auto workers' high salaries."
Mr. Tsongas also tried the warmup-jacket look, wearing one during a visit to a predominantly black high school here, but the visual highlight of his campaign so far has turned out to be less flattering. As his plane was taxiing at Chicago's Midway Airport on Wednesday, preparing to take him to Michigan, a wheel got stuck in the mud next to the runway -- and, unluckily for Mr. Tsongas, not far from television cameras.
Cheap symbols and visual puns are always tempting to journalists in need of something new to say on the campaign trail, and this one was irresistible because of its timing right after Mr. Tsongas's poor showing on Super Tuesday. What better way to show his "stalled campaign"?
The wheel stuck in the mud starred on the local evening newscasts. Even after the plane finally took off, WMAQ-TV featured a live report from the airport that gave the pun one further twist -- "Now the candidate's only other job is to avoid the political mud likely to be slung at him along the campaign."
Today Mr. Tsongas flung a little mud himself in an advertisement broadcast by television stations in Michigan and Illinois. It features drum rolls and rising music accompanying shots of Mr. Tsongas as an announcer says, in the voice of a hard-bitten detective: "This is Paul Tsongas. He's not pretty. He's not very polished."
Mr. Tsongas lacks politicians' endorsements, the announcer continues, "because he doesn't just make promises, he tells the truth." He has "ideas and the guts to make 'em stick." Then the music stops abruptly, and the announcer recites the words scrolling across the screen: "He's no Bill Clinton. That's for sure. He's the exact opposite."
For anyone who missed the first reference to truth, the ad ends: "Paul Tsongas. He's not afraid of the truth."
 
Other Contradictions
 One of Mr. Tsongas's aides describes the commercial as "going negative in a positive way." There may be some other contradictions -- if Mr. Tsongas is not an opportunistic politician, why is he smearing his opponent without offering any proof or chance for refutation? -- but it seems to be one of the campaign's more effective commercials.
Mr. Clinton was on the news this evening inspecting cheesecake at a factory and denouncing Mr. Tsongas's commercial. He promised to stick to the issues, which are the basis for his new commercial in Illinois attacking Mr. Tsongas. It shows a copy of Mr. Tsongas' booklet, "A Call to Economic Arms," next to a small photograph of the former Senator that looks awful enough to have come from his driver's license.
Pages flip as the announcer cites specifics, and the ad ends with the booklet shutting. "Isn't it time we closed the book on the 1980's?" the announcer says. "Paul Tsongas. More of the same."
It, too, is an effective advertisement, and it contains some truth: One of Mr. Tsongas's proposals, cutting the capital gains tax, is reminiscent of the 1980's.
But other ideas singled out in the ad, including the possibility of reducing future cost-of-living increases in benefits to wealthy Social Security recipients, are in fact popular among many of the reform Democrats that Mr. Clinton likes to associate himself with. Many neo-liberals have argued, for instance, that poor young workers in Detroit should not be subsidizing retirees in Palm Beach.
 
Back Home in Chicago
 But this is not really a week for new ideas, at least not new ideas that can be easily attacked with conventional techniques like 30-second commercials. And Mr. Clinton looks very comfortable falling back on the old politics.
The Arkansan appears regularly on the screen offering uncontroversial proposals like "putting people first" and "people-based economics." He does not explain what non-people-based economics would be, but he has the proper triumphant look of the front-runner.
So does his wife, Hillary, who took Mr. Clinton back to her old high school and demonstrated exactly how malleable campaigners can be.
Viewers who watched Mrs. Clinton's appearance on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" a few weeks ago detected a Southern twang as she talked about her marriage and Tammy Wynette, but there was no trace of it this week when she went back to her high school in the Chicago suburb of Park Ridge. In fact, for some reason it sounded as if her Chicago accent was coming back.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Jordan, Allies Again, Share Views on Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan, visiting Washington for the first time since the Persian Gulf war, met with President Bush today and later agreed to press for "full Iraqi compliance" with United Nations resolutions against Baghdad, the White House said.
Thus the King and the President appear to have begun mending ties. The relations, formerly close, ruptured last year when the Jordanians refused to join the forces ranged against Saddam Hussein of Iraq. 
 "He is my friend, and I welcome him back here," Mr. Bush said as the King arrived at the White House. It was the first meeting between the two since August 1990, although Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the King have met since then.
"The King feels that the relationship is back on track," Marwan J. Muasher, a spokesman for the Jordanian Government, said this evening. "Both sides want to look toward the future."
 
Relationship Inches Forward
 Administration officials have been encouraged by King Hussein's support for the Mideast peace process: Israeli talks with a Jordanian delegation have apparently accomplished more than talks with the Lebanese, Syrian and Palestinian delegations, officials say.
Experts on the region also said the King had brought to Washington new information on the position of the Palestinians since the latest round of Mideast peace talks ended last week.
But in the Administration and in Congress, there is still apprehension that Jordan continues to weaken the effect of a United Nations-mandated embargo on Iraq by allowing Baghdad to purchase in Jordan or ship through the country tons of goods and equipment in violation of sanctions. Only humanitarian goods like food and medical supplies may be imported by Iraq.
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has been seeking since late last year to block resumption of military aid to Jordan, citing the reports of embargo violations. Jordan denies it is violating United Nations resolutions.
King Hussein will meet Congressional leaders on Friday to discuss aid and other issues. The Bush Administration began to restore non-military aid last summer.
 
'Courageous and Forthright'
 While acknowledging past "difficulties" with Amman, President Bush told reporters at a photography session after greeting the King, "Jordan has taken a very courageous and forthright position on the peace talks."
The White House said King Hussein spoke to the President about Jordan's difficult economic situation and was assured that "the United States would continue to do what it could to help Jordan directly and through international financial institutions."
 
Hussein's Problems at Home
 "Jordan's economic situation is terrible," said Robert B. Oakley, a former diplomat who now directs Middle East projects at the United States Institute for Peace, a Government-backed institution in Washington. Jordan has lost most of its trade with Iraq and the income gained from serving as a port for Iraqi exports.
"More than 300,000 Palestinian-Jordanians were driven out of jobs in the gulf," he said. "From being employed and sending money home, they've come home to join the unemployed and become a burden."
Mr. Oakley, who recently toured the Middle East, said the King had to face other tensions that predate the Persian Gulf war. As an example, he said the King "has to face a Parliament with a plurality of Muslim Brothers opposed to the existence of Israel and the peace process."
In addition, Mr. Oakley said, there are close ties between the Jordanian and Iraqi military, forces that worked together in the Iran-Iraq war with the approval of the United States, which was interested then in building up Iraq at Iran's expense.
Those Jordanian-Iraqi ties can now be looked at two ways: The Iraqis could attempt to unsettle Jordan if the King moved too close to the United States, or Washington might see the ties as a route to the Iraqi military, where it hopes to encourage rebellion against Saddam Hussein.

HEADLINE: Rise in Japan Antitrust Fine

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 12

 BODY:
Responding to United States criticism that illegal monopolies face only light penalties in Japan, the Fair Trade Commission said today that it plans to increase the maximum fine to 100 million yen, about $752,000.
The change is the latest in a series of steps Japan has taken to make it costlier for businesses to engage in anti-competitive practices. 
 Last year, Japan raised surcharges to be levied on sales made by companies operating in illegal cartels to 6 percent from 1.5 percent. It also imposed prison terms of up to three years for violators.
Hiroshi Kasahara, the Fair Trade Commission's spokesman, said the new fines would be levied against corporations convicted of price-fixing, bid-rigging or monopolistic actions.
The maximum fine for individuals who violate the Anti-Monopoly Act will remain 5 million yen, or $38,000, -- the same maximum now for corporations, he said.
The plan was endorsed today by a special council of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, Mr. Kasahara said. The revision is to be submitted to Parliament, where passage is assured, and the commission plans to put it into effect some time in the fiscal year starting April 1, he said.
Reiichi Yumikura, chairman of the committee on competition policy for the Federation of Economic Organizations, said Japanese industry considered the proposed increase in fines "very severe."
But Mr. Yumikura, who is president of the Asahi Chemical Industry Company, a major maker of synthetic fibers, said in a statement that the Government should extend the coverage of the anti-monopoly law. The law now has many exceptions, he said.

HEADLINE: OTB Officials Take On Critics At a Hearing

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
The top executives of New York City's legal off-track gambling parlors clashed with state and city officials yesterday over whether the system was on the verge of losing money and should be sold to a private company.
A City Council committee asserted in a report that while profits declined in the last two years executives of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation authorized $267,000 for travel, meal and lodging; $40,000 for dining out and entertaining legislators; $428,000 to maintain a fleet of cars; $20,000 for an executive bathroom; $8,000 for employees to take a course in women's studies at Cornell University and $1,050 in political contributions. 
 The president and chief executive of the agency, Hazel N. Dukes, disputed many of the findings of excessive spending as inaccurate or as justifiable costs for an agency with an annual budget of more than $100 million. At a hearing in City Hall, Ms. Dukes, who was appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins in July 1990, maintained that she had put into effect economies that would save $7.6 million a year and that plans were in the works that would increase the city's share of OTB revenues.
She challenged an assertion by the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, that about 70 of the city's 95 off-track branches were unprofitable. She said two were in the red. Ms. Dukes asserted that that a principal reason that revenues had dropped was the Legislature's requirement that OTB turn over more than $80 million a year to the racing industry.
Ms. Dukes, asked by Councilman Israel Ruiz if she felt she was "not getting a fair shake" as an administrator because she is the first black president of the corporation, said that staff members of the Council's Finance Committee "had tried to find every disgruntled employee to testify" against her.
"I am as clean as clean can be," she said as supporters in the second-floor chamber applauded.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Illinois;
Clinton Hopes Groundwork of 1991 Will Keep Him Rolling in the North

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 12

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton was keenly aware of the Super Tuesday trap that his fellow Southerner, Senator Albert Gore, fell into four years ago when he rolled out of the South with a string of primary victories -- and skidded to a halt in the North.
That explains why the Arkansas Governor began establishing a northern beachhead in Illinois last year. Now, with an array of endorsements and a foundation of political support cultivated for months, Mr. Clinton is hoping for a decisive victory here on Tuesday to cap his Super Tuesday sweep and push him substantially closer to the Democratic nomination. And former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who opened a campaign office in Illinois only a few weeks ago, is trying to make a virtue out of necessity. 
 Mr. Tsongas's new television commercial in Illinois declares, "He's not the guy with all the endorsements from politicians because he doesn't just make promises." Former Senator Adlai Stevenson 3d, whose endorsement was one that Mr. Tsongas has managed to acquire, said in an interview today: "He's the underdog. He's had very little organization, very little money, but I think the message resonates."
 
'Strength Is Broad'
 Paul Green, an expert on politics at Governors State University, said Mr. Clinton should be considered the favorite here but added that his "strength is broad, but not very deep."
Both The Chicago Tribune and The Chicago Sun Times published public opinion polls last weekend showing a tightening race between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, but those surveys were conducted before Mr. Clinton got a burst of good publicity from his Super Tuesday victories. Some Democrats say that many Illinois voters are only beginning to focus on the race.
Mr. Clinton paid a highly publicized call on Mayor Richard M. Daley this week, but the Mayor remains neutral, although "friendly neutral," as one Clinton supporter put it. Still, Mr. Clinton has garnered the support of numerous Chicago pols, including many of the people around Mr. Daley. Mr. Clinton's campaign is heavy with veterans of Illinois politics, like David Wilhelm, the campaign manager, who also managed Mr. Daley's 1989 and 1991 campaigns.
Mr. Clinton, who prospered by building biracial support in the South, has also won some important endorsements here from black politicians, like former Mayor Eugene Sawyer, Commissioner Danny K. Davis of Cook County and Attorney General Roland Burris. Mr. Clinton's slate of delegates and endorsers spans the ideological and factional continuum of Democratic politics here, several Democrats said.
"They've spent a lot of time contacting and recruiting people, and it's paid off," said Thomas Hynes, the Cook County Assessor, who signed on with the Clinton campaign last year.
 
Mrs. Clinton's Hometown Roots
 Added to this are Hillary Clinton's hometown roots here and what many Democrats described as the affinity of southern Illinois for a Southerner.
Against this, the Tsongas campaign is vowing to regain control of the campaign debate here, after spending the final five days of the Super Tuesday primaries on the defensive. "Ultimately, it will depend on whether Paul Tsongas's message can overcome Bill Clinton's machine," said Dennis Kanin, the Tsongas campaign manager. "In Florida, we got sidetracked a bit because we wanted to set the record straight. We're just not going to get diverted this time."
Mr. Tsongas's television advertising tries to resurrect the anti-politician appeal that stood him in good stead in earlier primaries. "He's not pretty," the announcer declares. "He tells the truth. He has ideas to make our economy grow, build jobs and invest in future generations." The announcer adds: "He's no Bill Clinton. That's for sure."
Mr. Clinton's television advertising echoes the lines of attack set out in Florida, arguing that Mr. Tsongas's bitter medicine for the economy is simply a replay of "trickle-down economics" and would mean another "capital gains cut for the rich" with higher gasoline taxes and lower cost of living increases for the rest of America.
Kitty Kurth, who is coordinating the Tsongas campaign here, demanded, "If they have all this organization and all this strength," why "have we got all this negative campaigning?" Tsongas campaign officials say they are looking for votes across the board, but based on earlier contests, the suburbs and particularly the lakefront areas are considered fertile ground.
 
Tsongas and Labor Vote
 Mr. Tsongas is also trying to reach out to groups that have not been a mainstay of his support, including blacks and organized labor. But several labor officials here said he faces a big hurdle on that front: his refusal to endorse legislation that outlaws the hiring of permanent replacement workers for striking employees.
"I don't care who it is, where it is," said Paul Giblin, Illinois legislative director for the United Auto Workers. "If you're against that, that's apple pie and motherhood." Mr. Giblin, whose union had been supporting Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who withdrew from the race this week, said he expected auto workers in Illinois to wind up in various camps.
Some, he said, might go to former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who is making a concerted effort for labor votes. Others, he said, were backing Mr. Clinton. But Mr. Giblin said he heard very poor reviews of Mr. Tsongas's "pro-business" appeal from the "people I get feedback from."
Even before Mr. Harkin's withdrawal, Mr. Clinton had some labor backing of his own. Here in Illinois, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees was mailing literature supportive of Mr. Clinton to all 65,000 members in the state, as well as running phone banks.
 
Concern About Electability
 For all the talk of organization, however, Mr. Wilhelm, the Clinton campaign manager, said he expected the battle here to revolve around the two men's economic policies. "Illinois has 9.3 percent unemployment," Mr. Wilhelm said. "This is a state that's been a victim of trickle-down economics."
The Tsongas forces, meanwhile, are hopeful that their message can triumph once again. Ms. Kurth said the campaign had acquired 2,500 volunteers in the last two weeks. Mr. Stevenson said: "He's at least projecting the image of a man with the courage to tell the truth. That goes a long way"
Mr. Stevenson said that many of the elected officials backing Mr. Clinton "are doing so with little conviction and a great deal of concern about electability."
He added, "That is not to say they're any less concerned with Tsongas's electability."

HEADLINE: Surgeon General Warns of Smoking in Latin Lands

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Latin America and the Caribbean are on the verge of an epidemic of smoking-related disease like the one that has plagued the United States and Canada unless governments work to stem the popularity of cigarettes, the United States Surgeon General said today.
Issuing the annual Federal report on the health effects of smoking, the Surgeon General, Dr. Antonia C. Novello, said the threat required coordinated action among all countries. 
 While 80 percent of the 526,000 smoking-related deaths each year in the Americas occur in the United States and Canada, she said, Latin America is primed to be the "growth" region for cigarette-related disease as disproportionate numbers of young people and women take up the habit.
The report said the popularity of smoking in Latin America was more sensitive to price than in North America, and the per capita consumption of cigarettes in Latin America declined in the 1980's because of economic recession. But health officials fear that the incidence of smoking will start rising as economic conditions improve, Dr. Novello said.
"It seems to us this is the perfect window of opportunity now to take action," she said at a news briefing. "Knowing these facts, it is our hope that hemisphere neighbors, poised to follow the same path, can avert the death and disease that inevitably result from tobacco use."
Smoking's prevalence in Latin America is 37 percent for men and 20 percent for women, Dr. Novello said, compared with 30 percent for men and 25 percent for women in the United States. But in some urban areas in Latin America, 50 percent of youths smoke, and the rate among women, particularly young women, is also rising rapidly, she said.
Dr. Novello's report called for systematic studies to determine how many people smoke in Latin America, how smoking is viewed culturally, how tobacco is produced and consumed and how taxation and legislation might be used to curb smoking.
Among the things that account for some of the rising popularity of smoking in Latin America, it said, are advertising, urbanization, growing population, improving education and the entrance of more women into the workforce. If considering the economic effects of the growth and sale of tobacco, the report said, Latin nations should note that health costs associated with smoking will far exceed the benefits.
Joining Dr. Novello at the briefing, the director of the Pan American Health Organization, Dr. Carlyle Guerra de Macedo, said governments must give a higher priority to controlling tobacco. He called for international studies, with assistance from the United States, to help the extent of the problem and a commitment to keep smoking from becoming epidemic.
In a separate report, the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said surveys of teen-age smokers showed they chose the most heavily advertised brands when they took up cigarettes.
The agency said in its Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report that survey findings indicated smokers aged 12 to 18 preferred Marlboro, Camel or Newport cigarettes, the three most heavily advertised brands. Adult smokers also made Marlboro their first choice, followed by Winston and Salem. But adults smoked a wide variety of other brands, the report said.
The report noted that the preference for Camel jumped noticeably the year after the beginning of an advertising campaign featuring a cartoon camel, "Old Joe." On Monday, Dr. Novello called on the makers of Camel cigarettes to end their ad campaign featuring the character because studies suggested that it might encourage children to start smoking, a charge the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company denied.
Thomas Lauria, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, an industry group, said it was not extraordinary that younger smokers chose the most popular brands since adults did also. The industry does not encourage teen-age smoking, he said, but there is no evidence that advertising dictates who starts smoking and when. After people start smoking, he added, advertising influences brand choice.
