HEADLINE: Latest Plan to Cure Welfare Troubles Borrows W.P.A. Blueprints of 1930's

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
In this season of welfare discontent, one of the oldest ideas in social policy is getting talked up as the newest solution: the Works Progress Administration, Franklin D. Roosevelt's sweeping public jobs program.
The creation of a new W.P.A. has long been a favorite idea of few policy hounds and unsuccessful candidates. But today it reached a kind of political maturation when a group of Congressional Democrats announced a legislative plan to make it a reality. 
 Roosevelt used the program as an alternative to the dole in combating unemployment, putting an army of jobless people to work building roads, bridges, schools, stadiums, culverts, courthouses, and other structures, many of which endure.
Senators David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Paul Simon of Illinois and several others see an updated purpose: giving welfare recipients the dignity of serious work, while offering taxpayers the benefits of tangible returns.
"The taxpayers get very little for what they are spending," said Mr. Boren, who is calling his program the Community Works Progress Administration. "Those on welfare are deprived of a sense of personal worth which comes from the satisfaction of performing useful work."
W.P.A.-style proposals are a variation on "workfare," but much more ambitious than the kind of programs that have recently been tried, which involve limited hours, modest work projects and are all limited to welfare recipients.
A quarter of the slots in Mr. Boren's program, for instance, would be open to people who are not on welfare. And he is putting an emphasis on building and repairing things, while many recent workfare jobs have involved less visible tasks, like filing.
Mr. Boren was quick to acknowledge that in today's cash-tight Congress, a modest pilot program might be all he could realistically expect. And he can expect to encounter many pockets of opposition after formally introducing the bill in the next few weeks. In the past, many liberals have dismissed such proposals as punitive "slavefare," while conservatives have conjured public works images of six people leaning on shovels while one digs a hole. In addition, public employee unions have resisted the proposals, which would provide rival sources of public labor.
But the plan is significant because it puts forth a welfare proposal far more radical than most now being discussed.
"For all the rhetoric about welfare, the nation has not been committed to coming up with the bottom line -- an actual job," said Sheldon Danziger, a professor of social work and public policy at the University of Michigan. "By now we've learned that if we really want to tackle the welfare problem, the Government has to act as an employer of last resort."
The talk of a new W.P.A. comes as welfare rolls reach record levels each month, many states are cutting benefits and a number of conservative politicians are trying to gain political advantage from denouncing the system.
In recent weeks, President Bush has added his voice to the chorus of critics, with campaign commercials that promise to "change welfare and make the able-bodied work."
Beneath the suddenly roiling surface of politics, the country has been stressing two different approaches to welfare revision in recent years.
One school, led by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Representative Thomas J. Downey of Long Island, both Democrats, stresses the education and training of families on welfare. The two sponsored the 1988 Family Support Act, which now provides up to a $1 billion a year in Federal matching funds for states to train recipients.
But only about 60 percent of that money is now being spent, since states have had difficult coming up with their part of the matching funds. And in an economy where many people with more education and longer work histories are also unemployed, welfare recipients continue to face strong disadvantages.
The second approach, often called "the new paternalism," seeks to alter the behavior of the poor through financial rewards: those who stay in school get small bonuses in their welfare checks, for instance, while those who are frequently absent suffer financial penalties.
While these programs have a popular appeal, reinforcing middle-class values held by many voters, the amounts of money involved are usually modest, generally about $50 a month. And past studies of financial incentives have suggested that such small amounts have had little effect on major decisions like whether to work or marry.
The W.P.A.-type proposals are much bolder since they offer not just an incentive to get a job, but the real thing: the job itself.
"It represents a logical and radical approach that few politicians have been willing to support up to this point," said Mickey Kaus, who wrote an influential 1986 article in The New Republic calling for the replacement of welfare with a system of guaranteed Government jobs.
"Liberals have been unwilling to be tough enough, and conservatives have been unwilling to spend the money," he said.
Martin Anderson, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution who served as President Reagan's domestic policy adviser, took a harsher view, citing the potential for big boondoggles.
"Jobs in the public sector are grossly inefficient," he said. "It's a bad idea, whose time has passed."
Senator Boren's plan would retain the current welfare system for women with young children and those enrolled in a education or training program. But most others would have to take public works jobs for up to 32 hours a week. The jobs would pay either the minimum wage, or 10 percent more than a welfare grant, whichever is higher.
The program would be run by the Labor Department. Local community groups, called private industry councils, would receive a set amount of money and design the kinds of public works projects they wanted to conduct.
Co-sponsors of the measure include Senators Harry Reid of Nevada, Carl Levin of Michigan and Thomas Daschle of South Dakota, all Democrats. In the House, Representative Glenn English, an Oklahoma Democrat, pledged to introduce similar legislation.
 
A More Expensive Approach
 At a news conference today, they acknowledged that the plan would be more expensive than simply mailing welfare checks. Supervisors must be hired, and building supplies procured.
But standing before the grainy, black-and-white photographs of Depression-era projects, the Democrats ticked off a list of W.P.A. accomplishments in the agency's six-year span, which ended in 1941: 650,000 miles of roads, 18,000 playgrounds, 125,000 buildings.
"We face a basic choice," said Senator Simon. "Do we pay people for being productive or nonproductive?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In the Suburbs;
Clinton Pursues Disaffected Democrats

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., March 12

 BODY:
Arkansas Governor Bill Clinton set out to woo disaffected Democrats in suburban Macomb County today, appearing at an organized question-and-answer session where he tried to blend "old Democratic values" with a call for greater individual responsibility.
The Bush Administration, he said, has no strategy to preserve the automobile industry, reform health insurance or decrease crime. 
 Mr. Clinton calls for everyone, including members of unions, to accept change that would include relaxed work rules and increased opportunities for education and health care.
 
'Old Values'
 "Michigan is being punished now because your national Government has no strategy to take advantage of trade," Mr. Clinton told an overflow crowd at Macomb Community College here.
"I'm trying to give you a new Democratic Party based on old values that will make you want to come home to the Democrats in this county," he said. "But I'm telling you, there's nothing I can do to get around the fact that we have got to come together around values and across racial lines. And if we're not prepared to do it, we're not going to make it as a country."
But Mr. Clinton must convince the alienated Democrats who have voted for the Republican Presidential nominee in three successive elections here that the Governor of a small state who favored legislation promoting increased trade with Mexico is the best alternative.
Surveys taken of voters as they have left the polls around the nation in recent weeks have shown that Mr. Clinton is more likely to be an attractive choice for blue-collar and black voters.
In recent years, Macomb County, a working class, white-majority area, has become the most fashionable political laboratory for Democrats seeking to win back first the Senate and now the White House.
 
'I Want to Believe'
 It served no less a purpose today. "I want to believe in Bush," said Joan Telton, a registered nurse who came to hear Mr. Clinton speak today. "But look at what's happened in the last four years. It hasn't really touched my family, but that's because my husband is willing to go out and work 15 or 20-hour days. We're spending all of our time working."
Mr. Clinton and his advisers are convinced that Paul E. Tsongas holds little appeal to such voters because the former Massachusetts senator has become so closely identified with business interests. And Mr. Clinton is determined, as well, to neutralize Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s potential for attracting angry votes seeking to register a protest.
Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll-taker, noted that Mr. Brown, the former Governor of California, is using Michigan as a base from which to broaden his appeal by pitching hard to union voters. But Mr. Clinton is seeking to convince these same voters that he can address their unhappiness more effectively.
Mr. Clinton must first quell some fears among voters in Illinois and especially Michigan who distrust his record on labor issues, a subject that has been raised repeatedly during two days of campaigning in and around Chicago and Detroit. Union members have been particularly skeptical of his support for speeding up a free-trade agreement with Mexico that they feel will reduce American manufacturing jobs.
 
Union, Nonunion
 "I am pro-worker," Mr. Clinton said in Chicago today. "I am not anti-union. I believe that most people in the work force work in nonunion jobs, so I have to address union and nonunion. This is a false fight. We get into the choice of union and nonunion. That is the choice of the people in the work force."
Earlier today, Mr. Clinton again faced criticism from Mr. Tsongas, who has continued to paint Mr. Clinton as someone unfit to be President.
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Tsongas's attacks on his character were rooted in frustration because in Michigan and Illinois "we finally started having an economic debate again."
But Mr. Clinton predicted that he would survive the criticism leveled at him by political opponents or by any further investigations into his background.
"I have no control over what you write or what others say," Mr. Clinton told reporters. "I know what my character is, and the only way to demonstrate it is by living.
"I've been called everything but a blue goose," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Courting Labor;
Tsongas Tells Auto Workers Of 'Problem With Democrats'

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 12

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas ventured into labor territory today wearing an automobile union windbreaker, but his message at an auto parts plant here was one that workers are not used to hearing.
Only during questioning from workers did the former Massachusetts Senator acknowledge his opposition to legislation championed by labor that would bar employers from permanently replacing striking workers. He also told them he supports the free trade agreement with Mexico that most unions oppose. 
 And Mr. Tsongas sounded like a Republican when he called for more venture capital investment and took issue with traditional Democratic economic policies.
"The problem with Democrats," he said, "is that they give all these things away. It doesn't create jobs. The Democratic Party's got to get its act together and understand how you can bring the economy back."
 
'Problem Is Not Past'
 Mr. Tsongas recalled his high ratings with labor during his Congressional career but said relations soured over his opposition to the striker replacement bill, which is backed by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
"The problem is not the past," Mr. Tsongas said at a news conference at the Hermes Automotive Manufacturing Corporation, which has laid off more than half its workers in recent years. "The problem is the issue of striker replacement."
Insisting that arbitration was a better remedy, he said: "If there's a strike, if there's a lockout, the community gets killed. People lose their jobs."
Perhaps sensing that he does not go over well with union audiences, Mr. Tsongas abandoned talk of striker replacement and other topics critical to organized labor at a gathering later today in union hall at Rockford, Ill. Not once did he even mention the word labor. His only effort to identify with the audience on labor was in recounting the decline of his hometown, the "great textile city" of Lowell, Mass.
"Lowell's decline is what I grew up with," Mr. Tsongas said. "It's not a memo."
But his staff distributed flyers saying that Mr. Clinton "had one of the worst records on labor issues of any Governor," and noting that Arkansas is a "right-to-work state." The flyers offer a taste of television commercials that the Tsongas campaign plans to begin broadcasting on Friday in Michigan and Illinois that go after Mr. Clinton's labor record.
Mr. Tsongas has not been timid about criticizing Mr. Clinton on the issue. In conversations this week, he said, union officials told him they were nervous about whether Mr. Clinton could win a general election after accusations of an extramarital affair and efforts to avoid the draft during the Vietnam War.
Given his economic philosophy, it was far from clear that Mr. Tsongas could win labor support by finding fault with his chief rival.
"He's got some courage in walking into Michigan and auto worker territory and talking like he's talking, since his economic message is not that much different from George Bush's," said Donald R. Sweitzer, a senior campaign adviser to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa before he withdrew from the race this week. "But the bottom line is he'll be rejected Tuesday by the people he's talking to today. Labor folk have a problem with both of these guys but less of a problem with Bill Clinton."
While Mr. Tsongas was greeted politely at the Hermes plant, at least one worker was not impressed with him or Mr. Clinton. "I favor Mr. Brown," Anthony Zentarski, who works in the paint shop, said of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. "He just seems more in touch with the common worker."
At both labor events today, listeners said they wanted to hear what Mr. Tsongas had to say but were reluctant to commit their vote to him.
Greg Reiter, a firefighter in Rockford, noted that Mr. Tsongas did not say much about labor. "I like his ideas on rebuilding the country," said Mr. Reiter. "But there are questions he hasn't answered."

HEADLINE: U.S. Retail Sales Jump In Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Retail sales surged in February, and were far higher in January than first estimated, the Commerce Department said today in a report that analysts called the strongest evidence of economic recovery so far.
Sales soared 1.3 percent last month, after climbing 2.1 percent in January. 
 These were the first back-to-back sales gains exceeding 1 percent since 1985, and they prompted economists to scramble to raise forecasts of first-quarter national output.
 
 
'Recovery Is Here'
 "Recovery is here -- and it is on a firm footing," said Samuel D. Kahan, an economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. "This clearly lays to rest fears about a double-dip recession."
The gains were "huge," said Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "You can't find anything wrong with them," he added. "They're true strength."
The Bush Administration hailed the report, which suggested an economy increasingly likely to get noticeably better in this election year. "This economy is moving," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told a luncheon audience at the National Press Club. "It has started. You can feel it."
The unexpectedly large sales gains sent tremors through the credit market, which fears that too rapid a recovery will revive inflation. Interest rates surged, with the return on 30-year bonds pushing above 8 percent for the first time since early November. [Page D13.]
 
 
Tighter Credit Is Possible
 The Federal Reserve is now considered most unlikely to lower interest rates further in this business cycle, and some analysts are beginning to discuss the prospect that the Fed may tighten credit, which would be likely to raise rates.
But despite increasing confidence that the fledgling recovery will not suddenly swoon, as did last year's, most economists continued to expect that the revival would be halting and uneven. Such caution was consistent with other Government figures published today showing that first-time claims for unemployment insurance rose 22,000, to 459,000, in the latest week, the highest level in a month.
And one of the most politically sensitive indicators, the unemployment rate, may well continue to rise even in an expanding economy, as people who had given up looking for jobs are encouraged to look again, but without immediate success.
Democrats took a dim view of last Friday's unemployment report showing that the jobless rate rose two-tenths of a point in February, to 7.3 percent. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, said that people moving back into the work force "ran into a brick wall."
 
 
'On the Right Track'
 Still, analysts were highly impressed by the sales figures. Retail sales, which are considered one of the best indicators of current economic conditions, account for a third of gross domestic product and half of all spending by consumers.
"These data confirm that the economy is indeed on the right track," asserted Marilyn Schaja, an analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The 1.3 percent gain in February, to $157.7 billion, included every type of retailer except food stores and was just as strong when the automotive group, which accounts for 21 percent of the total, is excluded.
Sales now stand 4.6 percent above the level of February 1991, suggesting a modest rise in the volume of goods moving across retail counters, since consumer inflation over the period was a bit over 3 percent. The department adjusts its retail data for seasonal, holiday and trading-day variation, but not for price changes.
 
 
Big January Revision
 But while the February gain was nearly twice as large as generally expected, even after strong gains previously reported by department stores, the bigger jolt came from the fact that this occurred from a raised January base. The revised 2.1 percent gain reported today, to $155.6 billion, compared with a modest gain of six-tenths of a percent first reported for January four weeks ago.
In a re-evaluation of her forecast, Ms. Schaja predicted that gross domestic product would accelerate to a rate of 3 percent "by the second quarter" and that it was now "extremely clear that the Fed will probably not ease policy again in this cycle."
Mr. McKelvey said that the data released today prompted him to raise his estimate of first-quarter G.D.P. from negative growth to a rate slightly greater than 1 percent.
But while the recovery would likely continue, he said, it would be held in check by various factors, including firmer interest rates and a weakening of European and Japanese economies that is likely to reduce demand for American exports.
 
 
Durable Goods Up 2.3%
 The February sales gain was 2.3 percent for durable goods, which include long-lasting items like furniture and cars and account for 36 percent of the nation's retail business. Sellers of building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes racked up a 5.7 percent gain, while automobile dealers gained 1.4 percent. Sales of furniture, home furnishings and equipment rose 1.3 percent.
Among nondurables, items from clothing to motor oil, the gain was eight-tenths of a percent last month, with gasoline stations enjoying the biggest advance, of 3.1 percent. Sales of apparel and accessory stores climbed 2.3 percent, department stores and other general merchants posted a 1.4 percent increase, drug and proprietary stores gained 1.2 percent and restaurants and bars edged up one-tenth of a percent. Sales of food stores, however, declined eight-tenths of a percent.
For January, the revisions that more than tripled the initial estimate were about $900 million for auto dealers, more than $800 million for general merchandise stores, and $400 million for stores selling home furnishings.
The 2.1 percent jump for the month was the biggest since February 1991 and meant that the first two months of this year produced consecutive gains of 1 percent or more for the first time since August and September of 1985.
 
 
Many Concerns Remain
 Yet growing optimism about the economy, paced by a comeback in housing, was accompanied by concern among many analysts about a still-sluggish job market, pinched incomes, high debt and low -- albeit steadier -- consumer confidence.
When asked to explain how consumers could be stepping up their retail purchases in such an environment, Mr. McKelvey said it remained something of a mystery. It might partly be explained by larger and earlier tax refunds this year and by money the Internal Revenue Service has acknowledged sending to many people it mistakenly thought qualified for a low-income credit.
Another reason for the restrained recovery was cited by Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. He pointed to "substantially overbuilt" inventories that will have to be reduced in coming months before new demand prompts companies to raise output.

HEADLINE: Villa Victoria Journal;
In the Drug War, U.S. Sows Dollars, Reaps Hate

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VILLA VICTORIA, Bolivia

 BODY:
The woman, who would identify herself only as Gabriela, sat sullenly in the loft of a rickety hut with her tiny children. She had become the latest target in Bolivia's halting war on cocaine.
An hour earlier, an elite Bolivian anti-narcotics squad had barreled down a dirt road in a pickup truck and stopped at her house. A quick search behind the house revealed a path that led across streams and through swamps to a crude jungle laboratory for making cocaine base. 
 After dismantling the laboratory, the police had returned to Gabriela's home, where a search turned up 20 bags of coca leaf -- worth $350 -- that would probably have been used that evening in the lab.
"We know the people hate us," said Lieut. Ramiro Cuba Diaz, leader of the raid. "When we do this, we're taking their livelihood away from them."
 
Top Drug Traffickers Seized
 In the last three years, the Bolivian Government and the United States have tried to make this country a showcase in the fight against cocaine. Washington has spent $121 million to train Bolivia's crack police unit and equip it with M-16's, helicopters and four-wheel-drive vehicles, and an additional $293 million to help Bolivia develop altenative crops to cocaine and to pay farmers $800 for every acre of coca they agree to cut down.
Officials say that this year the Government has arrested more than a dozen high-level drug traffickers, shut down several big laboratories and seized almost two tons of cocaine base, an intermediate step in the refining process. But it is evident in talking with peasant coca farmers that the Government has yet to win the hearts of the people.
 
Broken Promises
 The field of conflict is well defined. There is a legal market in Bolivia for coca leaf chewed by local residents and for herbal tea and home remedies. Almost all the Bolivian coca that is bound for the illegal cocaine trade is grown here in the Chapare, an area about the size of New Jersey that butts up against the Andes and spreads out into the Amazon basin. As many as 150,000 Bolivians eke out a living growing coca.
In Peru, where two-thirds of the world's coca leaf is grown, attempts by stop cultivation and cocaine trafficking are severely hindered by the presence of leftist guerrillas. But in Bolivia, the main resistance to eradication of coca farming is economic.
Farmers who have accepted Government payments to cut down their coca plants and switch to other crops have found that at harvest time the price paid for their bananas, grapefruit, pineapples or other crops is so low that it does not support their families, or that the roads and bridges that the Government promised to build to get the produce to market have yet to be built.
After three years of intense efforts to get Chapare farmers to switch to other crops, the number of acres planted in coca has been reduced by only 15 percent, to about 84,000 acres.
"I think coca is here for good," said Pastor Garcia, who described himself as a middleman whose job was to transport coca. "It's the only product you can grow that you know you can sell the same day and earn enough to stay alive."
The industry seems vibrant enough at the coca market some 20 miles from here in Villa 14 de Septiembre. Under a corrugated metal roof that provides protection from the blazing jungle sun and torrential downpours, Andean women in felt hats, puffed skirts and brightly colored shawls sit on bags of coca leaf waiting for buyers. Hundreds of bags are for sale.
Villagers say there are no drug traffickers here, only legitimate buyers who will truck the coca to Cochabamba, some 100 miles into the mountains, where it will be sold to companies that make harmless herbal teas. But Government officials say most of the merchandise sold will eventually be bought by trafficking organizations and transported deep into the jungle to begin the process of making cocaine for the European and North American markets.
Officials argue that even though the numbers of laboratories raided and the amounts of cocaine seized went down in 1991, the size of labs being seized now is much larger and that intelligence gathered from jailed traffickers who are cooperating with the authorities should yield much more in the future.
 
Farmers Are Resentful
 "Two years ago, Umopar was corrupt, nonfunctional and would go into every operation yelling, kicking and screaming," said an American counternarcotics official, referring to the Bolivian drug police by their acronym. "Now they have cleaned up their unit and we have stepped back, putting them out in front. Now they take the initiative."
But in conversations with more than 20 coca farmers recently, only one spoke well of Umopar. Since September there have been over half a dozen incidents when peasants have tried to stop the police from destroying crops or when drug traffickers have shot at Umopar officers or agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration. One peasant has been killed and one D.E.A. agent wounded in recent shoot-outs.
"If there were real development, all our members would change to another crop," said Abelino Espinoza, a director of the coca market in Villa 14 de Septiembre. "But there is no market for these products yet. As far as we are concerned this 'development' is a deception by the Government. So we continue with coca."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bolivia's fight against cocaine, financed with more than $400 million from the United States, is centered in the Chapare region, an area about the size of New Jersey. Raids by elite anti-narcotic squads in the area, however, have reduced the acres planted in coca by only 15 per cent. "We know the people hate us," said an officer after a recent raid. "When we do this, we're taking their livelihood away from them." (Nathaniel C. Nash/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Executives in a Survey Start to See Signs of Turnaround

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Eyeing their cash registers, showrooms and shop floors, many American business executives are starting to see signs that the nation's sluggish economy is at last turning the corner.
Nearly half of 490 business executives surveyed in a New York Times/ CBS News Poll, see some inkling of improvement. Forty-seven percent of the executives, representing a randomly selected cross section of American industry from multibillion-dollar corporations to small family firms, said they were convinced that the economy was getting better. Forty-four percent said it was staying the same, while only 9 percent described it as getting worse. 
 This guarded optimism appears to be a recent sentiment. W. John Devine, chairman of Child World Inc. of Avon, Mass., a toy-store chain with 125 outlets in the Northeast and Midwest, marks the shift from the start of this year. Store sales stopped falling and increased a bit for the first time in 15 months. "It's nice to see plus signs in front of the numbers for a change," Mr. Devine said.
 
Retail Sales Surge
 Child World's experience was repeated at many other stores around the country. The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales surged 1.3 percent in February, and said that results in January were also far higher than previously reported. [Page D1.]
Retailing is not the only industry where executives are feeling more encouraged. In Sterling Heights, Mich., Don Holton, president of Automotive Plastic Technologies Inc., has also begun to see an uptick in orders for the molded plastic parts it makes for Chrysler, General Motors, Mazda and Toyota. "We're kind of bullish about what's going on here," he said.
Chun Chiu, president of Quality Semiconductor Inc., has noticed the improvement as well. His Santa Clara, Calif., company makes specialized chips that go into computer work stations. "It's increasing very slowly, but demand has been growing since the start of the year," Mr. Chiu said.
Business executives make the expansion and cutback, hiring and firing decisions that are closely linked to larger forces in the American economy like consumer confidence and spending. And the business people polled from Feb. 18 to March 6, who were mainly senior executives, at companies with yearly revenues of $5 million to more than $500 million, are considerably more upbeat in their assessments of the economy's path than most Americans -- though it could be that business people always tend to be more optimistic than others.
In a nationwide New York Times/ CBS News Poll of the public last month, only 13 percent of the people questioned replied that the economy was getting better, with the rest saying it was worse or the same.
To be sure, the business executives do not see strong economic activity, based on their own sales and orders. Fifty-six percent of those polled replied that the condition of the economy was still "fairly bad" and 15 percent more said "very bad." And the poll results, plus follow-up interviews with more than two dozen of these executives during the last week, indicate that there are regional differences, with the Northeast, Michigan and Southern California generally lagging behind the rest of the country.
Sloan's Supermarkets Inc., which has 46 food stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan, saw its sales dip 2 percent last year, and the softness has continued so far this year. "I don't see any signs of improvement yet," said Jules Rose, the chairman of Sloan's.
And the recovery many executives foresee will not be abrupt but gradual, more an economy rising from its knees than one sprinting ahead, they say.
 
Backing Up Optimism With Cash
 Still, the businesses that see sales and orders rising did express a willingness to back up their incipient optimism with their pocketbooks. Fifty-two percent of the companies said they planned to increase their capacity to produce goods and services, while 4 percent plan reductions and 42 intend to hold steady.
The companies intend to wring more production and sales from their current employees and will be cautious about hiring new workers. Only 38 percent of the companies said they planned to take on new workers, well below the 52 percent share that intend to increase capacity. The executive poll and interviews suggest that while the worst of the layoffs, which have made consumers so skittish, may be over, job growth will be slow at best.
In this economy, even optimists like Mr. Holton, the supplier of plastic auto parts near Detroit, which employs 1,220 people, are reluctant to take on new workers and run the risk of laying them off if the recovery fizzles. "Our game plan is to watch this thing carefully," he explained. "If growth continues, we'll try to meet the demand through productivity enhancements and overtime for our current workers."
"We're not going to take people on and let them off," Mr. Holton added. "The last thing you want to do is jerk your work force around."
But for all the caveats, the tentatively upbeat tone of the executive poll and the interviews do mirror the rising optimism that has been reflected in a string of encouraging economic statistics recently, from the strong retail figures released yesterday to increases in production, new orders and new export activity during February.
And last week, the United States Chamber of Commerce said business optimism nearly tripled from December to February. It reported that 47 percent of the more than 7,900 executives it had questioned said the economy would improve in the next six months, compared with 18 percent in the previous survey.
"Things have turned," said David Hale, chief economist of the Kemper Financial Companies in Chicago. "The question is whether it is sustainable."
 
Uptrend Seems On Firmer Ground
 The recovery is modest and the outlook is not certain. Yet unlike the economic improvement that began last spring after the Persian Gulf war and stalled by late summer, the current uptrend appears to be more firmly grounded in economics than the postwar euphoria of last year, executives say. The decisive moves by the Federal Reserve Board to sharply lower interest rates last year are having an effect on consumers by lowering interest payments on personal loans and mortgages, freeing up more spending money.
The Banc One Corporation, like many of the nation's banks, has witnessed a rush of homeowners seeking to refinance their mortgages to take advantage of the lower rates. During January and February, the 800 Banc One offices in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Texas and Wisconsin received more than 8,800 mortgage applications, about 65 percent of which were refinancing requests. Typically, the refinancing share would be below 25 percent.
"The interest rate drops we've had really do make a difference," said John B. McCoy, chairman of Banc One, a Columbus, Ohio, bank holding company. "The refinancings spill over to greater discretionary income for consumers. We're also seeing a decline in credit card and installment loan delinquencies. So the consumer is in better shape."
The impact can be seen in the housing market. New-home sales rose 12.9 percent in January, and the supply of unsold houses sank to the lowest level in five years. In some parts of the country, the next step in the recovery of the housing industry -- building new homes -- is beginning, with new-home starts up 5.5 percent in January.
Michael Hobbs of New Canaan, Conn., builds everything from $100,000 alterations to $2 million homes. Things were slow in the luxury residential market until February. But his company, Hobbs Inc., is now working on a half-dozen projects, twice as many as late last year. And architects' plans -- the source of new work -- are coming in at a brisk pace. "There's a lot of building going on now in Fairfield County," Mr. Hobbs said.
At Shope, Reno & Wharton, a Greenwich, Conn., architecture firm that designs luxury houses, typically costing $500,000 or more, inquiries from people who want to build new homes are streaming in. The 20-architect firm now receives an inquiry a day, compared with one a month last year. "We are very busy," said Allan Shope, a partner. "It started this year and it is directly related to lower interest rates."
In addition to lower rates, Mr. Shope said that his well-heeled clients had been encouraged to go ahead and build a new home because most believe that "the recession has bottomed out." A recent pickup in housing starts, led by luxury homes, may be a hopeful sign, but it does not mean the local housing industry has recovered from its deep decline, Mr. Shope and others stress.
 
Building Industry Remains Depressed
 In Connecticut, for example, the number of residential building permits issued in January doubled from a year earlier. Still, the permits taken out in January 1992, despite the rebound, were only about half the level of the 1987-90 period in the state. And the modest rebound in housing starts has not spilled over to commercial construction like office buildings.
So the construction industry as a whole, which employs carpenters, electricians and laborers, remains depressed. "I hope something is starting, but we've not seen any evidence of it yet," said John Cunningham, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters 210, whose 1,700 members in Fairfield and Litchfield counties derive four-fifths of their work from commercial construction.
In Southern California, the moribund commercial construction industry is likely to remain a drag on that region's economy for some time. With the 1980's office boom a memory, Joseph W. Bailey, a Santa Barbara, Calif., general contractor, has seen his business slide from one with 125 people and annual revenues of nearly $20 million during the late 1980's, to a staff of 75 people and estimated revenues of less than $12 million. "I see building activity continuing to fall," Mr. Bailey said. "In two or three months, we'll be down to 50 people unless things pick up."
Things are little better these days at Santa Cruz Motors, which sells BMW, Mazda and Oldsmobile cars. John Kiefer, the owner, sees a bit of good news for Detroit since Oldsmobile sales are rising. But in Santa Cruz County, where roughly three- fourths of the new cars sold are imports, the uptick in Olds sales has not been enough to offset the general decline. At Mr. Kiefer's dealership, new-car sales are off 25 percent this year. "Quite honestly, it just tanked since November," he said.
The big California economy, hit hard by the sharp fall-off in construction and defense industry cutbacks, is experiencing no recovery. The state's economy will shrink by eight-tenths of a percent this year, after falling 2.4 percent in 1991, David Hensley, director of the business forecasting unit of the University of California at Los Angeles, estimates.
By contrast, the nation's economy is expected to be nearly flat in the first quarter but pick up to grow by more than 3 percent during the second half of 1992, according to the Blue Chip consensus of more than 50 economic forecasters.
 
More Confidence In Competing
 The optimism expressed by many executives seems to be based partly on their own confidence that they are now better able to compete at home and abroad, even in difficult times. The efforts in recent years to become more streamlined and improve customer service, they say, have been difficult but have paid off. The New York Times/CBS News Poll found that 73 percent of the executives rate their industries "very good" or "fairly good" in terms of their ability to compete with other industrialized countries, including Japan.
The streamlining process is quite visible among big corporations like General Motors, I.B.M. and others. Yet from the interviews with business people, it is clear that much of the rest of American industry has embarked on the same path.
Take the example of Mark Roberts Inc., a Bartlesville, Okla., car dealership that sells Hondas and Chrysler mini-vans. Bartlesville is a company town, the home of the Phillips Petroleum Company, and the big company has trimmed its headquarters payroll recently by roughly 20 percent to save costs.
Anticipating a downturn in the local economy, Mark Roberts sold a smaller dealership in nearby Enid to set aside a cash cushion to ride out the downturn. Mr. Roberts also trimmed his work force slightly, from 44 last summer to 38 today.
But he also made investments, so that his dealership could increase its share of the local market. He spent $140,000 on 10 cars that are lent to customers who need them when their cars are brought in for servicing. Today, all cars brought to the Roberts garage for repairs are washed and vacuumed without charge, and a complimentary carnation is placed on the passenger seat. The result has been that car sales at Mark Roberts Inc. are running ahead of last year, despite the cutbacks by the town's big oil company.
"The only difference between me and Phillips is that the big companies make the paper and we don't," Mr. Roberts said. "All businesses have to become leaner and more efficient."

How the Poll Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News Poll of American business executives is based on interviews with 490 senior executives at companies throughout the United States, interviewed by telephone from Feb. 18 to March 6.
The sample of companies and executives called was provided by Dun & Bradstreet Information Services. The sample was randomly dawn from those listed in their nationwide data base of both privately held and publicly owned companies.
Companies with $5 million or more in annual revenues were eligible for the survey. Within each company one executive at a senior level was interviewed. Titles eligible for the poll included chief executive, president, chairman, executive vice president, senior vice president, owner and partner, starting from the top down.
Because smaller companies are most numerous, in order to provide more reliable comparisons between companies of various sizes, those with larger annual revenue were sampled at a higher rate. The completed sample included 274 interviews in companies with $5 million to $99 million in annual revenue, 121 interviews in companies with $100 million to $499 million and 95 interviews in companies with $500 million or more. The completed sample was then weighted by revenue size to reflect the actual distribution of all listed companies in the country.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than six percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out senior executives at all listed companies in the country with annual revenues of $5 million or more.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for the biggest companies, those with $500 million or more in annual revenue, it is plus or minus 10 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey can introduce other sources of error into the poll. (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Bond Yields Top 8%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Evidence that consumers emerged from a fourth-quarter funk and spent money at a healthy clip in January and February pushed yields on long-term Treasury bonds above 8 percent yesterday for the first time since early November.
The big gains most likely mean that recovery is under way, analysts said, although not at the rapid pace the sharp rise in retail sales suggests. 
 Indeed, even as the Government was reporting the gains in retail sales, it also said that initial unemployment claims rose by 22,000 during the last week in February, to 459,000, the highest level in a month.
Still, the sales gains, along with other recent signs of recovery, were strong enough to make further easing in monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board unnecessary for some months at least, the analysts said.
 
Gain in Retail Sales
 For a variety of reasons, economists had been expecting that retail sales figures released yesterday would show a good gain in February, but the 1.3 percent rise reported by the Commerce Department was at the high end of expectations.
The big surprise was a sharp upward revision in the January numbers. Retail sales rose by 2.1 percent, the Government said, not the six-tenths of a percent increase that had been previously reported. It was the first back-to-back rise of 1 percent or more in retail sales since 1985.
"The numbers show that consumption in the first quarter will be much higher than anticipated, and that will give people confidence that growth in the second quarter will be stronger than many thought, including myself," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
Nevertheless, analysts said consumers were unlikely to keep spending at such a rapid rate because important fundamentals that generally herald a sustained rise in consumption remained weak.
"The economy is improving, and we are in a recovery," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But these numbers were an overstatement of the improvment. This type of spending growth is way above growth in personal income, and it is unlikely that consumers will be willing to take on more debt to sustain it."
Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said, "A couple of months of good retail sales data are very nice, but we should be getting some good numbers after being in the tank for the last two years."
Over the next few months, Mr. Steinberg said, "it will be the bond market that will keep the recovery from getting too out of hand."
 
Long-Term Securities Sales
 Bond traders, who fear recovery will bring rising inflation with it, reacted quickly to the sales figures by selling long-term securities.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 99 5/8, down 7/8 point, to yield 8.03 percent, compared with 7.95 percent late Wednesday.
Bond yields have briefly reached the 8 percent level on several occasions this winter, but yesterday marked the first time since Nov. 5 that yields rose above that level and stayed there.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 9910/32 late yesterday, down 22/32 , to yield 7.59 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99, down 15/32 , to yield 6.99 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9913/32 , down 1/4 point, to yield 5.69 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.01 percent in late trading, up two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.17 percent.
A number of corporations offered new debt issues despite the sharp rise in interest rates.
Among the issuers was Bear, Stearns & Company, which priced a $150 million offering of noncallable 12-year senior notes.
The 8 3/4 percent securities were priced at $99.792, to yield 8.778 percent, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Bear, Stearns acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Bear, Stearns and the BT Securities Corporation acted as co-lead managers on a $200 million underwriting for the Stone Container Corporation.
The 10 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes were priced at $99.50, to yield 10.831 percent.
The high-yield securities are rated B-2 by Moody's and B+ by Standard & Poor's.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, a bid from a group led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company won a competitive offering of $229.71 million worth of Louisiana general obligation bond.
The securities, which are insured by MBIA Inc. and the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, were reoffered to investors with yields from 3.50 percent in 1993 to 6.70 percent in 2012.
Because the bonds are insurerd, the issue is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended March 2.
The money numbers were a bit stronger than anticipated, but elicited no reaction from credit market participants.
Nevertheless, "strength in the money numbers will continue to reinforce the belief that the recovery is here and could be stronger than originally forecast," analysts at MMS International, an economic forecasting and service company, noted in their daily market commentary.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Top Officer at Aetna To Join Liberty Mutual

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
After 18 years with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, Edmund F. Kelly is leaving to take on more reponsibility at a smaller insurer, the Liberty Mutual Insurance Group.
Liberty Mutual, based in Boston, named Mr. Kelly president and chief operating officer yesterday, filling roles most recently held by the company's chairman and chief executive, Gary L. Countryman. 
 Liberty Mutual, the country's largest writer of workers' compensation insurance, said Mr. Kelly had been hired for his broad background and track record of successes. At Aetna, Mr. Kelly was most recently a group executive, overseeing many financial products and building the managed health care business.
Mr. Kelly's task at Liberty Mutual, where he starts on April 1, will include developing those products, but he acknowledges that he will be joining the company with little personal experience in workers' compensation.
"I arrive with zero baggage in some areas," Mr. Kelly, 46 years old, said yesterday in a telephone interview.
By some measures, the scope of Mr. Kelly's responsibilities will remain roughly the same at Liberty as at Aetna: He will manage more than $40 billion in assets and about 20,000 employees.
Mr. Kelly said his strategy for his new post had not yet been formed. The workers' compensation field holds special challenges because the laws are different in each state. The system, a way to reimburse employees for economic hardships resulting from injuries and illnesses caused on the job, is an industry marked by soaring expenses. In the last decade, the costs of the insurance programs in all 50 states have risen roughly 150 percent, an increase attributed largely to rising medical expenses, litigation fees and the cost of expanding benefits.
Mr. Kelly joined Aetna in 1974 and held senior-level positions in its employee benefits division. As part of a corporate reorganization in 1991, Mr. Kelly was named one of four group executives sharing the majority of operating responsibilities.
Mr. Kelly graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology with a Ph.D. in mathematics in 1970. He will be relocating to the Boston area from his home in Simsbury, Conn., where he lives with his wife, Debbie. They have one adult daughter.

HEADLINE: New Unemployment Claims Rose 22,000 in Late February

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose to the highest level in more than a month in the last week of February, the Government said today.
Analysts said the increase was not worrisome enough to shake their belief that an economic revival had begun. 
 The Labor Department reported that the number of people filing new claims for jobless benefits increased by 22,000, to 459,000, for the week that ended on Feb. 29. The increase reversed a drop of 21,000 the week before.
 
Higher Figure Expected
 Economists had been expecting the numbers to bounce higher, because the previous week included the Washington's Birthday holiday, which gave laid-off workers one less day to file claims.
Given the strong showing for retail sales in January and February and other favorable reports, many economists said they were revising upward their estimates of growth for the January-March quarter this year.
But it will still be some time before the upturn in demand will translate into lower unemployment figures, analysts cautioned.
"The recovery first shows up on the spending side, then output and then employment," said Robert Dederick, an economist for the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. "It hasn't had time to show up in employment yet."
 
 
Unemployment May Rise
 The jobless rate hit a six-year high of 7.3 percent in February, and some economists believe the rate could climb as high as 7.5 percent in coming months before it starts to improve gradually in the second half of the year.
Samuel D. Kahan, an economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago, said the rise in jobless claims showed that the economy was still "not firing on all of its pistons." He said the coming economic activity was likely to be "nothing to get excited about."
Because the weekly number can be so volatile, many economists track the four-week average for claims. That figure rose to 451,500 for the last week in February, up from 445,250 in the previous week. The moving average and the one-week total were both the highest since Jan. 18, when the one-week claims figure hit 460,000.

HEADLINE: Ford to Expand Offer Of One Price for Escorts

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it was expanding nationwide a marketing program for its Escort LX that has won over many reluctant shoppers: one price, no haggling.
The pricing strategy has increased sales during a five-month test among dealers in the Northeast, Southeast and West. Dealers say consumers appreciate the simplicity of the one-price program, in which the 1992 LX models -- including four-door sedans, two hatchback models and station wagons -- are sold for $9,999. The models are equipped with many options, including air-conditioning, but an automatic transmission costs $732 extra. 
 By comparison, the sticker prices of those models would be as much as $1,700 higher, although most buyers negotiate for a lower price.
 
 
Restyled 1993 Models
 The national program will begin in May on the restyled 1993-model Escorts, and a Ford spokesman said the fixed price would probably be a few hundred dollars higher. Though dealers are strongly urged to participate, Ford cannot require them to do so.
Ford's decision highlights the auto industry's effort to simplify the car-buying process, in part by eliminating customers' bargaining with dealers. Industry experts say Ford is also responding to a key strategy of General Motors' fledgling Saturn division, whose no-dealing sticker prices have scored points with consumers. The Ford Escort, a subcompact, competes directly with Saturn models.
"Haggling is a sore point with consumers," said Peter J. Haag, senior vice president of MOR-Pace, a consumer research firm in suburban Detroit.
Indeed, auto leases are proliferating partly because they eliminate bargaining, industry experts say. And car buyers are increasingly flocking to services that find and buy cars for them. Auto Advisor, in Seattle, guarantees that it will find the lowest-priced car in a designated area for a fee that averages $390. The business grew by 50 percent last year, compared with 1990, said Ashly Knapp, its founder. "The No. 1 reason is people dislike confrontation with dealers," he said.
The roughly 2,400 Ford dealers testing the one-price program reported Escort sales in January and February that were 20 percent higher than those who did not offer the program, a company spokesman said. In the previous five months, the percentage of Escort buyers who previously owned imports jumped 50 percent. Over all, sales of Escorts are down 12 percent this year from a year earlier.
"It's done extremely well for us," said Gordon Stringfield, general sales manager of Larry Geweke Ford in Marysville, Calif. He said Escorts now make up 25 percent of his Ford car and truck sales, up from 17 percent before the program began. While the dealer profit is smaller on the designated models, the greater volume means higher revenues, he said.
Ford sold about 250,000 Escorts in 1991. The auto maker expects to sell as many as 350,000 this year, depending on the economy. Most Escorts are built at a Ford assembly plant in Wayne, Mich., although some, including the sporty GT model, which will not be included in the one-price program, are produced in Mexico.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dayton's Net Fell by 18.3% In Quarter

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, which operates several department store chains and the Target discount chain, reported sharply lower earnings yesterday for the fourth quarter that ended Feb. 1.
The company said the results reflected weak Christmas sales, continued stiff competition that has put pressure on its profit margins and a recessionary economy in California, where it does about 35 percent of its business. 
 Fourth-quarter earnings fell 18.3 percent, to $192 million, or $2.47 a share, compared with $235 million, or $3.50 a share, in the corresponding period last year.
 
Shares Retreat on Bad News
 Reacting to the bad news, Dayton Hudson shares fell yesterday by $5.625, to $61.25, in fairly heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Kenneth A. Macke, Dayton Hudson's chairman, said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in Minneapolis that he was surprised by the stock market reaction. "We thought our earnings were very much in line with what the analysts had projected," he said.
Mr. Macke said that while the problems that dampened the company's most recent earnings were continuing, Dayton Hudson was planning conservatively and slashing its operating expenses. Earlier this week, Dayton Hudson announced that it would layoff 630 employees in its embattled department store division, which includes the Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's chains.
Mr. Macke said sales in February exceeded the company's expectations. Dayton Hudson had projected that sales in stores open at least one year would increase 2 percent to 4 percent last month, but they climbed 6 percent.
The company also said it had put a more favorable inventory accounting method into place.
The company's full-year 1991 results were in line with most investment analysts' estimates. Several said they expected the company's income to remain flat, or perhaps even decline slightly, in the first half of this year and then pick up around mid-summer.
"We're still looking for them to sort of back into a relatively strong performance in 1992," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Mr. Macke said that Target would continue to fuel the company's growth and strength.
 
Grab for Discount Market
 In mid-1991, Dayton Hudson belatedly decided to make a grab for more of the discount market by reducing prices at Target and emphasizing its selection of consumer commodities, long after Wal-Mart and K Mart had embarked on similar competitive strategies.
Although the strategy has taken a big bite out of gross margins, analysts say it is sound and likely to pay off in the second half of this year, when comparisons will be equal. The company has been forced to compete by slashing prices in all its divisions, which ate into its profits in 1991, analysts said.
"We think the promotional atmosphere everywhere has leveled off," Mr. Macke said. "But the country is still overstored, and we will continue to be very aggressive on pricing."
Target's operating profit dropped 1.7 percent, to $458 million, from $466 million in 1990. But sales increased 11 percent last year, with sales in stores open more than a year up 4 percent.
Operating profits at Mervyn's, a chain of moderately priced department stores, plummeted 22.4 percent last year, primarily because more than half of its sales are made in its recession-ridden California stores. Sales in stores open more than one year declined 1 percent.
"If you look at Mervyn's sales outside California, they're much stronger," said Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Securities Inc.
Mr. Hood noted that although the divergence between sales in California and sales in the rest of the country continued to widen at the Mervyn's division, the gap was closing among Target stores.
For the year, Dayton Hudson's earnings plummeted 26.9 percent, to $301 million, from $412 million in 1990. Sales increased 9 percent to a record $16.11 billion, from $14.74 billion a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Weak Economy Pins Bush Down

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH is struggling to get out of a crossfire coming, on one side, from former President Richard M. Nixon, who has criticized Mr. Bush for not doing enough to sustain democratic reforms in the former Soviet Union, and, on the other side, from his Republican challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, for not putting America's interests first. Mr. Bush is pinned down in his efforts to move by the nation's weak economy and the huge budget deficit, which this year will exceed $400 billion.
Mr. Nixon warned Mr. Bush that if he does not act more boldly to keep economic and political freedom alive in the former Soviet Union, he will face the accusation, "Who lost Russia?" Mr. Bush said he would like to do more but he just doesn't have the resources. "There isn't a lot of money around," he said. "We are spending too much as it already is. So to do the things I would really like to do, I don't have a blank check for all that." 
 On both the tax and expenditure sides, the President has compounded the problem of what he called "constrained resources." In response to Mr. Buchanan's assault on Mr. Bush for not keeping his 1988 campaign pledge: "Read my lips. No new taxes," Mr. Bush apologized, said it was his greatest political mistake and that he would never raise taxes again.
On the expenditure side, Mr. Bush has aggravated his resources problem by yielding to Pentagon pressures for only minimal cuts in military outlays, despite the collapse of the Soviet threat and the end of the cold war. The determination of the Pentagon's leaders to hold on to large forces and big budgets was revealed by the classified 46-page policy statement, prepared under the supervision of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Pentagon's Under Secretary for Policy. The statement clearly needed the authorization of Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. The document asserted that the United States' political and military mission in the post-cold-war era would be to insure that no rival superpower would be permitted to emerge in Western Europe, Asia or the former Soviet Union.
Senior White House and State Department officials harshly attacked the document, titled Defense Planning Guidance for Fiscal Years 1994-99, calling it "a dumb report." Leading opponents of the Wolfowitz draft are considered to be the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger.
Mr. Bush, however, made clear more than two months ago in his State of the Union address that he would resist pressures for deeper cuts in military spending than he would propose in his new budget. His plan calls for Defense Department budget authority to remain within a few billion dollars of $270 billion from 1992 to 1996. Corrected for assumed inflation, this would represent a reduction of about 15 percent in military spending from 1992 to 1997. Or, as Mr. Bush said: "By 1997, we will have cut defense by 30 percent since I took office. These cuts are deep, and you must know my resolve: this deep, and no deeper."
A group of Democrats, led by Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, contend that much deeper cuts are both possible and desirable, in the interests of peace and economic strength -- and in light of the vanishing Soviet threat and rising economic superpowers in Japan and Europe.
"Now that the old Soviet threat is gone, the first question is whether the idea of threats is still useful," Mr. Aspin said. He noted that Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, does not think so, and has stated repeatedly that "we no longer have the luxury of having a threat to plan for" and that the level of United States forces is no longer based on apparent threats.
The Pentagon's document for guiding the preparation and planning of military budgets and forces offers as its defining concept the importance of keeping the United States the world's sole superpower. "We must maintain," it says, "the mechanisms for deterring potential competitors from even aspiring to a larger regional or global role."
With the blast from the National Security Council and State Department, Mr. Bush is now caught in a second crossfire over whether the United States should pursue a "lone superpower" policy -- which Pentagon hard-liners and those leaning toward an America First line would favor -- or a more collaborative role, in which other countries and the United Nations would assume a greater responsibility for security, including its economic burdens.
The lone-superpower line would continue the past practice of preparing to wage war against defined threats. The second approach would aim to build collective responsibilities for preventing wars, whether the threat is from the territory of the former Soviet Union or any other source. The two approaches have different implications for future military spending, United States budget deficits and national economic growth -- as well as for the means and freedom to deal with other national objectives, at home or abroad. The first is high-cost, high-risk, the second is lower-cost, with burdens and risks more widely diffused. Mr. Bush must make up his mind.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Contracts Fall to $348, Lowest Price in 4 1/2 Years

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of gold futures sagged well below $350 an ounce yesterday, amid fading expectations for either stronger inflation or higher gold prices.
Gold for April delivery fell $3.40 on New York's Commodity Exchange, to $348 a troy ounce, a new four-and-a-half-year low. 
 Silver and platinum futures also fell sharply, despite economic data that suggested the United States economy was improving -- ordinarily a constructive sign for those markets.
Oil prices posted moderate gains in a late flurry of mostly technical buying on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
March silver dropped 6.1 cents on the Commodity Exchange, to $4.086 an ounce. April platinum fell $3.30 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $360.10 a troy ounce.
 
Retail Sales Data Cited
 Analysts said the decline began overnight on the European market with heavy selling of gold and gold futures by Middle Eastern investors and gold producers. Reasons given for the selling were varied.
Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc., said American gold traders responded to the dollar's gains after the Government reported a 1.3 percent jump in retail sales last month. It was the first time sales had risen more than 1 percent for two consecutive months since 1985.
An improving economy makes it less likely the Federal Reserve Board will cut interest rates further, which in turn lowers the chances of a burst of inflation that might send investors running for the perceived safety of gold.
 
April Oil: $18.83
 But Peter Cardillo, research director at Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York, said the metal markets ignored the retail sales. Prices fell, he said, because precious-metal producers typically make sales commitments at this time of year and were selling futures to lock in prices.
"If they feel the market is not going higher, and there's a possibility it is going lower," he said, "this would be an opportunity to hedge."
An otherwise uneventful session in the energy pits was enlivened by a late rally by buyers trying to compensate for sales made earlier in the day.
Light sweet crude oil for April delivery rose 33 cents, to $18.83 a barrel; May sour crude climbed 32 cents, to $16.07 a barrel; April heating oil surged 0.88 cent, to 52.18 cents a gallon; April unleaded gasoline rose 0.66 cent, to 58.63 cents a gallon; April natural gas rose 1.3 cents, to $1.197 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Consumer Spending Report Bolsters Dollar in Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rallied against other currencies yesterday after the Government released better-than-expected consumer spending figures for February.
Analysts said the dollar rose sharply in early trading and was carried higher by the Commerce Department's report that retail sales rose 1.3 percent last month. But while the consumer spending figures were stronger than anticipated, the dollar gave up some ground later in the day as traders with large dollar holdings decided to sell rather than risk a decline, said Mike Faust, a foreign exchange analyst with MMS International. 
 Currency traders were somewhat nervous after central banks, including the Bank of Japan and the Swiss National Bank, intervened in the market earlier this week to stop the dollar's advance against their currencies.
The retail sales figure was the latest in a series of statistics pointing to a recovery. The data heartened investors, who saw better prospects for a rise in interest rates.
The dollar draws support from higher interest rates, which make American investments more attractive to buyers from overseas.
The Government also said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose to 459,000 in the last week of February, pushing the claims figure to its highest level in a month. The numbers, however, had little effect on the dollar, analysts said.
The dollar rose as high as 134.65 Japanese yen and 167.75 German marks.
The American currency ended the day in New York at 134.25 yen, up from 133.40 late on Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 134.00 yen from 133.70 yen; in London, it rose to 134.25 yen.
The dollar also rose to 1.6700 marks in New York, from 1.6635 Wednesday. In European trading, the dollar advanced to 1.6715 marks from 1.6650.
The British pound fell against the dollar, dropping to $1.7140 in New York, from $1.7260 on Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.7085 from $1.7250.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.5100 Swiss francs, up from 1.5075; 5.6710 French francs, up from 5.6485; 1,252.00 Italian lire, up from 1,246.50, and 1.19675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19585.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Manpower's New Inquiry

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, March 12

 BODY:
The Department of Trade and Industry in Britain has begun a new investigation into the 1987 takeover of the Manpower employment agency by Blue Arrow P.L.C., a department spokesman said today.
Last month, four employees of the securities giant County NatWest and a stockbroker from UBS Phillips & Drew Ltd. were convicted of conspiracy to defraud in connection with the bid that created the world's largest employment agency. 
 The case focused on a possible conspiracy to cover up a failed rights issue of 837 million, or about $1.7 billion at the time, by Blue Arrow to finance the takeover.
Blue Arrow itself, now renamed Manpower Inc. and based in the United States, was not charged. County NatWest, NatWest Investment Bank and UBS Phillips and Drew were acquitted in January.
On Monday, Lord Alexander, the chairman of County NatWest's parent, the National Westminister Bank, asked for a new inquiry into the matter. He cited accusations made by The Economist magazine last week that the bank and its chief executive, Thomas P. Frost, had misled Government inspectors and concealed documents during the last Blue Arrow inquiry.
But a department spokesman said the inquiry was not being made at NatWest's request.
"This is a new investigation under Section 432 of the Companies Act," he said, stressing that such investigations were made because of information the department had, not at the request of the company involved.
