HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

A Gift by Saatchi
In the 1980's, when the English collector Charles Saatchi bought or sold, the art world talked. His choice of purchases, which were often considered eccentric by other collectors, and his habit of buying many works by one artist and then rapidly selling them off, has been a subject of great interest among gallery owners and artists, auction-house experts and collectors. 
 This week, the talk is about the announcement that Mr. Saatchi has given nine works by contemporary British artists to the Tate Gallery in London. It is the first time the advertising magnate has donated artworks to any institution other than his own small London museum. The news came only days after Saatchi & Saatchi, the London-based advertising agency he founded with his brother, Maurice, disclosed losses of $103 million for 1991. The company also announced a $22 million profit over the last three years from the sale of the bulk of the advertising agency's art collection. In 1991 alone, sales from Saatchi & Saatchi's art totaled about $4.25 million.
Hugh Impey, a company spokesman, declined to comment on exactly which works had been sold or where. But he did say that while selling art has not been the main activity of the company, it has been its main profit center over the last two years. "We've been hit by over-expansion and enormous debt as well as the decline of advertising in Britain and the United States," Mr. Impey said. "So the sale of art has served us well."
For Mr. Saatchi, a man who has been known to spend millions on a single work of art, the gift is really quite small; the museum estimates its total value at only $170,000. What is interesting, however, is that he chose to give art by relatively young British artists, an area Mr. Saatchi has been avidly collecting and exhibiting at his small, private London museum. The presence of these works in the Tate's collection can only help increase their value, along with that of works he still owns by the same artists.
But in recent months, Mr. Saatchi has gained notice more for his aggressive sales of works from his collection than for what he has purchased. At Sotheby's auctions of contemporary art in New York in November, 35 of the 79 works offered belonged to him. At the time, art-world experts thought Mr. Saatchi was trying to raise money to pay debts he owed to the auction house. Mr. Saatchi is expected to sell many more works this spring. Sotheby's said the final count had not yet been decided, and as usual he would not allow his name to be associated in the auction catalogue with the works he would be selling. Sotheby's declines to comment on Mr. Saatchi's financial dealings with the house.
Mr. Saatchi is, however, allowing his name to be displayed beside the artworks he is donating to the Tate. These include works by artists Mr. Saatchi has been buying in quantity, ranging from well-known figures like the sculptor Richard Deacon to lesser-known names like the painter Jeffrey Dennis.
Unlike donors in America who, for the moment anyway, can claim substantial tax deductions for giving works of art to museums, Mr. Saatchi does not have the benefit of a write-off under the English tax code.
Part of the public's fascination has always been Mr. Saatchi's Greta Garbo-like posture; he almost never gives interviews, and this week his office said he was too busy to return telephone calls. Another reason collectors and dealers are intrigued with Mr. Saatchi is his well-known practice of selling artworks within months of buying them. Nicholas Serota, the Tate's director, said, "At this point, Charles's collection falls into two parts: fine classic postwar artists and young British artists."
Mr. Serota said he was particularly pleased with the museum's gift because it represented the end of a 10-year rift between the collector and the Tate.
"In 1981, we had a show of 12 new works by Julian Schnabel," said Sir Alan Bowness, a former director of the Tate. "Over half the works came from Saatchi's private collection, and the press accused him of promoting the artist's work and imposing his own taste on a museum. At the time, Charles felt his effort to help a public institution was met with unfair criticism."
Sir Alan said this episode had prompted Mr. Saatchi to start a museum of his own. "But that was all 10 years ago," he added. "By now he has established his credentials."
The Saatchi Collection, as his small museum on Boundary Road in Northwest London is called, has no permanent holdings; it is really a rotating public showcase for whatever from his collection he feels like showing at any one time. "Therefore it isn't strange that he should be donating works to the Tate," Mr. Serota said. He said the decision to donate these works had resulted from discussions he had had with Mr. Saatchi about the Tate's holdings. The new additions help round out the museum's collection.
"Now we have a serious and strong representation of these artists," Mr. Serota said. "We only had a small, early Julian Opie, for example; now we have in important one. We had a very early Richard Deacon and a recent work from 1991. There was a substantial gap which has now been filled."
 
Museum Plan in Limbo
 While all museums have been affected by the economy, the Newport Harbor Art Museum in Newport Beach, Calif., is one institution that has been directly affected by the suffering real-estate market. And by its own ambitions.
Five years ago, Orange County, a generally affluent area south of Los Angeles, decided to expand its small museum of contemporary art and started a $40 million fund-raising campaign. Donald Bren, who heads the Irvine Company, a major real-estate developer based in the city of Newport Beach, donated 10.5 acres for the site of the new building. Renzo Piano, the celebrated Italian architect who designed the Menil Collection's building in Houston and was co-architect with Richard Rogers of the Pompidou Center in Paris, was chosen to design the new building.
Two years ago, Mr. Piano was dismissed because, on being told his design was too expensive to build and asked by the board of trustees to provide a less expensive plan, he declined. Several months later, the trustees asked the New York City architects Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates to come up with another design.
But Kohn Pedersen Fox's scheme may not be built either. In December, before the new architects had a chance to finish the plan, the trustees voted to postpone the fund-raising campaign because of the poor economy and a slowdown in the real estate market, and to delay the new building indefinitely. By 1988, the campaign had brought in pledges of $10 million; the museum declines to release more recent figures. Michael Botwinick, the museum's director, said the institution had so far spent about $1 million on designs.
"Most of the money and support in the 80's in Orange County came from real estate," Mr. Botwinick said. "It only makes sense that we would catch the same cold. After all, cultural institutions in Pittsburgh suffered when the steel industry broke down. There's no question all of us are vulnerable."
Now the museum is in a holding pattern, hoping to resume its plans when the economy picks up. So far neither the exhibition schedule nor museum hours have been cut back. Kohn Pedersen Fox is finishing the conceptual phase, basic drawings and models as a sales tool for the museum in anticipation of a turnaround in the economy. "The big issue is how much money they can finally raise and how much the scheme will have to be modified," said Eugene Kohn, a partner in the architectural firm.
Mr. Botwinick reported that Mr. Bren has specifically said there was no time limit on his commitment to donate the land for the new building. But the museum director said he wasworried about the pledges the institution was counting on. "Confidence is shaken," he said. "Even when the economy picks up, the rules will have changed. Someone who seven years ago said, 'Put me down for $1 million,' may well have second thoughts."
 
Town House Is Sold
 The Manhattan town house at 36 East 75th Street belonging to Habsburg Feldman, the Geneva-based auction house that opened a New York City branch in 1987 in the hope of competing with Sotheby's, Christie's and William Doyle, was sold yesterday to a private family. The auction house closed its doors in New York five months ago. Now it has also stopped trading operations in Geneva.
"But Habsburg Holdings still exists," said Geza von Habsburg, one of the founders, who is a great-grandson of Emperor Franz Josef of Austria. "And part of Habsburg Holdings is Antiquorium, who are still holding sales of clocks and watches." Antiquorium is headed by Osvaldo Patrizzi, another founder.
Mr. Habsburg, who ran the Christie's office in Geneva for nearly 20 years, said he was a guest curator for "Faberge and His Patrons," an exhibition scheduled to open in June 1993 at the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg and then go to the Musee des Arts Decoratifs.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

A 'Waltz' That Lacks Uplift?
"The Baltimore Waltz," Paula Vogel's play about a brother and sister's fantasy trip to Europe while the brother is really dying of AIDS in a Baltimore hospital, finishes a seven-week run at the Circle Repertory Company this weekend. It had been scheduled to open later this month at the Capital Repertory Company in Albany, but the theater's artistic director, Bruce Bouchard, abruptly canceled the production, calling the play "a very tough and challenging work that asks an audience to work for 90 minutes." So? What's the problem? "My audience believes that I'm obsessed with death," Mr. Bouchard says.
Might it be that the audience has a problem with a play about AIDS? "Oh, it's not the subject matter," Mr. Bouchard says. "The play is a terribly moving catharsis. I wept until I thought I'd have a seizure." 
 Well, it turns out that "The Baltimore Waltz" is being replaced by "The Sum of Us," the Australian comedy about a gay man who is encouraged by his father to have a gay relationship. It had a successful run Off Broadway last season. Mr. Bouchard predicts that "The Sum of Us" will make two and a half times the income of "The Baltimore Waltz," which he says is essential to his Save the Theater campaign, since the Capital Rep is having financial difficulties. "It is in fact a hardball economic decision," he says. "I can make more money with an uplifting play than a cathartic play. Also, I could not get a corporate sponsor for 'The Baltimore Waltz.' People said the subject matter is tough. I got a corporate sponsor for 'The Sum of Us' in a second. But this was not a cavalier decision for me. I am not in business to disappoint playwrights."
Ms. Vogel's agent, Peter Franklin, says, "Bruce Bouchard never bothered to tell me he was canceling the play and he never expressed his reasons."
Ms. Vogel says: "Bruce doesn't even want to give the subject a chance. He didn't want to offend anybody. I don't consider Albany to be a backward place. It is the state capital. But when it comes to this subject, it's cold out there."
Mr. Franklin says a number of theaters have asked him about producing "The Baltimore Waltz," which, for starters, is to open in early April at the Alley Theater in Houston and Center Stage in Baltimore.
 
For Want of $120,000, a Furor
 Talk of resignation abounds at Circle Repertory Company after the postponement of the Broadway production of Lanford Wilson's "Redwood Curtain." Mr. Wilson, who was among the co-founders of the theater in 1969 with the director Marshall Mason and the theater's artistic director Tanya Berezin, says the board of directors refused them the financial support necessary to produce the play on Broadway. All three are members of the board.
The short version of this very complicated history is that Ms. Berezin, along with Mr. Wilson and Mr. Mason, the director of "Redwood Curtain," decided that Circle Rep itself should produce the play directly on Broadway since, Ms. Berezin says, they thought the theater could make more money than commercial producers have by transferring its plays in the past. ("Prelude to a Kiss," "Burn This," "Tally's Folly" and "The Fifth of July" are examples.) But Max Weitzenhoffer, a commercial producer who is president of Circle Rep's board, says he told the creative trio up front that the board would make a loan of only $60,000 toward the $800,000 the production would cost to take to Broadway after runs at the Seattle Repertory Theater and the Philadelphia Drama Guild.
"The company is not just Lanford," Mr. Weitzenhoffer says. "And I cannot make the board finance a Broadway show."
Fair enough, Ms. Berezin says. But after plans fell through to finance the play with an alliance of nonprofit theaters, the trio turned to individual investors and raised all but $120,000 of the $800,000. That's when they appealed to the board for last-minute help, Ms. Berezin says, and were denied, forcing the postponement.
Both Mr. Wilson and Mr. Mason say they feel betrayed as artists by the people whose mission it is to support them. "I felt abandoned by the board," Mr. Mason says. "I am considering a resignation, but that is not a threat, I'm just looking out for our artistic well-being." Mr. Mason is scheduled to direct Larry Kramer's new play, "The Destiny of Me," at Circle Rep next season.
Mr. Wilson says: "There's a lack of support from the board, no question about it. If we did resign I get the feeling they would be real happy to redefine themselves without us, but we'll cross that bridge if we come to it."
Ms. Berezin says now that "Redwood Curtain" is playing in Philadelphia and many commercial producers are interested in bringing it to Broadway, she is optimistic about healing the rift with the board. "As the artists grow, we've got to grow with them," she says. "I think it can be done."
 
What's Happening at Steppenwolf

"Wrong Turn at Lungfish" may not win any awards for most appetizing title, but considering the play was written by Garry Marshall (who directed "Pretty Woman") and Lowell Ganz, who co-wrote "City Slickers," "Splash" and "Parenthood," the odds are on its side. The play ran at the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago in 1990. Now, the producers James B. Freydberg, Jeffrey Ash and Jean VanTuyle will present a rewritten version at the Coronet Theater in Los Angeles for a six-week run from May 19 through June 28. The four-character dramatic comedy about a young street couple's relationship with an elderly erudite hospital patient will probably star George C. Scott, Laurie Metcalfe and Tony Danza. (Really.) Mr. Marshall will direct. Mr. Freydberg says a New York run is possible for the fall.
Meanwhile, at Steppenwolf, the world premiere of "The Song of Jacob Zulu" opens April 12 featuring the South African vocal group Ladysmith Black Mambazo. Zakes Mokae, who won a Tony Award for his performance in "Master Harold . . . and the Boys," will star in this first play by Tug Yourgrau, based on the true story of the trial of a 19-year-old black South African.
 
Gershwin, Gershwin Everywhere
 If you believe that there's no such thing as too much Gershwin, go to Rainbow and Stars on March 31, when the revue " 'S Wonderful, 'S Marvelous, 'S Gershwin!" will open for a six-week run starring Jo Anne Worley, Judy Blazer, Carol Woods and Peter Reardon. The show will be produced by Gregory Dawson and Steve Paul, who presented the sellout Rogers and Hart revue there last fall.


GRAPHIC: ABC will present Neil Simon's "Broadway Bound" on March 23, starring Anne Bancroft, above, Hume Cronyn, Jerry Orbach, Jonathan Silverman, Michele Lee and Corey Parker. The play, set in 1948, is the third in Mr. Simon's autobiographical trilogy ("Brighton Beach Memoirs," "Biloxi Blues") and follows Eugene Jerome's struggles to start a career as a comedy writer.

HEADLINE: In Hard Times, Just Plain Bars Are Timeless

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
IN the New York metropolitan region, there are Bars and there are bars. In the former, beers go for $4, the bartender wears a vest and a substantial pub-style menu is displayed on a chalkboard. In the latter, beers go for as little as $1.50, the bartender wears a faded New York Giants T-shirt and asks if you want a glass with your brew, and no matter what's on the menu, it's wise to stick to hamburgers.
The earthier bars are never referred to as taverns, pubs, lounges or, heaven forbid, night spots. In fact, they are rarely referred to at all except perhaps in the context of a news story. ("The car ran onto the sidewalk in front of the Suds Cafe.") Yet these unvarnished watering holes play a crucial role in the tragicomedy of big-city life. They serve as inexpensive sources of recreation, as anodynes to frazzled urban nerves and, in some cases, as democratic forums where people from different walks of life converge. 
 And in a time of economic distress for the hospitality industry in general, these fringe establishments are thriving, some in the most unlikely places, based on visits to a dozen such haunts and interviews with proprietors of many others. One would expect to find gritty, working-class bars in, say, Queens and Staten Island and marginal areas of Manhattan. What's surprising, though, is that many thrive in the gentrified neighborhoods of TriBeCa, Greenwich Village and midtown Manhattan, as well as in well-heeled towns like Greenwich, Conn.
"I would say that right now they are the places that are surviving this economy the best," says Raymond Foley, the publisher of Bartender Magazine. "People want value when they go out. They are also looking for a home base. The local bar offers both."
One vintage bar in Chelsea that seems to have a secure future is the Peter McManus Cafe on Seventh Avenue. It's an inviting place in a rough-and-tumble sort of way, with a well-worn tile floor, lead-paned windows and a splendid carved mahogany bar. A back room has eerie green and blue banquettes and cocktail tables.
The owner, Jim McManus, is a slow-moving, cocky Irishman with a 60-megabyte memory of anecdotes. "I started with my father and my brother 56 years ago," says the thick-set, silver-haired owner with obvious pride. "This place was a drugstore before that." In the middle of a chat, Mr. McManus launches into a discourse on how to make a perfect rob roy. "Swirl the shaker with the scotch and vermouth very gently," he admonishes. "You don't want to bruise the vermouth; it's delicate. Like wine."
At 7 P.M. on this day, the bar is filled with a casually clad, risible crowd ranging from business suits to blue jeans and flannels. Mr. McManus's son, Jamo, who is 38 years old, works here. He represents the third generation in the business and heads the kitchen, where generally satisfying pub fare like sandwiches, steaks and casseroles is prepared.
Jim McManus can spin tales taller than the head on a fresh draft beer. "One day Errol Flynn walked in here and was looking pretty gone," he recalls. "He said, 'I'll have a double vodka on the rocks.' I said, 'You're not gonna get it from me,' and I showed him the door."
Then there was the time that Burt Lancaster came in with Leonard Bernstein. "It was during the Vietnam War, and Lancaster made some remark about the American flag," Mr. McManus remembers.
He, too, was shown the renowned door.
 
A Social Symphony
 Most patrons of Carnegie Hall have probably walked past P. J. Carney's bar many times without ever noticing it. Little did they know that a social symphony of great color and texture holds forth there nightly. The small oval room with a U-shaped bar and scattering of tables and booths attracts a remarkable cross section of New Yorkers: businessmen, artists, students, musicians, itinerants, even some turnaways from the nearby Planet Hollywood restaurant. Carney's may not have the hood of the Batmobile on the wall, but it certainly has a better shepherd's pie (made with beef, not lamb) as well as a good hamburger and fish and chips.
Opened by P. J. Carney in 1927, then passed along to his son, the bar was purchased 10 years ago by a tall, thin, soft-spoken Irishman named Desmond Crawford. For many years this convivial little spot has been a favorite hangout for teachers and students of the Art Students League around the corner. It's a diverting place to spend a late weekend afternoon when the jocular regulars drift in.
Robert Cenedella, a teacher and full-time artist, has been going to the bar for more than 30 years. He treasures the place for its timelessness. "Nothing ever, ever changes here," Mr. Cenedella says, sipping an English ale at the horseshoe-shaped bar. He recalls going to P. J. Carney's with his mentor, the artist George Gross. "I had my first beer in that booth over by the window," he says. "It had to be, oh, 1959. I remember that seat because it had a broken spring that would stick you when you sat down. Well, two weeks ago, I sat over there with some students and the same spring caught me in the rear end!"
When Mr. Crawford is asked if he would ever change anything in the bar, he doesn't even pause to think it over. "Not a chance," he replies. "People feel as if this is their home and don't want people changing things around in their living room."
Among others who stop by P. J. Carney's for the ambiance and Irish ales are the neighborhood resident Buster Poindexter, the pop singer, and the musicians Cy Coleman and Joe Jackson.
 
Afterwork Clubhouse
 Milady's, at the corner of Prince and Thompson Streets in SoHo, is rather nondescript from the outside. Inside, though, about 6 P.M. on Fridays, it becomes a raucous after-work clubhouse. The spacious room has rec-room paneling, sound tile, red-and-white-checked tablecloths, Connie Francis on the jukebox and a big color television mounted overhead.
Two advertising executives shoot pool in one corner. Nearby a group of men and women in the printing business take their usual table. "I come here every day," says Martin Moore, 33, a printing company executive. "I even bring customers here to eat at lunch. We play pool, have something to eat. They feel they've done something rather than just sit in a restaurant."
Frank Genovese, the 35-year-old owner, grew up a few blocks from the bar, and later worked there before buying it 10 years ago. "I thought of making this place much fancier than it is," Mr. Genovese says. "But then in my experience the chi-chi places make a lot of money for a very short time -- but then?" He says his bar is having its best year in memory.
Milady's is primarily a neighborhood bar, although periodically celebrities like Madonna ("She comes with two huge people and has a club soda at the bar") and Sylvester Stallone drop in for fresh homemade ravioli or the house favorite, a charred chicken salad with five types of greens and a mustardy vinaigrette. Main courses top off at $9.
 
Accent on Food
 In fact, many of the old neighborhood joints emphasize food. For example, the 46-year-old Star Tavern in Orange, N.J., is locally renowned for superior, light-crusted pizzas with all kinds of toppings. It's a big barn of a place with an elongated bar, two overhead televisions blaring hockey games, and a 100-inch-television screen that descends for special sports events. The owner, Gary Vayianos, 38, agrees to talk only after he finishes playing electronic bowling with a customer.
The same thing that endears local bars to big-city customers applies here. "You don't change the place if it works," says Mr. Vayianos, a former practicing lawyer. "We have everyone from welfare mothers to millionaires from Montclair in here. It's a real mix. And they like the way it is." When he recently tried to remove a small section of the bar to create a passageway, he said, "customers got all upset about it, asking me who gave permission for that."
 
Ambiance: Macho
 The Bruce Park Grill, in dignified Cos Cob, Conn., is similarly close to being an icon among its bibulous, sports-oriented crowd. It has a decidedly macho ambiance: a dim, smoky mood, a long shuffleboard set running nearly the length of the room and plangent rock music that could create waves in a gin and tonic. Every other male customer looks like a former linebacker, and the $2.50 beers go down like Gatorade.
The octogenarian owner of the town's most colorful hangout, the Mianus River Tavern, better known as Augie's, refused to speak on the record for fear that publicity would change the gritty character of his blue-collar bar. He is so protective that the bar is not even listed in the Greenwich phone directory. Augie's is right out of an Edward Hopper painting, a wonderfully preserved -- or neglected, depending on your perspective -- tableau of Greenwich when most residents worked with their hands, not with their stockbrokers.
A magnificent carved oak bar dominates the faded, threadworn room. A few Formica-topped tables are lined up along the cherry red leather banquettes. Local electricians, builders and town road crew workers pack the spartan back room daily to fill up on "the cheapest lunch in Greenwich," as they refer to Augie's. Hamburgers, for example, are $1.25.
 
With a Past
 Down on far west Spring Street in SoHo is the Ear Inn, a saloon with pedigree. Several years ago, 326 Spring Street was named to the National Register of Historic Places. The first bar on this site opened in 1812 when the riverbank was 15 feet away and this neighborhood housed a substantial number of men who worked the piers.
You couldn't tell its lofty status from the interior, with its splotched old bar, slatted wood ceiling and dark, cramped feeling. Dangling over the bar on this visit is a giant hand-scrawled message from a former patron: "I won't miss work but I will miss you people next year when I'm in Jerusalem."
Some fear the Ear Inn may be losing its character as a local joint judging from the number of dark suits showing up there after work. "Ten years ago there was a frightening group of characters at the bar," says Thomas White, an investment counselor in Manhattan. "You looked in the door and had serious reservations about going inside. Now it's so much better."
The Ear Inn is popular among neighborhood residents for dinner. The straightforward and generally satisfying fare includes soups, chicken breast with mozzarella and ham, broiled salmon with a ginger-scallion sauce and spaghetti with meatballs. The most expensive item, the salmon, is $8.75.
The phone rings behind the bar. The bartender, holding the mouthpiece to his stomach, shouts, "PHILLLLLLLLL! Are you here?"
Phil shouts back over his beer, "If it's female, I'm at the health club."
"I'm sorry, ma'm," the bartender responds. "I believe he's gone to work out at the club."
Now, try that at the Oak Room.

HEADLINE: Syracuse Loses Senior Golf Event

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, March 12

 BODY:
The MONY Syracuse Senior Golf Classic has been dropped from the Senior PGA Tour, officials said today, leaving dates open from June 19-21.
The 10-year-old tournament, one of the Senior PGA's original stops, fell victim to the recession as organizers said they could not attract enough sponsors to continue to hold the 54-hole tournament at the Lafayette Country Club. 
 Last year, it cost $708,000 to stage the weeklong event. Organizers said they were about $200,000 short this year.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS: TV SPORTS;
Don't Hold Your Breath for Paramount Deal, Fans

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
So, Engulf and Devour (the friendly old epithet for Paramount Communications' acquisitive forerunner, Gulf and Western), is ready to gobble up the New York Yankees and make George Steinbrenner a bad memory?
Well, not yet, even if there is an inherent logic to the entertainment company's owning the very team whose games appear on Paramount's very own Madison Square Garden Network. 
 Yes, Paramount acknowledged yesterday a report that Steinbrenner and some of his merry limited partners had been talking to company officials about buying the team. But Paramount also said, "We have not received any concrete proposals nor have we made any."
Stanley Jaffe, the president of Paramount, was unavailable for comment.
Let's say Boss George is going gonzo over his banishment from baseball by Commissioner Fay Vincent and wants out. Paramount would not run into interference on corporate ownership of a baseball team, which major league baseball has permitted in several cities.
"There's no problem with corporate ownership," said Vincent. "We have corporate owners in St. Louis and Toronto." In Chicago and Atlanta, too.
Vincent is friendly with Jaffe and remembers him fondly from the days when Jaffe produced the movie "Kramer vs. Kramer" for Columbia Pictures, when Vincent ran the studio. Vincent said he learned of the Paramount-Yankees talks from Jaffe.
(Imagine if Vincent asked his old pal Stanley to get George off his back by buying the Yankees? Whoops, just a fantasy.)
If Paramount were a true buyer, it would not be likely to run into the problem of media ownership of teams, an issue that has centered on superstations like TBS and WGN, where signals are beamed nationwide and compete with local teams' broadcasts in other cities.
Baseball officials have tolerated the Atlanta Braves' ownership by Ted Turner, whose TBS superstation airs Braves games, and the Chicago Cubs' ownership by the Tribune Co., whose WGN airs Cubs games.
Paramount would certainly reap a certain cable TV harvest with the Yankees in the corporate stable because it would then have three teams -- the Yankees, the New York Rangers and the New York Knicks -- to own and televise on MSGN.
And it would put the Yankees under Bob Gutkowski, the president of Madison Square Garden, who negotiated the MSGN deal with the Yankees. Lord knows, he would be an improvement over Leonard Kleinman, Daniel McCarthy, Joe Molloy, Hal Steinbrenner, Shakes the Clown or any member of the conga line of Steinbrenner's post-banishment corporate brain trust.
Buying the team would free Paramount of future payments on its $486 million TV deal with the Yankees, now entering its fourth year of 12, but would naturally impose on it the spiraling costs of running the team. Any kind of deal would be an upfront buyout designed to control an asset that is MSGN's cornerstone.
"This is in effect repurchasing their rights fee," said Bob Pollichino, group vice president and general manager of SportsChannel, which owns the New York Mets cable rights.
But events may be preceding reality. Paramount may no more want to buy than Steinbrenner truly wants to sell or wants to give up his reinstatement fight. Perhaps some of the limited partners are just fed up and want to cash out.
An industry source familiar with the Paramount-Yankees talks said Paramount didn't anticipate taking any action for several months, pending Steinbrenner's campaign for reinstatement by Vincent as the team's managing general partner.
But an analyst with the investment firm First Boston, Martin Romm, discounted reports that Paramount would buy the team. Romm views any talks with the Yankees as a way to negotiate a reduction in rights fees for the rest of the MSG pact.
"The issue is the value of the contract today versus the value when MSG signed it," said Romm, who said the deal is worth substantially less than it was when it was struck in 1988 because of the team's poor record and the management turmoil that has existed since Steinbrenner's exile in 1990.
From another part of yesterday's statement, one might deduce that Paramount would like to reduce its rights payments: "Obviously, we are concerned about the future of the team since we have a major investment in it."
Romm added, "Paramount's concern is to protect the investment they made." He speculated that if Paramount were to consider acquiring the Yankees, it would demand that the remaining value of the MSG contract be discounted, thus reducing the team's purchase price. Various estimates have placed the market value of the Yankees at between $200 million and $300 million.
Another analyst, Christopher Dixon of Paine Webber, provided scenarios for what Paramount might pay for the Yankees. Assuming that Paramount required a 15 percent rate of return on its investments and using rough estimates of the Yankees' revenues and expenses, he said the team would be worth $140 million with $20 million in cash flow, or $245 million with $35 million in cash flow.
Baseball economics would not necessarily be in Paramount's favor if it owned the Yankees. Player salaries are escalating at an unprecedented pace, and there is the likelihood that national TV revenues will fall after 1993.
In addition, the Houston Astros and the Baltimore Orioles have found no buyers after being up for sale for quite a while. Tom Monaghan, the owner of the Detroit Tigers, recently put his team on the auction block.
How much of a premium Paramount would want to pay for the Yankees above recent team-sale prices of about $80 million and the $95 million pricetag for expansion teams in Miami and Denver remains to be seen.
"Paramount won't buy the Yankees at a scorched earth price," said Romm. "What drives their ego is to create value for the shareholder, and you don't create value by overpaying for the Yankees."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
End Foreign Ownership Of the Yanks

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THE guard had his orders. Nobody without a pass was allowed to stand around at courtside of the Miami Arena before a game between the Heat and the Knicks. The guard went around checking every scruffy reporter, every official, every ball boy. No pass, no loitering.
The mild-mannered gent in the suit did not have a pass. Didn't even pretend. Just shrugged and held out his empty hands. 
 "But he's the boss," a reporter said. "His company owns the Knicks."
"Ya gotta have a pass," the guard said.
Some owners we could mention might have blustered, might have cajoled, might have threatened. Stanley Jaffe, the chief operating officer of Paramount Communications, just went to his seat. I had never seen Stanley Jaffe before this moment last November, and I haven't spotted him since, but this was not a bad first impression of a man from a corporation that just might buy the New York Yankees.
Normally, I would be horrified at the prospect of a huge corporation's purchasing part or all of the Yankees. But in this case, Paramount would be taking the Yankees away from George M. Steinbrenner, and how bad could that be? A currently successful octopus replacing a rogue elephant down on his luck.
George Steinbrenner won four pennants from 1976 through 1981 by being ahead of his time in spending money on talented free agents. But he destroyed the organization by chasing good people away, by distracting the players, by getting nuts about being on television and the back pages of the tabloids.
It does not work having Steinbrenner suspended for life after paying a gambler to acquire dirt on a Yankee player. His employees keep waiting for the psychic message of what George would do if he were here. It is time for him to sell the club. Stay home in Tampa. Get a life.
I used to think the ideal solution would be for some personable and rich New Yorker to buy the Yankees. Somebody like The Donald. But Trump also got nuts, building too many gambling joints in Atlantic City and making whoopee when he should have been talking to his bankers. (Don't Trump and Bill Clinton kind of look alike?)
Maybe the age of individuals is over. Maybe there are no personable and rich New Yorkers who could afford the Yankees anymore, not at prices like $300 million. Instead, we are into the age of giant companies like Paramount, which owns Madison Square Garden, the arena and the network, as well as the Knicks and the Rangers and goodness knows what else.
It would be better if TV networks did not own ball clubs. Sometimes the Atlanta Braves right fielder is facing directly into the setting sun for no other reason than that Ted Turner and his TBS people want a baseball game to blend directly into a prime-time movie. It makes perfect sense for the Chicago Cubs to play in the National League West, but the team owner, the Tribune Company, also owns WGN and does not want more games from the Pacific time zone.
Baseball used to say it wanted only local ownership with community roots. The Tribune Company at least thinks Chicago, and the Busch company thinks St. Louis, and Paramount does have some of its major tentacles in New York. It is unfortunate that the Seattle Mariners tapped out while so many Americans are blaming Japan for the economic troubles left by the Reagan-Bush years. If a Seattle-based Japanese investor could help keep the Mariners in the Pacific Northwest, that would be the best solution.
Talk about foreign ownership; if corporate ownership could run Steinbrenner out of town, that would be liberating. Not that I'm fond of giant corporations. I liked Paramount better as Gulf and Western, the kind of ominous name straight from some old novel or movie, the kind of company that would evict widows and close down farms.
Gulf and Western tended to torment its own sports executives. Its anonymous corporate hit men drove the late Michael Burke straight to Ireland. It's hard to get straight answers in bureaucracies. One executive says we're pushing cheeseburgers this week; another says hot dogs. Which is it, guys? Ask Dave DeBusschere. Ask Craig Patrick. But lately, Paramount seems to have come through its identity crisis. There is an air of stability and confidence in the place. Maybe even a tad of respect and trust.
Oh, and about that guard at the Miami Arena. After running off the gent in the suit, he started to fret: "Is he really the boss?"
"Really," somebody said.
"Uh-oh," the guard said.
But it was cool. Stanley Jaffe never came back with the cavalry or the police or the guard's boss. Never played off-with-his-head, like some owners we could name.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Politicians Of Silence

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
I hope it will not annoy the Presidential candidates and other seekers of political office if I bring up a subject that they hardly mention as they dash around campaigning.
Drugs. You remember -- drugs, as in drug addiction, drug crime, drug disease, drug homeless, drug madness, drug guns, drug blood and drug babies. And as in The War Against Drugs, declared by Washington, way back, about three years ago. 
 Maybe it is not worth talking about anymore. Maybe the Bush Administration was right: declare victory, put it on the back burner and put out the pilot light. Then announce a new war, against a different national killer, like the capital gains tax or something.
And maybe all those state legislatures and governors were right to answer recession pressure by whacking away at treatment of drug addicts.
After all, it is a proven fact that drug addicts are too zonked out to vote. And it is another proven fact that middle- and upper-class Americans do not worry about drugs unless they hit their own families or neighborhoods.
So politicians assume, doubtless correctly, that Americans are too stupid to understand that one day some addict from a mean street somewhere might wander into their neighborhood and teach them a civics lesson by sticking a knife in their ribs.
Not everybody has forgotten. In New York City, about 750 people got together Wednesday at a benefit dinner organized by Tina Brown, editor of Vanity Fair, and by the Morgans Hotel Group. The purposes were to help the work against drugs with time and money, and honor Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal. In the past 25 years, he has not forgotten for an hour.
Dr. Rosenthal is head of Phoenix House, largest of the 250 American therapeutic communities. They are based on a no-magic treatment for addiction.
The prescription is for about one year of hard work -- all day, every day in a disciplined environment -- that has two objectives. The first is to equip addicts mentally, physically and spiritually to keep off drugs, forever.
The second is to give them the education, work habits and self-respect needed to earn a living in the world outside.
No magic, no guarantee. But 70 percent of the addicts who stick it out for a year stay clean and useful to themselves and society. Each addict costs about $45 a day in philanthropic or tax money. Pennies, compared with the tens of billions spent building prisons and stocking them with addicts on a perpetual round trip between street and cell.
Education against drugs, by schools and volunteer groups like the Partnership for a Drug-Free America, is making drugs less chic in schools.
But about 6.5 million drug users so abuse themselves that they cannot function in or for the American community. They fill jails, clog hospitals with needle-AIDS and TB, crowd shelters and provide morgues with a steady, dependable supply of the corpses of their victims.
Therapeutic communities will not end the drug problem, but they will help, a lot. Dr. Rosenthal says about 100,000 beds are needed. About a tenth that number exist now, more than half in New York and California.
And meanwhile the housing, land and shops for vocational training are available in closed military bases. The therapeutic communities plead helplessly for this wasted resource.
Since so many politicians are reluctant to bring up drugs now, how about legalizing the whole thing so we can stop bothering our heads? Dr. Rosenthal, like most drug experts, says it would be suicide for America. But then, nothing is perfect.
Oh, certainly, there would be more drug use and abuse. But to keep drugs out of sight of most Americans, electrified walls could be built around the poor white or black and Hispanic neighborhoods infected by drug addicts.
Then armed guards could be posted at gates. Addicts could be shot if they tried to get out. Other residents would have to show passes from the special legalization police.
Behind the walls, addicts could kill each other off; burying them would be cheaper than treatment. Maybe bounties could be paid for death certificates of crack babies. They would just drag through life anyway.
Yes, come to think of it now, it could work. Trees could even be planted near the walls.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Nixon's Tricky Crusade

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
In a memo circulated privately to his worshipers but meant to bludgeon President Bush publicly, Richard Nixon lays down this warning: If the U.S. doesn't get its act together to save Boris Yeltsin, the question of "Who lost Russia?" will be even more politically devastating in the 90's than "Who lost China?" was in the 50's.
I've got three quarrels with the Old Trickster's latest endeavor to help humankind: 
 First, the way he states the issue about Russia is as wrong and almost as phony as it was when he played that destructive game over China in the 1950's.
Mr. Nixon knows who lost China -- the Chinese: the corrupt and incompetent Nationalist Government led by Chiang Kai-shek, which the U.S. could not have saved from Communism with billions of dollars or bombs.
Mr. Nixon and the right-wingers who dreamt up this issue had no program to "save" China. Their sole purpose was to terrorize and defeat Democrats.
While he does have a plan to "save" Russia, Russia -- like China -- is not ours to win or lose. If democracy fails there, the blame will belong almost exclusively to the Russians. Not to Boris Yeltsin and his democratic advisers. They are good and seemingly capable people. But they are trying to do the nearly impossible -- convert 1,000 years of Russian backwardness, corruption, dictatorship, bureaucratic inefficiency, passivity, narrow nationalism and a huge, chaotic economy into a modern capitalist democracy.
Mr. Yeltsin and the Russians have a long, punishing road ahead. The most important thing for them to understand is this: They are responsible for their own fate. The worst thing for them to believe is that the West can or will save them.
Second, the West nonetheless should do all it sensibly can to help Mr. Yeltsin. And here Mr. Nixon repeats some useful points, but dodges the tough questions.
He calls for more humanitarian aid, a corps of Western manager/ teachers, greater access to Western technology and markets, debt rescheduling, a currency stabilization fund and the like. His contribution on these ongoing efforts is to argue for greater urgency.
But he finesses the issue of what should be expected of the Russians. He says, for example, that the West should stabilize the ruble "as soon as Russia gets control of its money supply." That's almost like saying as soon as it solves all its economic problems.
And he is silent on how to pay the bill, some $2 billion to $5 billion yearly for the U.S. alone. The only conceivable source of cash is the Pentagon budget. But the Old Trickster does not mention that honey pot.
My favorite Nixon point is the one about creating a single organization to coordinate all aid to Russia. It's absolutely essential, as I wrote two months ago.
Lastly, what troubles me about Mr. Nixon and the other foreign policy mandarins who applaud his new crusade is that they seem perpetually more interested in Russia than America.
They insist we should do everything we can to help Russia. Otherwise, they say, we will never forgive ourselves for missing this historic opportunity. Their imperative is to give even if it's wasted -- like the almost $50 billion in Western aid that has already "disappeared" in the last two years. But many of these same mandarins would never dream of "wasting" money on homeless, uneducated and unemployed Americans -- or see the plight of Americans as a historic challenge.
The expectations of the foreign policy mandarins like Mr. Nixon are also cockeyed. On the one hand, they maintain that a few billion Western dollars and a lot of Western love can spell the difference between success and failure in Russia. On the other hand, many of them argue that only the naive believe a minority kid can be educated or national health care made affordable in America.
By their thinking, everything is possible in Russia; nothing in America. By their thinking, it's fine to throw money down a Russian sinkhole, but the toughest standards must be applied to money spent at home.
I am all for an urgent, sensibly organized, comprehensive plan to aid Russian democracy. But I would do no less, and far more, for America. And the question I would put to Mr. Nixon and his faithful flock is this: Who is losing America?

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
F.C.C. Loosens Restrictions On Owning Radio Stations

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission today more than doubled the number of radio stations that a single company may own and also allowed a single owner to have as many as three AM and three FM stations in a single city.
The action, approved 4 to 0 with one abstention, comes as the industry is enduring its worst recession in decades. The F.C.C.'s chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, has argued that allowing greater consolidation will allow broadcasters to cut costs. 
 Andrew C. Barrett, the only black on the commission, abstained. In a rare public outburst, he accused his colleagues of paying "lip service" to minority broadcasters and leaving him out of last-minute negotiations.
Mr. Barrett, a Republican from Illinois, argued that the commission was "grossly altering" the ownership structure of the industry. Although he abstained, Mr. Barrett said he would probably change his vote to a formal dissent when the commission published the final rule in several weeks.
Key Democrats in Congress, who favor stricter limits as a way to preserve diversity in radio, quickly objected and promised to introduce legislation to reverse the decision.
But the chances are strong that the new rule will ultimately remain in place. While members of the House are clearly upset, senators who disagree with the change have restrained their comments in recent weeks. President Bush generally favors deregulation.
The rules adopted today, which take effect on Aug. 1, will permit a single person or company to own as many as 30 AM and 30 FM stations nationwide. Under the current rules, one owner may have no more than 12 AM and 12 FM stations nationwide and no more than one of each in any market. Minority owners are currently permitted up to 14 AM and 14 FM stations.
The changes are likely to lead to spirited bidding for some stations. Large broadcasting companies that are close to the old limit -- including CBS, Capital Cities/ABC, Group W-Westinghouse Broadcasting and Infinity Broadcasting are believed to be eager to buy additional stations in large markets.
But it is unclear whether the new ownership limits will have much immediate effect in New York and the other largest markets because big-city stations are generally profitable and under less pressure to sell.
"I think there will be a lot of interest, but I don't know how many opportunities there will be," said Robert F. X. Sillerman, head of the Sillerman Companies in New York, which owns 50 percent of WNEW-AM and has investments in many other stations.
But Mel Karmazin, the president and chief executive of Infinity, had said when the new rules were first proposed: "We would love to have another station in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. A change in ownership rules would be very favorable to us." Mr. Karmazin was out of the office and could not be reached today.
F.C.C. officials said the old rules had long been outdated because radio stations face ample competition from cable television and other forms of communication.
In a staff report on the industry intended to shore up its decision, the F.C.C. said that more than half of all stations in the country were losing money. Because many broadcasters could neither turn a profit nor sell their licenses, 153 stations simply shut in the last year.
The move is also part of a broader effort initiated by Mr. Sikes to loosen a wide range of other restrictions, including rules that limit a company to 12 television stations. Television was not addressed in today's action. F.C.C. officials said that in the next few months they also would accelerate action on a proposal to allow television networks to acquire cable television outlets.
The five commissioners spent the last week trying to resolve differences. Mr. Sikes and Sherrie P. Marshall generally supported a staff recommendation to eliminate the national ownership limits and allow companies to acquire four AM and four FM stations in a single city. Mr. Barrett, Ervin S. Duggan and James H. Quello wanted to move more cautiously.
 
Market-Size Formula
 Besides lifting the national ownership limits, the new rule will revise the so-called duopoly rule that barred a company from owning more than one AM and one FM station in a single city The new regulation would raise the limits based on the size of the market.
In cities with a total of fewer than 15 stations on both bands, a company will not be allowed to buy stations that account for more than half the market share of listeners. In all the bigger cities, the limit will be 25 percent.
In the cities with fewer than 15 stations a company may own three stations, but no more than two FM stations. FM stations, with their superior sound quality, are generally more profitable than AM stations.
Companies would be allowed to buy two AM and two FM station in cities with between 15 and 29 stations; three AM and two FM stations in cities with between 30 and 39 stations, and three of each in cities with more than 40 stations, like New York.
"We're delighted with the F.C.C. action," said Stephen A. Hildebrandt, chief counsel of Group W Radio, which owns a total of 17 AM and FM stations, including WINS in New York City.
 
'Competitive Disadvantage'
 Members of minorities in the broadcasting industry argued that the new rule would make it hard for people who own small stations to "trade up" to larger ones. The rule "means you put at a competitive disadvantage those who cannot afford to buy multiple stations," said Lois Wright, vice president of the Inner City Broadcasting, which owns WLIB-AM and WBLS-FM in New York and is general counsel for the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters.
But the angriest reaction came from Mr. Barrett, who complained that he had not learned about the final agreement until someone outside the F.C.C. presented it to him. "Don't play games with me," he told Mr. Sikes.
The commission also placed some restrictions on what are known as time-brokering agreements, under which one station can lease most of its air time to another station nearby. Under such agreements, which have become popular in the last year, the station that turns over its airtime usually becomes what amounts to a robot transmitter for the other.
The F.C.C. has permitted these arrangements but reuled today that a station could only enter one if it would be eligible to buy the other station under the limits set today.
In a related action, the commission asked for comment on a proposal to let banks and other lenders hold a security interest in a broadcast license as collateral for a loan.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 16, 1992, Monday

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
BUSH GIVES BREAK TO AUTO INDUSTRY ON GASOLINE FUMES

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Four days before the Michigan primary, President Bush told business executives today that the Government would not require automobile manufacturers to install pollution-control devices on new cars to capture gasoline fumes released into the atmosphere during refueling.
In making the announcement just three days after the primary in Texas, Mr. Bush settled a long dispute between auto makers and oil companies over which industry would be required to invest in new equipment to clear the air of benzene and other chemical compounds that contribute to urban smog. 
 The oil industry, which dominates the Texas economy, today lost the dispute that began 17 years ago, when the Government first considered controlling the fumes from refueling. The decision was roundly criticized by lawmakers and environmental groups as well as the oil industry.
 
A Tradition of Campaigns
 Doling out political favors has been an election-year tactic of Presidents for decades. Environmental officials asserted privately this week that Mr. Bush's strategy is driven by the belief that there is only one political gain available to him from the recession: packaging his stepped-up attack on environmental regulations as an effort to help business and preserve jobs.
The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would soon issue a new regulation under the Clean Air Act of 1990 directing service station owners in about 45 cities to install rubber collars on nozzles and vapor-recovery systems on pumps.
The Government said the average cost of such systems, already in use in California as well as the District of Columbia and other Northeastern cities, is about $2,200 a pump and $20,000 to $40,000 for each station. The environmental agency estimated the cost of installing fume-trapping canisters in cars at $20 to $30 for each car.
 
Small but Vital Step
 Gasoline fumes contain substantial quantities of benzene, a known cancer-causing chemical, and organic chemicals that combine with nitrogen oxide and other compounds to form smog. Except in cities that require containment systems at service stations, fumes that accumulate in gasoline tanks escape into the atmosphere during refueling.
The E.P.A. said today that gasoline fumes account for 2 percent of the urban smog problem. The agency said that although that percentage is small, there are so many sources of smog that identifying one and reducing it sharply would be a major improvement.
Mr. Bush and William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the E.P.A., said the decision in favor of the automobile industry was the result of new studies by the Department of Transportation. They found that installing canisters near gasoline tanks to capture the fumes would be a risk to passengers because of the increased chance the canister would catch fire or explode in a collision.
In addition, William G. Rosenberg, the assistant administrator of the environmental agency for air and radiation, said that the automobile industry deserved a break from requirements of the Clean Air Act, since it is already required to reduce emissions in new cars by developing more advanced engine and tailpipe controls.
"This was perceived to be the least-cost way for the consumer to pay, and a fairer distribution of the economic burden," Mr. Rosenberg said.
 
Under Immediate Attack
 The action by the Bush Administration was attacked today by lawmakers, environmentalists, independent station owners, and the Center for Auto Safety, a Washington-based consumer group.
"The on-board canisters were a cheaper and better way to control volatile emissions than the vapor-recovery systems at gasoline stations, which are expensive and difficult to maintain," said Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana who was a principal author of the Clean Air Act. "The so-called environmental President is playing politics with clean air."
The Center for Auto Safety disputed the Government's contention that vapor canisters were a safety risk. The group has said that cars already have similar canisters installed to control emissions and the Government has never maintained that they were a danger.
Environmental groups said the Clean Air Act, which the President vigorously supported, requires installation in cars and gasoline stations of systems to control gasoline fumes. Waiving one requirement was a purely political move that would do nothing to reduce pollution from vapors in less smoggy cities, they said.
 
An Act 'Held Hostage'?
 The Natural Resources Defense Council today listed 11 other regulations under the Clean Air Act that have been proposed by the environmental agency but which have been blocked by the White House. One covers emissions of toxic chemicals from factories, one of the largest sources of air pollution. "The Clean Air Act is being held hostage by the White House," said David D. Doniger, a lawyer with the group.
Independent gasoline marketers also criticized the President's action, calling it expensive, unnecessary and likely to reduce competition. They said the cost of installing vapor-recovery systems could put hundreds of stations out of business and allow the big oil companies to gain a much larger share of the $130 billion retail gasoline market.
The Petroleum Marketers Association of America said that although independent businessmen own two-thirds of the 175,000 stations across the country, they pump just 45 percent of the gasoline.
"The big oil companies don't like this much either, but they are in much better financial position to afford the vapor-recovery systems," said Phillip R. Chisholm, executive vice president of the association. "They have the advantage of their size. They also have higher concentration of stations in the markets that are most affected by this rule, which means they can get the contractors who do this work first and at lower costs."
As Mr. Bush campaigns against Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator who is challenging him for the Republican nomination, he is doing what politicians at all levels do in an election year: dispensing pork.
In addition to President Bush's announcement last week of a $514 million reclamation project to straighten the Kissimmee River in Florida, he has reduced some environmental regulations.
In the past month, the Administration relaxed regulations on the natural gas industry in Oklahoma. It also announced its intention to seek Congressional approval to bypass the Endangered Species Act in the Northwest to allow cutting of the last stands of virgin forest. Backers say that would preserve 30,000 jobs.
It was revealed this week that the Administration joined sides with the coal industry in a Federal Court lawsuit the industry hopes will weaken enforcement of the nation's strip-mining law. Earlier, the White House announced a program to remove regulation of the biotechnology industry, including making it easier for agricultural biotechnology companies to test living genetically-engineered organisms outdoors.

HEADLINE: Fading Red Line; A special report;
New Hope in Inner Cities: Banks Offering Mortgages

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
In blighted North Philadelphia, where gutted homes intersect with broken dreams, the banking industry is meeting the inner city.
Prodded by Federal laws and an aggressive community-action group called Acorn, banks here and in other cities across the country have started making mortgage loans in neighborhoods they have traditionally avoided. 
 In Philadelphia, bankers are setting the rules for this kind of lending. So far, $60 million has been lent in a widely watched program. It matters little if an applicant has a small income, an irregular job pattern or collects welfare or food stamps. He or she might still qualify for a mortgage, bankers here say -- a radical departure from tradition banking practices.
 
Benefits for Neighborhoods
 To bankers, the inner city is an "underbanked" market, in their parlance. And what they are finding is that making mortgages to inner-city borrowers promises to strengthen their bottom line in the long run, while not hurting it in the short term. More important, these loans have profound social and economic benefits for inner-city neighborhoods and for the quality of urban life in general.
"There's a lot of good business to be had," said Cathy Bessant, a senior vice president at Nationsbank, the North Carolina giant that recently committed $10 billion over the next 10 years for a variety of loans to inner-city neighborhoods across the nation. "About 60 percent of American households have an annual income of less than $25,000. It's a huge market that is absolutely underbanked and there are not many underbanked markets out there."
Since 1985, at least 29 banks across the country have put more than $500 million into inner-city mortgages. This translates into 16,000 mortgages. And more money is on the way. By far the biggest pledge is the $10 billion from Nationsbank, recently created by the merger of the NCNB Corporation and the C&S/Sovran Bank. And the Chemical Banking Corporation, which recently merged with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, has promised to set aside $750 million for inner-city mortgages in New York.
But lending to the inner city is not exactly like lending to the suburbs. Banks must adopt different underwriting standards to determine who is creditworthy and who is not -- for instance, looking at the steady repayment of small bills instead of at wealth. They must also develop creative marketing techniques to attract borrowers unfamiliar with mainstream lending. And banks are finding it necessary to provide intensive financial counseling before making any loans. These changes have not come easily.
"Few bankers do this out of the goodness of their heart," said Michael Shea, housing director for Acorn, formally known as the Association of Community Groups for Reform Now, a national nonprofit group. "If there was no community pressure and the law, few banks would do something. But now a lot of bankers see it's in their self-interest."
For banks familiar with the ways of corporate America and the board room, meeting with community-based groups of poor people is not something willingly done. But the recent wave of bank mergers, which must be approved by Federal regulators, has created an opportunity for housing advocacy groups to be heard.
There are many such voices. But by far the loudest belongs to Acorn, which has some 70,000 members, a $10 million annual budget and two decades of active history.
In Washington, Acorn once tied red ribbons around a Crestar Bank branch to object to what Acorn saw as the bank's practice of redlining, or denying mortgages to inner-city areas. With tactics like this, the nation's largest banks have come to the negotiating table just to silence objections that could derail or create costly delays to a merger.
 
'A Little Window Opens'
 "The banking industry has done all it can to avoid community reinvestment," said Deepak Bhargava, an Acorn legislative representative in Washington. "Our opportunity to be taken seriously is only when a bank goes to the Federal Reserve and says it wants to merge. That's when a little window opens for us."
A Federal regulator concurs. "Acorn is street-tough rough and they bedevil the bankers," he said. "But they've gotten banks to commit millions they otherwise would not have lent."
In Philadelphia, where Acorn has been most active, Ray F. Desiderio, a senior vice president at the Continental Bank, remembers the day the group threatened to oppose its 1986 merger with the Midlantic Bank. The threat, later withdrawn, was enough to get Mr. Desiderio to Acorn's shabby office here.
"The first meetings were rough," he said. "They were in North Philadelphia on a hot summer's night. Acorn's demands were an inch thick and we were caught flatfooted. When we looked at their demands, it was obvious we had to look at our policies."
His bank has since lent $20 million to the inner city.
 
The Process
Matching People With Mortgages
 A long, creaky staircase goes up to Acorn's office, where there's a hum of activity as low-income people are matched with mortgages. In one corner, Marilyn Ashley, an Acorn counselor, fields telephone calls and explains the program. Low-income people trickle in to fill out mortgage applications.
In another room, a representative of the Mellon Bank, one of the state's oldest banks, processes a mortgage for a middle-aged woman on her lunch break. No one who gets a mortgage ever has to go beyond this office.
"The major difference between this and traditional lending is that I'll come to you and I'll fit into your schedule," said Mike Garcia, a Mellon mortgage representative, as he photocopied documents. "A lot of branches don't have the expertise for this kind of lending. So they call me and I go out."
Mr. Garcia, who spends part of his week here, said he's seen it all -- from people who sign "X" for their name to a 70-year-old first-time home buyer who took out a 30-year mortgage.
Last year, Mr. Garcia processed 212 mortgages, for a total of $5.7 million in loans. About 30 percent came through Acorn, which represents mainly black home buyers. An additional 40 percent came through a similar program run by a Hispanic community group and the rest from groups representing Vietnamese and Irish low-income neighborhoods.
At one desk, Allison Hughes of Acorn tells a young woman who works as a probation officer what documents she needs to buy the house she now rents. At another desk, Ms. Ashley meets with a middle-aged man who received a house from the city without charge, but has no money to fix it up. She suggests giving the house back and instead joining Acorn's financial counseling sessions to learn to budget for a down payment and buy a modest house in better shape.
He is followed by a couple who speak only Creole and who were having trouble with their application. The couple brought along a young woman who translated while her own two children played in her lap and Ms. Ashley's. Ms. Ashley does many things to help people -- just that morning, she gave a wake-up call to a man who works nights and who asked her to help him keep his appointment.
 
The Rewards
Banks Say Loans Help in Long Run
The Philadelphia banks in the program, Mellon, Continental and Fidelity,, say their experience shows that a well-structured program can break even in the short run and promises intangible and financial gains over the long haul. The banks charge sufficient fees to cover costs and work hard to keep delinquencies and foreclosures low.
"These are not conventional loans and we make sure that we don't lose money," Mr. Desiderio said. "But they are totally beneficial to us because they improve our trade area. In the long run this will drop to the bottom line."
Bankers believe that as poor neighborhoods stabilize, the entire region benefits, which affects a bank's future profitability.
What is more, these mortgages help banks fulfill somewhat vague obligations of the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which requires banks to invest in communities that provide them with deposits.
"What happens to these neighborhoods when there are no loans?" said Bruce Dorpalen, Acorn's housing coordinator in Philadelphia. "You limit sales to those who pay cash or who make large down payments. Who is that? Absentee landlords or drug dealers.
"There is a market for these houses. Where bankers get religion is when then see they can do this with no risk."
 
The Counseling
Agency Works To Aid Applicants
 The key to success is counseling and marketing.
In Philadelphia, Acorn and similar groups counsel potential buyers in the responsibilities of home ownership and screen applicants for the banks. Sometimes, the applicants work more than a year with counselors to straighten out their finances and save for the down payment.
Each year, Philadelphia banks and Acorn hold a fair where hundreds of low-income people come and the banks vie for business. John V. Killen, an executive at Fidelity Bank, thinks of himself as the Phil Donahue of the fair. With microphone in hand, he plunges into the audience to get people to relax. "I once had 200 people rolling in the aisles," he said. "Many of them are bashful, shy and in need."
The terms of these loans might well cause most bankers to wince -- at first. A typical borrower earns from $10,000 to the mid-$20,000's a year and gets a mortgage -- which averages about $22,000 -- a percentage point or more below market rates. Fees are lowered and lending standards allow even welfare payments and food stamps to be counted as income.
Since many inner-city residents have never had checking accounts and pay only with cash, many have no credit history. So, banks look at rent and utility payments and outstanding debts to determine creditworthiness. Normally, banks require two years of steady employment. But here, since so many low-income residents switch jobs frequently, banks look for steady income, even if from many jobs.
 
The Customer
A Return Home To His Own Place
 One of the home buyers is Calvin Williams, who works in the personnel section of a department store. Mr. Williams, a divorced father of two teen-agers, has just bought a row home in the Strawberry Mansion section, a neighborhood balanced between forbidding, vacant homes and those that are occupied but well guarded.
For the last two years, Mr. Williams had been living in a New Jersey apartment and read all he could about home buying, including literature Acorn had distributed at work.
"I was born and raised in North Philadelphia and the only way to help the neighborhood was to go back, live there and keep up a home," he said. His friends thought he should move to a more stable area. But he wanted the house he found, and it was close to where his mother and daughters lived.
 
Federal Reserve Report
 He said he preferred dealing with a community group rather than going directly to a bank because "the whole notion of a mortgage is scary and it was a relief to go one-on-one with someone I could relate to."
While Mr. Williams was applying, he read about a Federal Reserve report last October showing widespread discrimination against blacks in home mortgage lending. The report looked at more than five million mortgage applications and found that blacks were turned down twice as much as whites, even at the same income level.
As a black, he was concerned, and went to the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia. When he saw that the Mellon Bank, one of the three working with Acorn, had a good record, he decided to give it his business.
"The Mellon person agreed to meet me at the Acorn office and everything was done on premises," Mr. Williams said. "That took away all the starchiness."
Just before Christmas, he got his mortgage and by the holiday he was going back and forth in his Volkswagen moving furniture, one carload at a time.
Like nearly all borrowers in the program, Mr. Williams's monthly mortgage is less than what he was paying in rent -- and for more space. "I feel blessed that everything fell into place," he said. "This block is holding together and to protect my investment, I am going to have to live here."
 
Working Together
Banks and Acorn Lobby Jointly
 With nearly 3,000 mortgages given out here so far, bankers elsewhere are calling for information.
They are told that delinquency rates are higher than traditional mortgage portfolios, but foreclosures are lower. Continental, however, has been able to bring delinquencies to conventional levels by calling borrowers who are late and getting them counseling.
Mr. Killen at Fidelity, which has lent some $25 million in the program, said he was working with Acorn to develop regular post-mortgage counseling. "We don't want the legal bills of foreclosure and we don't want people out on the streets," he said.
But the mergers that have helped create the lending programs are also a cause of concern for some. LaVerne Butts, a Philadelphia Acorn official, fears that mega-mergers may leave the poor in the dust. "Where's the accountability?" she asked. "We're doing wonderful things, but we're still swimming against the tide. Many of these banks still don't view low- and moderate-income people as people. When they get so big, who do you lean on?"
 
Aiming at Secondary Market
 Yet at present, the three Philadelphia banks seem responsive. They have lobbied with Acorn in Washington to find ways to make it easier to package these mortgages and sell them in the secondary market. This would reduce the banks' risk and free up more money to lend.
The biggest buyer of mortgages is the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, which resells them to investors. But Fannie Mae has been reluctant to buy such unconventional mortgages. Acorn hopes that large commitments like that of Nationsbank will help bring pressure on Fannie Mae. Already, Nationsbank is talking about joining with Acorn's Washington lobby.
"You wouldn't picture it," Ms. Bessant of Nationsbank said, "but community-based groups and giant banks lobbying together is a pretty powerful combination."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 27.28 to End Week at 3,235.91

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks advanced yesterday in moderate trading after a smaller-than-expected rise in producer prices indicated that inflation was being restrained.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,235.91, up 27.28 points for the day and 14.31 for the week, while the broader market was stronger, too. 
 The lower producer price numbers reduced the fear of inflation and diminished the chances that the Fed might tighten credit.
 
'Triple Witching Hour'
 Analysts at MMS International expect the market to trade in a narrow range into next week, ending with next Friday's "triple witching hour," when March options on individual stocks, the March Standard & Poor's 500 futures and options on the S.& P. futures all expire.
Vincent Graziano, head of equity trading for Labe Associates, noted that since mid-February, the market remained confined to its tight trading range of 3,200 to 3,300 on the Dow.
"While it looks for further signs of an economic recovery, the market will likely do what it has for the past month, and that is to move in no clear direction," Mr. Graziano said.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 177.9 million shares, down from 180.3 million on Thursday, with gaining issues ahead of losers, 987 to 675. The S.& P. 500 index rose 1.95 points, to 405.84, while the American Stock Exchange composite gained 0.47 point, to 404.06. The Nasdaq composite was up 2.70, to 618.62, and the Russell 2,000 was up 0.77 point, to 206.76.
The stock of Litton Industries jumped 1 1/8, to 97, after its board approved a 2-for-1 stock split. Pfizer, on the other hand, fell 1 1/4, to 71 3/8, after the Food and Drug Administration said it wanted the company to warn patients of the possible higher rate of fracture for some large heart valves. The F.D.A. said it might be necessary to replace the valves.
Athena Neurosciences, a pharmaceuticals manufacturer, rose 1, to 13 1/2. David Webber, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons, initiated coverage of the stock with a "buy" rating. The analyst said the rating reflected his optimism about the company's research into Alzheimer's disease and its research into other areas of new drugs for neuro-degenerative diseases like multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease and epilepsy.
Lotus Development rose 1 7/8, to 38 5/8, after several analysts repeated buy ratings for the software company after a meeting with management that included a demonstration of several new products.
T2 Medical, which operates infusion therapy centers where patients are given medicine and nutrients intravenously, rose 2 1/2, to 47 1/2. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette adjusted its recommendation on the stock to "very attractive" from "moderately attractive."
VLSI Technology, rose 1 5/8, to 9 1/2. The company and Intel, unchanged at 64, are in talks on a technology sharing agreement, in which Intel would acquire a minority equity interest in VSLI.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rockwell to Cut Earnings By $1.5 Billion This Year

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 13

 BODY:
The Rockwell International Corporation said today that it would reduce its earnings this year by $1.5 billion to reflect a change in the way it accounts for the health-care costs of its retirees.
At the same time, Rockwell said that it saw no signs of an economic turnaround and that because of the resulting weakness in its automotive- components, factory automation and electronics businesses, it now expected full-year earnings per share to be down by 15 percent, not including the effect of the accounting change. 
 In taking the charge, Rockwell became the latest company to adopt an accounting rule that requires future retiree health-care costs to be accounted for in advance rather than as they are incurred.
As a result of the change, Rockwell said it would restate its earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, the first quarter of its fiscal year. The company said the change would result in a loss for the first quarter as well as for the full fiscal year, but did not say what the restated first-quarter earnings would be. As originally calculated, the first-quarter earnings were $123.3 million, or 54 cents a share, down 13 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.
 
Stock Price Falls

 
 On the New York Stock Exchange today, Rockwell shares closed at $26, down 75 cents.
The company, which is based in Seal Beach, Calif., had previously warned that it might have trouble this year posting earnings comparable to last year's. In addition to its commercial businesses, Rockwell is a primary supplier to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and a leading Pentagon contractor.
Donald R. Beall, Rockwell's chairman and chief executive, said the company still hoped for an economic turnaround by 1993. "With the improvements we expect in our automotive and factory automation businesses, our outlook is for earnings higher than 1992," Mr. Beall said.
