HEADLINE: 2 S.&. L.'s and a Bank Are Closed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Two savings institutions and one bank in the New York area were closed yesterday, and their depositors face losses if their account balances surpass the $100,000 insurance limit set by the Federal Government.
All three institutions -- Central Federal Savings Bank of Mineola, L.I.; the Broadway Bank and Trust Company of Paterson, N.J., and the Danbury Federal Savings and Loan Association in Connecticut -- were victims of the sharp decline in real estate prices, which led to defaults on loans by developers and other customers. 
 Customers, branches and insured accounts at all three were transferred to healthy banks nearby. Deposits will continue to be insured and customers may use their checks and automatic teller cards until the branches open for business on Monday.
 
Limit on Deposits
 To limit the cost of the failures, Federal regulators arranged for healthy banks to acquire only the deposits insured up to the $100,000 limit.
For multibillion-dollar banks and savings institutions, the practice of Federal officials has been to arrange for the transfer to a healthy bank of all deposits, whether insured or not. Depositors in many smaller banks have been covered only up to the legally required level. Officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation have never said exactly how big a bank must be for all of its deposits to be protected, and they could not be reached late yesterday to explain their decisions on the three New York area banks.
The largest of the failed banks was Central Federal, which had assets of $675.5 million and 12 branches, mostly on Long Island. Chemical Bank paid $3.5 million to acquire about $500 million of insured deposits from about 80,000 accounts and will open Central Federal's branches for business on Monday.
Although Central Federal had been declared insolvent and placed under Government control in December 1990, some customers continued to hold uninsured deposits totaling about $2.8 million. Those customers are expected to lose part of their money, with the amount of the losses depending on how much the Government recovers when it sells Central Federal's loans.
Chemical, which already claims to be the largest bank on Long Island, promised to waive all fees for Central Federal customers through June and to hold unchanged the interest rates paid on existing certificates of deposit and other accounts.
In New Jersey, Broadway Bank and Trust, with $386.4 million in assets, was closed and the Federally insured deposits at its eight branches were transfered to the Hudson United Bank of Union City, which paid the Government $3.4 million. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said that as many as 255 accounts with uninsured deposits of $6.3 million above the $100,000 insurance limit could suffer a loss.
Jeff Connor, the New Jersey Banking Commissioner, said uninsured depositors that had business accounts might be eligible for a loan that could cover the amount of their loss. The loans, which would be the first of their kind, would be issued by Hudson United and guaranteed in part by the New Jersey Economic Development Authority.
 
Reminder of Problems
 In Connecticut, Danbury Federal was closed and its deposits at six branches were transfered to the Bristol Federal Savings Bank. Bristol paid the Government $922,000 for the $115.7 million of deposits, but there are additional deposits of $1 million that are not covered by insurance and not transferred to Bristol.
While none of the three were comparable in size to the Dollar Dry Dock Bank, which was sold to Emigrant Savings Bank earlier this month, or Crossland Savings, which was declared involvent recently and is now owned by the Federal Government, their troubles are a reminder that the problems of local banks are not over.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Senate passed election-year tax legislation that Bush is sure to veto. The vote was unexpectedly close, at 50 to 47. [Page 39.] 
 Prices received by producers edged up a modest 0.2 percent in February, as another decline in energy prices helped to offset the biggest surge in food costs in two years, the Government said. [39.]
Sales of North American-made vehicles rose 14 percent in early March compared with an unusually weak period last year. Analysts took heart from reports that sales to individuals -- as opposed to fleet buyers -- were strong. [41.]
The Government will not require auto makers to install pollution control devices on new cars to capture fumes released during refueling, Bush said, four days before the Michigan primary. [1.]
Banks nationwide have started making mortgage loans in neighborhoods they have traditionally avoided, prodded by Federal laws and aggressive community action groups. In Philadelphia, $60 million has been lent so far in a widely watched program. [1.]
Business inventories dwindled in January for the first time in five months. [40.]
 
International
A Citicorp unit in London began to foreclose on Randsworth Trust, meaning a total loss on a widely watched $425 million investment. [39.]
The first Western car assembled in Central Europe since Communism fell rolled off the production line in Hungary. [39.]
 
Companies
Chrysler directors are scheduled to meet in New York today amid speculation that the company is about to hire Robert J. Eaton, head of G.M.'s European operations, who would be groomed as a successor to Iacocca. [39.]
Rockwell said it would reduce its earnings this year by $1.5 billion to reflect a change involving retirees' health-care costs. [41.]
R. J. Reynolds plans an ambitious introduction of a different version of Winston that would be more like Marlboro. [46.]
Serius, a company founded by an 18-year-old, is offering a library of software that enables users to create their own computer program, matching some of the goals of Taligent, the I.B.M.-Apple software venture. [39.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Vehicle Sales Rose 14% in Early March

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 13

 BODY:
Sales of North American-made vehicles rose 14 percent in early March, compared with an unusually weak period last year. Although sales remained soft, analysts took heart from auto makers' reports of strong sales to individuals, as opposed to fleet buyers.
Sales of cars rose 9.4 percent, to 142,943, for the March 1-10 period, from 130,640 a year earlier. Sales of light trucks, which include mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles, were 90,183, a 22 percent increase from sales a year earlier of 73,905. Together, sales totaled 233,126, a 14 percent increase from 204,545 in the 1991 period. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for domestic cars was 6 million, compared with 5.9 million a year earlier and 5.9 million in late February.
Of the nation's Big Three auto makers, both General Motors and Ford showed sales gains in cars and light trucks. An estimate for the Chrysler Corporation indicated a gain only for light-truck sales and a decline for cars. Chrysler sales must be estimated for the 10-day periods, because the company releases only monthly figures.
 
 
Big Gains in Retail Sales
 "For the past two months there has been a dramatic, underlying change in the mix" of retail and fleet sales, said Wendy Beale Needham, automotive analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham in New York. "The domestic auto makers are enjoying double-digit increases in retail sales and declining sales of fleet vehicles." Sales to retail customers are typically much more profitable than those to rental companies and other fleets.
Auto makers do not normally break out fleet sales from other sales. But Joel Pitcoff, a spokesman for the Ford Motor Company, said Ford's sales to individual retail customers were up 28 percent in the period, compared with an overall 5.4 percent increase in the company's car sales.
A day earlier, at a press briefing, Ross Roberts, general manager of the company's Ford division, said, "We've begun hearing positive comments from our dealers in the Northeast United States for the first time in a few years."
Auto makers, dealers and analysts are straining to find positive signs of a turn in the market. Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said: "There's no doubt about it, the recovery is real. Trucks and vans are downright hot, and newly restyled lower-priced cars are selling much better."
But Mr. Webb conceded that he based his optimism on the fact that sales were not lower, given the high level of unemployment and weak consumer confidence.
Indeed, the aggregate sales figures were not strong, and some dealers reported that demand was erratic. "We saw a pickup in February, but things have gotten slow again," said Mark Herrmann, a G.M. dealer in Yonkers. Mr. Herrmann theorized that negative economic reports, like news of the rising unemployment rate, had made shoppers more wary about buying cars.
 
 
G.M. Car Sales Up 17.4%
 At the General Motors Corporation, car sales rose 17.4 percent, to 67,804 for the March 1-10 period, and light- truck sales rose 10.9 percent, to 34,294. G.M.'s GMC truck division and all of G.M.'s sales divisions except for Buick reported sales gains. G.M.'s Saturn models also continued to sell briskly.
The 5.4 percent gain at the Ford Motor Company represented sales totaling 40,717; Ford's light-truck sales rose 29.8 percent, to 30,121.
Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, estimated that Chrysler's car sales fell 12.6 percent, to 13,550; Ward's projected that Chrysler's light-truck sales rose 31.1 percent, to 22,550.
At the Toyota Motor Corporation, Bob McCurry, the auto maker's executive vice president of United States sales, said, "I'll need to see a couple of more months of steady improvement before I'm convinced we're breaking out of a recession."
 
 
Toyota Gains 37.3%
 The auto maker posted a 37.3 percent increase in sales of cars built at its three North American plants, selling 6,555, compared with 4,774 a year earlier.
The Honda Motor Company showed a bare increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in car sales, to 9,372. The Nissan Motor Company sold 1,358 domestic cars, down 20.1 percent. The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation sold 1,623 domestic cars, more than double its sales a year ago of 695.
As a group, the Big Three's share of domestic car sales fell to 85.4 percent in early March, from 85.7 percent a year earlier. The Japanese "transplants" -- companies that build cars in North America -- increased their share of domestic car sales to 14.6 percent, from 14.3 percent.
In light trucks, the Big Three dominated with 97 percent of the market, up from 96.5 percent a year earlier. The transplants held a 3 percent share of the light-truck market, down from 3.5 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Tax Plan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
In an unexpectedly close vote, the Senate passed election-year tax legislation this evening that President Bush is sure to veto.
The vote was 50 to 47, with four Democrats crossing party lines and three Democrats not voting. All 43 Republicans opposed the measure. 
 During the three days of debate, Democrats and Republicans traded accusations about who bore responsibility for the Federal budget deficit and who was more willing to provide tax breaks for special interests.
 
Two Points of View
 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee and managed the bill on the Senate floor today, said the measure would make the tax code fairer, promote economic growth and avoid enlarging the deficit.
But Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, took the Senate floor late in the afternoon to announce that he opposed the Democratic bill because it would not reduce the deficit and included "billions of dollars stuffed in the pockets" of real estate, oil and gas interests.
"The truth is that it is too little, too late to jump-start the economy," he said. "It will open up new loopholes that primarily are used by wealthy Americans and corporations."
 
Democratic Opponents
 The Democrats who voted against the bill were Howell Heflin of Alabama, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama. Senator Bradley did not vote, explaining that he had an agreement with Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, a supporter of the bill, who could not be present for the vote. And Tom Harkin of Iowa was absent.
Mr. Bradley was one of the main architects of the tax legislation in 1986 that eliminated or reduced many of tax breaks geared to specific industries, some of which would be reinstated in the new bill.
Among its provisions, the Senate bill would increase the income tax rate to 36 percent from 31 percent for single people earning more than $150,000 and couples earning more than $175,000. The tax rate on income exceeding $1 million would be 39.6 percent.
The extra revenues would be used to provide a $300 tax credit for children, restore the deductibility of contributions to individual retirement accounts for all taxpayers and provide $7 billion in tax breaks for home buyers and the real estate industry.
Republican and Democratic senators had introduced several amendments to spend more on reducing the deficit or expanding public works projects, all of which quickly failed. On Thursday, several Democrats nearly succeeded in tearing out the centerpiece of the Democratic bill, the tax credit for children, and replacing it with a reduction in the deficit and more public works.
The attention paid to the deficit, said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, came partly as a response to rumblings among some Democrats that tax increases for the affluent would be used to provide tax cuts for the middle class instead of reducing the deficit. But, he said, "it's a rumble instead of a revolt."
Indeed, with few exceptions, Democrats maintained that their plan would make the tax code fairer.
 
'Tax Fairness Is a Mirage'
 Republicans, meanwhile, argued that higher taxes for some groups would worsen the budget deficit by encouraging more Federal spending.
"Tax fairness is a mirage that disguises tax increases," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona.
Passage of the bill clears the way for a conference of House and Senate leaders, perhaps beginning on Wednesday, to eliminate the many differences between the measures. The leaders of both chambers then hope to gain passage of the conference's bill by next Friday, the deadline set by President Bush in his State of the Union address.
Mr. Bush has threatened to veto any legislation that includes tax increases, which appear in both bills. Today, in a speech to the Economic Club of Detroit, President Bush again promoted his own package, especially cuts in the capital gains tax rate, and acceleration of depreciation allowances.
"I will veto job-destroying tax increases and fight for job-creating incentives," Mr. Bush said, calling the Congressional tax measure "a $90 billion tax increase."
Although the President's March 20 deadline has no legal force, Democratic leaders in the Congress have raced to meet it to avoid accusations of inaction.
Along the way, the Senate took up a long series of amendments, passing several and voting down the rest.
New York's two Senators, Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, sparred repeatedly, with Mr. D'Amato, a Republican, introducing two amendments on welfare policies that passed on voice votes. One amendment would withhold some Federal money, now spent on poor families with children, from states that do not require work of adult welfare recipients without dependents. The other amendment would allow states to limit welfare benefits for people who have just moved from other states.
Mr. Moynihan, a Democrat, said that requiring welfare recipients to work was impractical unless the Federal Government also provided $5 billion over five years to create jobs for them.
Also passed on a voice vote was an amendment by Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, to allow people who have been unemployed for 12 or more weeks to withdraw money from I.R.A.'s without tax penalties.
 
Bentsen's Late Amendment
 Senator Bentsen rushed one amendment into the bill during the final minutes of debate, without providing any public indication of its content or allowing any discussion. The amendment authorizes $10 million to establish a center in Texas to "promote better trade and economic relations among the nations of Western Hemisphere."
A proposal by Mr. McCain to require a 60-vote majority to raise taxes but only a 51-vote majority to lower them prompted an especially lengthy and vigorous debate.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee, suggested that it was "demagogic" to favor a reversal of the current rules, which require a 60-vote majority to lower taxes but only a 51-vote majority to raise them.
"If low taxes are good, then no taxes are best of all, according to the logic of the distinguished gentleman from Arizona," he said.
Mr. McCain's amendment was put aside after only 35 Republicans and 2 Democrats voted to set aside a rule barring consideration of such a change. Sixty votes were needed.
The Senate also defeated several Republican amendments this evening that would have replaced the Democrats' tax increases with spending cuts or freezes, or would have helped Midwestern farmers. Each of the bills fell on procedural grounds.
Prominent differences between the House and Senate bills include the House's decision to give a tax credit on Social Security and Medicare while the Senate would give a tax credit for children. President Bush had proposed that a middle-class tax cut take the form of an increase in the personal exemption for children.
The Senate bill also calls for linking to income levels the capital gains tax due on profits from the sale of houses and other assets that have appreciated in value since their purchase. Middle-class taxpayers would pay a capital gains tax rate as low as 5 percent under the bill while wealthy taxpayers would continue to pay the current top rate of 28 percent.
The House bill called for taxing only gains after inflation, while Mr. Bush advocated a reduction in the capital gains tax to 15.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Rise 0.2%, Easing Inflation Concerns

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Prices received by producers in February edged up a modest two-tenths of 1 percent as another decline in energy prices helped to offset the biggest surge in food costs in two years, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said the small gain in its Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which measures inflation just before goods reach the retail level, followed two consecutive monthly declines, three-tenths of 1 percent in January and one-tenth in December. 
 Analysts said heavy rains and flooding in California and Texas pushed up food prices, but they contended there was no indication the underlying inflation rate would rise out of control even as the economy exhibits new signs of life.
A second report today from the Commerce Department said businesses lowered inventories for the first time in five months. Analysts said the inventory reduction, coupled with a report earlier this week of strong improvements in retail sales in January and February, could bring increased production and a growing economy in the months ahead.
"At this point, these are the types of economic conditions you want to have," said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. "The recovery is probably very near if not already here, and there is no inflation."
The wholesale price report was welcomed by the stock market today, where the Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.28 points, to 3,235.91.
But while there was no immediate concern about revived inflation, some analysts expressed uneasiness about price increases at the intermediate and crude stages of production. Intermediate goods climbed five-tenths of 1 percent, while raw commodities jumped 1.7 percent, both after two months of decline. These were consistent with the other recent reports suggesting a step-up in the pace of the economy
 
Food Prices Surge

 In a development likely to be reflected quickly at grocery stores, wholesale food costs soared 1.1 percent in February. Food prices had fallen in eight of the last nine months. The February jump was led by a 26 percent increase in the price of vegetables.
Outside the volatile food and energy categories, wholesale prices rose a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in February, the best performance since June.
Even with February's overall price increase of two-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest since a similar gain in October, inflation at the producer level was still declining at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent for the first two months of this year as a weak economy restrained prices.
 
Outlook on Inflation
 And even if a sustained economic recovery does get under way this year, analysts are not looking for inflation to worsen. Many are forecasting that wholesale prices will climb about 2 percent for the whole year while consumer prices will rise 3 percent. Such a development, coupled with similarly good results last year, would give the country the best two-year performance on inflation since the mid 1960's.
The reason for the optimism of many economists about inflation is their view that the recovery from the recession will, at least initially, be one of the weakest on record.
"The prolonged weakness that the country is going through has created excess capacity, which will persist, and that will mean that both wages and production costs will remain under downward pressure for some time," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
In the February report, energy prices edged down for a third straight month, falling one-tenth of 1 percent. But that decline was far smaller than the 2.8 percent drop in January or the 1.4 percent December decrease.
 
Energy Prices Jump
 Gasoline and home heating oil costs actually were up last month, rising by 1.9 percent and 16.2 percent respectively, but those gains were offset, on a weighted basis, by 1 percent drops for both electricity and natural gas prices.
In foods, the overall 1.1 percent increase was the largest since a 1.8 percent surge in January 1990.
In addition to the huge jump in vegetable prices, which analysts attributed to short supplies at the end of winter, egg prices rose 2.6 percent, beef prices were up 3.4 percent and pork prices rose 2.9 percent.
Prices of passenger cars, alcoholic beverages and soap all fell last month, helping to offset increases for magazines and prescription drugs.
The various changes left the Producer Price Index, before adjusting for seasonal variations, at 121.9 in February, compared with 121.4 a year ago. That means goods costing $121.40 in February 1991 would have cost $121.90 last month.

HEADLINE: As Economy Goes Bust, Barter Is Booming

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRADLEY BEACH, N.J., March 11

 BODY:
When Chris Hansen inspected the shoals of fresh fish laid out on crushed ice in the S & S Seafood store the other day and decided to buy $19 worth of yellowtail flounder fillets and glistening sea scallops, he was completing an exercise older than the Babylonian marketplace and as new as today's unemployment figures.
Just 90 minutes earlier Mr. Hansen, who owns an office-machines supply store in nearby Neptune, had sold $100 worth of computer paper and printer ribbon cartridges to Jeff Shields, owner of a brake and muffler shop farther down the New Jersey coast at Point Pleasant. 
 In both transactions, the purchases were paid for with a scrip issued by a barter exchange network that Mr. Hansen, Mr. Shields and the seafood store operator, "Captain" Sid Sobel, belong to, along with some 180 other business, professional and trades people in the south-central part of the state.
Across the nation, industry sources estimate, nearly one-quarter million people have joined some 400 barter exchanges to expand business opportunities and, increasingly, keep the credit wolf away from the door.
 
A Way to Move Inventory
 Paul E. Suplizio, director of the International Reciprocal Trade Association, a Washington group representing the industry, said barter trades now were worth $6 billion a year. He said the industry grew at an average annual rate of 8 percent for much of the 1980's, then spurted to 12 percent in 1990 and 1991 as the economy turned down.
Lois Dale, owner of Barter Advantage in Manhattan, which brings New Yorkers together to swap goods and services, has also noticed the effect of the economy.
"In this recession people are looking for another way of doing business, and joining a barter exchange is helping them preserve cash flow," she said.
And Ray Bastarache, owner of Barter Network Inc. of Milford, Conn., said, "Barter is a great tool to move excess inventory at a time when credit is drying up and consumer confidence is low."
While the concept of barter -- exchanging goods and services of like value -- predates the 28-century-old use of cash, the modern model resembles the old one as much as a $1,000 Halston suit resembles a pair of bib overalls.
The new method does not merely match individuals who have something to swap with each other. Rather, members join an exchange, for fees up to $500, and provide goods or services at full value to any member requesting them, earning credits in the form of scrip or trade checks instead of dollars. These, in turn, can be spent with any of the other participating members. An exchange broker serves as a clearinghouse manager and bookkeeper for the members for a commission that averages about 5 percent per transaction.
 
'Not Exactly Monopoly Money'
 "I've developed a lot of business through barter I wouldn't normally get," said Mr. Shields, the brake and muffler man. "People drive their cars here from all over New Jersey to use their credits. One member was in Florida, and he called me up to do his parents' car."
He said he earned $18,000 in barter credits last year and spent them all, mostly on items for his business, which can be written off as a tax deduction, but also for a new satellite dish, driveway and roof for his home.
"It's not exactly Monopoly money you're playing with," he said, "but I've bought all kinds of unexpected things with credits for work I never expected to get."
Members of the New Jersey network can, if they choose, hire a lawyer, have a wedding catered, order baskets of flowers or holiday gifts, get their driveways paved, their hair cut, their air-conditioners repaired, their carpets replaced, or rent video movies -- all without cash changing hands.
Cash is a word that Chris Christiansen, the broker for the New Jersey exchange, reacts to the way an an environmentalist would reflect on the vanishing rain forest.
"Money is drying up and if my membership had to pay cash out of their pockets for the things they want, they'd have to go without them in this credit crunch," said Mr. Christiansen, 46 years old.
 
A National Network
 His barter exchange, Itex of New Jersey, operates out of his home in the Jersey Shore community of South Belmar. Members pay under $200 to join.
The New Jersey exchange is a unit of the Itex Corporation of Portland, Ore., a national network that operates 63 broker offices across the United States. Twenty-two were added in the past eight months. Mr. Christiansen, who joined Itex seven years ago in Denver, was dispatched to New Jersey in 1989 to take over an ailing exchange run by an independent broker.
"When I got here, the economy was booming and there was no incentive to join a barter network," said Mr. Christiansen. "Things were so good, businessmen and professionals I contacted said they were turning away cash business and had no time to hear me talk about the advantages of barter. It took me a year and a half to sign up my first electrician."
Then the recession hit and soon the same business people were pursuing Mr. Christiansen, and they continue to do so. "I have to turn some of them down," he said. "There's only so many dentists and advertising specialists my other clients in the network can use."
 
A Question of Image
 Along with the increasing popularity of modern barter exchanges came an image, not altogether undeserved, that they were a dodge for those trying to avoid income or sales taxes.
The 1982 Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act conferred new respectability on barter. Under the act, Mr. Suplizio, of the industry association, said, exchanges must report members' names and transactions -- with $1 in trade value reported as $1 in cash value -- to the Internal Revenue Service, just as stockbrokers report their transactions.
In most cases, state and local sales tax on barters and tips are paid in cash.
Most members of exchanges do less than 10 percent of their gross sales in barter, said Bob Meyer, owner and editor of Barter News, an industry quarterly published in Mission Viejo, Calif. He said that figure represented business that probably would not have existed otherwise.
Since expenses like wages and utilities are fixed, and the retail price is not discounted, a $100 "sale" to a barter member may actually represent only $30 in real costs to the provider. But the $100 credit buys $100 worth of goods of services in return, whether it be flounder or computer paper.
"What the recession has done is open up the mind of the small businessman to another way of doing business," said Mr. Meyer.
"The big question is if, after the recession, they're going to find it as exciting an opportunity as they do now."
 
Astrology and Awnings
 In Connecticut, Mr. Bastarache runs one of the largest independent barter exchanges in the country, with 2,200 members, and boasts that he can arrange trades for weddings, births and divorces that do not involve a cent in cash.
His Rolodex also contains the names of a private investigator, an astrologer and a publisher of children's books.
Mr. Christiansen in New Jersey is constantly on the prowl for new clients with services that complement ones already aboard. This week he is searching for an awning supplier and a bicycle repair and rental shop and rejecting queries from builders, beauty parlors and dentists. ("Dentistry is a depressed industry since people feel they can postpone work on their teeth in bad times," he observed.)
More than anything, he said, he hated purging members for infractions like giving other members shoddy service for their trade dollar or overcharging them.
Not so painful was giving the boot to a beauty parlor that on slow afternoons provided male exchange members with services even older than barter economics.
"It took me the longest time to figure out why these guys were getting two $50 haircuts a week," Mr. Christiansen said.

HEADLINE: Senators Compromise on Aid for Israel

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Two Senators overseeing the foreign aid bill have reached a compromise on $10 billion in loan guarantees sought by Israel that would immediately grant $1 billion in guarantees and leave the rest subject to restrictions set by the President on building new settlements in the occupied territories.
Congressional and Administration officials said today that President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d were considering the draft compromise by Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Sen. Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, who are respectively the chairman and ranking minority member of the foreign operations subcommittee. 
 Mr. Baker met today with the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, to discuss the Administration's response.
 
Talks Still Under Way
 According to a senior Administration official, there is still a "significant difference" between the compromise and what the Bush Administration is seeking. The Administration has insisted on either a total freeze on new Israeli settlements in return for the full $10 billion in loan guarantees, or a partial freeze in exchange for a lesser amount of guarantees. It is not clear whether the Administration policy is simply a bargaining position or a firm stance.
The official emphasized that the negotiations were still under way, and various proposals are still being considered the White House.
Israeli officials, who are closely following the legislation, say they are waiting to see the final details of the proposal, and the Administration's response, before their Government reacts. The American-Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israeli lobby, has been encouraging a compromise.
According to Congressional and Administration officials, the draft includes:
*Authorization of $2 billion in loan guarantees for Israel for each of the next five years.
*Disbursement of the first $1 billion in guarantees within 30 days of passage of the legislation. Out of that first $1 billion, $150 million would be deducted as the prorated amount Israel is expected to spend, between the date of enactment of the legislation and the end of the fiscal year, Sept. 30, on new settlement construction in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
This is known in the legislation as the "Leahy deduction," because the Vermont Senator insisted that from each year's gross amount of loan guarantees a sum must be deducted equivalent to what Israel has spent building new settlements. This is to insure that the United States is not directly or indirectly financing such building. The first $1 billion, minus the deduction, would go through immediately and not require Israel to accede to the total freeze in settlements that the President has demanded.
*Disbursement of the second $1 billion in guarantees for 1992, as well as subsequent disbursements of $2 billion a year, could be held up if the President deems the level of settlement building activity "inappropriate."
This language in the draft legislation has been inserted to give the President authorization from Congress to link disbursement of the guarantees to restrictions on the building of settlements.
*Israel would be allowed some "natural growth" in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, even under a total freeze. This means that roads could be built and wells dug -- provided that they are for the general use of both Arabs and Jews.
 
Some Exemptions Allowed
 There are two other building exemptions in the draft. Israel would be allowed to build a certain amount of "security related infrastructure," as well as "scattered dwellings built to accommodate expanded families of those persons living in the territories."
This latter exemption means that a limited number of Israeli families already living in the territories would be allowed to expand their own homes, or build on already developed land, additions to accommodate growing families. This exemption in particular will probably be problematic for the Administration.
With American loan guarantees, Israel could go to private banks and Wall Street and raise the $10 billion at lower than normal interest rates. Israel alone would be responsible for paying back all of the money. The United States Government would have to set aside, however, several hundred million dollars in case of an Israeli default.
Israel has offered to pay that amount, which is fixed by the Office of Management and Budget, provided that it is reasonable. Israel would pay that reserve from the annual $3 billion in economic and military aid it receives from the United States.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Challenger;
Buchanan Sees Foreign Influence in Bush's Camp

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., March 13

 BODY:
As he scratches for votes in Illinois and Michigan, Patrick J. Buchanan is banking on a two elements -- anger and ethnic groups -- to propel his campaign back into political relevancy.
He is playing to anger about Japan's increasingly dominant automotive industry with a commercial that reveals links between some Bush campaign advisers and Japanese lobbying efforts in this country. 
 In the last two days, the challenger, who has so far brushed off suggestions that he bow out, has also continued to hammer the Bush Administration over its economic policies and the President's reneging on his 1988 campaign pledge not to raise taxes.
In Michigan, where the problems of the auto industry have unleashed a wave of economic xenophobia, Mr. Buchanan unleashed the new commercial charging that two advisers to the President and the chairman of the Republican National Committee have been paid agents of foreign interests, including a Japanese trade association.
"Mr. Bush's campaign is virtually a wholly owned subsidiary of Japan Inc.," Mr. Buchanan said at a press conference here. "He has got too many advisers around him or close to him who have interests or linkages to foreign interests and are arguing for these interests, rather than objectively for what is best for the United States."
The commercial asserts that Charles R. Black Jr., a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, was paid $45,000 in 1986 to represent Eitaro Itoyama, a member of the Japanese Parliament.
The commercial also says that James J. Lake, a senior adviser on issues to the campaign, was a lobbyist for the Japan Auto Parts Industry Association. It further says that Richard N. Bond, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was paid $10,000 a month as a lobbyist for the government of Eric Arturo Delvalle, who was President of Panama from 1985 to 1988 when he was deposed by General Manuel Antonio Noriega.
The Bush campaign has acknowledged that the commercial's assertions about the three men are accurate.
While his commercials hack away at the President in Michigan, Mr. Buchanan is using what little time he spends in Illinois to court the ethnic vote, especially Ukranians, Lithuanians and Croatians. Mr. Buchanan reminds these voters that he has championed a number of their causes, like independence for Ukraine, Slovenia and Croatia.
"Mr. Bush could send an army half way around the world -- 500,000 men -- to rescue Kuwait, a little country with an Emir with whom we had no historic ties," Mr. Buchanan told an enthusiastic rally at the Croatian Cultural Center in Chicago Thursday night.
But Mr. Buchanan has been thrown on the defensive by Mr. Bush's latest commercial pointing out that the Republican challenger owns a Mercedes-Benz. At a news conference today, Mr. Buchanan said that the advertisement was factually accurate but refuted its assertion that he called all American cars "lemons." But he admitted that he considered the three Cadillacs that he owned during the 1970's and early 1980's to be of poor quality.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Trailing President Bush badly in the polls and facing renewed pressure to drop out, Patrick J. Buchanan is trying to salvage his candidacy in Michigan. He greeted Jack Miller, a businessman, at Miller's antique Hudson Automobile dealership on a campaign stop yesterday in Ypsilanti. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE HOUSE BANK;
Lawmakers Brace for Storm on Checks

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Dispirited and fearful after voting early this morning to bare the tainted banking records of 355 members and former members of the House of Representatives, the chamber's lawmakers prepared today to place their political fate in the hands of constituents, and hoped for the best.
After a long night of anguished debate and emotional votes, party leaders jockeyed to defend members who had overdrawn their accounts at the House Bank, or to strike the wounded. Lawmakers and members of their staffs said they were rifling through their records to figure out whether they had overdrawn and, if so, by how much. 
 House Democratic leaders caucused to discuss ways to change the discredited House administrative apparatus, but they came up far short of proposals by some in the party to scrap the patronage system and bring in professionals.
Instead, they amended their party's rules to place more control of the House administration in the hands of the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who even many Democrats complained had been slow to react to the affair in the first place. This was a tentative first step to change what both Republicans and Democrats agreed was an antiquated management system that had set few guidelines to keep members out of trouble.
Many members flew home to confess that they had overdrawn their accounts, but few of them appeared to be among the worst offenders: those who consistently overdrew by $5,000 or more.
A resolution approved Thursday night by a vote of 391 to 36 gives the 24 worst offenders -- 19 current and 5 former members -- 10 days to appeal their cases to the House ethics committee before their names are made public.
All the hundreds of other members who wrote even one bad check will be listed within three weeks, and many must now brace for last-minute primary election challenges from politicians trying to ride the rising wave of anti-incumbency.
Compounding the lawmakers' problem is the difficulty they are having figuring out how embarrassed they should be. Because the bank did not send lawmakers overdraft notices, and because it did not note the overdrafts on their regular bank statements, members are now forced to search for red marks on their canceled checks to know which were overdrawn.
 
How Not to Run a Bank
 "I'm on the list somewhere -- I don't know where," said Representative Dan Glickman, a Kansas Democrat who is now sponsoring legislation to appoint a nonpartisan professional House administrator. "We all worry about it. I'm thinking of setting up my own bank now. I've learned a lot about how not to operate one."
The range in Mr. Glickman's tone, from concern to jocularity, reflected much of the confusion that now hovers over a town where politics is a science. Fearful as many lawmakers were about the consequences of the bank affair, leaders as well as backbenchers conceded that it was hard to know whether it would turn out to be a passing storm or instead lead to a voter rebellion against the Democratic-controlled Congress in November.
Representative Gerry Sikorski, a Democrat, went home to his district near Minneapolis and apologized for 671 overdrafts. "All we can do," he said, "is go around and tell it to people and be as open as we can." He added, "We should have known better."
About 60 House members had already acknowledged in recent months that they had written checks against insufficient funds. Dozens more have joined them in the last couple of days.
House Republicans, spurred by a group of freshmen known as the Gang of Seven, want to push the House ethics panel, the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, to extend its earlier investigation and look into whether any of those who overdrew their accounts used the money to finance their campaigns. At the very least, the Republicans say, such check writers should be punished for not filing amendments to their financial statements disclosing what were in effect interest-free loans.
"As painful as last night's debate and votes were," said Representative Frank Riggs of California, one of the seven junior insurgents, "it was only the first phase of a two-phased healing process, a complete Congressional catharsis."
The perceived need for reform will undoubtedly be reinforced by the disclosure today that Jack Russ, the House sergeant-at-arms, who was in charge of the bank and unexpectedly resigned on Thursday night, had told friends that Mr. Foley had promised him an interim job to insure that he did not lose his pension.
But some conservative commentators worried that the affair could feed anti-Washington sentiment that has weakened President Bush, a prospect that is driving some Democrats to suggest that they ought to call on the President, Vice President Dan Quayle and former House members who are now in the Cabinet to disclose their old House Bank records.
The conventional wisdom is that the Republicans stand to gain the most from the affair because 60 percent of the House members are Democrats and the House Bank was managed by officials chosen by the Democratic caucus.
Among the first to publicly acknowledge a problem was Representative Duncan Hunter of California, the chairman of the House Republican Research Committee, who admitted that he had overdrawn his account on more than 160 occasions.
About 1 o'clock this morning, just before the final rounds of voting, the House witnessed one of the harshest attacks on the floor in recent history. The speaker was Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, who said the Democrats had tried to cover up the affair.
He suggested, without offering proof, that Mr. Russ's interim replacement, Werner W. Brandt, "may have been involved in actions stopping Capitol police from investigating cocaine selling in the post office."
"Tonight," said Mr. Gingrich, whose emotions seemed to be fueled by the hisses of Democratic members, "we have a post office cocaine-selling scandal, a House banking scandal, and other scandals are coming -- and those who are responsible hiss."
After Mr. Gingrich's speech, the House voted unanimously to list all members who had overdrawn their accounts, as well as the number of overdrafts by each.
It then voted in favor of a proposal to disclose even more: the amounts overdrawn and the length of time overdrawn. But members of the ethics committee argued that this added information would take months to compile and would therefore probably be disclosed just before Election Day this November. The House then reversed itself on this latter proposal.
The affair reverberated across the nation. The Atlanta Constitution, for instance, published an article at the top of its front page under a headline that said, "Check flap hits more Georgia reps," in which local lawmakers made "damaging admissions." One, Representative Charles Hatcher, a Democrat, said he had overdrawn his account 780 times over 39 months.
Democratic leaders tried to make the best of a bad situation by changing granting Speaker Foley sole authority to nominate administrative officers of the House, a power now reserved for the entire Democratic caucus.
Mr. Foley said today that he hoped Congress could soon return to its work to improve the economy and health care. He predicted that "you won't see many" House members defeated in November because of the bank affair.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Debate;
Candidates Battle for Right to Call Themselves Friend of Middle Class

BYLINE: GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Mar. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas tonight accused Paul E. Tsongas of trying to "pound these middle-class and lower middle-class people into the dirt" by suggesting that some Medicare benefits could be limited in the future and that a middle-income tax cut was unnecessary.
In an hourlong debate broadcast by the local CBS affiliates here and in Detroit tonight, the Presidential Democratic candidates brought their attack advertising strategies to live television, but in an exchange that often descended into mere squabbling rather than confrontation. 
 "Imagine when there were six of us," Mr. Tsongas observed at one point.
For Mr. Tsongas and Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California, the task was to tar Mr. Clinton, who enjoys advantages in organization and money-raising that were only enhanced by a string of Southern victories earlier this week in which he amassed more than 500 convention delegates in a single night.
 
Tsongas Attacks Clinton
 For Mr. Clinton, the strategy was to cast himself as the only true friend of the working class, an assertion Mr. Tsongas sought to tear down by saying that Mr. Clinton has made too many promises and provided too few practical ways to pay for it.
The former Massachusetts Senator said that Mr. Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas proved that he had only raised taxes and been unable to improve the lot of citizens in his home state during the 11 years he had served as its chief executive.
"In terms of the taxes in Arkansas, the taxes that were raised were on gasoline, mobile homes, groceries," Mr. Tsongas said. "So the argument that we're protecting the poor doesn't wash."
 
Brown Touts Tax Proposal
 He called Mr. Clinton's proposal to reduce taxes for the middle class the Democrat Party's "own version of voodoo economics."
"At some point there has to be discipline in this system so we bring down the deficit," Mr. Tsongas said.
For his part, Mr. Brown said his proposal for a 13 percent flat tax would simplify the tax code and eliminate what he called the "banquet feast of corruption" that grows out of complicated tax laws.
"You can give people training and targeted investments to business and all the education you want until the cows come home," Mr. Brown said. Working people, he said, need power.
Mr. Tsongas also questioned Mr. Clinton's position on the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Clinton has said he supported the use of force against Iraq, but he has also said that he favored keeping sanctions in place longer.
The candidates competed for the right to name themselves the friend of the working class in a debate that was televised in two states that have borne much of the brunt of declining job growth in manufacturing industries.
But they also lost little opportunity to repeat their criticisms of each other at every turn by taking charge of a debate format that was designed to allow them to question each other. Mr. Clinton, for instance, asked Mr. Brown at one point if he felt a nickel-a-gallon gasoline tax that Mr. Tsongas has proposed would be the best way to end dependence on foreign oil.
"Who is that question for?" Mr. Tsongas interjected sardonically.
Mr. Tsongas took his veiled swipes as well, on one occasion saying that he is running for President for a "purpose," not for "ambition," as he has criticized Mr. Clinton for in the past.

HEADLINE: THE HOUSE BANK;
Of Checks and Balances And the Angry Voters

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 13

 BODY:
Checkbook in hand, JoAnne Squibb rushed to the bank this morning, determined to cover an account that sometimes falls out of balance. She had been reminded of her own precarious financial situation by the morning news, which was full of talk about how nearly 75 percent of the representatives in Congress had overdrawn checks in the House bank.
The more she thought about it, waiting in line at the bank, the angrier she got. "If those people in Congress can't manage their own personal money, how are they supposed to manage ours?" Ms. Squibb, a Seattle hotel worker, asked. 
 Attacking Congress is a sport as old as American democracy. But the check-kiting scandal, and disclosures that are bound to follow the decision to identify all members who had checking overdrafts in the House banking system, is expected to bring a bruising new intensity to a national pastime.
Signaling the dawn of a new political reality this election year, Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa, said on Thursday, "As of today, your talk show hosts have a topic, your opponents have an issue and your constituents have a reason to support term limits."
 
A Lack of Trust
 Even people professing to care not a whit about politics were talking today in the home state of the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, about the furor in the other Washington.
"I don't have a lot of trust in politicians and this just reinforces my view," said Tom Watson, sipping coffee this morning in downtown Seattle.
Asked whether the radio talk programs, which have helped whip up public anger about Congressional raises as well as the overdrawn checks, were making too much of the recent controversy, Mr. Watson said, "I think they should make a big deal out of it because it has to do with the integrity of the individual."
Mr. Foley, who put his own prestige and that of Congress on the line when he campaigned against term limits in this state last fall -- he was credited with helping to sway the electorate against the measure -- has long been held in high regard in his home state. But the check-overdraft problems have changed some views of him. Mr. Foley has admitted, along with other Congressional leaders, that he had at least one overdraft.
"The fact that he bounced checks has changed my mind about him," Patrick Momany, who owns a small tool-cutting manufacturing company, said of Mr. Foley. "I think we should fire all those guys!"
The explanations from some Congress members brought reactions from laughter to anger.
"It's hilarious; you had this one guy saying it was O.K. because every time he did it, he gave money to charity," said Mr. Watson, referring to Representative Duncan Hunter, a California Republican. "Actually, I admire some of them because they said, 'I'm guilty. Throw the book at me.' "
The amount of money at issue did not seem to bother many people.
"Look, anybody in public life is an easy target, so I don't want to take a cheap shot," said John Peterson, who sells, and sometimes hurls, salmon from his stall in the Pike Place Market. "But check-bouncing is illegal. I run a retail business. I'm familiar with the vagaries of bouncing checks. It's not the money; it's the level of honor."
His assistant, Ron Akrish, said this was the first he had heard of the check problems in Congress. Expressing wide-eyed astonishment, he asked: "Are you serious? They purposely bounced checks? Congressmen? That's criminal!"
In fact, it is doubtful that what went on in Congress was criminal. Members of Congress, in effect, had free overdraft privileges; they could overdraw their accounts and the House bank would cover the checks, without charge, because the money was available from other members' accounts. But critics say at the very least those who overdrew should have paid interest on the outstanding money, and perhaps should have reported it to the Internal Revenue Service.
This state, which became the focus of the term limits movement last fall when voters turned down a ballot question that would have thrown out the entire Congressional delegation, has had more than its share of news about the lost honor of politicians.
Less than two weeks ago, Senator Brock Adams, a Seattle Democrat, announced he would give up his campaign for re-election after The Seattle Times reported that eight unnamed women had accused him of sexual misconduct over a 15-year period.
Still, it is unclear whether larger national issues like health care or the economy will matter more in November than a politician's poor personal banking history.
"I voted against term limits in November, but this check-bouncing scandal is tempting me to change my view," said James Galvin of Seattle.
"I don't care about sex or checks," said Janet Wainwright, a movie promoter. "I care about whether they are going to deal with the real issues. I've written a few bad checks of my own, and I can think of worse things to do."
It is when people relate their own checking problems to those of the members of Congress that they seem to become most angry.
 
'What Bothers Me'
 "When I've bounced a check, it's been an accident, not deliberate," said Ms. Squibb. "What bothers me is that they did this knowingly."
It does not matter, said many people interviewed here, whether public or private funds were involved.
"It may be their money, but who covers the kite?" said Mr. Galvin. "Where do they get the money for the overdrafts? This is an abuse of a convenience, yes, but it's also a betrayal of the public trust."
Melissa Meier, an illustrator, said: "Indirectly, it's my money they're playing with. After all, who pays Congress? Taxpayers do. I don't get it. If the I.R.S. holds me to responsible finances, and my bank holds me to responsible banking, then my elected Congressman should at least do the same."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
A Tough-Talking Bush Visits a Hard-Hit State

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., March 13

 BODY:
President Bush campaigned across Michigan like a tightrope walker today, balancing expressions of concern for the faltering economy with tough talk about his critics and the recovery that he says is just around the corner.
Sweeping into the state for a five-hour visit, Mr. Bush was at his most partisan in accusing Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, of telling a "bald-faced lie" by suggesting that the Bush Administration might have influenced General Motors' decision not to close a Texas automobile plant and close one instead in nearby Willow Run, Mich. 
 He condemned Congress for barely giving his economic recovery program a "glance" and added that he recognized that Michigan was going through "hard times." The President said, "I came here for that very reason, to look you in the eye and tell you what we are going to do to turn this economy around."
 
No Talk of Sacrifice
 As he said this, Mr. Bush was looking at the members of the Economic Club, a pin-striped business group, rather than the automobile workers who have been hardest hit by the faltering economy in Michigan and who have been so assiduously courted by the Democrats who visited here on Thursday.
Mr. Bush paid one visit to a workplace in Michigan in advance of next Tuesday's primary -- a successful hospital-equipment manufacturer in Kalamazoo, where the unemployment rate is well lower than Michigan's overall 9 percent. And he carefully avoided any talk of sacrifice or belt-tightening.
"All we seem to hear on the news is gloom and doom," Mr. Bush told the business group, which received him warmly. "But let's not overlook some of the fundamentals that indicate we are poised, not there yet, but poised for an economic recovery."
Mr. Bush continued bringing some gesture of executive authority to his campaign stops. He told the Economic Club that his Administration would not require auto makers to install gasoline vapor-collecting canisters on new cars and that he would veto any legislation raising fuel-efficiency standards.
And during his visit to the Stryker Corporation, which makes stretchers, beds for intensive-care wards and other medical equipment, he took a gentle, veiled swipe at David A. Kessler, the head of the Food and Drug Administration. Mr. Kessler has angered the medical industry by curtailing the use of silicone breast implants and announcing that he was reviewing the safety records of other medical devices that were put on the market before 1976.
 
Looking Ahead Only
 Using language suggested to the White House by the medical industry, Mr. Bush said: "We've got to get the life-saving drugs and devices to those who need them. Regulation of the healing arts and health technologies have got to respond to patients' needs and must be based on sound science, not on ideological politics or scare tactics."
The President's campaignreflected the careful line he has been forced to tread between the politically necessary recognition that the economy is suffering and his desire to focus the political debate on what he plans to do about it, not on what has happened to American workers during his Administration.
Painting Mr. Bush as the candidate of strength and optimism and his Democratic, and Republican, opponents as the candidates of "gloom and doom" is also a central part of the President's re-election strategy.
So, in his upbeat speech today to the Economic Club, Mr. Bush said, "There's no sense pretending that things are better than they are, but there also is no sense underestimating our strengths and exaggerating our weaknesses."
Mr. Bush's visit here was aimed at keeping Patrick J. Buchanan's showing on Tuesday as low as possible in a state that the Bush campaign fears is ripe for the conservative challenger's message of protest.
The Bush campaign is only just starting to set its sights on Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the leading Democratic candidate, and Mr. Bush plans to go to Mr. Clinton's home state of Arkansas, the only state he has yet to visit as President, on Tuesday, reportedly to call on Sam M. Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart Stores.
But Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, insisted the trip, had "nothing to do with politics."
Mr. Bush's visit to the Stryker plant seemed designed in every way to accentuate the positive.
The President spoke from a stage that had been set up in front of racks on which shipping crates had been arranged as a backdrop -- each of them stamped "export" and some of them bound for Japan.
To bolster his argument that American companies can compete in the international marketplace with aggressive management and that the tougher trade barriers advocated by Mr. Buchanan are not necessary, the President said that Stryker is "the number-one seller of artificial hips in Japan."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Numbers alone cannot explain the interest in the turmoil within the Christian Science Church. One peculiarity of the church is its prohibition against giving membership figures, but the estimated total of 150,000 to 170,000 ranks Christian Science below the International Church of the Foursquare Gospel and the Coptic Orthodox Church. There are more Roman Catholics in North Dakota than Christian Scientists in the United States.
But Christian Science is a faith whose current financial and spiritual travails overlap with those of many other religious groups. It is also a native American species, a distinct contribution to the world's religions. It is a belief that at one moment seems respectable almost to the point of colorlessness, and at the next moment seems wildly unconventional, almost to the point of dangerousness. 
 A faith whose "discoverer and founder" is always referred to as "Mrs. Eddy" can never mask its genteel face. No doubt Mary Baker Eddy was at least partly the invalided Victorian author whose occasionally muddled metaphysical prose Mark Twain gleefully satirized. But she was also a rebel against Puritanism, yet one whose relentless pursuit of religious truth and organization of a new church demanded a good deal of Puritan iron.
Struggling to reconcile human suffering with her belief in a loving and sovereign divinity, Mrs. Eddy concluded that the material world of the senses is not God's creation. It is, instead, a tragic misperception blocking access to spiritual reality.
It is not surprising that most of her countrymen found Mrs. Eddy's solution to the problem of evil unconvincing. Unfortunately, they also accused her of sweeping aside the power of sin and disease with the broom of mental suggestion or mere willpower.
In fact, Mrs. Eddy's desire to restore bodily healing to a central place in Christianity, far from a doctrine of childish faith or positive thinking, was only part of a larger call to seek redemption from sinfulness and the illusion of material life through constant prayer and self-renunciation.
Christian Science at its best fosters a life of discipleship that other faiths can immediately recognize. And even believers who strongly reject Mrs. Eddy's basic premise about the ultimate unreality of matter can detect in it the common religious conviction that the world people see and touch is not the sum total of things.
All this would be reason enough to take an interest in the fate of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston, the world headquarters and Mother Church of Christian Science. Having started a series of expensive television and publishing ventures, the Mother Church now faces a financial crisis and accusations that it has been sacrificing religious integrity for media power.
The question of the red ink in Boston is linked to the much more profound question of how an aging, shrinking church can regain its vitality. That is a question being asked these days by churches many times the size of the Christian Scientists.
To the current Christian Science leadership, which remains in command despite this week's shuffling of posts, huge investments in a Boston television station, a 24-hour cable channel, a nightly news broadcast, an international shortwave system and a slick new monthly magazine were more than up-to-date extensions of The Christian Science Monitor, the church's highly respected newspaper. They were also ways to shake the church from its doldrums and let more people know of Christian Science's concern with the world's problems.
But can a religious body be reinvigorated by new programs and organizational measures?
To some distinguished Christian Scientists, the church's new media empire was the religious equivalent of junk bonds. They objected not only that it was financially imprudent but, more important, that it also was a distraction from a spiritual renewal -- a return in prayer, study and discussion to the sources of their faith in the Bible and Mrs. Eddy's writings.
The leadership and the critics are divided by two other questions that haunt many religious groups. First, is religious renewal likely to be achieved by emphasizing what is distinctive in a tradition, or by emphasizing the broad concerns the tradition shares with all humanity?
Second, does renewal require open discussion and robust self-examination within a religious body? The leadership of the Mother Church has repeatedly declared its devotion to a healthy multiplicity of opinions, even citing that to justify publishing a book that was rejected as heretical in the years before its publication was linked to a $98 million legacy to the church.
A very different impression is given by the honor roll of distinguished and loyal Christian Science editors and thinkers who have felt compelled to leave the Mother Church's employment or who have been forced out. But they, too, have not yet had to confront the fact that a genuine return to the sources of Christian Science may raise uncomfortable questions about Mrs. Eddy's metaphysics and the highly centralized church structure she erected.
This raises a final question: How much assertiveness is required for religious renewal, and how much is incompatible with it? A church whose authority is constantly assailed is not apt to flourish; neither is a church where all criticism must be veiled. Christian Science has tended to shun confrontation, trusting that things will eventually be set right by yielding to Divine Mind.
It is precisely the marketplace assertiveness of the church's new media enterprises that has led Christian Science critics to question their spiritual authenticity. But the critics, too, have had to assert themselves in uncharacteristic ways -- through simultaneous resignations, subterranean communication and statements to the press.
There can never be an exact recipe for religious renewal, but at least some of the ingredients are being tested within the ranks of Christian Science.

HEADLINE: Modest Inflation Report No Help for Bonds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A report that showed only a small increase in inflation was ultimately ignored by credit market participants yesterday, as traders sold Treasury securities and interest rates moved higher.
Prices of notes and bonds rose sharply immediately after the Government announced that its Producer Price Index rose by a modest two-tenths of a percent last month, and only one-tenth of a percent when volatile energy and food prices were excluded. 
 But the gains, which amounted to as much as 3/4 point on some securities, could not be sustained, as sellers emerged at the higher price levels. Selling of short- to intermediate-term notes was particularly heavy.
Rather than focus on the good inflation news, memories of strong January and February retail sales figures reported on Thursday continued to linger. And preliminary results of a University of Michigan survey reinforced the notion that economic recovery is under way.
 
Consumer Confidence Up
 The survey, taken at midmonth, showed that consumer attitudes improved significantly during the first half of March, and that expectations about the future were brighter.
"The market is very paranoid about the recovery, and the data this week have moved people away from thinking about a recovery with 1 percent to 2 percent growth to one with 3 to 4 percent growth," one bond trader said.
A number of analysts said those fears were overblown.
"The fact of the matter is that while the outlook has improved, the recovery is by no means firmly established," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh.
"The rise in short-term interest rates looks awfully premature. And if every positive development on the economy produces another rise in bond yields, we could have an aborted recovery."
Mr. Robertson and others pointed to car sales during early March, reported yesterday at a lackluster six million units, as one early sign that the vigorous spending pattern exhibited in January and February was not continuing in March.
 
Ignoring the Positives
 Market participants, however, failed to react to the auto sales numbers.
"Pessimism is so extreme that we are ignoring some clear-cut positives," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 999/32 , down 10/32 , to yield 8.06 percent, compared with 8.03 percent late Thursday and 7.92 percent on March 6.
Early in the session prices of the benchmark bond rose as high as 1009/32.
Among Treasury note issues outstanding, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 9821/32 , down 21/32 , to yield 7.69 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 9815/32 , down 17/32 , to yield 7.12 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 995/32down 1/4 point, to yield 5.83 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills moved higher.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.04 percent late yesterday, up three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.21 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by eight basis points, to a late rate of 4.54 percent.
Prices of issues outstanding in the investment-grade corporate bond market were dragged down by the slide in Treasury prices. Traders said that prices of most issues fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted securities were unchanged to down 1/8 point, according to market participants.

HEADLINE: Reynolds Plans a New Version of Winston

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
In another effort to revive Winston cigarettes, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company plans an ambitious introduction of a different version of its flagship brand that would be more like Marlboro, which overtook Winston in the 1970's to become America's best-selling cigarette.
Winston Select, as the new version is named, will be available nationally by early May, Peggy Carter, a spokeswoman for Reynolds in Winston-Salem, N.C., said yesterday. It is part of broad efforts by Reynolds, the nation's second-largest tobacco company behind Philip Morris, the maker of Marlboro, to reverse declining sales of its familiar brands. 
 Winston Select will taste different from existing Winston varieties, Ms. Carter said, offering what she described as "a smoother, rich flavor."
 
Appeal to Marlboro Smokers
 Winston's taste, she added, "is not as competitive with Marlboro as we'd like." In tests, Winston Select's taste had "a very high appeal to Marlboro smokers," she said.
Attempting to duplicate the appealing features of successful competitive products is a familiar strategy in consumer marketing. Sprite, for instance, the Coca-Cola Company's version of 7-Up, now outsells its rival.
Emanuel Goldman, a tobacco industry analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in San Francisco, termed the decision by Reynolds to call its Marlboro-type Winston by another name "the smart way to do it."
"If it works, terrific; if not, it hasn't damaged the flagship Winston brand," he said.
 
'Full Flavor' Category
 Winston Select will differ from most other new cigarettes in two significant ways. It will compete in the "full flavor" category, which has been shrinking as consumers switch to low-tar, low-nicotine brands. Yet that category remains important because it includes Marlboro, which outsells Winston, the country's No. 2 brand, by almost 3 to 1.
The other difference is that Winston Select will cost the same as Winston and Marlboro. By contrast, many new brands are priced lower to appeal to recession-squeezed consumers. But premium-priced brands produce more profits; hence, the efforts to enhance them.
In an interesting twist, Winston Select will be introduced by Trone Advertising in Greensboro, N.C., a small agency that Reynolds uses for special projects, rather than by FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York, the regular Winston agency.
Ms. Carter said Trone would handle Winston Select "for the introductory period, at least," adding that FCB/Leber Katz would continue as Winston's agency of record.
 
Arrival of Joe Camel
 Trone is best known for introducing to American smokers in 1988 the now-controversial Joe Camel cartoon character for Reynolds's Camel cigarettes.
Winston Select is the second effort by Reynolds to jump-start Winston sales in less than a year, following the introduction of new packaging, called Flavor Seal, that is designed to keep cigarettes fresher longer.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Japan's Growth In Savings Falls

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 13

 BODY:
Japan's growth in savings fell to a record low 6.5 percent in 1991, the Government reported today, fueling anxiety that the foundation of the postwar economic boom was eroding.
The Bank of Japan said it was the second consecutive year for a record low savings growth. In 1990, savings grew by 7.7 percent. 
 Fears are now mounting that lower savings will constrain investment needed for future economic growth.
Japan traditionally has had a much higher savings rate -- personal savings as a percentage of disposable income -- than the United States. Its rate now is about 15 percent, compared with the United States, savings rate of 5.3 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed As Traders Adjust Holdings

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was narrowly mixed against other major currencies yesterday as traders shrugged off an upbeat inflation report and spent the session adjusting their holdings before the weekend.
Gold also fell marginally, slipping 70 cents, to $346.70 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $346.75, off 35 cents from Thursday. 
 In the currency market, there was little reaction to the Government's report that wholesale prices rose two-tenths of a percent in February.
"Basically the dollar didn't trade today," said Walter Simon, a vice president with Bank Julius Baer & Company.
It is common on a Friday for traders to consolidate their positions as a hedge against any weekend news developments that might move financial markets.
Ronald Holzer, vice president and chief trader at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said the foreign exchange markets had been moved by events affecting other currencies rather than sentiment about the dollar.
The British pound has fallen in recent sessions in response to opinion polls indicating the opposition Labor Party might win next month's national elections, Mr. Holzer said.
The pound slipped against the dollar in New York yesterday, dropping to $1.7085 from Thursday's $1.7140. In London, sterling rose to $1.7120 from $1.7085.
The Japanese yen, meanwhile, has fallen amid growing signs of weakness in the Japanese economy and continuing declines in the Tokyo stock market. Yesterday, however, the yen was somewhat higher, strengthened in part by the Government's budget agreement for the 1992 fiscal year, Mr. Simon said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Airlines Halt Fare Increase

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 13

 BODY:
A plan to raise air fares 2 percent on excursion tickets Saturday has been rescinded.
American Airlines, Continental Airlines, Northwest Airlines, Delta Air Lines and USAir all said today that they would not go ahead with the increase. United Airlines also reportedly canceled its plan to increase fares but company officials were not available to comment. 
 "It reflects the competitive nature of the industry," Robert Decker, analyst with Duff & Phelps said. "It shows there are a couple of carriers that felt nervous enough about traffic levels that they don't want to rock the boat."
America West and Trans World Airlines, both operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, refused to increase fares for leisure and vacation travelers, and the other carriers finally canceled their own plans.
United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, originally proposed a 2 percent increase for all fares on March 3, but other airlines didnt want to increase business fares during a period of economic weakness.
The airlines then decided to raise only the excursion fare, delaying the actual date several times before finally deciding not to carry out the plan at all.
