HEADLINE: Brazil's Pristine Playground

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is head of the Rio de Janeiro bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
PAMPERED by the luxury of choosing among 4,600 miles of South Atlantic coastline, Brazilian beach connoisseurs increasingly choose Praia do Forte, a pastoral, seven-mile stretch of white sand, blue water and coconut palms.
While much of Brazil's coast rapidly succumbs to American-style strip development, this fishing village 800 miles north of Rio de Janeiro survives undisturbed, cocooned in a national park and protected by tough zoning laws. In addition to the primeval pleasure of walking for half an hour without crossing a single footprint in the sand, Praia do Forte offers comfortable lodging, excellent seafood and some intriguing birds, sea turtles and other wildlife. 
 At the foot of the village's beachfront lighthouse, turtle observation tanks and a museum display the work of Tamar, the world's largest project to conserve endangered sea turtles. Half a mile inland, the Sapiranga Ecological Reserve enshrines one of Brazil's last stands of primary Atlantic rain forest. And high on a nearby bluff, brooding stone arches and cannon-shaped water spouts recall an era when a 16th-century Portuguese castle here ruled over a private domain five times the size of New England.
The magnet of Praia do Forte draws an elite mix, as the Rio newspaper O Globo recently gushed, "Environmentalists, models, surfers, politicians, and movie and television stars.".
It is only beginning to crop up in American guidebooks on Brazil, but access for Americans is increasingly easy. Every Monday afternoon, Varig flies from Miami to Salvador. By arrangement, a minivan can shuttle visitors from the airport to Praia do Forte, 30 miles north on the newly paved Estrada do Coco, or Coconut Road.
My wife, Elizabeth, and I visited in September, a time when the Southern Hemisphere's winter rains disappear until the beginning of March. But in this languorous corner of the world, "winter" and "summer" have little meaning -- climate tables show that year round temperatures rarely dip below 70 degrees and rarely rise above 84 degrees. During the rainy "winter" months, March through August, the water here loses its smooth, azure quality and appears choppy and green. But swimming and sunning are year-round attractions.
The drive north made us appreciate the tranquil refuge that Praia do Forte has become. A divided highway at first, the road passes supermarkets and a petrochemical complex. Later a ribbon of asphalt, it passes vacation home developments, billboards beckoning weekenders and Brazil's equivalent of fast-food stands.
The state road ends abruptly at the southern edge of the wildlife reserve. At a right angle, an inauspicious, potholed dirt road continues one mile to Praia do Forte. Despite the tourist boom on Brazil's coast, this fishing village remains an intimate hamlet of sandy streets and low cottages with red-tiled roofs. On one afternoon, the only sounds were slapping dominoes played by two old men under the shade of a huge fig tree and the clopping of hoofs of a horse wandering riderless down the main street.
The pastoral atmosphere is no accident.
"Our slogan is: enjoy, don't destroy," said W. H. Klaus Peters, the German-Brazilian mastermind of the resort area, in a conversation in his office at the the Praia do Forte Resort Hotel, the largest of the village's nine hotels and inns.
In the 1960's Mr. Peters built a hotel in Sao Sebastiao, then a sleepy colonial port on the coast of Sao Paulo State. Soon after the hotel opened for business, Brazil's state oil company decided that Sao Sebastiao would be a good site for an oil tanker terminal.
Burned once, Mr. Peters, a Sao Paulo factory owner, thought big when he tried again. In 1972, well before ecotourism was an international byword, Mr. Peters and his brother, Manfred, bought a 25,000-acre coconut plantation that fronted on seven and a half miles of beach. The purchase gave him title to the fishing village of Praia, the castle ruins and the rain forest.
He created a foundation to administer the castle and turned the forest into a reserve administered by Brazil's federal environmental agency. The village's land title he donated to its inhabitants, but only after the municipality, Mata de Sao Joao, adopted in 1989 a series of strict zoning regulations -- a rarity for Latin America.
WITHIN the village of 3,000 inhabitants, buildings are limited to two stories and must be constructed of traditional native materials, such as roofing of colonial tiles or piassava palm fronds. No streets can be paved. No walls can be erected -- only fences. To prevent the kind of real estate speculation that has expelled fishing families from many of Brazil's coastal resorts, outsiders cannot buy village houses. Instead, houses can only be passed down within families. Although the village is open to the public, a police post placed squarely at the entrance discourages squatters and pickpockets schooled in the hard ways of Salvador, a city of 2.5 million people 50 miles to the south.
"Praia do Forte is one of Brazil's last authentic fishermen's villages," Mr. Peters said. "You can dance lambada in the village wearing a gold Rolex and nothing will happen to you."
Outside village limits, construction of vacation homes is limited to two stories, to traditional materials and to Mr. Peters's personal approval. Homeowners are required to plant four coconut palm trees for each one they cut down.
In another conservation effort, Mr. Peters encouraged Brazilian environmentalists to establish here, in 1980, the headquarters of the national turtle conservation project, Tamar, an acronym for tartarugas marinhas, or sea turtles in Portuguese. The richest nesting area along Brazil's coast, Praia do Forte is visited every October by hundreds of female sea turtles, which lay an average of 50,000 eggs in the sand . At first, Tamar workers had to collect eggs for artificial incubation. But due to a public education campaign and a new economic dependence on ecological tourism, fishermen stopped killing turtles and taking their eggs. Today the sea turtle has become Praia do Forte's symbol, featured on T-shirts and postcards sold in craft boutiques all over town.
Half of the proceeds from the sale of turtle shirts and souvenirs at the Tamar gift shop go to supporting what has become the world's largest sea turtle conservation project. Five of the world's eight sea turtle species swim in Brazilian waters and all are endangered. Tamar workers patrol 620 miles of Brazil's top nesting beaches, and this year they expect to release the one millionth turtle hatchling into the sea. The Tamar complex, accessible from the beach at the foot of the village lighthouse, includes a small museum and water tanks so visitors can observe sea turtles close up.
Turtle soup and turtle omelets long ago disappeared from menus of local restaurants. Instead, the village's half a dozen restaurants specialize in the Afro-Brazilian seafood cooking of Bahia State .
Plucked from the sea in the morning, shrimp, crab and fish end up seasoned with peanuts and palm oil on local plates in the evening. Beverages include passion fruit juice and chilled coconut milk. Restaurants, largely clustered around the Praca dos Artistas, or Artists' Square, include Tropical, Le Gaston, Boca Piu, Bar de Sousa and Bom Bordo.
We ate almost all our meals at our inn, Pousada Praia do Forte. Without the swimming pool and organized water sports of the Resort Hotel, the 18-bungalow Pousada has a low-key charm. Our palm-thatched bungalow, Badejo, came with full bath, king-sized bed and a hammock on the veranda, all 25 feet from the high-water mark on the beach.
Nighttime entertainment can be as simple as listening to the crickets as the moon rises over the South Atlantic. For the more active, several village lambaterias perpetuate the lambada, the popular sensual dance step..
During the day, visitors who start at Praia do Forte's landmark, the white-painted lighthouse, will discover the beach's wild beauty by strolling north. About a quarter mile from the lighthouse are the Papa Gente sea pools. Naturally carved from coral reefs, these two sand-bottomed pools fill chest high at high tide with crystal clear water. Unaided by diving masks or snorkels, waders can watch tropical fish swimming around these natural aquariums.
For the really energetic, a 10-mile hike takes one along isolated beaches to Imbassai. More fishing village than tourist town, Imbassai is accessible only by foot, by boat, or by jeep down a dirt track. Don't try to go by horse. The drays for rent in Praia do Forte proved to be lazy and expensive.
You can order lunch in advance from a 10-room inn at Imbassai, Lagoa da Pedra. To avoid sunburn, or even sunstroke, North American visitors should use sunblock year round and should walk only early in the day or late in the afternoon. Praia do Forte is 12 degrees closer to the Equator than the southernmost tip of Florida.
For a midday excursion, we disappeared into the cool and shaded ecological reserve. The Praia do Forte Resort Hotel provided a guide, who led us down forest trails, stopping to point out flora and fauna, including families of small monkeys, as well as a series of waterfalls where locals set handcrafted conical fish traps. Few guides, indeed few people at Praia do Forte, speak English. Non-Portuguese-speaking visitors may want to forgo the guide and wander on their own with a map sketched by a hotel receptionist.
Across from the road entrance to the Praia do Forte Resort Hotel is a lagoon and wetlands that contain another natural area, the Timeantuba Bird Reserve. Exploring by canoe, the casual naturalist can easily spot alligators, and the trained bird watcher can spot many of the 173 bird species that have been identified in the reserve.
Or one can hike or drive the three miles from the Praia do Forte Resort Hotel to the hilltop ruins of what looks like a fortified medieval manor house.
After Portugal laid claim to Brazil in 1500, the first settlers came to the Salvador area from southern Portugal, a feudal area with a tradition of great estates. In 1549 Salvador became the colonial capital of Brazil, and Tome de Souza became the colonial governor. Knowing about as much about Brazil as we know today about the planet Mars, the Portuguese crown awarded to Garcia d'Avila, the governor's bailiff, an estate that stretched over 308,000 square miles, an area about the size of Britain and France combined.
In 1549 the colonial grandee imported cattle and coconut palms from the Portuguese colony in Goa, India. After surveying his new lands, he started in 1552 to build his castle on a low bluff here, the highest promontory for miles around.
"It is the largest secular stone construction from colonial Brazil," said Mr. Peters. Searches of colonial archives in Portugal and in the Netherlands failed to produce a blueprint or even a drawing of the completed structure. Archeologists do not know if Garcia d'Avila dismantled a castle in Portugal and carried it here, or if he built his castle from ship's ballast stones and locally quarried stone.
Today the ruins rise three stories. The low arches, thick walls and fortified church tower reflect fear of sea attacks from pirates and hostile European powers and land attacks from Tupi-Guarani indians.
For over two centuries, the castle and its vast domains remained in the hand of the Garcia d'Avila family, constituting by the end of the 1700's the largest private property in the world, said Mr. Peters, founder of the Garcia D'Avila Foundation. As late as the 1850's, the stone manor house was occupied.
Slowly, the empire ruled from the mansion dwindled from 129 plantations to the sole Praia do Forte plantation that Mr. Peters owns today.
"It is the oldest plantation in continous use in Brazil," Mr. Peters said, waving toward long lines of coconut palms, some descended from coconuts brought here half a millennium ago from the beaches of Goa.
 
 
 
IF YOU GO
Getting There
 Varig Airlines flies every Monday from Miami to Salvador, Brazil, returning Friday morning. Varig, Cruzeiro, VASP and Transbrasil operate daily nonstop flights to Salvador from Rio de Janeiro. The trip takes two hours and costs $376 round trip. Americans need tourist visas for Brazil.
From Salvador's airport, it is a 45-minute drive down the Coconut Road to Praia do Forte.
Taxi Cometas, a 24-hour service at the airport, offers car service: $64 weekdays and $90 weekends and weekday nights. For a cheaper alternative, contact Deborah Scott Leitsch, the English-speaking manager of Odara Turismo, to arrange a van pickup; telephone (71) 86-1080.
For one to three passengers, the van costs $47 on weekdays; $60 on weekends and at night. For four to seven passengers, the van costs $60 on weekdays and $70 on weekends and at night.
 
Accommodations
 The principal hotel, Praia do Forte Resort Hotel, (71) 832-2333, has 132 rooms in a two-story building that snakes through a 35-acre, seafront coconut plantation. With the accent on the natural, the resort offers wind surfing, sailing, scuba diving, two tennis courts, two restaurants and four swimming pools.
The March rate for a couple and two children under 12 in the same apartment is $145.
This includes breakfast, taxes and sports activities.
About 300 yards down the beach is a more low-key alternative run by the same owner: Pousada Praia do Forte, (71) 835-1410.
Facing a reef and the open sea, this inn offers 18 private cabins and a restaurant with excellent Afro-Brazilian cuisine. A cabin for two, with breakfast and dinner, is $103 in March. Guests are encouraged to leave their radios and televisions behind.
Another beachfront inn is Pousada Solar da Lua, (71) 876-1029. The inn has 25 rooms and a Japanese restaurant.
 
Eating Out
 In the fishermen's village, restaurants specialize in freshly caught fish prepared in the distinctive Afro-Brazilian style of Bahia: Tropical (876-1009); Boca Piu; Le Gaston (Italian); Bar de Souza and Bom Bordo.
 
Excursions
 Odara Turismo, which has a branch office at the Praia do Forte Resort Hotel, offers half-day and full-day excursions by jeep.
For $20 a person, the three-hour, half-day excursion offers a tour of the castle ruins, a hike through the ecological reserve, a visit to a traditional manioc flour mill and a chance to swim under waterfalls of the Pojuca River.
For $60 a person, the full-day excursion adds an outdoor barbecue and a visit to a remote beach with dune formations.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: West Orange;
Home Builders Step Up Construction

BYLINE: By ALANS S. OSER

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE, N.J.

 BODY:
OTHER builders around New Jersey may differ, but Sam M. Gershwin is betting on a pick-up in the home-buying market. He says the evidence is already in hand. It's nothing dramatic, but it's enough to lead the building company in which he is a partner to accelerate production.
Mr. Gershwin is in charge of a town-house development here called The Highlands at West Essex, in rolling country off Oval Road, near the borough of Essex Fells. It is one of several New Jersey projects of Garden Homes Development of Short Hills. Eventually, there are to be 300 houses on the 65-acre site. 
 "This year there is more confidence among the buying public than than last year," Mr. Gershwin said. "We can tell from the number of people who come in and the way they talk. We're getting 35 to 65 visits per weekend, substantially more than last year."
The Highlands also has had 12 sales since the beginning of the year, which is double what it had by this time last year, Mr. Gershwin said.
What the coming months will show about sales is not certain, but what is striking in this Essex County township is that a sense of confidence has led building organizations with financial strength to step up the pace of construction over last year.
Using financing from its own company funds rather than a construction loan, Garden Homes, a long-established development organization, has started the framing for 35 houses at the Highlands, which are in clusters of 4 to 7 units.
At another location in West Orange, the same building organization has begun construction on 70 additional town houses at a project called Scenic Hill, near the Livingston and Short Hills line. "Even in a bad market last year we sold close to 100 units," said the executive in charge, Walter Oberlander. The development has a construction loan from First Fidelity Bank.
And at a third location in West Orange, another long-time New Jersey builder, Bertram Associates, based in Union, has started 50 town houses at a 271-unit project called Crystal Woods, near an established residential neighborhood off Exit 7 of Route 280.
THE West Orange developments also are notable as an illustration of the spectrum of settings and housing product with which builders seek to attract middle-income buyers to town-house communities. The average price is about $200,000 and the range is from $120,000 to $250,000, but the environmental differences among the locations are perhaps even more substantial than the price differences imply.
At Scenic Hill, units sell for as little as $120,000. Three other models sell between $140,000 and $155,000. In West Orange, this is as close to "affordable" as new housing gets.
The trouble spot for the sellers is unemployment, or the fear of it, by a significant number of possible buyers. "Many people still have a nagging fear of losing their job," said Michael A. Borodinsky, head of the central New Jersey branch office of Arbor National Mortgage Company, in Clark, through which many buyers at new developments have obtained mortgages.
The positive elements are that the interest rates have fallen, making home buying more affordable to a wider income range of buyers, said Mr. Borodinsky, and prices have declined. At The Highlands, prices were shaved by 10 percent on two models last August. Sales picked up.
WEST ORANGE is a township of 39,300 people living in about 11,000 housing units, spread out over 12 square miles. There are five golf courses, one of them public.
Roughly 1,500 condominiums were built in the 80's, says Susan Borg, the director of planning and development. "We have had so much development in condominiums that now we're looking not to approve them," she said. In one case last year, the zoning board refused to renew its approval of a 46-unit project on Pleasant Valley Road that lapsed when the builder failed to start construction.
Those projects already approved and begun are far from completed. At The Highlands, for example, 105 houses have been built and occupied. The current, third phase started a year ago and occupancy began in November. Last year's construction pace was 15 to 20 units, Mr. Gershwin said, compared with the 35 to 40 planned this year.
The architect, the Cahill Partnership, based in Reddington Township, has created four house models. The lowest-priced unit sells for $175,000 and constitutes 40 percent of the project. It offers 1,900 square feet of space plus a garage and basement, and illustrates the builder's effort to capture the young professional buyer, often a single person.
There are also two midpriced models, selling between $201,500 and $238,500, and constituting 55 percent of the units, and a $249,500 ranch model with a two-car garage.
Not surprisingly for a development that has brought housing to a new, exclusive location in the community and was long in the planning and development stage, there was an initial burst of buying. But last year, after a "reasonable" March and April, sales slowed drastically. A pick-up after the price cut in August help push total sales for the year to 30.
ALSO well advanced as part of the current phase of construction is a 5,000-square-foot clubhouse near a small lake built for water detention purposes. The secluded location borders the Essex Fells Country Club and a property called Pleasantdale Farm, which is owned by the Allied Corporation and used as a corporate retreat.
Mr. Gershwin sees nothing of the ebullience buyers showed in the mid-80's, when they might have bought a new home before selling one they already owned. That phenomenon was spurred in part by fears of price increases, which builders played upon to stimulate sales.
One buyer representative of the current attitude is Janice Murray, a district manager for A.T.& T. who is in contract to buy a Highlands unit. She sold her house in Plainsboro before buying, and it took her only four days to do it once she allowed buyers to view it. "I priced it fairly and I made sure it was in good condition," she said. "I let no one in until I was satisfied with its condition."
Garden Homes Development is a 32-year-old building company founded by the Wilf family, which was in the lumber business. In addition to town houses it develops single-family houses and commercial projects and it owns rental apartments as well. The single-family sites include Shackamaxon Estates, in Scotch Plains; Concord Park, in East Hanover, and Jade Meadows in Springfield. Other town-house projects are Castle Ridge, in East Hanover township, and Park Place in Springfield.
Crystal Woods, the Bertram Associates project, also is a project of a long-established building organization, whose president is Larry Pantirer. The architect for Crystal Woods is the Chester Partnership, based in Laurence Harbor.
THE project is planned as 265 town houses and 6 single-family houses on 47 acres, built as groups of 3 to 7 units, with motor courts serving private garages. The units are linked by a 10-foot element that the builder calls a lanai, a porch with enclosed storage space beneath that gives the units spatial separation. Occupancy has begun on the 98-unit first phase. There are three models, priced at $175,000, $185,000 and $210,000.
The effect of lower interest rates as an aid to sales was stressed by Mr. Borodinsky of Arbor National Mortgage. With interest rates at 8 percent for a 30-year loan, for example, a household with $74,000 in income could qualify for a 90 percent mortgage on a unit selling for $180,000, he said. A year ago, with rates at 9 1/2 percent, that household would have needed an income of at least $81,000.

HEADLINE: Talking: Mortgages;
Resolving Errors in Payments

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE makeup of monthly mortgage payments has become so complex in recent years that many borrowers wonder whether their lender is correctly calculating how much of the loan has been paid off.
Some borrowers may be concerned that their principal balance isn't dropping as sharply as it should, given the additional voluntary payments they have made. Or they may wonder why a large repayment of the principal is still due at the end of the term on a 15- or 25-year loan. Others may suspect that the payments due on their adjustable-rate mortgages are not reflecting the full extent of the drop in interest rates over the last year. 
 Peter Helie, president of William Pitt Real Estate of Fairfield County, Conn., was surprised to discover after an investigation in January that he had been overcharged by about $800 in interest on two variable-rate mortgages he was carrying. Even as a professional in the business, he said, "most of the time you tend to pay what you're billed without question."
Still others may worry because their loan was sold to a servicing company in another state and errors may have crept into the bookkeeping as a result. Further, the highly publicized accounts in recent months concerning the overstuffing of tax escrow accounts for tax payments by major companies such as General Mortgage Acceptance Corporation have added to the growing unease among consumers.
The borrowers least likely to be victims of errors are those with fixed-rate mortgages who pay their property taxes directly rather than through the lender, said Richard Roll, president of Mortgage Monitor. Founded early in 1991, with offices in New York City and Norwalk, Conn., the company regularly conducts custom audits on a borrower's behalf.
Those whose payments are regularly adjusted because they have a variable-rate loan and those whose taxes are paid by the lender are more prone to error, he said. The danger increases if the borrower has made voluntary payments to cut the principal balance or if the company servicing the mortgage is changed.
There also is a potential for problems if a variable rate loan carries a negative amortization provision. This feature holds the payments due at the same level even if interest rates rise by tapping paid-off principal to temporarily make up the difference. This is the feature, incidentally, that can lengthen the term of the loan unexpectedly.
There are several ways to get to the root of it all. Borrowers can pay a private service to handle the analysis and negotiate with the lender for any refund due. They can do most of the work themselves with the aid of a printout or a computer program supplied by a financial publisher. Or they can work from something called a "transactional history" normally supplied free by the lender.
Keith Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH Associates of Butler, N.J., a company that monitors mortgage rates nationwide, recommends first contacting whatever company is currently handling monthly payments, even if it is not the one that originated the loan. It should be able to provide a detailed payment history at no charge, he said. Much of this information will be needed even if a private company or a computer program will later be used for an analysis.
In some cases, a complete payments history may not be available. Richard DeLeo, vice president in charge of loan adminstration for Countrywide Funding of Pasadena, Calif., a company that services some 270,000 residential mortgages, said some mortgages taken over midstream arrive at his offices with incomplete files.
If so, Countrywide will try to recreate an accurate history. But if there are discrepancies the burden will be on the borrower to substantiate certain payments -- such as voluntary additions to principal -- through canceled checks. If there genuinely seems to be an error, Countrywide will work with the original lender to sort it all out.
BUT, Mr. DeLeo warned that it is unlikely any servicing company will make good on a shortfall or overpayment charged by a prior company that is now out of business. "We don't take the responsibility for someone else's errors," he said.
People who prefer to do the audit themselves can take this information and any pertinent facts listed on the original loan document -- such as the index to be used for rate adjustments -- and work with computer software to get a handle on what's been going on before challenging the lender.
Banker's Secret of Elizabethville, N.Y., sells for $39.95 a computer program and explanatory manual for this sort of analysis suitable for I.B.M. compatible machines. (Box 78, Elizabethville, N.Y. 12523, or call (800) 255-0899)
Peter Kaufmann, a high school mathematics teacher in New City, N.Y., used the program to track the extent to which he should have shortened the term of a $70,000 mortgage he took out in 1984 on a four-bedroom house. He had been paying an extra $100 a month toward the principal balance for five years. The bank, he said, was unable to help. Since it was an adjustable loan, he said, "it had been very difficult to track." The program showed him he would acually cut the loan term in half if he continued to make the extra payments. "It works wonders," he said.
For $15.95 Banker's Secret also will provide a printout of the full amortization schedule from Day One for anyone with a fixed-rate loan. For example, Michael Frasier of Albany is using a custom-modified schedule of this sort to make sure his bank is correctly crediting his voluntary additional payments. Financial Publishing Company of Boston (phone 1-617-262-4040) offers similar services.
Those who prefer to let a professional handle the audit and analysis should contact a company like Mortgage Monitor -- (800) AUDIT-USA -- or Consumer Loan Advocates of Lake Bluff, Ill. -- (708) 615-0024). With Mortgage Monitor the client can pay either a flat $149 or a contingency fee equal to 35 percent of the overcharge. A further $49 is charged if the company has to get the history itself.
The custom audit determines if all rate adjustments were correct, if the correct level of interest was paid on the escrow balances and if the size of the balance is excessive, if the borrower has paid down the principal to an extent that permits the elimination of private mortgage insurance and if voluntary principal payments were correctly credited.
If errors are found, the company will collect the refund from the lender on the client's behalf and make sure corrections are made.

HEADLINE: Cost of Home-Buying Falls to '74 Levels

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
LAST winter, Lisa and David Osterman toured dozens of homes in and around Princeton, N.J., in search of one to buy. But by spring they threw in the towel and signed a lease for another rental.
"We saw places in our price range," said Mr. Osterman, "but nothing we felt was worth the money." 
 Their decision to wait paid off. Last month, the Ostermans signed a contract to buy a builder's last house in a small development of 9 homes being built in Ewing Township outside Trenton. They will pay $228,000, near the top of their budget, for a 2,700-square-foot, four-bedroom home.
In the last year, the Ostermans' home-buying dollars, like those of thousands of other buyers, have been stretched by a substantial dip in mortgage interest rates, which last month fell to their lowest level in 20 years, and the continued drop in home prices. This double-barreled benefit has not only been a boon to first-time buyers, but, in the New York region, has also nudged some long-absent trade-up buyers back into the market.
"What a difference a year can make," said Mr. Osterman. "We are getting so much more than if we had bought last year. We thought a new home in this area was beyond our $230,000 budget. Better interest rates are helping us afford this house. We are glad we didn't settle for what we could afford last year."
A Mercer County location is important, he said, because the commuting time is about the same to his law office in Newark as it is to his wife's job as a marketing representative of a Virginia-based food company in Philadelphia.
Not since 1974, says the National Association of Home Builders, have homes been as affordable as they are today. Even so, this has not given sales in the New York area or other parts of the country the boost the real estate industry has been yearning for. Industry observers say the lingering effects of a sour economy, the glut of new housing and, most significant of all, fear of the future, are to blame.
From December 1990 to January 1992 interest rates slid by more than 1 percentage point, from 9.84 to about 8.51. Since January, the average rate on a 30-year, fixed-rate loan has bumped up a bit to about 8.8 percent, but mortage money still is much cheaper than it was just a year ago.
Lower rates and lower prices increased the buying power of the typical family by 13 percent from the last quarter of 1990 and the same period in 1991, the National Association of Home Builders has figured. The trade group's calculation was based on the sale prices of 459,476 new and existing homes in 191 markets across the country in that period. John Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, another trade group that tracks home sales and measures affordability, said that the lower prices and interest rates have had a bigger impact in the New York region than in the rest of the country.
"Prices went so high in the 80's," he said, "so the fallback is more dramatic."
Denise Mangini, a sales associate in the Princeton, N.J., office of Audrey Short Realty, who served as the broker for the Ostermans, said the prices for the first homes built in the development where they are buying were in the $230,000 to $260,000 range.
"I believe it was a break for them to be the last buyers in," she said. "The same home would have been priced higher. By waiting, they saved. And they could have gotten the home for $219,000 -- that was the price of the basic, no-frills model."
The features the Ostermans are putting in added about $9,000 to the price.
By delaying their purchase by a year, the Ostermans benefited in another way. After deciding not to buy last year, they found an apartment at $500 a month less than what they had been paying in their previous location. What they save on rent is going toward the down payment fund.
By summer, when the new home is to be ready, they expect to add an additional $6,000 to $7,000 to that fund.
WHILE brokers say that home and apartment prices have retreated to 1985-86 levels, the real bait for trade-up buyers to venture back has been the dip in interest rates.
"These days it usually takes more than lower prices to entice the people who already own homes," said Robert Eychner, president of a Manhattan real estate company that bears his name. "People have been watching prices drop for more than two years now. They are used to it."
Mr. Eychner said that some of the apartment owners who are testing the waters are looking again because they see that the kinds of units they had to pass up during most of the 80's are now drifting into their price range.
"What is different about the current climate is that interest rates have fallen to the point where the cost of borrowing makes a trade-up worthwhile," said Mr. Eychner, "even for those who might have to give up a profit or take a small loss on the sale of the place they own now."
The 1980's are now notorious for having been a decade of double-digit interest rates and soaring prices. But according to the National Association of Realtors, the median resale price of one-family homes in the metropolitan region has been declining steadily since 1989. That year it peaked at $183,600. In the last quarter of 1991, the trade association put a preliminary median cost at $170,800.
At the same time, interest rates have fallen from 10.27 percent on a 30-year, fixed-rate loan in 1989 to the current level of about 8.8 percent on the same type of mortgage.
To afford a home at the 1989 price, the trade association calculated that a buyer would need an annual income of $63,020. During the last quarter of 1991, it took an income of $52,066 to qualify for a mortgage on a median-priced home. The calculation is based on a down payment of 20 percent of the purchase price.
But all this has not made the region a bargain by any means. New York and its suburbs still rank among the most expensive places to buy a home. Only people in California cities like San Diego, San Francisco and Los Angeles are worse off when income and home prices are compared.
In the San Francisco bay area, for example, the National Association of Realtors put the median-priced home at $252,000 and calculated that a buyer would need an income of about $78,000 to purchase it. The median income for the region is about $34,000.
That the gap between income and prices is still an insurmountable hurdle for many households can be seen in the affordability index of the National Association of Realtors. Its calculations say that families in the New York region with the median income of $33,492 earned only 64.3 percent of what it took to buy the median-priced home.
Still, there has been a significant improvement since 1989, when the median income of $30,867 was only 42 percent of the $63,020 needed to buy the median-priced home in the region.
"There is no question that what we have now is an unprecedented opportunity," said Jay Shackford, director of marketing for the National Association of Home Builders. "The reason that we are not seeing more movement is that people are still nervous. They may not be out of a job but they are seeing the giants cut back and they wonder who will be next. Everything is there but buyer confidence."
Buyers with the most leverage in this market are people like Ingrid Johnson, a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, and her husband, Gary Bunton, an investment banker, who bought their condominium apartment in Greenwich Village in the early 1980's, before prices in Manhattan started to soar.
They are close to signing a contract for another Manhattan apartment, which, at 3,000 square feet, is twice the size of the three-bedroom duplex they live in now with their three children.
"We could continue to stay where we are and be comfortable," said Ms. Johnson. "Our daughters are still small and because our apartment is a duplex it seems like more space than if it were on one level."
Their daughters share a bedroom now, Ms. Johnson said, "but we knew the time would come when they would want more privacy and space."
"Interest rates are so good now that we realized if we were going to move there would probably be no better time than now to do it," she added. The last time they checked the market, she said, was about two years ago, just before their third child was born. At the time, she and her husband felt prices were too high to justify a move.
"WE would not have been able to get an apartment that was much bigger than the one we have now," she said. "For a lot more space we would have had to go to the suburbs. We are city people and the commute would not be worth the savings."
The seller of the loft Ms. Johnson and Mr. Bunton plan to buy put his apartment on the market 18 months ago for $1.2 million. The price has been cut several times since then. Mr. Eychner, who is the couple's broker, said they will make a deal at around half the the original asking price.
Ms. Johnson and Mr. Bunton expect to come out ahead with the sale of their Greenwich Village apartment. They plan to ask somewhere in the high $400,000's.
But it has not been only upper-income families who have been able to take advantage of the favorable home-buying climate. Last fall, Danny and Nancy Salgado moved from an apartment in Yonkers into the first home of their own, in Yonkers, after 16 years of marriage.
In their case, it took not only the dramatic change in the home market and the fall in interest rates but also special state programs to make homes more affordable.
Like many families, the Salgados saw their dream of home ownership move beyond their grasp during the 80's.
THEY found that even with two incomes -- Mr. Salgado is a pest-control technician and his wife is an office receptionist -- rent on an apartment large enough for their family of five did not give them much room for putting money aside for a down payment. With a combined income of $43,812, well above the area's median income of $33,492, the Salgados' wages still would not stretch to cover mortgage payments on most homes.
Last year Mrs. Salgado put the family's name in a pool of candidates for an affordable unit in Trinity Court, a new 30-unit townhouse styled complex in Yonkers.
"I had my heart set on buying one of the homes in Trinity Court," said Mrs. Salgado, whose three children are 18-year-old Nancy Lizette, 14-year-old Danny Jr. and 8-year-old Natalie. "But at the same time we were applying for a home there, our daughter was about to start college. Even with the lower price I didn't see how we could make it work."
Their leg-up in the market came in the form of a special low-interest, low- down-payment home-loan program sponsored by the State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sonny Mae. The agency's mortgage programs are designed for people who otherwise would have little chance of buying a home.
The agency issues bonds to generate a pool of money for mortgages, and public and private affordable-housing organizations have been using the low rates and favorable prices to put more middle- and low-income buyers into their first homes. The Salgados' income made them eligible for one of the lower-priced homes in Trinity Court.
The three-bedroom unit they bought would normally sell for $124,500. But a $25,000 grant from the state's Affordable Housing Agency brought the price down to $99,500. The down payment on the Sonny Mae loan from the Bank of New York was 5 percent of the purchase price, or $4,975.
"We have a beautiful home now," said Mr. Salgado, "But the best part of being an owner is that we are building equity instead of just paying rent."

HEADLINE: UConn Team's Success Is Well-Kept Secret

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
EVEN during this mildest of winters, most evenings are chilly on the University of Connecticut campus at Storrs -- cold enough to make watching a hockey game at the outdoor rink a numbing experience. At a time when the UConn men's and women's basketball teams play their home games in a glitzy new arena, the men's hockey team is one of the few college squads still relegated to playing out in the cold.
Despite that handicap the hockey team has enjoyed its best season ever. That will probably come as news to many UConn basketball fans, quite a few of whom may not know that the university even has a hockey team. 
 While students must rely on a lottery to obtain basketball tickets, no tickets are required to watch the Husky hockey team play. The rink's grandstand accommodates about 1,500 fans, but it never comes close to being filled.
After losing three of their first four games, the Huskies (the nickname seems especially appropriate for this hardy breed of athlete) went unbeaten during their next 23 games before losing last weekend to Babson College in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division III tournament at Middlebury College in Vermont. (Though most of its sports program are in Division I, the highest level of competition, UConn is permitted to play some sports, like hockey, on a lower level. These Connecticut teams are not eligible to play in national tournaments.)
Despite its sparkling performance, the hockey team played at home before small crowds that averaged 300 and drew practically no media attention. Where the basketball team often attracts as many as 100 reporters, the hockey team, when playing at home, draws 1, from the student newspaper, The Daily Campus.
Lamar Chance of the UConn sports information office provides coverage of the team for about a dozen newspapers in Connecticut and Massachusetts. "After home games I go back to my office and write a couple of paragraphs and file it by modem," he said. When the team is on the road, the assistant coach, Brian Verrier, phones Mr. Chance with a summary, so he can compile a few papagraphs for the newspapers. Do Mr. Chance's stories always make the papers? "At least a paragraph or two, usually do," he said. "But we got better coverage as the season went on."
Not only was this the team's best season ever, but it was its third winning year in a row, something that happened only twice before since hockey became a varsity sport at Connecticut in 1960-61.
Much of the credit for Connecticut's recent hockey success has gone to Bruce Marshall, the head coach since 1988. Mr. Marshall, 29 years old, a 1985 UConn graduate, played varsity hockey for four years and was co-captain of the 1984-85 team, the first Husky squad to qualify for the E.C.A.C. playoffs.
 
Breaking Five Records
 "Our seniors were freshmen when I took over, and we've been together for four years," said Mr. Marshall, whose first team won only 6 of 27 games. "They've been the catalysts this season."
The chief catalyst has been Bryan Krygier, a senior forward from Bloomfield Hills, Mich., who broke five school scoring records this season. Most of those records had been held by his brother, Todd, Mr. Marshall's teammate at UConn, who now plays for the Washington Capitals of the National Hockey League. Bryan Krygier, who is a co-captain of the team, set records in career and season points, career and season assists and season goals.
"Todd was happy for me when I broke his records," said Mr. Krygier, who transferred to UConn after having spent a year at the University of Illinois at Chicago, which plays in Division I. Todd Krygier attended the Huskies' game against the University of Massachusetts, Boston, when his brother broke his career assists record. When he was taken by the Hartford Whalers in the 1988 supplemental draft, Todd Krygier became the first UConn player to enter the N.H.L. His brother Bryan may become the second. Scouts from a half-dozen N.H.L. teams, including the New York Rangers, have watched him in action this season.
A third Krygier brother, Mike, a UConn junior, finished second to Bryan this season in total points and assists and was third in goals scored.
Asked to compare Todd and Bryan Krygier, Mr. Marshall said: "Todd has great speed and a tremendous shot. Bryan is a great playmaker, with exceptional vision and great decision-making skills."
By producing an N.H.L. player, UConn's hockey program was enhanced, the coach said. "It's nice to be able to tell a prospective recruit that Todd Krygier came out of our program," he said.
Selling UConn hockey to prospective players has not always been easy. The main drawback has been the 31-year-old outdoor rink, which has a roof that looks like an overturned ship's hull. Though it extends downward on the sides, the roof still leaves both ends of the rink exposed. Windblown snow has been a problem during games.
"It is a hindrance in recruiting," Mr. Marshall said. "But then, in recruiting we stress the value of a UConn education. And we tell kids that if they're not going to come here because of the rink, then they're making their decision for the wrong reason."
As for being overshadowed by the men's basketball team, Mr. Marshall said that, if anything, its success has helped the hockey program. "Quite often, when I'm talking with a recruit, they'll say, 'I've seen your basketball team on television,' " the coach said.
Bryan Krygier, who scored 36 goals this season to break the previous record of 34 set by Harry Geary during the 1985-86 season, said he was not bothered by playing home games outdoors. "After a while you get used to it," he said.
Not all visiting players do. Most teams dislike playing at UConn. The warming hut near the rink, which serves as a locker room, has no showers. Visiting players have to go to other campus buildings to shower.
 
More Victories, More Fans
 All of the other rinks where UConn plays have locker rooms and showers. And some, like the one at the United States Military Academy, are downright luxurious. When the Huskies and Army played to a 4-4 tie at West Point late last month, about 2,500 spectators were in attendance.
Still, the home crowds at Storrs have been getting bigger. "Since we've been winning, more fans have been coming out," Bryan Krygier said.
Of the 26 players on the UConn squad, only four are from Connecticut. Fifteen are from Massachusetts, and most of the others are from elsewhere in the Northeast.
"There are some great young hockey players in Connecticut, and we'd like to get more of them," said Mr. Marshall, who scouts high school players in New England, New York and New Jersey.
Mr. Marshall knows that luring players to UConn would be much easier if there were a closed-in rink on campus, he said. UConn's athletic director, Lew Perkins, agreed.
He would like to replace the rink, Mr. Perkins said. "But given our priorities and the state of the economy, I'd be lying to you if I said we were going to do it by next season or the year after. But eventually we'll have to do it."
Mr. Perkins estimated that enclosing the rink and installing locker rooms and restrooms would cost $2 million to $3 million. When that happens, UConn will lose the distinction of having one of the few open-air hockey rinks in American collegiate circles, a distinction the Huskies can live without.

HEADLINE: The State of the Manhattan Commute

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A SALESMAN who is a half-hour late for a power breakfast with his biggest customer, or a lawyer who misses most of her daughter's first piano recital, might find it hard to believe. But the daily journey of New Jersey's half-million commuters to and from Manhattan, transportation experts say, has been improving in terms of congestion and delays.
In part, that reflects some substantial investments by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in ramp repair and track maintenance. More significant, though, is the fact that the ranks of New Jersey commuters have been dwindling of late. Last year, the total number of individual trips under and over the river, most of them by commuters, was 406.6 million, down about 8 million from 1990. 
 "There's a little less congestion on everything," said Richard C. Leone, the Port Authority's chairman, "and that is very noticeable during rush hours. It's probably a byproduct of the recession."
 
Loss of 300,000 Jobs
 Fewer New Jerseyans have jobs to commute to, he suggested. Over the last four years, New York City has lost about 300,000 jobs.
The Manhattan-bound commuting network includes PATH and N.J. Transit trains, the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels, the Weehawken and Hoboken ferries and the George Washington Bridge.
Because the network is so interconnected, a problem in one area often spills over into others. Word of a stalled train sends riders scurrying to their cars; a delay at one tunnel evokes a backup at the other. But a little competition within the network can sometimes help relieve congestion. The success of the two small ferry lines has siphoned off about 13,500 commuters a day who would otherwise be using the tunnels, rails, bridge or PATH.
An experimental electronic toll-collection program for specially equipped buses using the Lincoln Tunnel is proceeding well, the Port Authority says, and is helping the traffic flow. And the $900 million spent to improve PATH's efficiency and the $100 million spent on improving approaches to the George Washington Bridge have helped substantially, Mr. Leone said.
 
Improved Performance
 Even N.J. Transit trains, sometimes criticized for failing to meet their schedules, have achieved a better on-time performance.
The overall satisfaction with the commuting network expressed by transportation officials, however, is not always shared by individual commuters. Random interviews found some people with new complaints -- a Maplewood resident, for example, who observed an increase in PATH delays in recent months, or a Manalapan resident who complained that the N.J. Transit buses had been more crowded lately.
But in general, those interviewed said either that they had seen some slight improvement in their commute or, more often, that they had seen no particular change in the last year.
One common refrain, however, was unhappiness with the increases in fares paid by many New Jersey commuters. The cost of driving a car back and forth across the bridge or through the tunnels, for example, rose by one-third last April. As of July 1990, fares rose on N.J. Transit trains; the cost of a one-month commuter ticket from Edison, for example, jumped from $139 to $171.
For those Manhattan-bound commuters who use the Port Authority bridge and tunnels to get to work, the future is likely to look a great deal like the present. Mr. Leone says he expects no fare increases in the near future.
An N.J. Transit spokesman, Jeff Lamm, would make no such predictions because of uncertainty over the amount of Federal mass-transit funds that will be available in fiscal 1993.
The Port Authority estimates that by 2015, the commuting population will rise by only 15 percent. Long before then, a number of developments should have improved the transportation network's efficiency.
In light of the success of the ferries, the Port Authority is studying preliminary proposals for additional ferries at other points along the waterfront.
The expansion of the electronic toll-taking program at the Lincoln Tunnel to a greater number of buses and possibly to vans and automobiles should help speed the flow of traffic within the next five years, the Port Authority says.
The major change that is apt to occur first, however, involves N.J. Transit, though its impact will also be felt elsewhere in the commuter network. A recently enacted Federal transportation bill provides funds that will allow nearly all N.J. Transit train passengers to take trains heading directly into New York City. Many of these passengers now use PATH.
PATH SYSTEM
The Port Authority Trans Hudson system carries nearly 100,000 passengers a day into the World Trade Center and to stations from Christopher Street to 33d Street.
A network of buses and trains takes commuters to the main PATH stations in Hoboken, Newark and Jersey City. For example, independently operated vans and buses along with state-owned N.J. Transit buses deliver commuters to Newark's Pennsylvania Station and Journal Square in Jersey City, and passengers switch to PATH trains for the last leg of their journey into Manhattan.
Over the last few years PATH ridership has remained relatively constant at about 52 million passenger-trips each year. But in 1991 it fell by about 600,000.
The PATH fare has remained at $1 each way since 1987, and the Port Authority expects no change in the near future.
N.J. TRANSIT

A public transportation service, N.J. Transit is operated by the New Jersey Transit Corporation, a state agency created in 1979. Its 1,800 buses serve 154 routes, and its 642 trains operate on 12 rail lines.
N.J. Transit buses, along with dozens of independent bus operators, use the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee, the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken and the Holland Tunnel in Jersey City to transport nearly 140,000 commuters into Manhattan on an average weekday.
N.J. Transit trains from the south connect with Amtrak's Northeast Corridor and take some commuters directly into Penn Station in Manhattan. N.J. Transit trains from northern and western New Jersey end their runs at the Hoboken Terminal, where passengers change to PATH or commuter ferries.
Between 1990 and 1991, the total number of passenger trips on direct-to-New York trains dropped from about 23,000 to 21,850.
Over the years, fare increases may have played a role. For example, the monthly commuter fare from Metro Park in Edison to Penn Station in Manhattan was $139 in 1988. In 1991 the same monthly ticket cost $171.
Officials of N.J. Transit are concerned that a rail fare increase may be inevitable if Federal transportation operating subsidies -- the staple of most urban mass-transit systems -- are cut, as anticipated, in President Bush's fiscal 1993 budget.
Within the next few years, N.J. Transit officials say, two major developments are in store for their rail commuters. The projects will be paid for with hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal funds earmarked for capital expenditures. One project will connect the Morris and Essex lines with Amtrak's Northeast Corridor at Kearny. That will make it possible for passengers on those lines to commute directly into Manhattan, bypassing the Hoboken Terminal and the PATH system.
In addition, the Secaucus transfer will allow N.J. Transit passengers from the north to switch at a new station in to trains running directly into New York on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor.
GEORGE WASHINGTON
 BRIDGE
Owned and operated by the Port Authority, the bridge was opened to traffic in 1931. It is the only 14-lane suspension bridge in the world.
On an average weekday nearly 200,000 auto and bus passengers pass through the 31 tollbooths on the New Jersey side. The number of passenger trips in 1991 was 151.2 million, down 4.2 million from 1990.
The fare, which includes travel in both directions, was raised from $3 to $4 in April 1991. A 20-ticket book for the bridge can be purchased for $60, a daily saving of $1.
Over the last year the Port Authority has been making extensive repairs on the ramps and approaches leading to both the New Jersey and New York sides of the bridge. Those repairs have taken place largely at night and on weekends, causing few delays for commuters. As much as $100 million has been spent in the last few years on maintenance and upgrading of the bridge.
LINCOLN TUNNEL
The tunnel, which is also owned by the Port Authority, connects Weehawken on the Hudson River waterfront with midtown Manhattan. It consists of three tubes and was completed in May 1957.
More than 72,000 automobile passengers and 114,000 bus passengers use the tunnel each weekday. The total number of trips in 1991 was 133.6 million, down 1.9 million from the previous year.
Automobile tolls were raised last year to $4 for a round trip and $72 for a book of 20 tickets.
The Port Authority has completely refurbished the north tube -- the oldest of the three tubes -- and plans to start work on the south tube sometime this year. The repairs have had little impact on commuter traffic flow, since they have been done almost entirely at night.
Recently, electronic toll collection devices were installed, enabling specially equipped buses to move through the toll plaza without stopping. The program is still experimental, but officials say some form of the technology will probably be in place for cars, trucks and buses within the next five years.
HOLLAND TUNNEL
 Opened to traffic in 1927, the Holland was the first Hudson River vehicular tunnel. More than a mile long, it serves about 56,000 commuters a day traveling between Jersey City and downtown Manhattan. Fares for the Holland Tunnel are the same as for the Lincoln Tunnel.
In 1991, the total number of trips through the Holland Tunnel was 50.2 million, down 300,000 from 1990.
WEEHAWKEN FERRY
The Port Imperial Ferrybus System, owned by Arcorp Properties in Weehawken, has grown rapidly since it began operations in 1987. During the first year of operation the ferry had about 370,000 passenger trips with two Weehawken dockings and two New York dockings, one at 38th Street and the other at the Whitehall Terminal downtown.
By 1991, with four ferries making a combined total of 100 round trips each day, the total number of passengers had grown to more than two million. That also represented an increase of 360,000 over 1990.
Officials of Arcorp Properties say they are now contemplating some additional ferry service as well as improvements to the existing terminals.
The fare for a one-way crossing to 38th Street is $4; for downtown, $5. Midtown fares include free bus service on the New York side to several areas of Manhattan. Monthly tickets can be purchased for $125 to midtown and $140 to downtown.
HOBOKEN FERRY
A joint venture of the Port Authority, Hartz Mountain Industries and Arcorp Properties, the ferry service started in October 1989. The ferry makes about 60 round trips a day between the Hoboken Terminal and Battery Park City near the World Trade Center. Last year there were more than 1.5 million passenger trips, an increase of 400,000 over 1990. The $2 price of a one-way ticket has not changed since the service began.
Another ferry operator, TNT Hydrolines in Atlantic Highlands, carries an average of about 950 passengers a day from two dockings in Monmouth County to the financial district in lower Manhattan.
Fares for the 20-mile, 45-minute trip average $20 for a round trip. Monthly 40-trip ticket books cost $420. By way of comparison, a similar monthly ticket for N.J. Transit into Penn Station would cost about $250, not including the cost of parking at the train station, and the trip would take about an hour and 15 minutes.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: A Reluctant Rejection On Davids Island

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
WHEN the City Council decided last week to sever the contract that gave Xanadu Properties Associates exclusive rights to build a luxury residential colony on Davids Island, the developer had gone as far as he could go, he said, in reducing the density of the project.
"You reach a point where a project cannot be further downsized," said James M. Kozak, a vice president of the Xanadu partnership. "To further reduce the plan's density would be to end up with a scheme that no bank would finance." 
 The city, for its part, had concluded that the $1 billion project would win neither the necessary two-thirds vote of the County Board of Legislators nor approval by the Secretary of State in Albany. So reluctantly, at least for three of five members of the City Council, Xanadu's request for a contract extension was rejected Tuesday night.
Mayor Timothy C. Idoni, who had been in favor of extending Xanadu's exclusive rights for another five years, changed his mind after a six-hour public hearing Monday night. He praised the plan, nevertheless, as a proposal of "exceptional quality" before joining the rest of the Council in rejecting it.
He also said that "environmental concerns have been carefully and thoroughly addressed" by the developers, in what amounted to their third major version of the plan, and that they had produced "real public access" to the island, a sore point that arose when the original plan barred the public.
Mr. Kozak said, "Everyone wanted public access and parks, but no one was giving us abatements."
"There must be a balance between economics and the environment," he said. "Our plan struck that balance, but it was on a razor's edge. If the plan was downgraded any further it would have been no longer feasible."
 
'They Left the Door Open for Us'
 Gordon Marshall, a Xanadu partner, said he was "gratified that they left the door open for us," referring to the Mayor's stated intention to "open the process to new proposals from other developers, including Xanadu." But Mr. Marshall said it would be improper to approach Gail S. Shaffer, the state Secretary of State, "or anyone else, without being the designated developer."
"If the city should reopen the process, we would like to participate," he said. He said his partners had been having discussions with Ms. Shaffer "and felt we were on the right track" when the City Council acted. He said there was no way of knowing how any new proposal would differ from the most recent version.
He had some words of caution for any interested developer. "I don't think there is an understanding of what has to be done before you can develop that island," he said. "People think it is a bucolic island that only needs to be built on."
"Davids Island has the remnants of Fort Slocum, which it took the Army a year to build," he said. "Buildings are burned out and the former gymnasium, which had a metal arched roof, looks like a pile of metal spaghetti. It would cost $60 million just to dismantle the buildings."
The bridge, which became a focus of disagreement at many levels, "would have cost $40 million," Mr. Marshall said. "We spent over $20 million for all the studies," an investment that other developers would have to repeat "because we consider our results to be proprietary."
 
$130 Million Before the Shovel
 "Then there's another $10.35 million we would owe the city upon closing," Mr. Marshall added. "So that's a total of more than $130 million," he said. "How many developers are prepared to spend that before a shovel goes into the ground?"
Any return to negotiating over Davids Island might be delayed, meanwhile, in the wake of last week's vote. Mayor Idoni said, "Davids Island will still be part of our development process, but downtown has to be our immediate interest."
Many proponents of granting Xanadu an extension cited the poor economic condition of New Rochelle's downtown as underscoring the need for new ratables, or taxable property, that Davids Island promised. Robert Angarola, president of the school board, put it this way:
"New Rochelle is in dire need of development, and it needs it now. Some say the developer has inflated the property taxes the project will produce, but any new revenue is acceptable."
 
The Process Is Called the Problem
 Richard Syracuse, a builder and developer, said, "You won't get another developer in this current economic situation and with New Rochelle's viability in question." The process is the problem, not the developer, he added.
Mayor Idoni, speaking after the vote rejecting Xanadu, was more optimistic about the chances of improving the city's long-stagnant downtown. "We are negotiating with the Starrett Housing Corporation for the construction of 300 rental units and could have a preliminary agreement next month," he said.
"In addition, we are one of four finalists as the site of a new headquarters for Unicef," he said. "Two others are in New York City, and the other is in New Jersey." The Mayor said he hoped New Rochelle would be favored because it "sits astride I-95," the New England Thruway. Unicef is now situated near United Nations headquarters in Manhattan.
Mayor Idoni said the proposal would bring 700 to 1,000 Unicef employees to New Rochelle. They would work in a new 20-story building near the Metro-North tracks opposite a mall on Huguenot Street.
 
A Development Framework Sought
 The Mayor suggested another reason for delaying resumption of Davids Island activity. He thought it would be useful if city officials sat down with interested parties at the county, state and even Federal level to agree on a framework in which a developer could work.
Stephen P. Tenore, the chairman of the Board of Legislators and the New Rochelle representative on the Board, said, "I see an opportunity for the county, the Secretary of State and the city to jointly establish what is acceptable to all before we deal with another developer."
"We should become pro-active instead of reactive," he said. Mr. Tenore had warned that only 1 of 17 county legislators had indicated support for the proposed bridge to Davids Island, and that warning did as much as anything else to kill Xanadu's extension.
"My own interest," Mr. Tenore said, "would be less density, much less height in the apartment buildings and complete public access to the island. He had also objected to a projected 800-boat marina "that would be only 1,000 feet from Glen Island Beach."
 
Lack of an Escape Clause Cited
 He also objected to "the fact that the projected extension for Xanadu provided no escape clause," which would mean the city "would be unable to act for five years even if Xanadu's proposals were rejected by Albany."
The disagreements over Xanadu's proposal covered several aspects of the ambitious plan to turn the desolate island into a luxurious community of residential towers with only two apartments on a floor, scores of town-house units, a yacht club, a marina, a heliport and a 3,465-foot bridge.
The developers first introduced the concept of residential exclusivity, with the public barred from the island. Ms. Shaffer, among others, found this to be elitist and said that turning publicly owned coastal land into private use was unacceptable.
Xanadu then offered a half-acre site near the bridge's island terminus that would be open to the public during daylight hours. That, too, was rejected. The final version contained 19 acres of public promenades and parks, with access extended to a crescent-shaped rocky jetty protecting the marina.
 
Residents Protested Loss of View
 As for density, the original plan called for four 50-story apartment towers, with other families living in town houses on landscaped grounds. Mr. Marshall said the city had hoped for a 4,500-unit colony but that figure was cut to 2,000 and then 1,750.
Shoreline residents in New Rochelle and the communities to the north on Long Island Sound bitterly protested that the plan would adversely affect their view. Building heights were cut to 31 stories and, finally, to one tower of 19 stories and three of 15 stories.
Environmentalists and others were most strongly opposed to the bridge and to a waste-treatment plant that they said would pollute the atmosphere and the fragile waters of the Sound. Xanadu changed its original plan, which provided secondary treatment, to a promise to build a more effective tertiary-treatment plant.
Experts hired by the developers said the tertiary process would reduce the introduction of harmful nitrogen into the Sound to a negligible four parts per million. The Federated Conservationists of Westchester County said the developer's study of Sound waters overlooked information generated by the Long Island Sound Study, a five-year effort.
 
Bridge Stirred Heated Debate
 The argument over the bridge was probably the most heated and the least likely to be resolved because it hinged less on esthetics, which the developers recognized with a slimmer, more graceful design, than on the fact of the span itself. The environmentalists said ferry service was an appropriate alternative.
Xanadu said ferry service would be hazardous in the busy waters between the island and the mainland. The developer also said that automobiles moving across a bridge would produce less pollution than 100 cars starting up cold at the ends of the bridge.
A ferry would require construction of a huge parking lot in south New Rochelle near the shore facing the island. Eight homes would have to be removed from that area for construction of a bridge, the developers said.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

ARDSLEY AUTO AUCTION
Fifteen Chevrolets dating from the early 80's to the 90's will be auctioned off Saturday at 11 A.M. in Ardsley. What makes the event unusual is the fact that the cars belong to the Town of Greenburgh and they are being sold as an economy measure. 
 "This is a new policy," said Paul J. Feiner, the Town Supervisor "In times like these we have decided that it is unnecessary for high-level town employees to be issued automobiles at the taxpayers' expense." His car is among those for sale, along with the Controller's, the Town Attorney's and those formerly driven by the heads of all municipal departments.
The auction will be held at the Greenburgh Town Park, on Heatherdale Road, and the cars will be available for inspection from 10 to 11 A.M. For more information, call 993-1540.
 
ADIRONDACK HISTORY
 In almost every nook and corner of the Adirondack Park's six million acres something of interest has been going on this year during the park's centennial. One event taking place in central Westchester is a talk by Barbara McMartin, author of "Hides, Hemlocks and Adirondack History," scheduled at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Mount Pleasant Library.
The book, published this month by North Country Books in Utica, describes the adventures and misadventures of New York and Boston financiers who invested in tanning and lumber enterprises deep within the Adirondack forests in the 19th century, only to have the projects fizzle out by the 1890's.
Through diligent research Ms. McMartin has dispelled many myths about the demise of the two industries. The cost of building and paying interest on the construction of the tanneries, supporting the towns that grew up around them, frequent fires, the depletion of hemlock stands, the vagaries of the financial world and the difficulty of governing the enterprises by absentee owners on Wall Street were some of the reasons for failure.
Ms. McMartin is chairwoman of the Adirondack Centennial Committee, and she has coordinated more than 50 organizations statewide to produce a calendar of lectures, art and quilt exhibitions, photographic displays, boat races, skiing competitions, concerts, environmental symposiums, nature walks, craft workshops and guided hikes.
Admission to the lecture is free.
 
DANCE FUND BENEFIT
 Music is expected to have charm enough to turn browsers into buyers at an art and collectibles auction for the benefit of the Dance in Education Fund of White Plains. A chamber ensemble of music students at the State University of New York at Purchase will play for potential purchasers of toe shoes autographed by New York City Ballet members who wore them, dance-related dolls, books, jewelry and fine art from prestigious Westchester and Manhattan galleries.
The silent auction and a boutique sale will begin at 6:45 P.M. Saturday in the Performing Arts Center on the campus, followed at 8 P.M. by a dance concert featuring advanced students from the Steffi Nossen School of Dance in White Plains and a piano recital by Jess Meeker, who has composed and performed at Jacob's Pillow in Massachusetts and at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan and during his stint as musical director of the Dance in Education Fund.
Successful bids will be announced during intermission at 9 P.M., and the performance will end at 10 o'clock. For tickets and more information, call 761-7774.
 
TROMPE L'OEIL MASTER
 William M. Harnett does not come to mind as one of America's most memorable artists, yet he enjoyed great celebrity during his lifetime, which ended 100 years ago. An exhibition of 50 Harnett paintings can be seen at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan through June 14.
His life and work will be explored in a lecture and slide show Friday by Marvin D. Schwartz, art historian, former fellow at the H. F. DuPont Winterthur Museum near Wilmington, Del., curator at the Detroit Institute of Arts and author of many articles for Art News magazine, Antiques magazine and other publications.
Harnett's forte was trompe l'oeil, so realistic that it aroused the suspicions of United States Treasury agents who were convinced that his depictions of currency were actual bills incorporated into the canvasses. For a time consideration was given to soaking the "bills" off the paintings and arresting the artist as a counterfeiter.
Eschewing traditional still-life subjects of fruit in bowl, deadfowl on table and flowers in vase, he turned to manmade objects, including musical instruments, books, bric-a-brac, pipes and household objects. He also produced innovative miniatures -- exquisitely detailed still lifes measuring four by six inches in addition to realistic life-size paintings.
The lecture will begin at 8 P.M. in the Hiram Halle Memorial Library on Route 4 in Pound Ridge. Admission is free.
 
ROCKLAND BOAT SHOW
 The last big boat show of the winter is to be held Thursday through next Sunday at Rockland Community College in Suffern. The promoters claim that boats purchased at the show will be fitted out for spring delivery.
Fishing and power boats dominate the collection, which also includes day cruisers, sailboards, sailboats, inflatables, canoes and scuba equipment, boating gear and clothing, boat slips and marine publications.
Daily seminars will cover a variety of topics, beginning with freshwater fishing for bass at 5:30 P.M. Thursday. Saltwater fishing, how to get a captain's license, how to select a fishing charter and scuba diving will be among other subjects.
To reach the college, take Exit 14B of the New York State Thruway (Interstate 87) and follow signs for Rockland Boat Event. Hours are 5 to 9 P.M. Thursday and Friday, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Saturday and 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $5. Children will be admitted free with a parent. Call AZA Promotions of Washington Crossing, Pa., at (215) 493-4427 for more information.
 
ON WOMEN'S PROGRESS
 "Women in the Work Force: Have We Progressed?" is the subject of a talk by a woman who has made considerable progress since graduating cum laude from Princeton University in 1974 and subsequently receiving her doctorate from the Harvard Law School.
She is Margarita Rosa, the first woman, the first Hispanic person and the youngest individual to serve as the state's Commissioner of Human Rights, a post for which she was nominated by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and confirmed by the State Legislature in 1990. From 1985 to 1990 she served as the commission's general counsel and its executive deputy commissioner.
Her talk will begin at 3:30 P.M. Tuesday in Reid Hall at Manhattanville College, 125 Purchase Street, Purchase. Admission is free.
 
ODETTA IN PAWLING
 Odetta, one of America's most dynamic folk singers for more than 40 years, will appear at the Towne Crier Cafe in Pawling Saturday at 9 P.M. A protegee of Harry Belafonte decades ago, she has performed throughout the United States, Western Europe, Russia, Japan, Africa and Israel. She entertained at the White House during President Kennedy's administration, sang at the reopening ceremonies at Ford's Theater and has led the national anthem at Shea Stadium.
An active participant in the civil rights movement, she joined the marches in Selma, Alabama, and Washington, and she is involved in fund-raising for the Folk Music Archives at the Library of Congress.
Admission will be $16. The cafe is at 62 Route 22, and the phone number for reservations is 855-1300.

HEADLINE: Is Japan Out to Get Us?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert B. Reich's essay "Is Japan Really Out to Get Us?" (Feb. 9) says there must be hidden motives behind criticism of Japanese economic policies, since the stated motive simply can't be true. "There are several possible explanations for this outpouring, but Japan's recent behavior is not one," he says. 
 Mr. Reich's ad hominem attacks on several dozen authors and books all depend on this assertion, which is simply wrong -- or, at a minimum, is very hotly debated. (For the record: in this essay Mr. Reich made no such attack on me.) This is not the place for a full re-arguing of the case these books present. I will simply mention recent reports by two of Mr. Reich's colleagues at Harvard, Dennis Encarnation of the business school and Robert Lawrence of the Kennedy School of Government, demonstrating that, even now, Japanese practices make it uniquely difficult for non-Japanese businesses to invest and operate in Japan.
The illustrations Mr. Reich did offer to support his point -- for instance, the popularity of some American-brand goods in Japan -- will be familiar to anyone who has ever heard a briefing from the Keidanren, Japan's major-industry alliance. They are political facts, in contrast to academic facts. Like the statistics that politicians will use in their speeches this year, they are very carefully chosen and sometimes deliberately misleading figures, designed to sell a political argument. My point is not that Mr. Reich is being deliberately misleading or that he is anyone's shill. Rather, the point concerns intellectual intensity. If similar statistics came from, say, George Bush or the chairman of General Motors, Mr. Reich would examine them very skeptically -- as he should. But he passes on these factoids about Japan with total credulity.
Mr. Reich's most profound misconception is that the authors he discusses are calling the Japanese system bad or unfair. Virtually every one of these books says that the Japanese system is admirable and superior in certain ways, such as its emphasis on savings. Their main argument is that there are significant, long-term differences between the Japanese and American economic structures. Recognizing these differences doesn't mean that Americans should get mad at Japan. On the contrary: only by recognizing the differences can the countries collaborate in the long run.
In his writings Mr. Reich often describes a "borderless" world, in which American, Japanese and German companies are impossible to tell apart. Everyone can agree on this as an ideal. But the people Mr. Reich criticizes all say that this is nowhere near the reality of corporate or governmental life in Japan, and won't be for the foreseeable future.
 
JAMES FALLOWS
Washington
