SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1205 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Now That They Must, Former Soviets Hustle for Money

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Visit with the new Siberian oil barons. Listen to the ambitious managers at the Vaz Auto Works in Togliatti. Get to know the street merchants, consultants, real estate brokers and commodity traders in Moscow. Or watch seven men and women, hired by an entrepreneur in Kiev, assemble small electric water pumps at tables in a sooty rented factory room, using screwdrivers and wrenches.
A surprisingly vital if sometimes crude capitalism is emerging in the countries that made up the Soviet Union as people join the struggle to make money -- sometimes with enthusiasm for their new lives, in other cases simply to hang on to an old standard of living or to afford enough food. "The opportunities are so blatant -- the gap between what people have and what they want is so great -- that people are rushing to fill it," said Marshall Goldman, associate director of Harvard's Russian Research Center and a frequent traveler to Moscow. "Some are acting out of desperation and others are grabbing opportunity." 
 Whatever the reasons, after 70 years of socialism and job security, millions of people -- nobody knows exactly how many -- seem to have taken to capitalism, with all its uncertainties, as the unavoidable next step in their struggle for a better life. Many are doing so only in small ways, hustling for a few extra dollars. But the political import is still significant, since their actions are in effect supporting the free-market policies of Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin. "They believe he'll create new conditions for survival," said Andrei N. Kakoshin, deputy director of the Institute of the United States and Canada, a research organization in Moscow.
Officials of the International Monetary Fund, in fact, say that Mr. Yeltsin may already have acquired the political room necessary to proceed to the next painful stage of making the economy more competitive, a stage in which credit would be cut back and workers would be laid off.
The grass-roots vitality could, of course, turn to lethargy and revolt as this more difficult phase begins. Shrinking the work force at inefficient, costly industries is viewed as the necessary next step to profitability and competitiveness, not only by the I.M.F. and Western industrial nations, but also by many of Mr. Yeltsin's ministers. Inequities in income might also breed disillusionment and resistance, especially among the elderly, with their meager pensions, or among workers whose wages fail to keep up with inflation, which in recent months has been about 300 percent at an annual rate across the former Soviet lands.
Measuring the suffering is difficult, but specific problems offer a glimpse. For example, Boris Pinsker, a Russian economist, cites reports from gynecologists that pregnant women appear to be in poorer health than a year or two ago, and that malnutrition is more common.
"Forty percent of the people we have polled tell us that they don't know what to do and they will wait passively to see what happens," said Tatyana Zaslavskaya, a sociologist and director of the Soviet Center for Public Opinion and Market Research, which periodically polls 3,000 people across the Commonwealth. "They are the aged, the less educated and those who don't have good health, and as a rule they are paid less."
Such people are already losing ground to a growing corps of managers, entrepreneurs, merchants, consultants, traders and others nimble enough to make money in the new capitalism. They often succeed because they are more adept as traders, buying and reselling what already exists, than as manufacturers, who might increase the national wealth by making new products. Production, in fact, has fallen sharply over the last year, in factories and on farms, as Corporate Russia adjusts to a world in which enterprises scramble for supplies and customers while they shake off central authority. Some companies even elect to produce less rather than more, believing that shortages push up prices and profits.
But with all the drawbacks, these scenes are becoming more frequent, particularly in Russia and Ukraine, the two most populous republics:
* Seated at the conference table in his large office, Yuri Vershinin, general director of the Tyumen Oil and Gas Company, outlines expansion plans. Mr. Vershinin, a 49-year-old engineer, has become the commander of a company with 6,000 employees that pumps thousands of barrels of oil a day from wells in Siberia's Tyumen Province. "We want not only to pump oil, but to explore for it, refine it and own gasoline stations," he said. "We understand that we need the profit from all these operations to develop new fields."
* Rair Simonyan is a prestigious Russian economist, chief of research at the state-funded Institute of World Economy and International Relations. But his salary of less than 2,000 rubles a month, or $20, no longer covers his family's expenses. So he founded a consulting firm and runs it from his institute office, with institute employees on his staff and a list of foreign companies as clients. "We have commercialized our knowledge," Mr. Simonyan said. "We gave a lot of advisory service free, and now we charge for it." (Millions of others have similarly commercialized themselves, from the cardiologist at a state hospital who now sees patients privately to the elderly woman with a 342-ruble-a-month pension who waits two hours in line at a state store to purchase a shirt and then resells it on the street to a passerby who wants to avoid lines.)
* Nikolai A. Glushkov, vice general director of the Vaz Auto Works, which makes 700,000 of the 1.2 million cars manufactured annually in the former Soviet republics, hosts a dinner attended by several other top Vaz executives. They are working 12-hour days, taking control of a huge state company that is in the process of becoming a shareholder's corporation. Management -- 150 executives -- is to get 5 percent of the stock under Russia's privatization law. Mr. Glushkov, a 42-year-old physicist, says he has a personal dream: to leave to his children stock in an enterprise made so prosperous "they can live off what they inherit, even if they are lazy."
Second jobs, as well as extra hours, are becoming a common way to jack up income, Ms. Zaslavskaya says. But as workers advance into capitalism, they pay a price in uncertainty. That is particularly true in the construction industry, one of the first to spawn private companies. Today, 2 million of Russia's 8.5 million construction workers are privately employed, the Federation of Independent Trade Unions of Russia says. They earn 1,500 rubles a month on average, in contrast to the average 900 at state-owned construction companies. But they also work longer hours -- nine a day, without a paid lunch period, in contrast to eight hours a day, including a 45-minute lunch break, in the state sector.
And while state workers have rarely been laid off, their private sector colleagues live constantly with that problem, says Eugene Rechetnikov, a Federation official. So last December a union was founded to represent privately employed construction workers. "Salary is not a problem," Mr. Rechetnikov said. "Their main goal is protection from dismissal."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
California Republicans Ready for Civil War

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Barring a political miracle, President Bush will have long since nailed down the Republican Presidential nomination by the time the big California primary rolls around on June 2. Nevertheless, the primary promises an emotional battle for the heart and soul of Republicanism in the largest state. It could also bring an early preview of the 1996 Republican Presidential sweepstakes.
The reason is that Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Bush's challenger on the political right, has vowed to turn the primary into purgatory for Gov. Pete Wilson, a middle-of-the-road Republican considered something of a traitor by the party's right wing. Mr. Buchanan, with bloody historical allegory, promised to stage the "Antietam of the Republican Party" on primary day, to bring retribution for the conservatives who "have had their noses rubbed in the dirt" by Mr. Wilson and Mr. Bush. He told a television interviewer in Michigan that California voters "have begged us virtually to come out and make the case against Pete Wilson Republicanism and George Bush Republicanism for the conservative cause." 
 Governor Wilson, who calls himself a "compassionate conservative," lost no time in firing back, using some of the strongest words used yet by a prominent Republican in denouncing Mr. Buchanan. "I think some of his comments have been downright racist, anti-Semitic," he said. "There's no place in our Republican Party for that."
Behind the testy exchange lurked some complex national and state politics. Though Mr. Wilson vows he is just trying to be a good governor for now, it is widely assumed that both Mr. Wilson and Mr. Buchanan will be Presidential contenders in 1996, and the primary could provide the first test of wills between the two men. It could also affect Mr. Wilson's efforts to gain a Republican majority in the state Legislature by encouraging Republican candidates of his own stripe.
In 1991, his first year as Governor, Mr. Wilson found his programs opposed most vigorously by a hard core of Republican conservatives in the state Assembly who are known cheerfully around the capital as the cavemen. When he called on the Legislature to raise taxes to help erase a staggering $14.3 billion budget gap, the cavemen howled.
Mr. Wilson has since been tending to his right flank because conservative Republican voters, while perhaps not a major factor in California general elections, can be a potent force in the Republican primaries. On the day Mr. Wilson blasted back at Mr. Buchanan, he was in Stockton campaigning for Dean Andal, an Assemblyman who won a special election last year by declaring himself more conservative than Mr. Wilson.
A combination of reapportionment and a voter-passed measure that sharply limits the terms of legislators appeared this year to have given Mr. Wilson an opportunity to reshape the Legislature more in his own image. But the Buchanan factor has given Republicans pause and Democrats glee. Should the challenger invigorate the angry right and bring crowds of them to the polls, some of Mr. Wilson's candidates could suffer.
Among them is Governor Wilson's hand-picked successor in the United States Senate seat he vacated last year, John Seymour, who, like the Governor, differs from the national Republican Party on certain salient issues -- he espouses "choice" on the abortion issue, for example. He faces a primary challenge from the conservative Orange County Congressman William E. Dannemeyer.
But the Wilson headaches are potentially migraine in the races for state Assembly, where the Governor must obtain a two-thirds majority for crucial budget votes. Twenty-three of the 80 seats are open and pitched battles for the Republican nomination are under way in the districts where Republicans have a chance. Even some Republican incumbents face stiff right-wing challengers. For example, here in the Sacramento area, Assemblyman B. T. Collins, a moderate Republican who won a narrow victory in a special election last year, faces a rematch against Barbara Alby, a conservative.
 
A Dubious Reward
 The danger is that Mr. Wilson's reward for besting the Democrats on reapportionment is a Legislature dominated by a combination of antagonized Democrats and resentful Republicans. The prospect delights the powerful Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, who is struggling to retain Democratic control of the Assembly and nursing resentment that Governor Wilson backed a proposal to limit state officeholders' terms.
The entire episode is complicated by the fact that Mr. Buchanan's campaign manager, his sister Angela (Bay) Buchanan, is a Californian who ran and lost a race for state treasurer in 1990. She is reported to be interested in challenging Mr. Wilson for the gubernatorial nomination in 1994. She told reporters last week that her brother decided to attack Mr. Wilson because of the role he played in trying to get the state Republican Party to suspend its rules and endorse President Bush at its recent convention. The effort was called off.
For their part, Mr. Wilson and his staff dismiss the Buchanan challenge. The Governor called the Buchanan blast "more whistling past the graveyard." In an interview, Mr. Wilson said that Mr. Buchanan's appeal is mainly a vehicle for people wanting to protest the economy. One of his spokesmen, Dan Schnur, termed it a "distraction" from the Governor's political agenda of gaining a majority in the Assembly.
Either way, Mr. Buchanan's plans to camp out for two months in California this spring promise to enliven a Republican primary that might otherwise have passed without much notice.

HEADLINE: No Balance? No Problem!

BYLINE: By CARLYLE C. DOUGLAS

 BODY:
A voter could wind up in trouble with the law for treating a checking account the way some politicians treated theirs in a bank run by the House of Representatives for its members. After audits last year showed that most members sometimes overdrew their accounts and some members did so routinely, House Democrats began looking for a way to contain the damage. They hoped to get away with simply closing the bank and making public the names of the two dozen worst abusers of a system that allowed members to write insufficiently funded checks without penalty or interest.
But with the issue being forced by the Republicans -- who have less to lose simply because there are fewer of them -- the House Democrats agreed last week to the publication of the names of all 355 current and former members who wrote checks against insufficient funds over a 39-month period investigated by a House panel last fall. The names of the 24 worst abusers are to be released this week, with the rest following in 10 days. The abuses ranged from apparently inadvertent overdrawing of less than $100 in a few checks to habitual writing of dozens of uncovered checks a month for thousands of dollars. 
 The House bank was less a bank than a check-cashing convenience for members. Their paychecks were automatically deposited and they were allowed to write checks against future deposits. Theoretically, members were notified of their overdrafts and asked to cover them within a specified time. But some members said they were never notified, and others, who knew they were overdrawn, simply considered it a running salary advance.
With the economy out at recess, the time could not be much worse for reminding voters that until very recently their national legislators had a handy dollar-stretching perk. Release of the details is expected to cost some members their seats, though some of the lesser miscreants have confessed and asked forgiveness from their constituents.
Representative Gerry Sikorski, a Minnesota Democrat, owned up to writing 671 bad checks for a total of $119,966.97 and directed his contrition to the voters back home.
"We should not have been so casual and careless with our personal account," he said. "We are sorry and apologize."
The mess has already cost one job, that of Jack Russ, who resigned last week as the House's sergeant-at-arms, the office responsible for administering the bank. Mr. Russ, a Democratic appointee who had himself written 19 bad checks for a total of $56,100, was blamed by some members, who said he had run a rather loose ship.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Genius for Hire: The Soviet's Best, At Bargain Rates

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The millions of scientists and engineers of the former Soviet Union, once feared and respected throughout the world for their big rockets and thermonuclear bombs, for their mathematical rigor and breakthroughs in fields like nonlinear optics, are now desperate amid a crumbling economy. Many have been thrown out of work. The lucky ones who still do science often help support themselves and their families by moonlighting. Inevitably, a growing number who can afford to do so are leaving to work in the West. And those left behind can often be hired for a song.
That point was driven home last week as a top team of more than 100 fusion scientists at the Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy in Moscow signed a contract to go to work for Uncle Sam. The cost to American taxpayers for one year's effort was an amazingly low $90,000. So eager was the team to work for the United States that it fired up its world-class apparatus for exploring the feasibility of nuclear fusion even before the contract was signed. 
 How far will the trend go? What are the risks and benefits of saving Russian science? What is its ultimate fate? Western experts have many thoughts but few hard answers as they watch, in awe, as the world's largest scientific enterprise goes into free fall. "It's the end of a pattern established over a period of 60 years," said Dr. Murray Feshbach, an expert on Russian science at Georgetown University. "Funding has been cut back sharply. The pipeline for training is in total disarray. People are voting with their feet, going into cooperative and private activity."
On Friday, the National Academy of Sciences said the stakes for the West were so high that it should redouble its efforts to fund, hire and cooperate with Russian scientists, lest they be tempted by lucrative job offers from third-world despots. It called for a quick infusion of up to $150 million in scientific aid.
 
New Frontiers
 Dr. Loren R. Graham, an expert on Russian science and technology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the risks and rewards for the West went beyond security to issues of culture, beauty and the wonder that comes with pushing the frontiers of knowledge.
"There are some areas of science where the old Soviet Union was a world leader," he said. "There were centers of excellence. If those dry up and disappear, it's a loss not just for Russia and former Soviet republics but for world civilization."
It was the Russian chemist Dmitri Mendeleev who came up with the periodic table of the elements in the 19th century. In the early 20th century, Ivan Pavlov probed the riddle of behavior. Soviet scientists put the first satellite and man into space. Pytor Kapitsa, Nikolai Basov and Lev Landau won Nobel prizes for physics.
But, overall, the seclusion and secrecy of the cold war took a toll. The Soviet Union lagged behind the West in breakthroughs in some high technologies and in the creation of computer chips. Ironically, their backward computer hardware forced Russian software designers to make their programs elegant and efficient, with the result that their skills are now much in demand in the West.
Today turmoil in Russian science is ubiquitous and links to the West are the foremost prize, not only because of the West's deep pockets but also because of its better working conditions, tools and equipment. The National Academy of Sciences says that hundreds if not thousands of Russian scientists have already flocked to the United States as visiting scholars at universities and institutes, providing an influx of new ideas as they shop for jobs that would allow them to stay permanently.
Dr. Mohamed S. El-Genk, a nuclear engineer at the University of New Mexico, recently brought experts from the Kurchatov Institute in Moscow for a semester in Albuquerque, even though he says it is better to fund them at home in Russia. "If you bring them over here, there's a chance they won't want to go back," he said. "You'll be draining the country of its talent."
Scientists left behind are signing Western contracts as fast as they can to supplement dwindling incomes. A Russian computer scientist, Boris A. Babayan, is setting up a laboratory in Moscow for Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., that will employ his team of about 50 software and hardware designers. Mr. Babayan created the supercomputers used by the Soviets to design nuclear arms. Sun Microsystems will pay each of his team's members a few hundred dollars a year -- ample pay by Moscow standards.
 
Computer Experts
 "Mr. Babayan has a very clever computer architecture and a spectacularly smart research team," said David R. Ditzel, Sun Microsystems' director of advanced systems. Understandably, executives of the Microsoft Corporation, the nation's largest software company, and of Apple Computer Inc., say they too are in talks with Russian computer experts.
The drama at the Kurchatov Institute in Moscow, named after the father of the Soviet A-bomb, is similar to that of the computer wizards. The top nuclear-fusion team faced a bleak situation. It had excellent equipment -- a tokamak fusion reactor boasting the world's most powerful heater of fusion fuel -- but little money to run it or pay salaries. So starting in November the team courted the Federal Department of Energy, which pays for such research in the United States. The $90,000 deal was sealed last week.
 
Fusion Power
 "We hoped that Kurchatov would be doing this research themselves," said Dr. N. Anne Davies, director of the Energy Department's fusion research program. "When that wasn't possible, we were willing to fund it." How far might such arrangements go? "Our budget is very tight," Dr. Davis replied. "We'll take it on a case-by-case basis."
Such deals are starting to irk American scientists who face tight budgets themselves and growing competition from the tide of Russian scientific immigrants. "We can't afford to buy the whole Soviet scientific establishment," said Dr. Stephen O. Dean, president of Fusion Power Associates in Gaithersburg, Md., a nonprofit group that promotes fusion research. "We can't create a welfare program for them. We've already got lots of people in our own program who we would like to fund but can't."
Dr. Feshbach of Georgetown University said fears that America would spend lots of money buying up Soviet brainpower were unfounded. Hirings and attempted hirings, he said, would probably be limited to the cream of Russian science.
"Not everybody in this country or that country is a genius," he said. "Not everybody is a spectacular academician like Sakharov," the father of the Soviet H-bomb. Nevertheless, Dr. Feshbach estimated that anywhere from 1 percent to as much as 25 percent of the vast scientific workforce of the former Soviet Union might eventually forge links to the West to survive. "It's really rough on these people," he said. "Their lives are under enormous stress."

LENGTH: 1373 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
As the World Turns, U.S. Policy Stands Still

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is hard to put an exact date on it but sometime over the summer, foreign policy just vanished from the American political debate, as though it were some fad that went out of style.
Robert S. Strauss, the American Ambassador to Russia and former Democratic national chairman, came home last week, read the newspapers, then told Congress that the absence of any serious debate on the question of aid to Russia was "just shocking." 
 "This ain't beanbag we're playing," he said. "These are big-time issues, this is life or death, this is the future of nations."
What happened to foreign policy as an issue? In part the debate died of fatigue, as the American public emerged from the cold war and the Persian Gulf war exhausted by the burdens of leadership and discouraged by one of the worst recessions since World War II. In part, the debate was murdered by a conspiracy of Republicans and Democrats, each certain that this would serve their political interests.
And in part, the absence of a foreign policy debate seems to be showing that the Bush Administration never had any larger vision in foreign policy than it did in domestic policy. What it had was a gulf war policy, and the right instincts to stand aside when great revolutions were unfolding in the Communist world. But now that it must shape a post-cold-war order to lock in the changes in the East, it finds itself groping. The Administration's apparent aspiration is to retain American hegemony on the cheap. In its dream world foreign policy would all be like the gulf war -- everyone else would pay and America would have its way. America would apportion the burdens of power, but not power itself. That approach will be a hard sell to the allies.
If one wanted to try to fix the date when foreign policy began to disappear from political debate it may well have been last July 28 in Manchester, N.H., when Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, then a Democratic Presidential hopeful, held up a suitcase plastered with stickers bearing the names Moscow, Paris, Turkey, Kuwait and Greece. The suitcase, he said, belonged to President Bush, who was traveling abroad so much he had ignored domestic needs. "Unpack your bags and stay here in America," Mr. Harkin demanded of the President.
While the President dismissed the critique with a wave of his hand, it hit home. Within days Mr. Bush, worried about giving the Democrats an opening to attack him at his most vulnerable spot -- his shortcomings in domestic policy -- began to distance himself from the one area where his Administration had been hailed as a success, foreign policy. The Democrats also did not want to push foreign policy issues, for fear of playing to Mr. Bush's strength. Instead, they pushed a few small initiatives of their own vis-a-vis Russia, but generally adopted the position that if the President wanted any more foreign aid he would have to get out front and they would back him up.
After you. No, after you.
"Congress would be willing to do what is needed, with the right leadership," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat. "The reason you are not seeing much of a debate on these things is that given the manifest unpopularity of foreign aid, there are very few people who see much mileage in publicly calling for it -- in the absence of Presidential leadership. Because without the President's support it is not going to happen and so you are left with the worst of all worlds: getting flak for supporting an unpopular program without the satisfaction of seeing it implemented, or even being able to point to its accomplishments."
It would be bad enough if no one was saying anything. But everyone is saying "No" -- no to any new foreign aid initiatives. Last week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appealed to Congress for $700 million to support United Nations peacekeeping troops to buttress the long-sought resolution of the conflict in Cambodia. He ran into a buzz saw of opposition from Democrats and Republicans alike.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who heads a key appropriations subcommittee, treated Mr. Baker as if he had landed from Mars, saying: "I know you've been on the road, but the home team's got to look at these budgets closer." The Administration's request for more funding for the International Monetary Fund, so it would have the resources to bolster the infant democracies in the former Soviet Union, got a similar thumbs-down.
These two cases are particularly poignant, because the lack of action deprives any Administration of tools it would need to shape the post-cold-war world -- a world likely to be characterized by multilateral efforts, led by institutions like the United Nations and the I.M.F., to settle regional disputes or provide economic aid where the superpowers might have once done so alone.
Mr. Bush has taken the position that he can go silent on foreign policy and just turn things over to his Secretary of State, but that does not work. Three months ago, Mr. Baker gave a speech at Princeton about the collapse of the Soviet Union. The speech articulated a lot of what needed to be done to support democracy in Russia. But there were two problems with it.
First, there was an enormous gap between what Mr. Baker said needed to be done and what he and the President were willing to push for at the time. Second, the speech was given by Mr. Baker, and therefore few noticed. Only the President can command such attention, but history will record that when America's enemy during 45 years of cold war collapsed, when a hostile standoff that had shaped the institutions and budgets of the American Government for four decades had finally ended, all Mr. Bush had to say was: We won.
Which raises another question -- the seeming paucity of foreign policy vision both in the Administration and among the leading Democratic candidates. Vision does not necessarily mean having a perfect road map for the future. The world is in too much flux for that now. Vision in the leadership sense can also mean simply acknowledging when historic changes have taken place, giving voice to their import and galvanizing the bureaucracy, Congress and the nation to debate and shape a long-term response that will serve America's interests. Vision isn't necessarily giving the right answers immediately; sometimes it is just asking the right questions.
 
Nixon's Critique
 That was the essence of former President Richard M. Nixon's critique of Mr. Bush last week: that what is happening in Russia today is comparable only to the defeat of Napoleon at Waterloo, the Versailles Peace Conference and the creation of NATO and the Marshall Plan. Get excited. Bring the nation's leadership together to define a moment that may only come along once a century.
When the Bush Administration came into office it ordered up a three-month-long strategic review, which produced a foot-high pile of documents and analyses on which policies of the Reagan Administration it wanted to continue, and which should be abandoned. Yet, when the cold war ended, the President never even gave a speech.
The only effort so far to put together a coherent blueprint for the post-cold-war era has come from the Pentagon, which is arguing that in a one-superpower world America should use its strength to deter aspiring tyrants like Iraq or North Korea as well as aspiring allies like Germany or Japan from overreaching, and thereby destabilizing the globe. While the arguments are debatable, the effort at least is being made. If Secretary Baker or Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, have done any such forward thinking of their own, they have not shared it with the public. Nor have the Democratic candidates. When Bill Clinton was asked for his reaction to Mr. Nixon's call for aiding Russia, he merely responded: "My view is that a constructive engagement there, with our allies, is good for Americans at home."
To be sure, after the primary campaign is over, the President and the candidates might feel more comfortable showing leadership on these issues. The question is: What will such a wait cost? Foreign policy cannot just be put on hold. The world does not stop for the American election campaign.

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
In the Worst of Times, America Keeps Giving

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Few nations rival the United States in its collective lust to get. But none rival it in its collective urge to give. Though the country is struggling to pull out of a recession, and some of its more charitable souls are shaking their heads over disclosures of free spending and high living by an official at the United Way of America, the unique American institution known as the nonprofit sector finds itself worried but well.
Whether they put dimes in the can on the store counter or write checks to their school or community hospital, or -- most of all -- put dollars in the collection plate, 75 percent of the households in the United States donate to charity, according to Independent Sector, a Washington-based group representing the nation's nonprofit institutions. Those households that gave in 1990 donated an average of $978 to such diverse causes as education, the environment, health care, homelessness, the arts and nuclear disarmament. 
 In 1990, giving totaled $122.6 billion and 9 in 10 dollars came from individuals, according to Giving USA, a New York-based magazine that monitors charities. Even adjusting for inflation, the 1990 total is nearly three times greater than in 1955. Though figures are still being compiled for 1991, experts say giving remains steady and is possibly increasing.
More than 96 cents of every dollar given, whether by foundations, corporations or factory workers, stays in the community it came from, according to Independent Sector. "The main reason people give is to provide help to the less fortunate," said Virginia Hodgkinson, the group's research director. "The second is to preserve institutions society uses. And the majority of giving is to institutions people know -- their church, synagogue, or their school."
The quintessential symbol of this generosity and its roots in the community has been United Way of America, the umbrella association representing 2,100 local chapters. After William F. Aramony resigned as president recently because of public outrage over his $463,000 salary-and-benefits package and other perquisites, some charity workers wondered whether donors would become less generous.
"Yes, members are nervous," said Brian O'Connell, president of Independent Sector. "The public's confidence is all we've got."
But other experts, while agreeing that the United Way itself may suffer setbacks in its fall campaigns, do not expect any long-term impact on charity in general.
"I'd be surprised if there were a major ripple effect," said Eleanor Brilliant, a professor of social work at Rutgers University. "People may be looking at charities somewhat suspiciously right now. But if you go to church and give there, what have Aramony's peccadilloes got to do with what you put in the collection plate?"
Giving USA found that more than 53 percent of all charitable gifts in 1990 went to religious organizations. After religion, education came in second, receiving 10 percent of all donations. Human services garnered about 9.6 percent, and health care about 8 percent.
Though the old guard charities like the Red Cross, the American Cancer Society, the United Jewish Appeal and Catholic Charities U.S.A. dominate, the charitable arena is far more crowded than ever before. Close to 500,000 organizations are registered as tax-exempt charities, and the number of tax-exempt foundations, which dropped dramatically in the early 1970's because of changes in the tax laws, has crept back up to more than 31,000.
 
Collecting Food
 One of the most successful new players is Second Harvest, a network of 182 food banks that grew out of a local project in Phoenix, Ariz. Its founder, John Van Hengel, asked supermarkets and food processers to donate healthy but unsalable products -- green beans cut too short to meet a canning company's standards, or canned and dry goods near their expiration dates. Last year Second Harvest ranked fourth on the list of leading national charities, with contributions, mostly of food, worth $394.8 million.
Community-based foundations formed to combat local problems have also proliferated. Less traditional charitable endeavors enjoy some success, from the hospice movement to environmental groups and organizations working on international problems like famine and community development.
About $2.3 billion was given to environmental causes in 1990, up 25 percent in constant dollars from 1989, according to Giving USA. Donations to international causes, $2.2 billion in 1990, have been much more inconsistent, spiking up in times of international crisis (the gulf war, the fall of Communism, the Ethiopian famine) and dropping sharply in between.
 
The New Wave
 Some of the new charities, particularly those associated with the women's movement or gay rights, have sometimes been viewed askance by traditional charities. Many of the newcomers have banded together into the 15-year-old Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, and some have become adept at marketing and direct-mail fund raising.
"Giving is a function of asking," said Robert Bothwell Jr., president of the committee. "With the cutback of government revenues in the early 1980's under President Reagan, some charities who didn't understand how to convert themselves and subsist on private revenues fell by the wayside. Others made the conversion and are stronger."
According to a recent study by Lester M. Salamon of Johns Hopkins University's public policy school and Alan J. Abramson of The Urban Institute, since 1982 private giving has generally not been able to make up for reductions in Federal spending. They found that increases in private giving have offset only 46 percent of the loss of Federal funds.
Corporate giving has remained fairly constant over the last few decades, even in recessionary times. But some charity watchers say the next surge in giving is likely to come from the third major group of donors -- foundations.
"We're just tailing off the most massive period of private wealth generation in history," said Waldemar A. Nielsen, author of "The Big Foundations." Generally, he said, the rich establish foundations as their monument, but they often put it off until they are in their 60's or 70's "because it is a premature death ritual." But he said there are 210,000 people in the country with fortunes of at least $10 million, and many are in their 50's and 60's.
"In the next 10 to 15 years," he said, "we could see a massive increase of resources in the nonprofit world."

HEADLINE: HURDLES INCREASE FOR MANY WOMEN SEEKING ABORTIONS

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
While lawyers and politicians focus on the legal battle over the right to abortion, millions of American women are finding that their access to abortion is growing more and more limited.
Despite the Supreme Court's 1973 ruling in Roe v. Wade that abortion is a constitutional right, a combination of economic forces, political pressures, and doctors' changing attitudes has put abortion out of reach for many women. 
 "About 20 percent of American women who want abortions cannot get them," said Janet Benshoof, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Reproductive Freedom Project. "Because of money, geography and the shortage of doctors who will perform abortions, abortion is not an option for many poor women, rural women, teen-agers and women in the military."
 
Fewer Perform Abortions
 Other experts offer higher estimates, but all agree that the percentage of women who have no access to abortion is increasing steadily, as the pool of hospitals, clinics and doctors willing to perform the procedure continues to shrink.
For many poor women, abortion has been out of reach since 1977, when Congress barred the use of Federal money to pay for abortions. The recession has intensified the situation: several abortion clinics report performing more second-trimester abortions, as women take longer to gather the money to pay for the procedure.
And rural women increasingly must travel long distances, often crossing state lines, to get an abortion. Many cannot manage the hurdle of arranging transportation, lodging and a baby sitter to stay with their young children.
 
Less Training Is Offered
 Fewer and fewer doctors are trained to perform abortions; some are opposed to the practice, and others say they are unwilling to deal with the pickets, protests and bomb threats that come with doing abortions. There is also a growing sense among young gynecologists, now that most abortions are performed in outpatient clinics rather than hospitals, that abortion is not part of health care they need to provide, even though 1.4 million women underwent the procedure in 1988.
It is impossible to gauge exactly how much protests against abortion have limited women's access to the procedure, but it is clear that what abortion-rights advocates see as a problem, anti-abortion groups hail as a victory.
"From our point of view, abortion is an act of violence against the mother and the child, and any time that violence can be avoided, it's a step forward," said Olivia Gans, director of American Victims of Abortion, an offshoot of the National Right to Life Committee. "What we're slowly seeing is the American people collectively making changes to reflect mainstream American concerns about abortion."
Sandra Andersen, the executive director of Planned Parenthood of Southern Indiana, planned to start offering abortions at her Bloomington clinic to serve women from a 29-county area with no other abortion clinic. She has two procedure rooms set up and 10 nurses and counselors trained to assist.
But she can't find a doctor to do the abortions.
"I've been looking since last June, and I'm nowhere," she said. "We've called the medical schools, we've called every other abortion provider we can think of, and we haven't got anyone."
Many of the doctors who have been most committed to performing abortions, often because they remember the botched abortions of the era before Roe v. Wade, are retiring.
"I remember seeing vaginal lacerations from hangers, and wards full of women with infections from criminal abortions," said David McDowell, a 66-year-old Plattsburgh, N.Y., gynecologist who performed abortions until his retirement in 1984. "I remember a gal who had a piece of a wooden packing crate in her. If you don't have those memories, and you don't see the urgency of the need, you're not going to want the bother of doing abortions, and I guess that's what's happened in Plattsburgh, where no one does abortions now."
Those who run abortion clinics, even in large cities, say that recruiting doctors is now their most serious problem.
There are many measures of the difficulties women face in obtaining abortions. Some are statistical:
*Only 13 states pay for abortions for low-income women.
*Eighty-three percent of the nation's counties, home to 31 percent of women of child-bearing age, have no clinic or hospital providing abortions, although some of these have private doctors who quietly perform a few abortions for longtime patients.
*The number of hospitals offering abortions dropped from 1,654 in 1977 to 1,040 in 1988, the latest year for which data are available. And from 1980 to 1988, the nation's abortion rate dropped 7 percent, to 27 abortions per 1,000 women of child-bearing age from 29 per 1,000.
*In 1991, only 13 percent of the nation's obstetrics-gynecology residency programs required training in first-trimester abortions, and only 7 percent required second-trimester training; in contrast, nearly a quarter of all programs required both forms of training in 1985.
 
A Three-City Trek
 But the best indication probably comes from stories like that of 23-year old Mary Jiveden of New Haven, W.Va., a divorced, unemployed beautician with a 2-year-old daughter. Ms. Jiveden discovered she was pregnant during a checkup in late December.
"I had gone out with this guy one time, and it was kind of like date rape, and I had no idea I was pregnant until the doctor said I was," she said.
Ms. Jiveden did not know where to go for an abortion, and when she called the health department and hospitals, they told her they were not allowed to make referrals, presumably because of the regulations prohibiting federally financed family-planning programs from discussing abortion.
Many calls later, a receptionist in a gynecologist's office advised Ms. Jiveden to get a big-city newspaper and look for an abortion-clinic advertisement. The closest place she found was in Charleston, about four hours away. So Ms. Jiveden left her daughter with a friend and went.
But when Ms. Jiveden was examined at the Charleston clinic, she was told that she was 17 weeks pregnant, and the clinic did not do abortions after 16 weeks. She was referred to a Cincinnati clinic, where the cost would be $850, and the limit was 19 1/2 weeks. Ms. Jiveden went there a week and a half later, thinking she was 18 1/2 weeks pregnant.
"They said I was 21 weeks, and they couldn't do it, and they referred me to Dayton, where it would cost $1,675," she said. "I refinanced my car, sold the V.C.R., borrowed money from everyone I could, and went to Dayton. But there they said I was high-risk, because I'd had my daughter by Caesarean. They said it would be $2,500, and I'd have to fly to Wichita. I just didn't think I could manage that."
So Ms. Jiveden is waiting to have the baby, a prospect that fills her with hopeless dismay.
"Now that I know I have to have it, I'm trying to get used to the idea," she said. "I'm not thinking about adoption, because I've never understood people having a baby just to give it away. So I've been thinking a lot about trying to love this baby the way I love my daughter. I don't know how I'm going to make a life for myself and these kids."
 
Stories of Desperation
 Counselors at abortion clinics across the country say they hear stories of desperation every day, of rape victims unable to pay for an abortion, of poor mothers using food money to pay for the procedure, of teen-agers too young to have a driver's license who take the family car and drive to a clinic hundreds of miles away.
Others take so long making arrangements, or borrowing money, that they pass the first-trimester limit most clinics impose. Abortions in the first 13 weeks usually cost $200 to $300. At the few clinics that will perform them, abortions late in the second trimester, a riskier, more complicated procedure, usually cost $2,000 or more.
"We've extended our limit from 21 weeks to 26, and our second-trimester abortions have gone from 10 percent to 20 percent of the procedures we do," said Lynn Thogerson of the Feminist Women's Health Center in Atlanta. "Because of the recession, some women are taking a longer time to get the money together."
Only 13 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, use their own money to pay for abortions for women on Medicaid, and some of them have recently cut back the categories of women they will pay for.
The shortage of doctors willing to do abortions is also having effects nationwide. The Planned Parenthood affiliates in Waco and Odessa, Tex., like the Indiana affiliate, are unable to find doctors for the abortion services they want to start. In Vermont, physician's assistants are now performing abortions, a practice several other states may soon approve. Even prominent urban clinics have difficulties.
"When the doctor who does abortions for us in Brooklyn had to go away for two weeks because his brother died, we couldn't find anyone to fill in, and we had to cancel abortions for two weeks," said Alexander Sanger, the president of Planned Parenthood of New York City. "Getting doctors is the No. 1 problem everywhere."
Meanwhile, fewer young doctors are being trained to perform abortions. Since the late 1970's, many obstetrics-gynecology residency programs have made abortion an elective, or stopped offering any abortion training at all. Hospital abortions, which were a majority of all abortions in 1973, are now a rarity, making up about 10 percent of all abortions. So young doctors who want to learn the procedure often have to moonlight at a clinic.
Becoming known as an abortionist carries its own perils. Buck Williams, the only doctor in South Dakota who performs abortions, works in a cinder-block office with bullet-proof windows and burglar alarms. Abortions have been part of his Sioux Falls practice for 11 years, and for 11 years, he has had to walk through pickets to enter his office.
"There's ugly phone calls and death threats, and one of the reasons I can keep doing this is that my kids have grown up," he said. "It's a lot harder for someone with small children who knows how his family is going to be affected. And there's a perception among doctors that if you do abortions your practice will be ruined, because your other patients will leave."
Hospitals that perform abortions often come under intense pressure, too. In St. Paul, for example, the Pro-Life Action Ministries lobbied to stop the county from renewing the St. Paul-Ramsey Medical Center's 35-year lease -- and the group is campaigning for a county ballot initiative to force the hospital to stop doing abortions.
"The anti-choice movement has led a two-pronged attack on abortion," said Kate Michelman, president of the National Abortion Rights Action League. "One is ending the legal right, the issue going to the Supreme Court. The second prong has been limiting access, by cutting off Federal funding, harassing doctors and hospitals, requiring parental notification and other things. And it's been very successful."
Both doctors and women's advocates say abortion has become isolated from mainstream medical practice, a situation that is partly an unintended outgrowth of the trend to outpatient abortion clinics.
"Back in the early 70's, Planned Parenthood led the fight to get abortions done in outpatient clinics, and it seemed like a good idea at the time, a way of providing easy access to good, cheap care," said Mr. Sanger.

HEADLINE: THE HOUSE BANK;
G.O.P. Sees the Bank Affair As Big Campaigns Weapon

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Republicans are hoping to use the House Bank affair and the impasse over tax legislation to make substantial gains in the House and to hold on to the Presidency.
But Democrats argue that whatever the headlines in March, by November the economy will matter much more. 
 As representatives went home this weekend to explain the bank affair on their own terms before official lists of those who overdrew their accounts were released, Republicans were licking their chops over their prospects in the House, which Democrats have controlled since 1955.
In a report that underscored the political potency of the issue, The Associated Press said tonight that it had been given a list of 21 Democrats among the 24 lawmakers considered "abusers" of the House Bank under a formula devised by the House ethics committee.
Missing from the list were three Republicans who the news agency said were also among the "abusers," and The A.P. said only that it had "obtained" the list from "Congressional sources" and did not explain why those sources had not identified the Republicans.
The list included four New Yorkers: Representatives Robert J. Mrazek of Long Island, Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn and James H. Scheuer of Queens. An aide to Mr. Mrazek said the list reference to him was inaccurate. But Mr. Solarz said its reference to him was "fairly accurate." [Page 28.]
 
G.O.P. Sees Its Chance
 "We've never had a better chance to persuade voters that who runs the House makes a difference," said Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.
In recent years only a handful of incumbents have actually been defeated for re-election, though dozens have retired. But Mr. Vander Jagt predicted that this year would bring "a landscape change," comparable to the elections of 1932, 1946, 1964 and 1974, when scores of lawmakers were turned out of office.
Advisers to President Bush's re-election campaign are finding both the bank and the tax package spicy topics for the President and his backers. Mr. Bush has spent weeks belaboring Congress for not passing his tax and economic growth program quickly, and the deadline for passage, which he proclaimed in January, will fall this Friday. Vice President Dan Quayle got to work on the issue this week, labeling the House Bank problem "a national disgrace."
Republicans see these issues as explosive electoral tools to prove to voters that Democrats can solve neither national problems like the recession nor personal ones like balancing their own checkbooks, and that votes for Congress, especially the House, should be cast on more than local concerns.
But it may not be that simple. Even if the bank issue remains in the public mind by Election Day, its impact seems sure to hurt Republicans as well as Democrats. And with four recent House alumni serving in Mr. Bush's Cabinet, the imminent disclosures could hit the Administration harder than Congress.
Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said voters would look at individual situations and punish Democrats and Republicans alike. By November, he predicted, they will be ready to forgive House members who are "up front" about their mistakes.
Gary Jacobson, professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego, said he felt the disclosures would embolden talented challengers in both parties who "smell a little blood."
But Norman Ornstein, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, disagreed, saying the publicity given the lawmakers' overdrawn accounts would only erode responsible interest in public service. "We'll get demagogues, some multimillionaires and some people who fancy themselves purer than Mother Teresa," he said.
Nor is there much sense that the attack Mr. Bush has promised to launch when Congress fails to pass the tax package he has proposed by Friday will have much effect. Democrats are seeking to get their own bill, with middle-class tax cuts and upper-bracket increases, to him by that day for a veto that no one expects to be overridden.
Linda Divall, a Republican poll taker, said she thought the public reaction to the impasse would be to see the President and the Democrats as guilty of "partisan posturing" and say "A pox on both your houses."
The risks are greater for Democrats, of course, both because there are more of them in the House to be challenged and because Republicans will campaign against their decades of control.
While the bank issue is "very troublesome for incumbents of both parties, said David R. Mayhew, a professor of political science at Yale University, "it gives enemies of the Democratic House a new way to beat up on it."
Such an attack may be especially effective because "not much successful legislating is taking place this winter," he said. "So the record is otherwise barren."
The context for these concerns was set in 1990, when the average winning margins for House candidates of both parties declined for the first time in more than a century.
One poll after another has found that respect for Congress as an institution is at record low levels. And the distinction that voters have made for decades -- thinking that Congress was worth little but their own representative was a valued public servant -- may be weakening.
Fred Steeper, a Republican poll taker from Michigan who works with the Bush campaign, said the bank issue "could be the final straw that really crystallizes people's dissatisfaction with Congress."
 
A Personalized Issue
 And Professor Jacobson, in San Diego, said the issue could "personalize and individualize" a normally abstract issue like the Federal budget deficit. "Attacks on Congress in general don't do much damage to individual members," he said. But with this issue, challengers could say: "Joe Smith cannot balance his own checkbook. How can we expect him to balance the Federal budget."
Thomas E. Mann, director of government studies at the Brookings Institution, warned that effects of the bank affair would be "limited by the unavailability of challengers in certain districts and by the resourcefulness of members in offering satisfactory explanations of their behavior to their constituents."
This may be easier than some people think, he said, because with the haphazard records kept by the bank, "the vast majority are not abusers in any fair sense."
Mr. van der Jagt, a 13-term Congressman, said Republicans were doing better at recruiting challengers than in any recent year. But he added that one limitation on the advantage Republicans might have from the bank issue was that their kind of suburban voters were more likely to take this issue seruiously than were Democratic voters in big cities.
"Republican voters hold their Congressmen to a higher standard, in general, than Democratic voters hold their Congressmen to," he said.
Mr. Fazio, who has served seven terms in Congress, acknowledged the difference. "Suburban constituencies can relate more to banking issues," he said. "It will not be a major problem in some urban constituencies."
That difference, and the fact that many candidates, including Republicans, will be running in changed districts because of redistricting, are major reasons that Republicans want to contest the bank issue on more than a district-by-district basis, but in terms that decades of power have left the Democrats unfit to rule.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record;
Unions Are Split on Backing Clinton

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 13

 BODY:
Workers in Michigan and Illinois, two big-labor states whose primaries on Tuesday may well decide the Democratic Presidential nomination, will find no definitive reading on Gov. Bill Clinton's labor record if they look toward his home state of Arkansas.
Here, he is either effusively praised or sharply damned, with little neutrality in between. 
 There are as many contradictions here as verities. And there are people who say that is precisely the way Mr. Clinton has played things, working sometimes with big labor, sometimes with big business, scrambling to keep from being caught in a political squeeze in a severely depressed state with a right-to-work law.
The leaders of seven major unions in Arkansas have come out in strong support of the Governor's Presidential bid, saying that in his 12 years in office he has been a friend of big labor, pushing for more jobs and higher wages.
 
Mixed Reviews All Around
 But other labor leaders in the state say Mr. Clinton has done little for worker safety and benefits. Similarly, the Governor gets mixed reviews from many business leaders in his state.
The labor leaders on record in support of Mr. Clinton's candidacy represent the United Paperworkers International, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the United Food and Commercial Workers, the United Steelworkers, the United Rubber Workers, the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
"Organized labor in Arkansas is solidly behind Bill Clinton," those leaders declared in a recent statement released by Tommy McFalls, a paperworkers official and vice president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O.
"He has stood with us in our fight to raise wages, protect jobs, enhance worker safety and expand opportunity for all people," the statement says. "Brothers fight. But when push comes to shove, Bill Clinton has always been in our corner."
 
A Major Detractor
 But the leading labor figure in the state, J. Bill Becker, president of the Arkansas A.F.L.-C.I.O. for the past 28 years, adamantly disagrees.
"Bill Clinton is mainly the friend of big business," Mr. Becker said in an interview. "Labor has backed him some in the past, true, but only because he's been the lesser of two evils in a right-to-work state in the Deep South."
While Mr. Clinton has been Governor, Mr. Becker argued, Arkansas has remained at the bottom in most statistical measures of economic progress and quality of life. He contended that Mr. Clinton has boasted about the state's right-to-work law and its bottom-ranked wages in an effort to lure business to the state, has ignored safety concerns and has done little to push for better benefits for working people.
"Every time he's claimed to be our friend, we've ended up with a knife in the back," Mr. Becker said.
 
Sued by U.A.W.
 Recently, Mr. Becker sent a lengthy confidential memorandum to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters in Washington in which he discussed Mr. Clinton's labor record.
"I concluded that, at best, the Governor had sided with labor on only one of every four issues," Mr. Becker said in the interview.
One major union in Arkansas, the United Auto Workers, has taken the Governor into court, charging in a pending suit that he and officials of the Arkansas Industrial Development Commission interfered with the collective bargaining process by guaranteeing a $300,000 loan for a plastics manufacturer that was facing tough labor negotiations. The negotiations ended in a strike.
Mr. Clinton and the other state officials have countered that the loan was not an anti-strike fund but was meant to help the company expand and regain its financial footing, saving jobs.
 
Right-to-Work Supporter
 U.A.W. officials in Arkansas declined to comment on the dispute, saying it is up to the courts to resolve. Nor will they say whether they have been in contact with auto workers officials in Illinois and Michigan, states where U.A.W. votes will be pivotal Tuesday.
The Governor's labor record is increasingly becoming an issue in the Michigan and Illinois primaries. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts tells his audiences that Mr. Clinton has tried to lure industry to Arkansas by boasting that it is a right-to-work state with the fifth lowest wages in the nation.
Mr. Clinton says he has helped Arkansas become one of the leaders in attracting and creating jobs, but he denies using the pitch described by Mr. Tsongas.
In fact, over the years some of the literature and advertisements produced by the state's industrial development commission have pointed out that the state has a right-to-work law and "competitive" wages that are among the lowest in the country.
Former Governor Edmund G. Brown of California contends -- and Mr. Clinton denies -- that the Governor presides over a state with one of the country's worst records of worker safety and one of the worst working climates.
One study, produced by the National Safe Workplace Institute, a non-profit study group based in Chicago, ranks Arkansas 50th in accident prevention, enforcement of safety regulations and worker's compensation.
Another not-for-profit study group, the Southern Regional Council of Atlanta, ranks Arkansas 49th in overall working climate, 48th in earnings, 47th in workplace conditions, 45th in quality of life and 35th in worker protection.
The other day while campaigning in Chicago, Mr. Clinton said he was "pro-worker, not anti-union."
"Most people in the work force work in non-union jobs," he added. "So I have to address union and non-union."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Tsongas Being Haunted By Memory of Dukakis

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 14

 BODY:
Standing between Paul E. Tsongas and the White House is not just Gov. Bill Clinton or President Bush, but the ghost of Michael S. Dukakis.
Mr. Tsongas jokes about the inevitable comparisons to the other Greek-American Presidential candidate from Massachusetts, the one who infuriated many Democrats four years ago for letting the White House slip beyond his reach. But memories of Mr. Dukakis haunt Mr. Tsongas and his campaign. 
 Many Greek-Americans who put their hearts, and donations, into the Dukakis campaign stayed clear of Mr. Tsongas this year out of fear of getting burned again. Other voters wrote off Mr. Tsongas as an uninspired, plodding campaigner in the Dukakis mold who would not respond swiftly to opponents' attacks. Underlying these anxieties was a conventional wisdom that nominating another Greek-American from Massachusetts was the recipe for electoral disaster.
"All of 1991, that was question No. 1," said Mr. Tsongas, a former Senator. " 'Do you think the country's ready for another Greek from Massachusetts?' I just didn't see any worth in spending my time articulating why I'm different from Michael or somebody else."
Although Mr. Tsongas takes comfort in the fact that no one has asked him the "Greek from Massachusetts" question in a month, he has nonetheless set out to distinguish himself from the former Massachusetts Governor. Declaring, "I'm a Greek from Massachusetts who fights back," Mr. Tsongas now readily attacks the Arkansas Governor, his chief rival, in commercials and speeches.
In truth, Paul Tsongas and Michael Dukakis are both strikingly similar and strikingly different.
While they are both unabashedly liberal on social issues, Mr. Tsongas is far more conservative on economic matters. He bills himself as a pro-business candidate, while Mr. Dukakis was constantly at war with the business community in his state.
Both are sure of themselves often to the point of stubbornness, but Mr. Tsongas leavens that with a self-deprecating wit. Though he was usually deadly serious, Mr. Dukakis was a crisper speaker than Mr. Tsongas, who at times leaves audiences straining to make out what he is trying to say.
 
A 'Different Style'
 While Mr. Dukakis acknowledged that Mr. Tsongas has a "different style," he refused to concede that his 1988 campaign lacked humor. "I used self-deprecating humor from time to time," the former Governor insisted. He was very serious on that point.
Mr. Tsongas is more relaxed about running for President. When he is not curled up asleep on his chartered jet, he commandeers the loudspeaker to address the passengers as "Captain Tsongas." After the crew maneuvered through turbulent weather the other day, the candidate's Boston accent boomed from the speaker as he urged people to buckle up. "If you don't comply," he quipped, "we'll drop you off the plane. Probably over Atlantic City."
Mr. Tsongas's jokes may be flat, but Mr. Dukakis gave the phrase "stiff candidate" new meaning. On his campaign plane, he preferred sitting erect in his seat, balancing his family's check book or scrutinizing position papers. While Mr. Tsongas plunges into crowds in search of a baby he can hoist up, Mr. Dukakis and babies were a bad match; sometimes he would awkwardly hold one almost at arm's length.
"Tsongas has a better sense of the theater involved in running for President," said Andy Paven, a traveling aide to Mr. Tsongas who also worked for Mr. Dukakis in 1988. "I could never picture Michael getting photographed in a Speedo."
Of course there was the 1988 episode that will go down as one of the most embarrassing photo opportunities ever, when Mr. Dukakis donned a helmet and rode around in a tank.
It is a mistake Mr. Tsongas will not repeat. "Riding around in a tank has no relevance to my message," he said.
Perhaps from his brush with death as a cancer patient, Mr. Tsongas speaks more passionately about religious and spiritual issues than did Mr. Dukakis, who rarely strayed far from his mantra of "good jobs at good wages." Mr. Tsongas was near tears last week when he told reporters of a Palm Beach County deputy sheriff who was struck by a car and killed while clearing traffic for the campaign motorcade.
Even more than their Greek ancestry, both Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Dukakis are products of a white suburban reform culture in Massachusetts politics, which may account for similarities in how they approach running for President.
 
Met More Than 20 Years Ago
 They met more than 20 years ago, when Mr. Tsongas was on the Lowell, Mass., City Council and Mr. Dukakis was a State Representative. Both worked to revitalize Lowell.
Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Dukakis also operated in a heavily Democratic state where they had little experience battling Republicans and forging biracial coalitions to get elected. They each seem to have something of a moral righteousness, some say arrogance, in believing strongly that their answers were the best.
That got Mr. Dukakis in trouble. He did not believe that people would be swayed by the Bush campaign's pounding his record to portray him as a dangerous liberal.
Though he said that people forget that "we had a little bit of tough stuff" against Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri in the heat of the 1988 primaries, Mr. Dukakis said he did not mind Mr. Tsongas alluding to him as a Greek who did not fight back, .
"Look," he said, "it's part of the business. I don't have a problem with that stuff."
Even as he attacks Mr. Clinton, Mr. Tsongas seems uncomfortable about it, often finding himself knocked off stride by volleys from Mr. Clinton. In an article last week in The Boston Globe, Martin F. Nolan, a columnist, noted that after Mr. Tsongas won the New Hampshire and Maryland primaries, he did not boast about it on news programs, thereby allowing Mr. Clinton to get the attention.
"That sort of decision," Mr. Nolan wrote, "where counterchic and anti-charisma intersect with hubris, makes Tsongas seem most Dukakis-like."
Will the anti-charisma candidate from 1988 help the anti-charisma candidate for 1992? Though Mr. Tsongas helped raise money for the Dukakis campaign, the former Governor knows that returning the favor could do more harm than good.
Praising both Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton, the man who was on his way to the Democratic nomination four years ago said in his matter-of-fact manner: "I don't see any great value in endorsing. I like both of them."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
Clinton's Rivals Seek Midwest Toehold

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 14

 BODY:
The Democratic Presidential campaign focused on the critical primaries of the industrial Midwest this weekend, with Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas running strongly in Illinois but with former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California trying to trip him up in the more uncertain political terrain of Michigan.
The stakes on Tuesday are high. If Mr. Clinton wins both states, after his sweep of the South on Super Tuesday, many Democrats say he will be hard to stop in his drive for the nomination. 
 Mr. Tsongas badly needs a strong showing to steady his campaign and demonstrate that his message of economic sacrifice can play in a part of the country that is expected to be a battleground this fall. Mr. Brown, meanwhile, is trying to fill the void left by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa as the outspoken defender of labor, and thus maintain his toehold in the race.
The oratory and the television advertising have turned very harsh, although the underlying debate remains what it has been throughout this campaign: Who can best ease the nation's economic woes? The Tsongas campaign is running television commercials that assail Mr. Clinton as an over-promising politician laden with special interests. "You've got a choice," the announcer declares, "Clinton's promises, or Tsongas's commitment to jobs and economic growth."
 
Brown Plays Trade Theme
 The Clinton campaign continues to portray Mr. Tsongas as just another disciple of "trickle-down" economics, who can find a place in his economic policy for a cut in the tax on capital gains but offers little for the middle class. And Mr. Brown is playing the trade issue, considered potent in this region, by attacking both Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton for supporting "fast-track" authority for President Bush to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico.
Mr. Brown is considered a wild card here, where he has been campaigning hard among auto workers, whose union is suddenly at loose ends after Mr. Harkin's departure. Mr. Brown spent today with members of the United Automobile Workers union in Dearborn and Flint, again arguing that a free-trade agreement with Mexico would cost American jobs.
On the Republican side, Patrick J. Buchanan continued to campaign through Michigan and Illinois today, well aware that the relevancy of his campaign could depend on his showing there. He implored people to vote for him to "keep this debate going over the future of the Republican Party."
President Bush, who campaigned in Michigan on Friday, was back at Camp David for the weekend.
 
Clinton Favored in Illinois
 Mr. Clinton holds a substantial lead in a new poll in Illinois, and his aides have a hard time containing their optimism these days. He campaigned in a shopping mall in southeast Illinois today, telling people that a vote for him would "get your country back."
"I offer you something that is bigger than the fight between Democrats and Republicans," Mr. Clinton said.
He also defended himself against the suggestion that he was anti-union, saying, "I'll give you fair enforcement of the labor laws, not the biased enforcement you have on the Federal level now."
Mr. Clinton, whose coalition in the South was a hardy combination of black voters and middle-income whites, keeps honing his populist attack on Mr. Tsongas. In a debate Friday night in Chicago, Mr. Tsongas accused Mr. Clinton of wanting to give "candy" to people with proposals like a middle-class tax cut, but refusing to provide the leadership needed for economic recovery. Mr. Clinton countered, "He wants to continue to pound the middle class and lower middle class into the dirt."
Mr. Tsongas tried to make common cause with a group of unemployed people in Flint today, comparing the layoffs in that city to what happened to his hometown of Lowell, Mass., during the decline of the textile industry in the Northeast. Again and again, he told his audience that the way to create jobs was to reinvest in the nation's manufacturing base. "Let me tell you, there are no magic bullets," he said.
The former Senator was asked in polite questioning about his refusal to endorse legislation that outlaws the hiring of permanent replacement workers for strikers. "I understand that my position on striker replacement hurts me, but it's better policy," he said at a news conference. "We're going to give the American people a choice. We're going to tell them the hard truth and make the hard choices. My responsibility is to grow this economy."
A poll published in Sunday's Chicago Sun-Times showed Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Tsongas, 48 percent to 21 percent, among Democrats in Illinois, with Mr. Brown at 7 percent. The survey, conducted March 11-12, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points. David Wilhelm, the campaign manager for Mr. Clinton, said he found the poll "hard to believe," but added, "I think we've had a good week."
Dennis Kanin, Mr. Tsongas's campaign manager, said today: "I think we've got to spend the next couple of days getting the message out and trying to close the gap as much as we can. I don't think the people in Illinois or Michigan know much about any of these candidates, and unfortunately for us, Clinton got a big bump from his Super Tuesday win."
Mr. Tsongas also played down the polls. "Obviously, the polls that you are seeing reflect the bump for Super Tuesday and the early ads that were used against us," he said today. "The polls set a baseline -- let's see what happens on Tuesday."
The situation in Michigan is considered far murkier than in Illinois. No one is sure how strong Mr. Brown's bid for union support will turn out to be. And whereas Mr. Brown often drew from Mr. Tsongas's support in other states, his bid for middle-income people could draw from Mr. Clinton here.
