HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues;
The New, Volatile Politics of Welfare

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Sixteen years after Ronald Reagan transformed the "welfare queen" into a weapon of class warfare in his first try at the Presidency, candidates of both parties have been emboldened by the recession to make welfare a seminal political issue.
Because of its delicate relationship to issues of class and race, welfare has long been a ticklish subject for political discourse. But elected officials and political strategists agree that any reluctance to exploit welfare as an issue has dissolved in the last year as politicians have searched for ways to tap the electorate's economic discontent. 
 The new politics of welfare has been on display in forums from the Southern Presidential primaries to the mayoral race in San Diego.
President Bush's advertisements pledge that he will "change welfare and make the able-bodied work." Commercials for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential front-runner, have him "insisting that those on welfare move into the workplace."
 
'Welfare Scapegoating'
 In the San Diego race, a poll taker for County Supervisor Susan Golding, a Republican, advised her in a memorandum late last year to "create a storm of publicity" by proposing deep welfare cuts, even though he acknowledged that the cuts might be illegal.
Such political tactics have generated a counterassault, led largely by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, on what he calls "welfare scapegoating." Mr. Cuomo has criticized politicians of both parties for blaming the nation's economic problems on welfare spending and, by implication, on the poor.
"The poor people don't have any power," Mr. Cuomo said in a recent speech. "That's why welfare's such a terrific issue. Who's going to march against you, a 15-year-old girl with a baby? She doesn't even get to the polls."
In a year when there seem to be few differences between candidates, some political scientists believe that welfare could become the issue that most distinguishes Democrats from Republicans. In the Presidential race, the distinction has been reinforced by the White House's eagerness to rush to the right in trying to defuse Patrick J. Buchanan's campaign.
"The largest difference between the parties is not over economic policy but rather the view that one takes about poor people," said Lawrence M. Mead, a New York University professor whose book "The New Politics of Poverty" is to be published by Basic Books in April. "Are they victims entitled to protection, or people who could be self-reliant but are exploiting society?"
 
The Race Question
 In some cases, the political message on welfare has been communicated subliminally, seemingly aimed at evoking common stereotypes. Republicans call New York "the Cadillac of welfare states." President Bush, in his State of the Union Message, said welfare was never intended to become "a narcotic" or "a habit."
Their critics say part of the subliminal message is race. Forty percent of the families in the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, are black; 38 percent are white, and 16 percent are of Hispanic descent.
But in what may be a legacy of David Duke's campaign for Governor of Louisiana last year, politicians have become much bolder in moving from subliminal messages to overt ones.
In Massachusetts last fall, State Senator Michael C. Creedon, a Democrat, said of the state's welfare program for able-bodied adults: "General Reliefgoes to people who are urinating on the floor in the bus station in Brockton and throwing up. They take that $338 and go to the nearest bar and spend it." He was not concerned how his comments would be received, he said, because welfare recipients do not vote.
Many politicians who have seized on the welfare issue have argued that economic recovery depends on righting what Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, has called the "imbalance between taxpayers and tax receivers." In the process, the concerns of middle-class people, who vote in large numbers, have inevitably been pitted against those of the poor, who do not.
In New York, for instance, two Republican state senators recently sent mailings to constituents saying that the welfare system was racked with abuse and threatened school financing and property tax stability.
One of the two, Dean G. Skelos of Nassau County, wrote that Democrats "want to leave welfare cheats and Medicaid thieves alone, at your expense, contributing to higher property taxes and a declining educational system."
The other, Joseph R. Holland of Rockland County, chairman of the Senate Social Services Committee, made the same case in a fund-raising appeal in January. "Every day you go to work," he wrote, "a portion of your hard-earned paycheck is taken away from you to pay for the most inefficient, fraudulent and bureaucratic welfare system in the country."
Such charges are the stuff of campaigns all over the nation, and it is often hard to assess their merits. In New York, the State Department of Social Services estimates fraud to be relatively small, amounting to perhaps $100 million of the nearly $17 billion spent on welfare and Medicaid last year. But the state's special prosecutor for Medicaid fraud control, Edward J. Kuriansky, called that estimate "Pollyannaish" and said the figure for Medicaid fraud alone could be several billion dollars.
Public opinion polls consistently show that Americans support assistance for the truly needy. But they are increasingly disdainful of welfare recipients who do not try hard to find work or go to school and who bear children without means of support.
On the surface, the polls suggest that the welfare issue would play better for Republicans than for Democrats. But political strategists from both parties say it presents opportunities for moderate Democrats and poses potential risks for President Bush.
John E. McLaughlin, a Republican consultant in Alexandria, Va., said the welfare issue provided a chance for a Democrat like Mr. Clinton to show independence by breaking with his party's traditional stance. Mr. Clinton has proposed a two-year limit on public assistance for able-bodied adults.
And Mr. McLaughlin said Mr. Bush's focus on welfare could backfire. "The Democrats are making the race a class battle," he said, "and if the President cuts welfare and is unwilling to decrease taxes for the middle class, it sends a very bad signal."
The political exploitation of the welfare issue has emerged as efforts to change the welfare system have gained popularity in the states with remarkable speed.
As the recession has strangled state budgets, many states have cut grant levels sharply and eliminated welfare programs for the able-bodied. Some also have either enacted or proposed measures to use the welfare grant as an incentive for finding work and regulating family size.
Critics say such plans are based on myths about welfare. They say there is little scientific evidence to show that lower grants will prompt recipients to find jobs, especially during a recession. They point to Federal statistics showing that the average number of children in welfare families has decreased from 3.0 in 1969 to 1.9 in 1989.
And they stress that the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program, whose costs are shared by the Federal and state governments, accounts for only 3.4 percent of state budgets.
What has really broken state budgets, in New York and elsewhere, is Medicaid. While state payments for cash assistance to welfare families grew by 15 percent from 1989 to 1991, Medicaid payments grew by 36 percent.
But much of the growth in Medicaid has been driven by the increasing cost of long-term care for the elderly. And because many elderly Medicaid recipients are from the middle class, the Medicaid program has been sparedpolitical attacks. Many welfare experts say their greatest fear is that elected officials, in their rush to score political points, will enact welfare changes that do far more harm than good.
That was the concern of Sabra Burdick when she resigned on Feb. 4 as Maine's director of income maintenance after Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., a Republican, proposed to deny benefits to welfare mothers who gave birth to more children.
Ms. Burdick, who was appointed by the Governor, said she had argued against the proposal by citing studies showing that the size of welfare families in Maine had decreased significantly in the last 20 years. But she said Mr. McKernan seemed determined to make "a philosophical statement."
"I'm afraid it does sell, but I don't quite understand why," she said. "My bottom-line issue, of course, is it's the kids who are going to be hurt."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Increasing Need for a Strike on Iraq

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
A year after the end of the Persian Gulf war, senior United States officials are expressing a rising feeling that military force must be used soon to eradicate Iraq's remaining capacity to make weapons of mass destruction.
In interviews this week, the officials emphasized that military action would be taken only with United Nations approval and would not be aimed at reopening the gulf war or deposing the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. The Central Intelligence Agency is already mounting an undercover effort to separate Mr. Hussein from his power base in the military and the Baath Party, and speed his downfall. 
 Some flagging hopes remain that he will accede to diplomatic pressure and voluntarily dismantle Iraq's remaining Scud missiles and factories for making nuclear bomb parts and other arms, including chemical and biological weapons. Those actions were required by the United Nations cease-fire resolution that formally ended the war in March 1991.
 
The Endgame Begins
 But the officials made it clear that they believe that an endgame has begun in which Iraq will either bend quickly to that and other United Nations mandates or suffer the consequences. The Administration is confident, they said, that world opinion and United Nations voting will support the use of force if it becomes necessary.
This week's defiant visit to the United Nations by Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, has in a sense started the clock ticking, they said.
"Tariq Aziz has had his day in court, and he did not persuade," one official said on Friday. "So we'll send some more inspectors over there" to press for demolition of weapons complexes. "If Iraq's behavior still falls short, we'll have to make a decision."
Asked if the United States would wait a year or even six months to push for military action, the official said, "I don't think this will be strung out indefinitely."
A second Bush Administration official said that the United States and Iraq were locked in a duel of wits, in which Baghdad tests Washington's patience to its outer limits, then retreats when a confrontation seems likely.
The United States, that official said, "is philosophically inclined" to strike at Baghdad at the first opportunity at which the Administration feels it will have world backing. "But they know how to play the chess game too," the official said, and such an opportunity has yet to arise.
 
Four Formal Warnings
 Since the gulf war ended in late February last year, the United Nations has formally warned Iraq four times that it is violating the terms of the cease-fire, in which Baghdad pledged unconditional cooperation with efforts to catalogue and destroy its programs for nuclear, biological, chemical and missile warfare. The most recent warning came on Friday.
In his visit this week, Mr. Aziz promised limited cooperation with United Nations cease-fire resolutions and on other issues, including a longstanding and central demand that Baghdad fully disclose the scope of its nuclear, chemical and biological arms programs.
But Mr. Aziz also resisted plans for continued monitoring of Iraq's military industries, ruling out future inspections that might serve "either political or intelligence purposes."
Most important, he sidestepped demands that Iraq destroy missile manufacturing equipment and, most important, that it dismantle a nuclear weapons research complex at Al Atheer, south of Baghdad.
Iraq insists that Al Atheer and other military complexes can be converted to civilian uses, a premise the United States and others reject. While some United Nations envoys said they saw hints of flexibility in Mr. Aziz's statements, the American representative, Thomas R. Pickering, denounced his remarks as a deception.
 
Hints of Resistance
 Working with United Nations support, the International Atomic Energy Agency has agreed to send a team of inspectors to Al Atheer next month to inspect the nuclear complex and to plan its destruction. Iraq has dropped broad hints in recent weeks that it will resist such intrusive actions, suggesting that the safety of inspectors cannot be guaranteed.
Should Iraq continue to defy the cease-fire resolution, American and United Nations options are effectively limited to two choices: further warnings or force.
Trade sanctions imposed against Iraq shortly after its invasion of Kuwait 19 months ago remain in force. They have proven remarkably resilient, Administration officials asserted this week. One official said Friday that United States analysts had detected little change over the last year in the effectiveness of the trade embargo, which has grounded Baghdad's commercial air fleet, shut off its oil exports, severely limited imports of essential goods and depleted Iraq's reserves of foreign exchange.
The United States moved this week to close the largest remaining leak in the embargo by winning a commitment from Jordan's ruler, King Hussein, to try to reduce the flood of smuggling across his border into Iraq.
The Administration has been debating the need for undercover attempts to remove Mr. Hussein and military action against Iraqi weapons sites since at least last fall. But a number of outside experts argue that military force is, for now, unwarranted.
"There's no reason for us to do anything," said James E. Akins, a former American diplomat in Iraq. "Sanctions are certainly hurting Iraq, and ultimately, they're going to bring about the downfall of the Government." He added, "If we were to attack again, it's very likely that we wouldn't bring down Saddam, and equally likely that we'd only strengthen him" by rallying anti-Western sentiment to his side.
Mr. Akins and others also said that an American-led military strike against Iraqi weapons sites this summer or fall appeared increasingly unlikely because of the domestic political debate it would stir. In a presidential election year, Mr. Akins said, a military strike could be seen as a crass attempt to garner votes for an economically beleaguered Administration.
United States officials insisted this week that politics would play no role in any American decision to advocate force.

HEADLINE: Haitians Return to Deepening Misery

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 13

 BODY:
When the Coast Guard cutter Dependable berthed here this morning amid a collection of rusty freighters and listing wrecks, the marines aboard joined local photographers in crowding the gangway to snap pictures of the thin and threadbare Haitians who are expected to be among the last of the thousands forcibly returned to their country.
But if a strong sense of relief was felt by many of the Americans involved, from the coastguardsmen who have busily plucked Haitians from dangerous seas to the diplomats who have wrangled constantly with a Government the United States does not recognize, for most of those snared in the five-month operation, the future has become neither clearer nor brighter. 
 The charged debate in the United States over the Haitians' treatment has mainly focused on the risk of politically inspired violence that the returnees might face in the wake of a military coup that overthrew the country's first elected President on Sept. 30. But for most of the returnees, the most immediate concern remains what most now admit forced them to flee in the first place: poverty and hunger in a country whose modern economy, by many measures, has almost ceased to exist.
As the returnees filed off the ship and into the hands of the Haitian Red Cross and immigration officials, little hint remained of the stories many had told to the authorities at the United States refugee camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Often vague claims of political fears that many said justified their flight were displaced by vivid tales of hardship illustrated by their thin frames and gaunt, worried features.
 
Even More Miserable Now
 Almost to a person, each of these refugees complained that, unable to scratch out a living, they had been compelled by misery to leave their country. What they could not know, especially those who had been cut off for weeks from news of their country while they waited at the Guantanamo tent city for news of whether they would be admitted to the United States, was that the Haiti they were returning to, already the hemisphere's poorest country, had become a starkly more miserable place in their absence.
"We have two children, and we can't even send them to school," said Altes Paul, an unemployed 25-year-old who fled a month ago. "As long as there is no work, I can't tell you I won't leave again. We have a right to survive."
Some spoke with fear of repression, but most looked grimly toward a future that they said held little hope for them.
"Everyone you see here left because they had no money, nothing," said Pierre-Louis Jean-Francois, a 43-year-old from the drought-stricken north of the country, speaking in Creole as he crouched on the concrete amid a small pile of belongings. "Now we are back to nothing. When the Americans see us like this, don't they have any pity?"
 
Farmers Eating Seeds
 Back in his home region, which is denuded of trees and suffering an intense drought, the few hospitals and health clinics are now filling with severely malnourished children. International development experts say that to ward off starvation, many farmers have resorted to eating the seeds that would have produced the next crops.
United States immigration officials, and even some refugee advocates, now say it is becoming increasingly clear that only a fraction of the more than 15,000 Haitians who have been picked up at sea since the overthrow of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide had political motives for trying to reach the United States.
But Mr. Jean-Francois's plaintive question continues to reverberate troublingly, many say. Advocates for the refugees and Haitians themselves still bitterly ask how the United States can justify sending thousands of people back to a country where violence, much of it politically inspired, remains endemic, and the already stinging poverty has been worsened by an international embargo.
"Represssion is really severe in the countryside," said Guy Bauduy, a conservative Senator who has been a strong backer of the provisional Government that replaced Father Aristide. "Part of it is politically motivated, but most of it involves people taking advantage of the situation for a settling of accounts."
 
General Climate of Violence
 Stung by the alarming stories of violence and repression told by people who fled Haiti twice in the recent refugee crisis, United States officials say they have monitored more than 300 returnees in the capital and the countryside and "have found no evidence to substantiate and much that contradicts" allegations of politically motivated attacks, though they acknowledge a general climate of violence.
Arthur C. Helton, director of the Refugee Project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, condemned the recent decision by the Justice Department to keep more than 200 Haitians who have met the standards required to seek asylum but who have tested positive for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. They have been in effect quarantined at Guantanamo Bay, without legal representation, until their refugee applications have been adjudicated. Those who are rejected, officials say, will be returned to Haiti.
Immigration officials say that even those who pass the test for asylum will have to seek individual waivers from the Attorney General's office to lift strict restrictions on the entry of people "who have a communicable disease of public health significance."
 
'AIDS Is Not a Bar'
 Mr. Helton said, "Testing positive for AIDS is not a bar to refugee status, and these people should not be returned."
For the seemingly fortunate ones who have been cleared to pursue asylum claims, there is also the uncertainty of not knowing whether their applications will be quietly rejected once public attention to Haiti dies down.
Of the wave of more than 15,000 boat people who have passed through Guantanamo in recent months, 6,197 have been "screened in," which means cleared to pursue asylum claims in the United States. In the previous decade, 28 out of 23,000 Haitians picked up at sea were allowed to enter the country legally to seek asylum.
Despite the higher numbers, some refugee advocates worry that few of those allowed to enter the United States will be allowed to stay.

The baby was born last month at the refugee center in Guantanamo, Cuba. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Koreas Reach A-Pact; Effect Is in Doubt

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 14

 BODY:
North and South Korea today agreed to inspect suspected nuclear weapons sites on each other's soil by mid-June, but the accord appeared to fall far short of the kind of specific assurances that Washington and Seoul have sought in trying to stem the North's nuclear ambitions.
The agreement seems likely to intensify the argument over whether continuing talks between North and South are really making progress, or are being strung along by Pyongyang's Communist Government as an elaborate delaying tactic. 
 In recent weeks, several Administration officials, including Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, have said they believe that North Korea is racing to produce weapons-grade plutonium that could be hidden whenever inspectors finally enter the country.
Mr. Gates has said that Pyongyang could develop a nuclear weapon in months, but others, including experts at the Pentagon and the State Department, say a more realistic estimate is a year or two.
Today was the second time in a month that North Korea indicated that, in principle, it was willing to admit international inspectors.
 
International Inspection
 In a separate series of talks with the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, the Government of President Kim Il Sung has indicated that it would finally approve an inspection regimen required under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which it signed six years ago. Formal ratification by North Korea's Parliament is expected next month. It would likely be months before the first inspectors arrived.
The negotiations between North and South involve a separate set of inspections: visits across the heavily guarded Demilitarized Zone to affirm that the Korean peninsula is nuclear-free.
The United States, which kept nuclear weapons in South Korea for decades, is believed to have removed the last of them several months ago. Washington has said that under proper conditions, North Koreans would be permitted access to American bases in the South to confirm that no nuclear weapons exist.
But until now, Seoul insisted that Pyongyang must agree to a precise timetable for inspections. The first trial inspection, South Korean officials said as recently as last week, should take place next month.
Those conditions were abandoned in today's talks over the creation of a Joint Nuclear Control Commission composed of military experts from North and South. Establishment of the commission is the most important of a critical series of confidence-building measures that Seoul and Pyongyang agreed to when they reached a broad Agreement on Reconciliation and Nonaggression in December. That accord called for the commission to be set up by March 19.
Today's agreement specifies that the commission be established by the end of next week. Over the next two months, it says, the commission's members will make joint efforts to develop a specific inspection plan. In a statement today, the South Korean Government said it now hoped to carry out the first inspection by early June.
 
Some Loopholes
 "Our aim is to begin the mutual inspection within the first half of this year," Lim Dong Won, the chief South Korean negotiator, was quoted as saying by the semi-official Yonhap news agency.
But the agreement does not appear to hold the North to a strict schedule and it does not make specific mention of North Korean sites like Yongbyon, a secret complex where President Kim's Government is believed to be building a reprocessing plant to produce weapons-grade plutonium.
South Korea, Japan and the United States have made it clear that until full inspections are forthcoming, Pyongyang will remain cut off from economic aid and much-needed business alliances. But the United States has generally taken a harder line than Seoul has over how specific the timetables and locations should be. South Korean officials have said in recent months that their strategy is to keep the two sides talking.

HEADLINE: Senate's Tax Bill Wraps Up a Bouquet of Trial Balloons

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
The tax bill the Senate passed Friday night is not just a $300 credit for children, a 36 percent rate for the affluent or a new set of rates for capital gains taxes. Nor is it merely legislation intended to make health insurance much more widely available, especially to workers in small businesses.
Those items, and a few more that deal with growth, make up a Democratic statement of what ought to be done to make American society fairer. And it will remain such a statement, an argument for voters, even after President Bush makes good on his promise to veto whatever emerges from a House-Senate conference on this bill and the companion House measure. 
 No one in either chamber thinks a veto can be overridden, so this bill will not become law.
 
 
Laden With Special Provisions
 But there is much more in the bill. Its 1,421 pages (before amendments) were laden with provisions that affect much narrower interests of special concern to one or more Senators. Only a few of these provisions offered much of an electoral statement.
Some, like a proposal by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, to replenish the United Mine Workers Health Fund, have an obvious local appeal.
And some others were timed to get a little election-year attention. Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, got a provision adopted to allow penalty-free withdrawals from Individual Retirement Accounts for purchases of new cars.
 
 
Student Loan Proposal
 But most of the smaller provisions would have minimal political impact, even if Mr. Bush were willing to sign the bill into law.
A new student loan program, for example, intended to overcome the repayment problems of existing programs, might be an important change in national policy. But it would hardly be a great vote-getter for Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, its sponsor on the Senate Finance Committee.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, won acceptance of a measure broadening the tax-deductibility of charitable contributions of items like stock. While museums and universities may consider this a wise development in tax policy, they cannot profit from a bill that will not become law.
 
 
A Foot in the Door
 The reason for these seemingly fruitless efforts is to pave the way for future action. Mr. Moynihan calls the practice a "footnote." If a provision has been passed once, even if fails to be enacted, it seems less controversial the next time around. So when another tax bill comes along, as one surely will, the measures that one house -- or, better yet, both houses -- previously agreed on are more likely to be agreed on again.
There is likely to be another tax bill this year. It almost certainly will have neither the middle-class tax cuts and upper-bracket increases that the Democrats want, nor the large reduction in the capital gains tax that Mr. Bush seeks.
But most senators expect to see another set of extensions for a few relatively inexpensive credits, like those fostering research and experimentation and low-income housing. And they think it likely that some relief from the "passive loss" rules for the real estate industry, and elimination of some of the luxury taxes on planes, yachts, furs and jewelry will be included.
And there might be room for a few of the seemingly obscure sections that may get to the President's desk as part of a bill he will veto.
 
 
A Rare Critic
 Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, called it a process of "legitimizing" pet provisions. He said senators feel "if you get it in once, you can get it in again."
He is a rare critic of the practice, complaining that the Senate bill included not only the provisions that stimulated real political debate, but also a series of special-interest proposals -- from tax relief for oil and natural gas drillers to "a new credit for restaurant owners, a provision to allow universities to issue more tax-exempt bonds, and provisions for fishing fleets, the Federal Express pilots' pension planand the securities industry."
Many of those proposals might have merit, he said. But he asked what they had to do with either economic growth or tax fairness, and suggested that if they were worth doing, perhaps they were worth doing more openly, with hearings and debate.


GRAPHIC: Revenue estimates are for cost or gain over five years, calculated by the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation.
 
TAX CUTS FOR INDIVIDUALS
 
SENATE: Create a permanent $300 tax credit for children under 16, available to families with Adjusted Gross Incomes under $47,500, and phase the credit out for families with A.G.I.'s between $47,500 and $60,000. After $60,000, the credit would not apply. Cost: $28.0 billion
 
HOUSE: Two-year tax credit for one-fifth of Social Security and Medicare taxes paid by workers, up to $200 a year for individuals and $400 for couples. Unlike the Senate measure the credit in the House bill would be paid even if it exceeded Federal taxes owed.
 
BUSH: Increase the personal exemption for children under 18 to $2,800 from $2,300.
 
SENATE: Simplify and expand the earned income tax credit for families with two or more children but repeal a supplemental credit for children under one year old. Cost: $1.0 billion.
 
HOUSE: Increase the earned income tax credit for families with two or more children, but repeal a supplemental credit for children under 1.
 
BUSH: No provision.
 
SENATE: Allow either a deduction of interest paid on student loans, or a tax credit of 15 percent of such interest up to $300. A new pilot program of student loans with I.R.S. collecting payments. Cost: $0.9 billion.
 
HOUSE: Tax credit of 15 percent of student loan interest up to $300, and up to $500 when interest equals 10 percent of taxpayer's income. Credit phased out at Adjused Gross Incomes between between $75,000 and $100,000 for couples paying a dependent's interest and at A.G.I.s between $50,000 and $75,000 for couples paying their own interest.
 
BUSH: Allow deduction of interest paid on student loans.
 
SENATE: Restore complete deductibility at all income levels of up to $2,000 for contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts. Create new I.R.A.'s: contributions would not be deductible but income withdrawn would not be taxed if deposits are left in account for five years. Cost: $5.0 billion.
 
HOUSE: No provision.
 
 BUSH: Create new I.R.A.'s with nondeductible contributions of up to $2,500. Withdrawals would be untaxed if left in account for seven years.
 
For other I.R.A. provisions, see Real Estate category.
 
TAX CUTS FOR BUSINESSES
 
SENATE: Lower tax rates on capital gains from current range of 15 to 28 percent to a range of 5 percent, for those with lowest incomes, to 28 percent. Assets would have to be held two years to qualify. Institute effective maximum rate of 14 percent on gains from new investments in small business held five years. Cost: $7.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Whatever Happened To Sports?

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
ONCE upon a time sports itself was everything. Who won? Who lost? Who hit the big home run? Who fumbled at the goal line? Who made the crucial free throw? Who missed the short putt? Which boxer deserved the decision?
But more than ever before, the erosion of sports is threatening its quality of life as entertainment and enjoyment. 
 Yesterday, the names of three Mets -- Dwight Gooden, Vince Coleman and Darryl Boston -- surfaced in the Port St. Lucie, Fla., Police Department's investigation of a March 3 rape complaint by a New York woman who contended that the incident occurred in Gooden's rented home there nearly a year ago.
Gooden, Coleman and Boston declined comment. But the investigation continues. So does the erosion. What's on the police blotter is more important than what's in the box score.
Spring training was always the best time in baseball, a time of hope when every team was in first place. Not this year.
Only a week ago, Pascual Perez, sitting in his limousine, insisted that his failed Yankee drug test was all a mistake. Since then, the Yankees' exiled principal owner, George Steinbrenner, acknowledged having talked to Paramount executives about that conglomerate's desire to purchase the franchise whose previous president, Leonard Kleinman, has yet to drop litigation against Commissioner Fay Vincent.
But it's not just baseball.
In a Southeastern Conference basketball tournament game between Louisiana State and Tennessee Friday night, 10 players, including all-America center Shaquille O'Neal, were ejected for a bench-clearing brawl. Under N.C.A.A. rules, O'Neal was ineligible for L.S.U.'s semifinal loss to Kentucky yesterday.
And Olympic basketball suddenly has a dangerous dispute. Michael Jordan, Patrick Ewing and John Stockton are objecting to the use of their images by USA Basketball in Olympic merchandising. The three National Basketball Association stars, who each have Nike sneaker contracts, might withdraw from the Olympic team that will play in Barcelona, Spain, this summer.
Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion, is awaiting sentencing on March 26 in Indianapolis after having been convicted of rape.
Darryl Strawberry of the Dodgers put his byline on a book manuscript that he acknowledged he didn't read before it was published.
Jerry Tarkanian has or has not resigned as coach of the University of Nevada-Las Vegas basketball team that lost its litigation demanding consideration for the N.C.A.A. tournament.
In the National Hockey League, the April 8 start of the Stanley Cup playoffs has been jeopardized by a lack of progress in the labor negotiations between the players and the owners.
Even in golf, usually the most serene sport, PGA Tour commissioner Deane Beman is disputing an incendiary "Can Beman Survive?" cover story in Golf Digest magazine.
Almost every day a professional or college athlete is on a police blotter somewhere for something. Or a college is under investigation for violating N.C.A.A. rules.
Not that sports never had some erosion. Eight members of the 1919 Chicago Black Sox were banned for conspiring to dump that year's World Series. In college basketball, Madison Square Garden had to be fumigated from the stench of the 1951 point-shaving scams. Drugs and criminal cases have involved other famous athletes. Labor disputes have disrupted major league baseball and pro football seasons. Tennis players turned tournaments into kindergarten classes.
Much of today's erosion can be linked to the money that sports attracts. Relatively much more money than ever before.
Despite the recession in the national economy, sports salaries and television contracts keep spiraling upward, separating the identity gap between performer and spectator as never before. With all that money, more temptations are more affordable. More athletes are vulnerable. More struggles develop between the club owners and the athletes. More colleges need more good athletes (not always good student athletes) to supply more good teams to pay more mortgages on more stadiums and arenas.
Once upon a time sports itself was everything. But now it's money that seems to be everything. If money is the root of all evil, it's also the root of this erosion. And as long as that philosophy endures, the erosion has only begun.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Lynn Looks for a New Conquest

BYLINE: BY TIMOTHY W. SMITH

 BODY:
Two weeks ago Mike Lynn ended his 18-year relationship with the Minnesota Vikings by selling his 10 percent share in the team to a group headed by the team's president, Roger Headrick.
Two options now open to Lynn include purchasing a controlling interest in the New England Patroits or trying to land an expansion franchise for Memphis, an effort that he helped spearhead in the early 1960's. Lynn still owns a home in Memphis. 
 Although Lynn, speaking by telephone from his home in Minneapolis, would not talk specifically about his plans, he indicated that he did not see himself as a minority owner. That's why he sold his share to Headrick, after Headrick and six others bought out Irvin Jacobs and Carl Pohlad for a reported $52 million.
 
Seeking Control
 "I have no interest in having what ultimately amounted to a 10 percent interest in a team that I wasn't the principal managing partner or had no control of," Lynn said. "I'm much more interested in having a controlling interest in a team and maybe being involved with one partner."
N.F.L. officials are still trying to attract a buyer for the Patriots but face a formidable obstacle on two fronts. The team is heavily in debt and plays in Foxboro Stadium, which is 45 miles from Boston. The league wants to maintain a presence in Boston and is seeking an owner who won't move the franchise to another city. The solution might be a new stadium tied to a convention center in Boston. But convincing city, county and state government officials and private interests that a new stadium for the Patriots will be a boon to an economically depressed state will be tough.
Lynn said he was instrumental in guiding the effort for the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome in Minneapolis, which was completed in 1982.
"The opportunity to work with the public and private sector to find a way to build a new facility is one that not many people have had," Lynn said. "I did it in Minneapolis. The stadium here is a success story. It's not supported by taxpayers, and it has $25 million in its coffers."
 
'I Gave Up Too Much'
 Even though the Vikings made the playoffs 12 of the 17 years when Lynn was general manager, his legacy with Minnesota will be marked by the trade with Dallas for running back Herschel Walker in 1989. The Cowboys wound up with eight draft picks, including the Vikings' first- , second- and third-round picks in this year's draft.
"Did I give up too much?" Lynn said. "I gave up too much. In retrospect, maybe I gave up three more picks than I should have. But Herschel is a good back. He ran for over 800 yards last year, and he was only on the field for 60 percent of the time. Just think if he had been on the field 100 percent of the time. He might have run for 1,200 yards."
Though he was roundly criticized by Vikings fans for the Walker trade, Lynn does not look back on his time with Minnesota with any regret.
"When you run a team, you have three constituencies that you have to satisfy," Lynn said. "You have the public, which we gave some competitive and enjoyable games. You have the team, and all they ask is that you give them necessary tools to win. We had more players in the Pro Bowl than any other team during my time there, so I'd have to say we had the talent.
"And finally you have the shareholders, who ask if you're profitable. We were one of the most profitable teams in the N.F.L. We were the only team to make a profit during the 1982 strike."
 
W.L.A.F., Year 2
 When ABC and USA Network began to get nervous about low ratings for World League of American Football games last year, and when 26 of 28 National Football League owners, shareholders in the World League, began to fret over significant financial losses during the first season, most people thought the fledgling spring football league was dead.
But the World League is back for its second season, this time as part of the N.F.L's international division. The 10-game regular-season schedule of the 10 teams, six in North America and four in Europe, will begin next weekend.
A major feature of this spring's refurbished package was the promised infusion of N.F.L. players into the World League's talent pool. Each N.F.L. team was supposed to make four players available for the spring league's draft, in hopes of making the World League teams more competitive and more attractive to fans. But for the most part, the allotments have been uneven and the talent relinquished by the N.F.L. clubs has been marginal at best. None of the young N.F.L. stars like Raiders quarterback Todd Marinovich, Lions quarterback Andre Ware or receiver Herman Moore were offered to the World League.
Joe Bailey, the chief operating officer of the World League, wouldn't criticize the N.F.L. for sticking with the letter of the agreement while ignoring the spirit of it. After all, Bailey pointed out, the 100-odd players the N.F.L. provided this year is much better than the 5 it sent last year.
The Washington Redskins, winners of the Super Bowl, made one player available, while the Raiders sent nine players. Of the 110 players from the N.F.L., some culled from practice squads, 80 remain on active World League rosters after a three-week training camp that ended this past week. But another cut is tomorrow, when each team has to get down to 36 players.
"There isn't any question that there is very little difference between a segment of players in the N.F.L and World League players," Bailey said. "Some of it is serendipity. Some of it is that a player might not fit into the coach's philosophy or plans."

HEADLINE: Sanitation Workers Approve a Contract

 BODY:
New York City's sanitation workers overwhelmingly approved their new contract with the Dinkins administration by a vote of 4,281 to 429. the union has announced.
The mail-in ballot followed the negotiating committee's 85-to-0 approval of the tentative agreement, worked out by the executive board of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association. 
 Under the new contract, which is modeled after the city police accord, sanitation workers will receive a 4.5 percent raise over 15 months, pushing top base pay to $36,876. The contract also provides an increase of $595 in longevity pay.
"Understanding the problems of the economy, our membership recognizes that this is an exceptionally good contract," said Edward Ostrowski, president of the union, noting the 91 percent approval vote.
He said agreement has also been reached on the recycling program and collection routes, although further negotiations will be required. City authorities have called this agreement a major step toward making the city's recycling program more cost-effective.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 545 words

HEADLINE: Foreign, to the Democrats

 BODY:
When even Richard Nixon voices alarm at how little help America has offered Russia's bold reformers, how does President Bush respond? In terms that leave him sounding like Mad magazine's Alfred E. Neuman: "What, me worry?"
Well, Mr. Bush said last week, maybe the Administration will try to help stabilize the ruble. But otherwise, "There isn't a lot of money around . . . I don't have a blank check." As if anyone were asking for one. Given the chance of a lifetime to encourage democracy, the Leader of the Free World can only sigh. Are his Democratic rivals any more responsive? 
 The three remaining Democratic candidates barely deign to notice that, apart from trade, the U.S. has any interests abroad. On the pivotal issue of aid to Russia, they at least state responsible positions, best of all Bill Clinton. But even here their proposals are too little and too lame.
That's not just a sin of omission. Their reticence clanks jarringly against the central theme of their campaigns. The Democrats all want to shift billions from defense to domestic spending. But the critical precondition for that is Russia's transformation from foe to friend. Aid now can speed it.
All three Democrats favor a new internationalism, and they insist they want to promote economic growth. For now, aid to Russia can help advance both. Some of the aid will pay for food and consumer goods made in America. And in years to come, expanding markets could help propel U.S. growth.
Paul Tsongas would take $2 billion from defense and use it for humanitarian aid. And he wants to establish an "Executive Peace Corps" of retired business people to train entrepreneurs in Russia.
In December, he said: "We have to help the Soviet people through the winter. So if there's going to be mass starvation, deprivation, then we're going to be looking at some serious problems militarily. If you're going to starve them first then don't be surprised if . . . you're going to have a right-wing takeover." But he's had little to say since.
Jerry Brown's campaign staff says he favors aiding Russia, but he's managed to steer clear of the subject almost entirely.
Mr. Clinton has been more outspoken. In a March 5 debate, he urged that the U.S. "Help them dismantle their nuclear force, help them get through the cold months, help them [get] a convertible currency . . . . give a lot of incentives to our companies to do joint ventures." That's still short on specifics. But in contrast to Mr. Bush, it's at least arguing for aid, and in public.
Mr. Clinton did it better in a December speech at Georgetown University: "I know it may be bad politics to be for any aid program. But we owe it to the people who defeated Communism, the people who defeated the coup. And we owe it to ourselves. A small amount spent stabilizing the emerging democracies in the former Soviet empire today will reduce by much more the money we have to commit to our defense in the future. And it will lead to the creation of lucrative markets which mean new American jobs."
It's obviously easier to make a speech than to carry out a policy. But at least Mr. Clinton talks sense to Americans about the opportunity in Russia. President Bush seems unwilling even to say, let alone do, the right thing.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 705 words

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Who Fed This Caesar?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A year after the Persian Gulf war Saddam Hussein remains a menace, evading United Nations orders to destroy his nuclear and missile manufacturing plants. President Bush has hinted at renewed military action if the evasion goes on. There could be a June Surprise.
With all that was and still is at stake in Iraq, Congress has been surprisingly slow to look into past American policy. What was the United States doing while the Iraqi dictator was growing into such a menace? 
 In the absence of serious Congressional inquiry, the answer to that question has begun to emerge in the press. It is a shocking answer: The United States was feeding Saddam Hussein's war machine and his ambition.
That is the consistent theme of reports in The Washington Post, in The New York Times in a January piece by Seymour Hersh, and in a series by Murray Waas and Douglas Frantz in The Los Angeles Times over the last month. These were some of the important U.S. policy decisions they found:
In 1982 the Reagan Administration, wanting to prevent Saddam Hussein's defeat in the war with Iran, decided to provide him with secret intelligence. The intelligence helped Iraq learn the disposition of Iranian forces.
The Administration also allowed Iraq's regional allies, which at the time included Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Jordan, to send Baghdad American-made arms. Among the weapons supplied were thousands of TOW anti-tank missiles, Huey helicopters, small arms and mortars.
In the same year the State Department removed Iraq from the official list of terrorist countries, thereby making it eligible for U.S. aid. In fact, Saddam Hussein continued to harbor terrorists, and we knew it.
The United States immediately began giving Iraq guarantees for credit to buy American farm products. Farm and other credits for Iraq eventually came to $3 billion -- no doubt freeing Saddam Hussein to spend money on arms.
The Los Angeles Times stories described George Bush as playing a leading part in pressing U.S. support for Iraq over the next years, acting first as Vice President.
In June 1984 Vice President Bush telephoned the president of the Export-Import Bank to urge approval of a $500 million loan guarantee for Iraq to build an oil pipeline. Ex-Im, which had been reluctant, approved.
In February 1987 Vice President Bush telephoned the Ex-Im president to press for $200 million in loan guarantees. Economists warned the bank that Iraq could not repay the loans, but the bank approved the guarantees.
In March 1987 the Commerce Department approved export licenses for shipment to Iraq of dual-use technology, useful for scientific or military purposes. Over the next few years exports of this kind totaled $600 million, and much of the equipment may have gone into aerial spying and other military uses.
In August 1988 a cease-fire ended the Iran-Iraq war. But the American tilt toward Iraq continued. Some intelligence was being provided as late as May 1990.
In 1989 Mr. Bush, now President, signed a national security order directing Government agencies to improve ties with Iraq.
In October 1989 Secretary of State James Baker telephoned Clayton Yeutter, then Secretary of Agriculture, and urged him to approve $1 billion in new loan guarantees to Iraq despite fears that the credits were being misused. In November Mr. Yeutter approved the guarantees.
In January 1990 President Bush signed an executive order finding that it would not be "in the national interest" for the Ex-Im Bank to stop loan guarantees to Iraq.
In April and again in June 1990 the Commerce Department proposed restrictions on high-technology exports to Iraq. An inter-agency group chaired by Robert M. Gates, then deputy national security adviser to President Bush, rejected the proposals.
In July 1990 the Senate voted overwhelmingly to cut off loan guarantees to Iraq because of Saddam Hussein's human rights violations, including the gassing of a Kurdish village. The Administration condemned the vote.
On July 31, 1990, with 100,000 Iraqi troops massed at the Kuwait border, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly went to Capitol Hill and testified against ending loan guarantees to Iraq.
On Aug. 2, 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 22; Column 5; Spring Times Supplement

LENGTH: 1489 words

HEADLINE: ARTS AND ENTERTAINMENT;
THEATER

BYLINE: By DAVID RICHARDS

 BODY:

March
"CONVERSATIONS WITH MY FATHER." Herb Gardner's new play chronicles 40 years in the life of the Goldbergs, a Jewish immigrant family not unlike the playwright's own, on the Lower East Side. Judd Hirsch stars. Previews began March 3; opens March 22. Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200. 
 "HAMLET." Stephen Lang tries his hand at the English-speaking theater's most challenging role, in a production directed by Paul Weidner. Previews began March 11; opens April 2. Roundabout Theater Company at the Criterion Center, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 869-8400.
"DEATH AND THE MAIDEN." Glenn Close, Gene Hackman and Richard Dreyfuss star in a drama by the Chilean writer Ariel Dorfman about a woman who plots revenge on the man who she thinks raped and tortured her 15 years earlier. Mike Nichols directs. Previews began Feb. 18; opens March 17. Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 307-4100.
"FOUR BABOONS ADORING THE SUN." John Guare's new play with music takes place at a dig in Sicily where two newly married archeologists (Stockard Channing and James Naughton) have taken along their children from their previous marriages. That means nine kids -- more than "The Sound of Music." The director, Sir Peter Hall, has his hands full. Previews began Feb. 22; opens March 18. Vivian Beaumont Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
"THE MASTER BUILDER." The love of Hilda, an enchantress from the mountains, pushes Solness, an aging architect, to dangerous heights. Literally. Ibsen's 1892 drama is the third production of Tony Randall's National Actors Theater. Previews began March 11; opens March 19. Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6280.
"JAKE'S WOMEN." Jake is a writer. He's having trouble with the women in his life, who are seen in two incarnations -- as Jake imagines them and as they really are. Alan Alda stars in Neil Simon's Pirandello-esque comedy, which has been rewritten since an abortive 1990 tryout in San Diego. Previews began March 12; opens March 24. Gene Saks, as usual, directs. Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52d Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 307-4100.
"FORBIDDEN BROADWAY'S 10TH-ANNIVERSARY EDITION." More cream pies from the people who make a living by making fun of the reigning hits and players on Broadway. Previews begin March 17; opens March 26. Theater East, 211 East 60th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 838-9090.
"GUYS AND DOLLS." This 1950 musical by Frank Loesser, Jo Swerling and Abe Burrows is one of Broadway's classics. And the cast that the director, Jerry Zaks, has assembled for this revival -- Nathan Lane, Faith Prince, Peter Gallagher and Carolyn Mignini -- doesn't look half bad, either. Previews begin March 16; opens April 14. Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
" 'TIS PITY SHE'S A WHORE." Giovanni loves Annabella, his sister, in John Ford's lurid masterpiece, directed by JoAnne Akalaitis, the Public Theater's head honcho, and featuring Val Kilmer, who played Jim Morrison in the film "The Doors." Previews begin March 17; opens April 5. Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 598-7150.
 
April
"THE END OF THE DAY." The hero of this comedy-drama by Jon Robin Baitz ("The Substance of Fire") is an expatriate Englishman who wants to wriggle free of his ex-wife's family and his Beverly Hills psychiatric practice. Nobody will let him. Directed by Mark Lamos. Previews begin March 20; opens April 7. Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42d Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 279-4200.
"A SMALL FAMILY BUSINESS." When Jack McCracken takes over the family furniture business, he vows it will be run with scrupulous honesty. By the end of Alan Ayckbourn's 1987 comedy, the corruption is all-pervasive. Previews start March 31; opens April 27. Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 645-5590.
"FIVE GUYS NAMED MOE." Cameron Mackintosh, producer extraordinaire of stage epics, changes his tactics with this intimate revue honoring the 1930's American jazzman and alto saxophonist Louis Jordan. Where else can you hear "There Ain't Nobody Here but Us Chickens" and join the cast in a conga line? Previews begin March 13; opens April 8. Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
"A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE." Alec Baldwin gets to wear the torn T-shirt and Jessica Lange blanches in the revival of Tennessee Williams's 1947 masterpiece, directed by Gregory Mosher. Previews begin March 17; opens April 12. Ethel Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
"TWO TRAINS RUNNING." August Wilson continues his cycle of plays about African-American life in the 20th century with this drama, set in a neighborhood restaurant in Pittsburgh, circa 1969. Among the characters who look upon the place as home are a fast-talking ex-convict (Larry Fishburne, the father in "Boyz N the Hood") and a pretty waitress and cook (Ella Joyce). Lloyd Richards is the director. Previews begin April 7; opens April 13. Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 582-4022.
"METRO." A runaway hit in Warsaw, this Polish musical is described as a cross between "A Chorus Line" and "Hair." It features a cast of 38 Polish actors (performing in English) and, apparently, is all about getting into a show. Previews begin March 26; opens April 16. Minskoff Theater, Broadway at 45th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 307-4100.
"HIGH ROLLERS SOCIAL AND PLEASURE CLUB." The composer and pianist Allen Toussaint heads a cast of eight, performing the music that makes New Orleans what it is, especially around Mardi Gras time. Previews begin April 6; opens April 21. Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 944-9450.
"SHIMADA." Jill Shearer's play, which stars Ben Gazzara, is set in a P.O.W. camp in Burma in 1945 and in present-day Australia. It is said to focus on Japan's economic might and that country's methodical acquisition of the world's major assets. It is also said to be a mystery. Previews begin April 11; opens April 23. Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
"MAN OF LA MANCHA." Raul Julia and Sheena Easton are top-billed in the 25th-anniversary production of the Dale Wasserman-Mitch Leigh-Joe Darion musical about a man with an impossible dream. Previews begin March 31; opens April 24. Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 46th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 307-4100.
"JELLY'S LAST JAM." Jelly Roll Morton: the man, the music, the piano. The director and playwright George C. Wolfe, the lyricist Susan Birkenhead and the composer Luther Henderson pay tribute in a new musical starring Gregory Hines. Previews begin March 28; opens April 26. Virginia Theater, 245 West 52d Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
"THE EXTRA MAN." The central character in Richard Greenberg's play is a young bachelor, who shows an excessive interest in the lives of his sleek urban friends. Previews begin April 28; opening date to be announced. Manhattan Theater Club Stage I, at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 581-7907.
"FALSETTOS." An amiable guy named Marvin comes out of the closet and comes of age in "March of the Falsettos" and "Fal settoland," two one-act musicals by William Finn. Each has already had a separate run. Played back to back, they make for a particularly revealing chronicle of life and love in an age of AIDS. Previews begin April 8; opens April 29. John Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 239-6200.
 
May
"SALOME" and "CHINESE COFFEE." In repertory: "Salome" is the exotic drama by Oscar Wilde; opens May 21. "Chinese Coffee" is a new two-character play by Ira Lewis; opens May 28. What's noteworthy is that Al Pacino appears in both. Circle in the Square, 254 West 50th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 307-2700.
 
June
"THE PRICE." Two estranged brothers meet after many years to dispose of their dead father's belongings in this revival of Arthur Miller's 1968 drama. The cost of furniture is debated. So is the cost of one's actions. Previews begin May 20; opens June 10. Roundabout Theater Company at the Criterion Center, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street. Information: (212) 869-8400.
"RICHARD III." Ian McKellen is the hunchbacked villain in this stunning production from the Royal National Theater of Great Britain, which moves the Shakespearean history forward to a fascist state in the 1930's. Previews begin June 9; opening date to be announced. Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene. Information: (212) 307-4100.

HEADLINE: TOURS

 BODY:
Here is a sampling of tours by bus, van and foot that are scheduled during the spring in New York City. Dates and times are subject to change.
 
Today 
 BROOKLYN NAVY YARD. A tour of America's first dry dock, with James S. Kaplan, a historian, and Thomas Montvel-Cohen of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Company. Sponsored by the Friends of the Parks. Meets at 1:30 P.M. at Flushing Avenue and Cumberland Street. Fee: $1. Information: (212) 473-6283.
"BEVERLY HILLS EAST," mid-Manhattan. A walking tour past buildings that have had as residents Katharine Hepburn, Bill Cosby, Van Johnson, Marilyn Monroe, Greta Garbo and Montgomery Clift. Information: (212) 517-0201.

Meets at 2 P.M. at the Prospect Park Boathouse, reachable from the Lincoln Road and Ocean Avenue entrance, East New York section. Free. Information: (718) 287-3400.
BOROUGH PARK, Brooklyn. A walking tour of this Orthodox Jewish neighborhood, including a visit to a synagogue and a mikvah. Men should wear hats and women should wear skirts or dresses. Led by Joel Schwartz, a member of the Council of Jewish Organizations, Borough Park. Sponsored by the 92d Street Y. 11 A.M. Fee: $20. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 996-1100.
"SYNAGOGUE VOICES," Lower East Side, Manhattan. A tour of the Eldridge Street Synagogue, an architectural and historic landmark currently being restored. The tour includes a gallery visit and slide show. Sponsored by the Eldridge Street Project. Sundays, every hour from noon to 4 P.M. Fee: $5 ($2.50 for the elderly). Information: (212) 219-0888.

Information: (212) 979-2388.

"REAL COOL," Central Park, Manhattan. A walking tour to learn how plants and animals have been coping with the cold weather. Sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 2 P.M. at the Loeb Boathouse, 75th Street and the East Drive. Free. Information: (212) 427-4040.
SEGUINE MANSION TOUR, Huguenot, S.I. A tour of the Greek Revival mansion on Raritan Bay, which was once home to Joseph Seguine, a 19th-century fishing magnate and farm owner. Sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 2 P.M. at Seguine Avenue, off Hylan Boulevard. Free. Information: (718) 667-6042.
"A WETLANDS TREASURE," Udall's Cove, Little Neck, Queens. A walk through one of New York's most pristine environments. Sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 1 P.M. at the northernmost end of Little Neck Parkway and 255th Street. Free. Information: (718) 699-4204.
"THE WOMEN OF WASHINGTON SQUARE," Greenwich Village, Manhattan. A walking tour through Washington Square with an emphasis on the history of women who lived in the area and worked in the arts and the labor movement. Led by Joyce Gold, a professor of history at New York University. Meets at noon at the arch in Washington Square. Fee: $12. Information: (212) 242-5762.

Stops include the First Shearith Israel cemetery, the founding site of B'nai B'rith, tong headquarters, dim sum restaurants and the Chinese Museum. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. 1 P.M. Fee: $9 ($7 for students and the elderly). Reservations and meeting place: (212) 439-1090.
JEWISH HARLEM, Manhattan. A walking tour past the synagogues, theaters, and mansions of prominent Jewish families of the 1920's. Led by Marvin Gelfand, an economic historian. Sponsored by the 92d Street Y. March 22 at 1 P.M. Registration and meeting place: (212) 996-1100.
"PEDDLER'S PACK: A JEWISH HERITAGE TOUR," a walking tour led by a costumed actor through the Lower East Side. Stops include the Jewish Daily Forward Building, the Educational Alliance, and the Rabbi Jacob Joseph Yeshiva. Sponsored by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street. Meets at the museum at noon. Also April 5 and 19, May 3, 10, 17, 24 and 31, June 7 and 21, same time. Fee: $12 ($10 for students and the elderly). Information: (212) 431-0233.
"CIVIL WAR AND DRAFT RIOTS," lower Manhattan. A walking tour that explores events in New York City during the Civil War. Stops include Newspaper Row, Sweet's Restaurant, the site of the original Brooks Brothers building and the home of a Confederate spy. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $9 ($7 for students and the elderly). 11 A.M. Also May 23 at 2 P.M. and June 21 at 1 P.M. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 439-1090.
STATEN ISLAND WALK, Stapleton and Fort Wadsworth. A four-mile walk along the eastern shore of Staten Island past homes, the Stapleton Navy Complex, the Alice Austen House, and into Fort Wadsworth. Sponsored by Shorewalkers. Fee: $3. Meets at 10:15 A.M. at the Staten Island Ferry Terminal in lower Manhattan. Information: (212) 982-9714.
"A TOUR OF TWO CITIES," lower Manhattan. A walking tour that incorporates the history of conflict and cooperation between the Dutch, African and American Indian populations in early New York City. Stops include the Trinity Church Burial Ground, Wall Street and Battery Park. Sponsored by Reclaim the Memories. 1 P.M. Also April 25, same time. Fee: $12 ($5 for children). Reservations and meeting place: (212) 299-7011.
TURTLE BAY, Manhattan. A walking tour of the eastside neighborhood where Katharine Hepburn and Stephen Sondheim reside. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. 3 P.M. Fee: $5. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 265-2663.
 
March 27
FINANCIAL DISTRICT, lower Manhattan. A walking tour from the Battery to the Civic Center, past some of the oldest and newest examples of Manhattan architecture. Sponsored by Urban Explorations. 10 A.M. Fee: $15. Reservations and meeting place: (718) 721-5254.
 
March 28
ELLIS ISLAND. A guided tour of the museum and grounds with an emphasis on the history of American immigration. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $15 ($12 for students and the elderly), which includes fare to Ellis Island. 11 A.M. Also on April 11, May 2, and May 23 at 11 A.M.; and on June 3, June 17 and June 20 at 10 A.M. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 439-1090.
GREENWICH VILLAGE, Manhattan. A tour of the neighborhood. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. 3:30 P.M. Fee: $5. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 265-2663.
HISTORIC GREENWICH VILLAGE, Manhattan. A walking tour for history buffs and architecture lovers. Sights include the home of Edgar Allan Poe on West Fourth, the Church of the Ascension where President Tyler was married, and historic Jefferson Market Courthouse. Sponsored by Sidewalks of New York. Meets 2 P.M. at the arch at Washington Square. Fee: $10. Also on April 18, May 16 and June 20, same time. Information: (212) 517-0201.
"TIFFANY'S BROOKLYN," A mini-van tour of Brooklyn sites that contain Tiffany pieces, including the Lafayette Presbyterian Church, at South Oxford Street and Lafayette Avenue in Fort Greene, home to one of the largest Tiffany stained-glass window collections. Led by Louis Singer. 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Also May 23, same time. Fee: $25. Information: (718) 875-9084.
THREE PARKS IN QUEENS. Forest Hills, Queens. A seven-mile walk past Willow Lake, Flushing Meadows Lake and Kissena Lake. Sponsored by Shorewalkers. Fee: $3. Meets at 9:45 A.M. at the northeast corner of Queens Boulevard and 71st Avenue. Information: (718) 261-3579.
 
March 29
"THE STREETS WHERE WE LIVED," lower Manhattan. A walking tour of Chinatown and Little Italy. Sponsored by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 97 Orchard Street. Meets at the museum at 2 P.M. Also April 12 and 26 at noon; May 10 and May 24 at 2 P.M. and June 7 and 21 at noon. Fee: $12 ($10 for students and the elderly). Information: (212) 431-0233.
"THE CALL OF THE WILD," New Springville, S.I. A walk through William T. Davis Park to listen and learn about birdcalls. Sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 3 P.M. at the parking lot at Travis Avenue. Free. Information: (718) 667-6042.
"CHELSEA SAINTS AND SINNERS," Manhattan. A walking tour past the Chelsea Hotel and the General Theological Seminary. Sponsored by Sidewalks of New York. Meets at 2 P.M. in front of the Flatiron Building at the intersection of Broadway, Fifth Avenue, and West 23d Street. Fee: $10. Also on April 5, May 10 and June 7, same time. Information: (212) 517-0201.
"HISTORIC HARLEM," Manhattan. A walking tour of Harlem below 125th Street that will emphasize the history, architecture and culture of the area with stops at the Apollo Theater, the former Temple Israel Synagogue, the Workmen's Circle Building, and Fiorello H. La Guardia's childhood home. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. 1 P.M. Also on May 17 and June 17; same time. Fee: $9 ($7 for students and the elderly). Reservations and meeting place: (212) 439-1090.
"A TOUR NAMED JACKIE," Manhattan. A walking tour that focuses on the East Side neighborhood of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and the places she frequents. Sponsored by Sidewalks of New York. Meets 2 P.M. at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 91st Street and Fifth Avenue. Fee: $10. Also on April 26, May 24 and June 21; same time. Information: (212) 517-0201.
"DEATH SCENES OF THE RICH AND FAMOUS," mid-Manhattan. A walking tour past the hospitals, churches and funeral sites of long-gone personalities, including Rita Hayworth, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Fatty Arbuckle, Ethel Merman and Billie Holiday. Sponsored by Sidewalks of New York. Meets 2 P.M. at 13 West 54th Street, the town house once owned by Rockefeller and the site of his death. Fee: $10. Also on April 26, May 31 and June 21; same time. Information: (212) 517-0201.
LOWER EAST SIDE, Manhattan. A walking tour of the area that was home to thousands of new immigrants with a stop at the Eldridge Street Synagogue, built in 1886 and now under restoration. Meets at 1 P.M. at the corner of East Broadway and Oliver Street. Sponsored by Citywalks. Fee: $12. Information: (212) 989-2456.
"NEW YORK YESTERDAY AND TODAY," lower Manhattan. A walking tour from City Hall through the financial district to Battery Park. Stops include Trinity Church, Federal Hall, Castle Clinton, Delmonico's and Hanover Square. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. 1 P.M. Also April 25 and May 30 at 1 P.M.; May 17 at noon, and June 13 at 11:30 A.M. Fee: $9 ($7 for students and the elderly.) Reservations and meeting place: (212) 439-1090.
BLACK WOMEN'S HISTORY TOUR, lower Manhattan. A historical walking tour that focuses on early black women's contributions to society and organizations, with stops at St. Phillip's Church, the African Free School, the African Dorcas Society and the National Organization of Negro Women. Sponsored by Reclaim the Memories. 1 P.M. Also May 2, same time. Fee: $12 ($5 for children). Reservations and meeting place: (212) 299-7011.
"LILLIAN WALD'S NEW YORK," lower Manhattan. A walking tour of the lower East Side neighborhood that Lillian Wald, a philanthropist, devoted her life to improving. Led by Joyce Mendelsohn, an architectural historian. 1 P.M. Sponsored by the 92d Street Y. Fee: $15. Registration and information: (212) 996-1100.
"SPRING BREAK," Kissena Park, Flushing, Queens. A nature walk to see the sights of spring. Sponsored by the Urban Park Rangers. Meets at 1 P.M. at Kissena Park Nature Center, Rose Avenue and Parsons Boulevard. Free. Information: (718) 699-4204.
"RADICAL WALL STREET," lower Manhattan. A walking tour of the southernmost tip of Manhattan with an emphasis on radical history from the 1600's to the present, with stops at Fraunces Tavern and the New York Stock Exchange. Also the history of Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty will be told from a radical's perspective. Led by Bruce Kayton, a radical historian and politician. Sponsored by Radical Walking Tours. 1 P.M. Fee: $6. Meets in Bowling Green Park, between Broadway and State Street. Information: (718) 492-0069.
GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY TOURS, Sunset Park, Brooklyn. A walking tour of the hilly, 478-acre burial ground by John Cashman, a historian. 1 P.M. every Sunday through June 28. Meets at the main cemetery entrance at Fifth Avenue and 25th Street. Fee: $5. Information: (718) 469-5277.
"VERRAZANO TO SHEEPSHEAD BAY," Fort Hamilton and Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. A seven-mile walk along the western shore of the borough from the Verrazano-NarrowsBridge to Coney Island. Sponsored by Shorewalkers. Fee: $3. Meets at 11 A.M. at the last station of the R subway line, 94th Street and Fourth Avenue, Bay Ridge. Fee: $3. Information: (718) 428-4558.

CARIBBEAN RESORTS A number of resorts in Jamaica and St. Thomas have special air fares in connection with stays. The fare is available from Kennedy, Newark and Islip (L.I.) airports; various airlines are used. For a seven-night stay, rates at Couples start at $2,510 for two people sharing a double room through April 2; at Grand Lido, rates begin at $1,695 for each of two people sharing a double room through April 30, and at Jamaica, Jamaica, rates start at $1,350 for each of two sharing a room through April 2. The program must be booked through a travel agent. For general information, call the resort at (800) 524-2000.

Contact Flexi-Pax Tours at (800) 545-5540 or, in New York, (212) 692-9550.

Tickets are nonrefundable and must be purchased at least 14 days before departure. A Sunday stay is required. For more information, call (800) 776-3000.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk
