HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Troubled Housing Developers Shed Golf Courses

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C.

 BODY:
Slower home sales have driven residential developers to sell the amenities they once counted on to hasten land sales and raise prices -- their golf courses.
At least 10 percent of 2,600 residential developments centered on golf courses are in some sort of financial distress because of a lack of sales, according to real estate and golf industry analysts. 
 And perhaps hundreds have sold -- or are quietly trying to sell -- their courses, either to free up cash or to get out of a business they never should have been in in the first place.
"They're sick of it and want to get rid of them," said Craig Price, the executive vice president of the American Golf Corporation, of Santa Monica, Calif., which manages and owns 150 golf courses around the nation and often buys courses from developers.
"We're talking with one developer in Chicago who thinks golf is the dumbest thing he's ever seen," Mr. Price said, "but he's got all these experts telling him to put in a course. Now the project is 100 percent over budget and he's not selling anything and he's wondering why he's got this golf course."
Many of the distressed golf-course developments are in the South, particularly in Florida and in the Carolinas, where nearly three-fourths of all golf courses built in the last few years were conceived as fixtures for housing developments.
It is difficult to ascertain precisely how many courses in South Carolina are for sale, since developers or their lenders are reluctant to advertise their problems, said Rick Bell, a golf course-real estate analyst in Winston-Salem, N.C.
"This is a very quiet network," he said.
Developments in South Carolina were concentrated on the coast and in the foothills area of the Blue Ridge Mountains near this city in the state's northwestern corner. Perhaps surprisingly, Myrtle Beach, which has become a golf mecca in the last decade with the construction of more than 60 golf courses, has few courses with housing developments.
"Myrtle Beach is the Disney World of golf," Mr. Bell said. "Myrtle Beach as a real estate investment is awful. People who go to Myrtle Beach just don't buy real estate and developers have been concerned about Myrtle Beach's image as a moderate-priced market."
But some 100 miles down the coast, at Hilton Head Island, and to a lesser degree Kiawah Island, the opposite has been true. There, all but three of the 35 courses are tied to residential developments. To developers there and around the country, the golf course-residential development idea seemed as sure and as solid as a Jack Nicklaus tee shot.
The huge influx of new golfers, estimated by the National Golf Foundation at a million a year, was straining courses, and developers speculated that if golfers wanted more courses, they would want to live beside one, too. They hired designers to create championship courses, much as a builder hires an architect, and then subdivided the surrounding acreage for sale at prices 20 to 50 percent above course-less developments. House prices in the developments typically range from $200,000 to beyond $1 million.
Mr. Craig said two types of developers were attracted to such projects -- golfers whose desire to own a course obscured good business judgment and builders who saw the boom in golf and wanted to cash in. The National Golf Foundation predicted in 1988 that the country needed 350 new courses a year for a decade to meet the growing demand for places to play.
Soon, hundreds of new courses were being planned or built. In 1989, 54 percent of the courses opened were tied to housing developments.
The most-noticed courses are designed by renowned golfers -- Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Mr. Nicklaus, who commands a fee of at least $1 million for his designs -- and top-ranked designers, such as Pete Dye, Joe Lee and Tom Fazio.
The designers have no financial stake in the course, but in the mid-80's financing for golf courses was easy to come by, especially through savings and loan associations. To a lesser degree, banks provided money, as did insurance companies, which typically worked out joint ventures with developers.
Many developments did quite well. In South Carolina, Dataw Island, an Alcoa Properties development east of Beaufort, was particularly successful, Mr. Bell said. Lots range in price from $75,000 to $90,000 and homes from $300,000 to $1 million. The complex covers all the island's 800 acres.
But soon the market became flooded with high-cost properties just as the real estate market in general slumped. Financing dried up and some residential developments featuring golf courses, such as the unfinished Timberlake Plantation on Lake Murray near Columbia, S.C., went into bankruptcy. Late last year, the golf course was sold at auction for about $2 million and now operates as a separate enterprise.
"We went on a binge," said Lewis Goodkin, a Florida real estate analyst. "There are too many of the wrong kind of courses. We didn't segment the market enough and inadequately responded to daily fee and public and semi- private courses."
Sagging sales made developers fall behind on their loans because the upfront cost to build a golf course is huge -- between $3 million and $10 million, depending on the design. Analysts say that such high development costs simply cannot be repaid with membership fees and sales in the pro shop and restaurants.
To be sure, golf is a rapidly growing sport, but the newcomers are less affluent and less fanatic. They cannot afford or are not willing to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars for a course-side lot.
"It's much like the situation in Fort Lauderdale, where you'd find the vast majority of people who have docks don't have a boat," Mr. Goodkin said. "Most people who live around a golf course don't play golf. They buy there for the greenbelt and the privacy."
Because of the situation, many entrepreneurs are finding good buys.
Clarence Edwards, a businessman here, was able to buy the Links O'Tryon golf course and development about 30 miles north of Greenville in Gowensville in 1988 from a company in bankruptcy. In January, he sold the course to another company. He would not disclose the price, but said the deal left the residential development debt-free.
Mr. Edwards said he reduced prices and since Jan. 1 got five contracts to sell lots, compared with none in the last five months of 1991. All the lots will be used for primary residences, not second homes, as has been the norm at most link-side developments.
"You have to be flexible," he said of golf-course developments. "You can't always do what you set out to do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Clarence Edwards near one of the greens at the Links O'Tryon development in Gowensville, S.C. (Lyn Riddle for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1960 words

HEADLINE: Boy's Dream Becomes Man's Pain

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
FOR five months Sylvester Williams has lived with four other inmates in a dormitory room at the Connecticut Correctional Center on Whalley Avenue in New Haven. As the oldest in the room, he said, he often counsels the others, telling them that selling or using drugs is not the answer. A good, solid education, he reminds them, is the only thing that matters. "But then," he said, "they look at me as if to say: 'Hey, look at what you had, and look at you now. So who are you to be talking anyway?' "
 Mr. Williams, 34 years old, a former all-American basketball player and starting forward with the New York Knicks, is now serving three and a half years for second-degree assault on his girlfriend. He has spent the past two years in and out of jail and in a drug rehabilitation program. He was stabbed during an argument with his girlfriend in November and is confined temporarily to a wheelchair as a result of surgical complications following the incident.
 
'Baby in a Man's Body'
 In a recent interview at the prison Mr. Williams described his life as a kaleidoscope of triumphs and shattered dreams. The man known to his fans as Sly Williams grew up in New Haven poised to play basketball, he said, with little interest in his education or in confronting his personal problems. He attributed his descent to his inability to escape self-inflicted burdens and a lack of childhood role models. 
"By the time I walked away from the N.B.A.," he said, "I had realized that though I was 29 years old, I was, in fact, a baby in a man's body."
For decades the world of professional basketball has served as an attractive inducement for young men in city neighborhoods who see scholarships and national television exposure as an opportunity to overcome economic and social limitations. But the successes of professional players like Charles Smith and John Bagley, who grew up in Bridgeport, often overshadow the tragedies like that of Mr. Williams, who forfeited his future by investing too much of his talents into becoming a big-time ballplayer.
Though there are no precise statistics and few methods to track athletes once they leave college or the professional leagues, a significant number return home undereducated and with no alternative career goals. Richard Lapchick, director of the Center for Sports and Society at Northwestern University in Boston and an expert on the status of minority athletes, said the former ballplayers often end up in jail or in trouble with drugs because they cannot adjust to mainstream society.
Despite efforts in recent years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association to upgrade academic standards for players and by high school and college athletic officials to stress the importance of finishing college and formulating career goals, he said, "there remains this prevailing belief in black communities that you can make it to the pros when, in fact, the odds of that happening, depending upon what sport you're talking about, are about 1 in 10,000."
A study released last year by the N.C.A.A., which focused on 85 institutions with large sports programs, found that 26.6 percent of black athletes graduated from those colleges, compared with 52.2 percent of white players and 45.7 percent for all athletes. The dropout rate for white athletes decreased as they progressed through school, while 38.3 percent of black student athletes left school in their fourth or fifth years without graduating, and nearly as many dropped out during their first two years.
Mr. Williams, who was raised in a four-room apartment in the Hill section of New Haven with his mother and 11 brothers and sisters, said his family was supported by a monthly welfare check. As a youngster, he said, he learned how to play basketball in an empty lot, using discarded metal barrels as hoops. When he made the varsity basketball team in his freshman year at Lee High School, he thought his future was sealed.
 
'The Right Path'
 "I had it in my mind that one day I would play for the New York Knicks," said Mr. Williams, who is 6 foot 7. "I knew that they earned a lot of money, and that would allow me to take care of my family. I was determined to follow the right path and meet the right people, so I could attain that goal."
Though he maintained a C-plus average in high school, Mr. Williams said that his obsession with basketball overshadowed everything else in his life. He recalled that the seduction of the crowds that attended his games and the attention he received from the local media were overpowering. "I always wanted to be wanted," he said. "And here I had this gift, where I could walk out on a court, shoot baskets and put smiles on everybody's faces. It was hypnotic."
By the end of his senior year in 1976, Mr. Williams had become New Haven's hometown hero. He had become an all-American and was largely responsible for Lee High School's state's championship. Recruiters from more than 300 colleges were knocking at his door, he said.
His troubles began, he said, while he was attending the University of Rhode Island, where he had received a four-year athletic scholarship. Not only was he not prepared for college-level academics, Mr. Williams said, he also felt obligated to the university's athletic officials, who had given him a major role in shaping the team and raising its standards.
 
Academic Probation
 "In their eyes I came for the athletic program, not academics," he said. "And they did everything in their power to make certain I'd be able to play."
But after playing three seasons with Rhode Island, Mr. Williams was placed on academic probation at the end of his junior year. Soon after, he said, he received notice from the National Basketball Association that he had been drafted by the Knicks. At the age of 20 he had reached his goal in life.
"It was all happening so fast," he recalled. "Here, I'd never had a job before and was now making over $100,000. I had no self-discipline and had stopped growing emotionally. I had thrown my education out the window and had gotten used to thinking that as long as I played basketball, all my problems would go away."
He was plagued with psychological problems and a faltering marriage, Mr. Williams said, and his career with the Knicks was rocked by a series of suspensions, fines and disputes with the team's management. Despite his problems he continued to excel on the court. In four seasons with the Knicks he recorded a total of 2,788 points and 1,054 rebounds.
In 1983 the Knicks traded Mr. Williams to the Atlanta Hawks; he signed a contract with the team for $450,000 a year. But by then, he said, basketball, too, had become a source of stress. Lacking negotiation or business skills, he said, he could not adjust to the pressures of his career. He said the teams reneged on their promises to let him play a minimum length of time in each game. In addition, he said, he continued to fuel his reputation as a renegade by missing practices and games.
 
Return to New Haven
 "Everybody knew that I had this attitude," he said. "Why I acted like I did I just can't explain."
At the end of his second season with the Hawks, Mr. Williams signed a contract with the Boston Celtics. But when he was allowed to play only four minutes a game, he said, he left the Celtics after one season, feeling bitter and frustrated. In 1987 he left the N.B.A. to play for a professional team in Spain.
While he was there, Mr. Williams said, he received word that his brother had committed suicide after shooting his son. He said the family tragedy, along with a pending divorce, psychological problems and disillusionment over the business aspects of professional sports prompted him to leave professional basketball and return to New Haven in 1988.
But once he came home, those who once rallied around him now avoided him or expressed disappointment over his decision, he said. Although he felt he had eliminated a great burden from his life and could now make up for lost time, he said, "everybody still saw me as Sly Williams the great basketball player, not this lost man who was destroying himself slowly but surely."
Because he lacked business skills, Mr. Williams said, he spent freely much of what he earned, yet he remains uncertain about what happened to the money he invested through financial advisers in the mid-1980's.
Within two years of leaving the N.B.A., Mr. Williams said, his money ran out, and he could not find a job. "Most employers told me that because I'd once made a half a million dollars a year, they didn't feel I'd be satisfied making $6 an hour," he said.
Except for his children and his girlfriend, Shirley Massey, he said, he isolated himself and often had suicidal thoughts. Financial difficulties and substance abuse led to arguments between Mr. Williams and Ms. Massey, he said, and the couple's arguments sometimes became violent.
 
Helping College Athletes
 In addition to his current prison term of three and a half years, Mr. Williams was convicted on a prior assault charge involving Ms. Massey and sentenced to three months in prison and to a drug treatment program. Ms. Massey is caring for his two children from his former marriage, he said, adding, that they are his only visitors.
In 1985 the Center for Sports in Society founded the National Consortium for Academics and Sports in an effort to prevent young athletes from dropping out of college and to urge those who leave before graduating to return after playing professionally to complete their education. Seventy institutions now participate in the consortium, including the University of Hartford and the University of Connecticut.
"We've come a long way since Sly Williams's time," said Mr. Lapchick. "But we still have a long road ahead of us. At least now many kids say they are playing sports to avoid drugs and alcohol and as an opportunity to better their lives. Those are the positive things we hoped would happen."
At Warren Harding High School in Bridgeport, Aaron Harris, Lonnie Jones and Allen Henry are among the current basketball stars. The school is No. 1 in the state in basketball this year and has produced the second-largest number of professional athletes among all high schools in the country.
The three players, now seniors, said athletics have kept them from succumbing to drugs and helped them to develop self-esteem and academic self-discipline. They gave credit to their parents and to their coach, Charles Bentley, for their determination to complete their education and return to Bridgeport to pursue business careers.
Mr. Bentley, who grew up in public housing in Bridgeport, said he has always tried "to knock the glamour out of professional sports" by emphasizing academics before athletics. He said he also advocates the upgrading of curriculum standards in urban schools beginning at the elementary level.
One of Mr. Bentley's former basketball players, Charles Smith, who graduated from the University of Pittsburgh and now plays for the Los Angeles Clippers, has created a foundation in Bridgeport that provides tutoring and educational support to children in the city.
Mr. Williams, meanwhile, said he hopes to be released from prison within four to five months. At that time, he said, he would like to find a job as a coach or work with urban youngsters, helping them to develop concrete goals in their lives. He added that he and Ms. Massey would also like to seek counseling to resolve their problems.
"All I'm asking for is a chance to do something positive with my life," he said. "I want to give something back by preventing someone from making some of the mistakes that I did. I want to prove to myself that there is indeed life after basketball."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In 1981 Sylvester Williams, foreground, played for the Knicks. Now in prison, far left, he is recovering from a knife wound. (Dave LaBianca for The New York Times; Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Hearing the Wake-Up Call

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The economic downturn in Massachusetts definitely has a silver lining, says State Treasurer Joseph D. Malone: "It will serve as a wake-up call for all state governments that they must become efficient, effective and agile."
For his part, Mr. Malone, who has been in office a little more than a year, has answered the call with a couple of innovative projects backed by money from the state teachers' and employees' pension fund. 
 The first program, unveiled in January, provides $125 million in mortgage money for middle- and low-income families. The program makes it easier to borrow by accepting down payments of as little as 5 percent and offering lower closing costs.
A second program, announced last month, uses $50 million in pension money to bail out small businesses whose loans have been called in following bank failures.
Both programs appear to be the first of their kind in the nation and have attracted the interest of several other state governments.
The treasurer's job is the first elected position for the 37-year-old Mr. Malone, who has worked as an official of the state Republican Party and as a principal in a health club business owned by his family. He served as the party's sacrificial lamb in the 1988 senatorial race against Edward Kennedy. But he rode into the treasurer's office in 1990 on the wave of local discontent with the Dukakis Democrats. He moved quickly after being sworn in, articulating a "corporate mission" to give better value to the state's taxpayers.
In keeping with that mission, Mr. Malone insisted that the investments in the small business and mortgage programs bring a fair-market return to the pension funds.
"I was very much impressed with Joe's quick grasp that these programs must make sense from an investment standpoint," said Jack R. Meyer, who serves on a nine-member advisory commission to Mr. Malone and is also chief executive of the Harvard Management Company, which oversees Harvard's endowment. "Many states embark on programs without considering that point of view and end up with hidden subsidies that amount to another form of taxation."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph D. Malone

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Canada Braces for a Spring Without Zing

BYLINE: By BOB McKENZIE; Bob McKenzie is the hockey columnist for The Toronto Star and hockey analyst for The Sports Network.

 BODY:
It has been 52 years since the New York Rangers last won the Stanley Cup and they can easily dredge up at least that many excuses. Now, much to their everlasting chagrin, they could end up with one more.
And what a beauty. The National Hockey League may be on the verge of its first full-scale players' strike. The N.H.L. Players' Association has been without a contract and in a legal strike position since last Sept. 15. The players say they won't finish this year -- the 1991-92 regular season ends three weeks from today -- without a new collective bargaining agreement. Since the players and owners are far apart on the major issues and both are taking the hard line, there is legitimate fear that a strike could end the 1992 Stanley Cup playoffs before they begin. 
 Aside from diehard Ranger fans who believe Mark Messier is their messiah, and the principals of the conflict itself, who in America really cares if this will be a spring sans hockey? Probably just the scattered fans in a few traditional United States hockey hotbeds and the beloved warm-weather oddballs. Not enough to cause a national stir certainly. Especially with this potential walkout coinciding almost perfectly with the opening of the major league baseball season.
 
One Frenzied Reaction
 It is a slightly different story in Canada.
"I'll die; I'll just die if there's no hockey in April," Montreal Canadiens Coach Pat Burns said earlier this season. "I just might kill myself. I know the players have problems and they need to have them solved, but if they walk out right before the playoffs, I'll go out of my mind. I'll die."
Burns's frenzied reaction is fairly typical of the average Canadian, whose idea of a good time is watching a potential 42 consecutive nights of hockey leading up to the cup final in late May. In defense of the nation, it is not necessarily a bastion of hosers, cooking up a mess of back bacon on the Coleman stove, Molson's in hand, displaying gap-toothed grins. (Even if some of us do have the right name, eh?) To put it in terms of sporting sophistication you Americans might understand (and appreciate), more than four million fans flocked to watch the Toronto Blue Jays last year as they set a major league single-season attendance record.
Still, hockey is simply a part of us. An N.H.L. strike is a matter of utmost fear and loathing. If you're still having difficulty identifying with this national crisis, consider a fall without the World Series.
The news only gets worse. The angst of the fans -- and this, my American cousin, is a universal truth -- counts for nothing. The duration of a strike in sports is determined by the players' and owners' ability to cope with the financial consequences. Every fan vows during a strike never to watch another game, but a quick look into the stands of the National Football League or major league baseball discounts the tough talk considerably.
If the majority of Americans have no deep concerns for a hockey strike, it seems a bit much to expect them to be worked up about the issues. Suffice to say the players are looking for each of the N.H.L.'s 24 clubs (Ottawa and Tampa Bay arrive next fall) to shell out about an additional $900,000 per year in tangible benefits (increased share of playoff revenue and pension-plan improvements), as well as the intangible benefits of one-time-only unrestricted free agency for any player with 10 years service.
 
Deficit Is Projected
 The owners, meanwhile, contend that more than half the teams in the league will lose money this season, many of them a million or more dollars. The league is projecting an overall deficit, which is truly amazing since it just recently collected a $50 million franchise fee from each of the two new expansion entries.
As for the N.H.L.-N.H.L.P.A. conflict itself, it's always interesting to size up the heroes and villains. Since the average player's salary has escalated from $276,000 last year to $379,000 this season, a 37.3 per cent increase, and there is this recession thing everyone keeps talking about, it would be easy to pin this one on the players. But the short-term financial woes of the N.H.L. belie the fact that a good number of owners have made considerable profits for many years and never much thought about giving the players their due.
Many years after their union brothers in baseball, football and basketball realized the score, hockey players have finally woken up. In Bob Goodenow, they have a new union leader, an American lawyer with an icy stare that sees a sport run by some of the most conservative sports entrepreneurs on earth.
If the players are excessive in their demands -- a possibility given the tough economic times -- it's only because the pendulum is naturally going to swing back hard after being firmly lodged so high on the other side for so long.
But need there be a strike? We'll soon find out if the party is truly over in this, the N.H.L.'s 75th anniversary season. As for those Ranger fans, a strike may not be such a bad thing after all. Sure, the Blueshirts won't win the Stanley Cup this year. But then no one else will either.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The Port Authority and Starrett Lehigh Buildings;
For 2 Huge Relics, Different Futures

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
TWO 1930's red-brick structures -- relics of Manhattan's industrial past, when giant warehouses were in great demand -- dominate their localities.
But though their pasts are similar, they have developed very differently, one catering to what is left of the island's light industry, the other focusing on high-tech and office tenants. 
 Both the 15-story Port of New York Authority Building, at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets, and the 19-story Starrett Lehigh Building, at 601 West 26th Street, between 11th and 12th Avenues, were built to accommodate railroad freight.
Each occupies a full city block and each has about two million square feet of rental space, giant loading docks for tractor-trailers on the ground floor and elevators to bring 29-foot trucks to the upper floors.
There the similarity stops.
The Port Authority building originally housed the agency's offices and the Union Inland Freight Station #1, a truck terminal operated jointly by eight railroads for the distribution of freight. In 1973, after the authority -- by then the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- began moving its offices to larger, more modern quarters in the World Trade Center, the structure was sold to the Sylvan Lawrence Company, real estate investors, for $24 million.
The building has since been updated, with new elevators, lobbies, windows and a fire-safety system. The modernized structure, in the heart of Chelsea, with its many shops and restaurants, has a subway station in the basement, making it easily accessible.
Although space is still rented for warehousing, the railroads moved out in 1963. Much of the building is now rented for back-office computer operations, said Charles L. Goldenberger, president of Sylvan Lawrence. It is nearly 80 percent full and commands rates of $8 to 18 a square foot, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate brokerage firm. Among the tenants are The New York Law Journal and Citibank.
"We are emphasizing computer data processing space," said Mr. Goldenberger. "And if companies want large floor space for computer operations, they have few options in Manhattan. So we've been pretty much insulated from the recession."
Built by the Lehigh Valley Railroad with railroad tracks on its ground floor, the Starrett Lehigh Building is handicapped by what was once its most important feature -- location. It is a block from the Hudson River.
"The Lehigh Valley Railroad had its terminus in New Jersey," explained Alvin Schwartz, a senior vice president of Helmsley-Spear, the landmarked building's current owner.
"So they would put railroad cars on barges and float them across the river. Diesels would pull them into the building for loading and unloading."
BUT the tracks have been removed and the ground floor has been converted to retail space, most of which is empty. The building itself, with sweeping loft-type windows and rounded corners that make it look a bit like a cruise ship, is showing its age. The red brick is sooty, the elevators are still manually operated and the original windows, built for light industry, are outdated and single-pane. Neighboring buildings are in sore need of paint and modernization, making the setting unattractive for office occupancy.
Mr. Schwartz maintains that the building is mainly handicapped by the lack of public transportation. There are no subway stops nearby and the closest Manhattan Transit Authority bus stop is at the corner of 23d Street and 11th Avenue. Mr. Schwartz said that he has been trying for years to get the Transit Authority to bring bus service closer but "they turned a deaf ear."
"We considered a jitney service," said Edward J. Stein, manager of the Starrett Lehigh Building, "but with insurance the numbers are astronomical. Our tenants are paying $6 a square foot, which is down to bare basics, and it just won't support it."
He said that 10 years ago, when he became manager, the building was nearly full. However, the recession bankrupted many tenants, including Zayre Stores, which had rented a quarter of a million square feet of warehouse space. Many other former tenants were in printing-related fields, which Mr. Stein says were hurt by computerization, the development of photocopy machines and the high cost of New York City labor.
Today, most tenants use Starrett Lehigh for warehousing. Many, such as Liz Roberts, a women's clothing firm, are in the garment industry. Other large tenants include Baby Watson Cheesecake and Motorola, which has a repair facility on the ground floor.
Space in the building is advertised at $6 a square foot, one third of what the more prime space in the Port Authority building goes for. Even at those rates, the building is 40 percent vacant.
Mr. Stein is convinced that when the recession ends, his building will "turn around." He says that many tenants need large, open spaces at inexpensive rentals and that Starrett Lehigh's 130,000-square-foot floors will fill that niche.
"It's a perfect building for light manufacturing," Mr. Stein said. "We can take trucks up to all of the different floors. It cuts down on stealing and time. The rent is low and, because all of our elevators are manual, our people see everyone who enters or leaves the building. So the building is one of the most secure in Manhattan."
MR. STEIN maintains that during tough economic times, high taxes drive industry out of Manhattan. However, when the economy picks up, he says, many will realize that the convenience of the city "is worth more than a fancier, less expensive showroom in Secaucus," N.J.
"They'll see that it's worth a lot to be able to deliver their merchandise to anywhere in Manhattan in 10 minutes, rather than being stuck in the tunnel for an hour on the way," Mr. Stein predicted.
Josh N. Kuriloff, a director at Cushman & Wakefield, agrees that there is a market for older office, warehouse and light-manufacturing space in Manhattan, even in a recession.
However, he says, the owners must continuously update their buildings during good times, as Sylvan Lawrence has, to remain competitive in hard times.
Katey Marshall, a spokeswoman for the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said in an interview that the city is considering offering tax incentives to owners of older commercial buildings who upgrade their structures. She maintained that while traditional industries, such as the garment industry, are having difficulty, Manhattan was beginning to attract high-tech companies, which would require updated premises.
"The key," Mr. Kuriloff said, "is proper positioning, which is hard for landlords to do after the highs of the 80's. They have to lower their rents, sometimes below break-even rates. They also have to be prepared to compete on concession packages, free rent and construction dollars. It's a matter of facing reality in difficult times."
He sees New Jersey and Brooklyn as Manhattan's main competitors for light manufacturing and warehouse tenants. For white-collar tenants, Mr. Kuriloff said, Wall Street is a major attraction.
"When the market is spiraling upwards as it was in the 80's, the occupancy costs of prime real estate, such as in the Wall Street area are very high," he said. "So there is great pressure to move back-office space out of buildings that go for $20 to $30 a square foot to secondary space. That's when older buildings do best. But in a downward market, these buildings must offer better deals because prime space has come down in price."

HEADLINE: Yes but No; No but Yes

BYLINE: By Daniel J. Kevles; Daniel J. Kevles heads the program in science, ethics and public policy at the California Institute of Technology.

 BODY:

LIFE ITSELF
Abortion in the American Mind.
By Roger Rosenblatt.
194 pp. New York: Random House. $20. 
 IN "Life Itself: Abortion in the American Mind," a well-intentioned but debatable book, Roger Rosen blatt examines the ambivalence about the subject specifically reflected in recent polls of Americans, with the intention of stimulating the kind of national discussion that would make for greater tolerance on both sides of the issue. In 1990, Mr. Rosenblatt, a journalist and commentator for "The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour," talked to a number of people in Iowa about abortion, a major issue in the state's election campaigns for Governor and United States Senator that year. He was surprised by what he learned. Whether for or against the right to abortion, individual Iowans were divided in their private thoughts about the moral and legal aspects of the issue.
Mr. Rosenblatt suggests that the conflicts he found in the Iowan hearts are national in scope and that most Americans are profoundly ambivalent about abortion. Even the polling data are contradictory: a 1990 survey by Louis Harris and Associates showed 73 percent of Americans favoring abortion rights, while a February 1991 Gallup poll found that 49 percent agreed that abortion was "an act of murder" and 28 percent who would not go that far called it "the taking of a human life."
Describing himself as "conventionally pro-choice," in a useful historical survey Mr. Rosenblatt points out that hardly any societies -- the only one he mentions is the native Formosans -- have ever given abortion unqualified approval, especially on the demand of the mother. He contends that questions central to the current abortion debate -- when a fetus becomes a person, what circumstances justify an abortion, and whether the power of decision over abortion should reside in the individual or the state -- have nowhere been fully resolved. In recent decades, abortion has been legalized, albeit with varying degrees of restrictions, in many nations, yet in most of them anti-abortionists have not, by and large, embarked on a crusade against abortion rights. In contrast, Mr. Rosenblatt believes the United States is currently in a state of civil belligerency over the issue.
Mr. Rosenblatt seeks to account for this American exception by ascribing attitudes in the abortion controversy to features of American culture. Some of his interpretations appear stretched -- for example, he concludes that our propensity to endow every person's life with optimistic expectations prompts anti-abortionists to save the fetus for its future and their opponents to protect the options of the pregnant woman. Other interpretations carry punch. He argues, for example, that our evangelical tradition leads many Americans to project their private moral convictions onto the public arena, "to see America as themselves."
Our deep middle-class discomfort with sexuality and our ambivalence about the social role of women are perhaps most important, Mr. Rosenblatt feels. To many people in the American middle class, he says, abortion is a sign of careless and illicit sex, a symptom of an unruly licentiousness. It is also a threat to the bourgeois dream because it enlarges the freedom and independence of women who might otherwise remain subordinate in their social and sexual habits to traditional wifely and motherly roles.
The voices from Iowa, heard here from both sides of the abortion divide without the usual shouting-match anger, reveal common anxieties about the disintegration of the family and the fate of unwanted children. Both sides also express a common respect for the rights of privacy, and support for measures that would reduce abortion by preventing unwanted conceptions. The degree of shared concern stimulates Mr. Rosen blatt to argue, in what is the central theme of "Life Itself," that a consensus might well be formed in support of a suitable modus vivendi on abortion. He has one to advocate: Permit abortion, in recognition of the rights of privacy and individual self-determination, but discourage it, in acknowledgment of the broad moral objections it provokes.
NEVER mind for the moment that Mr. Rosen blatt offers little practically to discourage abortion besides sex education. His case for discouragement seems unfair to innumerable women who already face social and economic obstacles and personal anguish in terminating pregnancy. It is also unpersuasive, wishfully at odds with some of his own observations, including the evidence from Iowa. Anti-abortionists there may endorse sex education, but it is possible that unlike abortion rights advocates, they mean education for abstinence rather than for contraception.
Building on a point made by a chaplain at the University of Iowa, Mr. Rosenblatt holds that opponents of abortion might "tolerate a pro-choice law" just as people in the United States tolerate religious differences. The analogy is inappropriate, however, since differences in belief are more easily tolerated than morally charged differences in behavior.
Even more puzzling than why the right to abortion is so hotly contested in the United States is the question of why an apparent minority of the population -- the faction who oppose the right -- exercise so much political clout. As Mr. Rosenblatt reports, the right to abortion is in increasing jeopardy -- from the courts and from bills to restrict or prohibit abortion that have been introduced into the legislatures of some 45 states, as well as from a chilling intimidation of physicians that, for example, has driven out of South Dakota all but one doctor willing to perform the procedure. For all the stated overlaps and consensus, there is an emotional energy behind the anti-abortion drive that would seem to prohibit agreement on the "permit" part of Mr. Ros enblatt's formula. Wishful thinking does not end political conflict.

HEADLINE: The Pentagon's Superpower Fantasy

BYLINE: By James Chace; James Chace, who teaches international relations at Bard College, is author of "The Consequences of the Peace," a forthcoming book.

 BODY:
The United States is not a superpower. There are no more superpowers, despite a new Pentagon document outlining a $1.2 trillion strategy to prevent any other nation from challenging this country's primacy.
If the Persian Gulf war proved anything, it proved that one nation can't dominate the world. The war was paid for by our allies, mostly by Germany and Japan. Superpowers can afford to pay for their own wars; we cannot. We are in hock to foreigners for more than half a trillion dollars, mostly because of foreign holdings of U.S. real estate, Government paper, commercial bonds and notes and other assets. 
 Without the $54 billion in aid that the Bush Administration received for the gulf operation, the U.S., with a budget deficit projected for 1992 of about $400 billion, could not have afforded to mount such a campaign. It is highly unlikely that we will receive support for similar foreign policy adventures, certainly not to police the world as the Pentagon intends us to.
And we will not find it easy to lead a campaign against world disorder when we depend on those allies who now read a Pentagon document stating that our aim is "to discourage them from challenging our leadership or seeking to overturn the established political and economic order." See if the Japanese and Germans are ready to pony up billions of dollars to support that kind of policy.
The Pentagon's America-firsters ignore the economic dimension of U.S. foreign policy. They don't understand it is more important for the U.S. to cooperate with the other great powers to insure a healthy functioning of the world economy than to spend its energies and funds by unilaterally assuming the task of enforcing global peace and stability.
In the Pentagon's analysis, there is a striking absence of any concern with ends and means. For a country that, in a decade, has gone from being a creditor nation to being the largest debtor nation, we should be especially wary about pursuing high-flown notions calculated to make the world safe for democracy. If we try to do so, we will end up betraying the concept of collective security that Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman saw as the cornerstone of the U.S. security -- the concept that was the foundation of a successful Western alliance.
The Administration is subordinating policy to politics in an election year. In Mr. Bush's effort to inflate his image as a tough commander in-chief, his Defense Department is seeking new enemies that require little or no change in Pentagon budgeting. These "enemies" happen to be our allies -- the same allies who paid for the gulf war.
But what will be the price of the Pentagon's fantasy to insure that "the world order is ultimately backed by the U.S.?" As Marion Donoff, the publisher of Die Zeit, the German weekly, wrote prophetically in 1982, "One must fear that in 10 years the United States will indeed be militarily invulnerable, but that in the civil realm, she will have become, to a catastrophic degree, a backward nation."
The collapse of the Soviet empire, the end of the struggle for ideological supremacy between Moscow and Washington, the absolute necessity to rethink our military commitments and force structures -- all this presents a signal occasion for embracing a new internationalism.
It would rest on the proposition that a global balance of powers is coming into being. Above all, it would require the U.S. to abandon the false idea of "the superpower," which had its origins in a cold war that is now history. Yet it would preclude a withdrawal into ourselves.
Ultimately, the success of the U.S. will lie in the quality of its society, not in a quixotic pursuit of superpower invulnerability. But, in his re-election bid, George Bush bid seems to be making a different calculation.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1395 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
CLINTON, BUILDING STRONG COALITION, LEADS IN MICHIGAN

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has built an imposing lead in Michigan's Presidential primary race by assembling a powerful coalition spanning the state's strongest Democratic constituencies -- trade unions, blacks and conservative whites, including ethnic voters who backed Republicans in the 1980's.
The main threat to Mr. Clinton in Tuesday's voting here may turn out to be not former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, whose campaign has failed to generate a spark in this chronically depressed industrial state, but former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who has transformed himself in recent days into the scourge of free trade and champion of the fearful. 
 A poll published in this morning's Detroit News showed Mr. Clinton with 49 percent to 18 percent for Mr. Tsongas, 17 percent for Mr. Brown and 15 percent undecided. The survey of 506 likely Democratic voters was conducted on Thursday and Friday, just as Mr. Brown began to win the endorsement of big local unions and catch the eye of television news shows.
 
Large Gap in Illinois
 Robert H. Giles, the News's editor, said that the longer polling continued, the stronger Mr. Brown got, which suggests a late surge that could push him past Mr. Tsongas.
A Clinton victory in Illinois, which also votes on Tuesday, has seemed likely for several days, partly because of months of effective organizational work. Mr. Tsongas is running a weak second there, too, although Mr. Brown is less of a threat and Mr. Tsongas may be stronger in the Chicago suburbs. If Mr. Clinton were to win both states by large margins, he would quickly become the prohibitive favorite at the party's national convention this summer.
On the Republican side, President Bush is leading his chief challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan, by a better than 3 to 1 in polls in this state and better than 5 to 1 in Illinois, despite Mr. Buchanan's intensive effort in Michigan, where he had hoped economic despair would help him revive his campaign.
"The most likely outcome of the voting in Michigan," said David Rohde, a professor of political science at Michigan State University, "is that we'll see the end of the nomination fight in both of the parties."
Many prominent Michigan Democrats hope that isn't so, at least in their party, and are urging voters to mark their ballots "uncommitted" in an effort to bring about a deadlocked convention and the entry of some other candidate. Among them are Frank Garrison, the head of the state labor federation; Representative John D. Dingell, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, and Senator Carl Levin.
But most politicians here consider those men wishful thinkers at best.
The greater threat to Mr. Clinton is the pattern of erratic turnouts in Michigan, which makes upsets common. The Clinton campaign needs a strong black vote, and an endorsement from Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit last Friday could help the Arkansas Governor avoid embarrassment. In the 1988 primary, blacks turned out in large numbers and gave the Rev. Jesse Jackson an upset victory; in the 1990 governor's race, they did not, and the heavily favored incumbent, James Blanchard, a Democrat, was ousted by John M. Engler, a Republican.
Not many politicians have managed in recent years to bring together black voters and white ethnic voters in this polarized state. But last week Mr. Clinton appealed for tolerance as a key to progress in speeches in black neighborhoods of Detroit and in Macomb County, north of here, to which many whites moved in the 1960's and 1970's as Detroit grew more and more black.
"It has been, 'We're the party of the blacks at the expense of the white middle class,' " said Leo Lalonde, the Macomb Democratic chairman. "Clinton is maybe going to change that. For sure, he's going to take this part of the state by a ton."
Putting together a broad coalition has been easier because there is no traditional liberal in the race, which is an astonishing phenomenon in the state where Walter Reuther of the United Automobile Workers built a powerful labor and minority partnership that dominated Democratic politics for years. Many had hoped that Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa could knit that partnership back together, but he pulled out of the race a week ago.
 
Tsongas Takes Stand
 "You can't be everything to everybody," Mr. Tsongas said today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," in a renewed effort to suggest that Mr. Clinton lacked strong convictions and to attract those who had backed Mr. Harkin. "You have to stand for some things."
Mr. Tsongas probably has less of a natural following here than he has in any other major state, in the view of a ranking Democratic official in Lansing, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Tsongas says our economic problems are more our own fault than Japan's, and that may be true, but Michigan doesn't want to hear it and won't buy it," the official said.
The former Senator has been hurt here not only by his support of a fast-track free-trade negotiations with Mexico, which the unions fear would mean the export of thousands of jobs, but also by his opposition to a law that would ban the hiring of permanent replacements for striking workers.
Mr. Brown has taken the opposite stand on both issues, and that has won him plaudits and apparently a lot of new supporters. At a Jefferson-Jackson dinner in Detroit on Saturday, his comments drew the loudest applause, and he attracted more attention by re-enacting with several hundred supporters the mythic 1932 Detroit-to-Dearborn hunger march, which ended with five people being killed by the Ford-dominated Dearborn police.
"These people died, and now they're coming at you, not with bullets, not with gas and water hoses," he said at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant, where the clashes occurred 60 years ago. "They're coming at you with a fast track, and they're going to take your livelihoods and put them down in Mexico."
Although the Californian is backed by workers in Ypsilanti, where the mammoth Willow Run plan is to close soon, and by the leadership of the 70,000-odd Teamsters in the state, he still trails Mr. Clinton among union members in The Detroit News poll, 50 percent to 17 percent, with Mr. Tsongas also at 17 percent. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.
"I don't think he can win," Mayor Young said, "but Jerry Brown certainly represents the alienation and resentment many of the people in Michigan feel. They're afraid they're next, afraid their jobs are going. They're angry. They feel betrayed by this society and by their government."
In Michigan, Mr. Brown has begun to pick up significant black support for the first time, including two Wayne County commissioners, state legislators and, this morning, Representative John Conyers Jr., one of the best known black politicians in the Midwest.
Tonight, in a television debate in Chicago that was also broadcast here, Mr. Brown assailed Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas for supporting the fast-track negotiations and said Mr. Clinton had unfairly taxed the poor in Arkansas. He also accused the Arkansan of funneling state legal business to his wife's law firm.
"He reinvents himself every two weeks," Mr. Clinton shot back, jabbing his finger at Mr. Brown.
 
Difficulty for Buchanan
 Mr. Buchanan, whose Michigan backers had high hopes two weeks ago, appears to have run into difficulty in raising money. Television station executives say he had made only limited purchases of advertising time through Friday. A new, more stringent election law may well discourage the Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan, a Buchanan target, from crossing over to vote in the Republican primary.
"Buchanan's running on empty as far as money is concerned and as far as momentum is concerned," said William Ballenger, editor of a newsletter called Inside Michigan Politics.
Mr. Buchanan took only 21 percent in The Detroit News poll, with Mr. Bush at 71 percent. David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan official from Louisiana, had 2 percent, with 5 percent undecided.
Mr. Bush campaigned here last week in a less fevered style than he had displayed earlier in the political season, and Robert M. Teeter, his campaign chairman, who comes from Michigan, said he was "pretty comfortable" with the President's situation.

HEADLINE: A Top G.M. Official Is Reported Chosen To Succeed Iacocca

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15

 BODY:
Yielding to the wishes of Lee A. Iacocca, the directors of the Chrysler Corporation have agreed to name a General Motors executive to succeed him as chief executive, several people with knowledge of the board's deliberations said tonight.
After two days of meetings in New York, the board's 10 outside directors settled on Mr. Iacocca's candidate, Robert J. Eaton, who currently heads G.M.'s highly profitable European operations. 
 Chrysler spokesmen and executives declined to comment today on what was decided, and the company scheduled a news conference for Monday morning at its headquarters in Highland Park, Mich.
Chrysler, for many years one of the 10 largest American companies, has slipped a few notches in the last two years. The most troubled company in a desperately troubled American industry, it remains at the center of many debates about the American economy: how to insure fair-trade rules in other nations, how to meet the huge cost of retirees' benefits, when corporate debts become too heavy, and whether extremely well-paid executives exercise adequate judgment in adapting to changing economic conditions.
Mr. Iacocca, who joined Chrysler in 1978 as president and chief operating officer after he was forced out of the Ford Motor Company by Henry Ford 2d, is scheduled to retire as chief executive at the end of this year. He may retain his position as chairman, and it is not clear just how much power he would like or will be able to keep.
During his tenure at Chrysler, Mr. Iacocca, who is 67 years old, became America's most visible business leader, a prominent spokesman in the company's advertisements, and a voice for the American auto industry in its struggle with Japan.
He wrote the best-selling business autobiography of all time, "Iacocca," and led fund-raising to refurbish the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island.
Mr. Eaton, the president of General Motors Europe, is an experienced engineering executive who previously supervised G.M.'s technical staffs. Chrysler's succession plan should remove some of the uncertainty that has hung over the auto maker after the resignation or retirement of nine corporate officers in the last two and a half years.
Among those were Gerald Greenwald, Mr. Iacocca's heir apparent, who resigned two years ago to lead an unsuccessful attempt to buy the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines. He then joined Dillon, Read & Company in New York.
Last month, Robert S. Miller Jr., the vice chairman, left Chrysler to become an investment banker at James D. Wolfensohn, a Wall Street investment firm. Mr. Miller and Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, had been widely viewed as the team that would lead Chrysler once Mr. Iacocca departed.
 
End of the Line for No. 2?

 Monday's announcement could signal the start of a new power struggle at Chrysler involving several top executives, and perhaps Mr. Iacocca himself. In turning to Mr. Eaton of G.M., Mr. Iacocca seems to have slammed the door on the advancement of Mr. Lutz, who coordinates the company's development of vehicles and is highly popular among Chrysler employees. The wooing of Mr. Eaton apparently signals that Mr. Lutz, who is 60 years old, was weighed by Mr. Iacocca and found wanting.
It is not clear when or why Mr. Iacocca turned against Mr. Lutz. The two men have similar outspoken personalities, and in the past Mr. Lutz has disagreed with Mr. Iacocca in front of subordinates.
Because of Mr. Lutz's popularity within the company, the recruitment of Mr. Eaton, who is 52, could foster resentment.
The biggest question may be the future role of Mr. Iacocca himself. He had announced he would retire as chief executive at the end of the year, but he has also hinted that he wants to wield influence and power as a director of the company. Some people have suggested that he might want to head the the powerful finance committee.
It is not uncommon in American corporate history for a retired chief executive to have difficulty surrendering control. Many of them have continued to hold at least one rein as directors of their companies.
In 1990, the last year for which data are available, Mr. Iacocca was paid $4.65 million by Chrysler and received stock valued at $718,000. In Japan, where Mr. Iacocca is bitterly resented for his criticism of Japan's trade policies, such compensation has been sharply criticized. Critics note that Mr. Iacocca and other American auto executives, whose companies are in deep trouble, earn far more than their successful Japanese counterparts.
Mr. Eaton's pay at General Motors has not been disclosed on the company's financial statements. The compensation he will receive at Chrysler is likely to be disclosed in proxy statements that Chrysler will issue in the next few weeks in advance of its May 14 meeting of shareholders.
 
Executive Suite Politics
 Mr. Iacocca's decision to retain some power, the frustration and disappointment of Mr. Lutz, and Mr. Eaton's impact as an outsider could once again be setting the stage for what has been a recurring drama of executive suite politics in the automobile industry. Indeed, Mr. Iacocca was at the center of an epic struggle to rule Ford during the 1970's, in spite of the wishes of Henry Ford 2d.
The issue of succession at Chrysler comes at a crucial moment for the nation's No. 3 auto maker, which, despite some gains in recent months, remains in precarious financial condition. And to some extent, many auto industry experts say, Chrysler's fate may depend more on how strongly the nation's economy recovers than on who is at the helm.
In its precarious position, encumbered by debt, beset by unrelenting competition from larger domestic and foreign companies, Chrysler can ill afford a divisive struggle over who will succeed Mr. Iacocca. Yet Mr. Iacocca may have introduced just that divisiveness in reaching outside for Mr. Eaton.
A lot depends on Mr. Lutz. If he acquiesces to Mr. Eaton's recruitment and can transfer the loyalty of his subordinates to Mr. Eaton, the chances for harmony will improve.
 
Danger to Morale
 Mr. Lutz, a veteran of corporate infighting at Ford, where he once ran European operations, may need to be convinced that his talents are still highly valued. Unless that happens, morale could plummet among the engineers and product planners who have rallied behind Mr. Lutz and his close ally, Francois Castaing, vice president of engineering.
Indeed, it is Mr. Lutz who has received much of the credit for the new vehicles Chrysler is planning, which have received good reviews in the automotive press and are being counted on to drive the company's recovery.
These vehicles include the Grand Cherokee model Jeep and the L/H midsize models that are scheduled for the fall. It has been many years since Chrysler introduced completely new midsize models.
 
Infighting at Ford
 Because Mr. Iacocca was at the center of the struggle to rule Ford during the 1970's, it should be easy for him to identify with Mr. Lutz's frustration. Mr. Ford, in 1968, recruited a senior G.M. executive, Semon E. (Bunky) Knudsen as president of Ford. That made Mr. Iacocca so angry that he almost quit. Mr. Knudsen's tenure was marked by infighting, and he left after 17 months, leaving Mr. Iacocca once more as Mr. Ford's heir apparent.
But the infighting grew so ferocious in 1977 that Mr. Ford delivered an ultimatum about Mr. Iacocca to Ford's directors: "Him or me."
Mr. Iacocca's most enduring achievement at Chrysler may be his role in the Federal Government's bail-out of the company from 1979 to 1984. While others may have imparted more technical expertise, no one was more articulate or persuasive in persuading the Government to guarantee more than $1 billion in loans, suppliers to grant discounts or organized labor to give wage and benefit concessions.
By promoting the bailout, Mr. Iacocca advanced the theory that Government should act to help corporations survive, even when their woes might have stemmed from management mistakes or market forces.
No one can forecast precisely whether buyers will respond to Chrysler's new vehicles or whether they will be in the mood for buying vehicles at all. In either case, the auto maker might find itself with its back to the wall. Its finance subsidiary must refinance billions of dollars of debt at a time when its borrowing power is severely constricted.
 
Appeal for Stockholders
 Major stockholders of Chrysler in recent weeks had urged the company to appoint Mr. Lutz as chief executive-designate, and they are likely to be concerned about the hiring of Mr. Eaton. If the shareholders were concerned mainly about the lack of a succession plan, the hiring of Mr. Eaton may set their minds at ease.
But if they see an outsider as a divisive element, Chrysler's share price may suffer.
In the last few months, partly on the strength of the positive reviews of the new vehicles, Chrysler's stock has risen from about $10 a share to as high as $17.87; it finished on Friday at $16.75, up 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.

Chronology: The Iacocca Era At Chrysler
 1978: Iacocca dismissed by Henry Ford 2d, joins Chrysler.
 1979: Congress approves $1.5 billion in loan guarantees to save the company.
 1983: Chrysler pays off the remaining $800 million of Federally insured loans.
 1984: Company reports record profit, introduces mini-vans, which create a new category of vehicles.
 1987: Chrysler buys American Motors for $1.5 billion, obtaining valuable rights to Jeep.
 1990: Chrysler and Fiat break off talks on forming alliance; Iacocca says he will stay on past normal retirement age.
 1992: Succession plan approved. (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Israelis Step Up Skirmish With U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 15

 BODY:
Israeli officials stepped up their attacks on the United States today over allegations that Israel had illegally resold American weapons technology to China, South Africa and other countries.
At the same time, military experts here said the arms-sale charges suggest that the longstanding strategic relationship between the United States and Israel might be at an important turning point. 
 If so, the Middle East peace conference could be undermined, some of them warned, arguing that an Israel that doubts Washington's steadfastness would be much less likely to offer the Arabs concessions that might involve security risks.
Relations between the United States and Israel have been slipping for months, and there were no signs after the Israeli Cabinet's weekly meeting today that matters would soon improve.
Although the Cabinet chose not to discuss the technology dispute, several officials normally charged with conveying the Government's public messages emerged from the meeting to denounce what one of them called a "deliberate campaign of slander against Israel."
Health Minister Ehud Olmert, who is close to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, linked the weapons issue to the visit to the White House last week by King Hussein of Jordan, and said the developments showed that "something much deeper here is wrong in the basic attitude" of the Bush Administration toward Israel.
"We're living in a different world, and we have to get used to new game rules," Mr. Olmert said.
Once again, the Israelis denied unswervingly that they had broken agreements with the United States and had re-exported American weapons and arms technologies to third countries without Washington's permission.
The charges, the focus of a draft report prepared by the State Department's Inspector General, came to public attention with a report in The Washington Times that Israel had given China technology from the American-made Patriot missiles sent here last year to help defend Israel against Iraqi Scud missile attacks during the Persian Gulf war. This was followed by other accounts, including a detailed article in The Wall Street Journal about a pattern of Israeli violations involving sales of missiles to South Africa and China and cluster bombs to Ethiopia and Chile.
In all cases, Israeli officials insisted, the charges are baseless -- a theme echoed by military specialists here. They argued that some suspected sales had never happened. In others, they said, transfers involved technology that did not reveal American secrets or require American permission.
"I think Israel is very careful in this area," said Dore Gold, a military expert at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University, who has served on occasion as a government consultant. Referring to charges that Israeli companies had installed American components in their weapons, or had copied them with modifications before reselling them, Mr. Gold said:
"It is an area like patent law, where someone will say, 'Hey, that was my idea.' There is a strict school of American thought that says that if there is an American bolt and nut in an Israeli system, then it's American technology in the whole system."
Zeev Schiff, military specialist for the newspaper Haaretz, wrote in a commentary today that "because of the crisis of confidence existing between President Bush and Mr. Shamir and a few of his ministers, there is a tendency these days to believe almost anything that Israel is accused of."
 
Cheney and Arens to Meet
 The dispute is expected to be discussed on Monday by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, who is visiting the United States and who has denied the accusations repeatedly.
A leading concern among Israeli officials is that they may risk losing future American technology transfers that this country depends on to maintain an advantage against its Arab neighbors. There are also worries that the United States might scale back its support for the Arrow anti-missile system, a pet project of Mr. Arens that has already suffered technological troubles.
Perhaps even more than the American allegations themselves, which reportedly were made known to Israel weeks ago, the recent spate of related news articles have also upset Israeli officials, who see them as the product of orchestrated leaks.
"This deliberate campaign of slander against Israel is intended to undermine Israel's position in the American public and in the American Congress," said Benjamin Netanyahu, a senior Shamir aide. He did not say who in Washington might be behind the effort.
Beyond the immediate question of who may have sold what to whom, some experts here say the dispute may signal a fundamental change in American-Israeli relations. It affects, they argue, security arrangements that until now have been kept distinct from political disagreements like the one over Israel's request for $10 billion in American loan guarantees to help resettle Jewish emigres from the former Soviet Union.
"This could be a major turning point in the strategic relationship," said Gerald M. Steinberg, a strategic-studies specialists at Bar Ilan University near Tel Aviv.
"Agreements going back 25 years were that each side would not look too closely at the other's technology improvements. Now we're seeing this issue being reopened. Where Israel thought it was in the position of sharing information with an ally, the State Department report is putting Israel back in the position of being a client."
Mr. Gold of the Jaffee Center cautioned that "this can't help the peace process" because the dispute would inevitably shake Israel's confidence that "if it is willing to take risks, American security will be there."
Some opposition figures restated often-expressed accusations that the Shamir Government had mismanaged relations with Israel's chief ally and benefactor, which supplies $1.8 billion a year in military aid and $1.2 billion in economic assistance.
But Mr. Netanyahu said that within a few years Israel would no longer be able to count on this aid, and he suggested that a cutoff might not be so bad. "We are discovering that the economic dependence is also creating political dependence," he said, "and that you cannot reach political independence without economic independence."

HEADLINE: Bush Is Urged to Speak Up for Russia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 15

 BODY:
Worried that economic desperation could transform the former Soviet republics into hostile dictatorships, many Republicans in Congress have joined Democrats and former President Richard M. Nixon in urging the Bush Administration to take the lead in backing billions of dollars more in aid to the republics.
After Mr. Nixon described the American aid granted so far as "pathetically inadequate" last week, several prominent Republican legislators began to echo remarks by some Democrats that strong Presidential leadership is needed on the issue. Mr. Bush's backing is necessary both to assure support in Congress and to reduce the political heat that lawmakers face in an election year over backing more foreign aid, those legislators have said. 
 To help preserve Russia's experiment in democracy and the free market, many legislators want Washington to back a new $12 billion contribution to the International Monetary Fund as well as several billion dollars for other programs, including a fund to support the ruble.
 
On the Brink of a Pit
 "They're at a point in history where either the stabilization occurs or you really go into a deep pit in which there appears to be no bottom whatsoever," said Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican and influential member of the Foreign Relations Committee who recently visited Russia and other republics. "This is why we're hopeful that our Government will move."
The United States Ambassador to Russia, Robert S. Strauss, told a Senate committee last week that two leading conservative Republicans, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, had urged him to take the lead on assistance to the Commonwealth of Independent States because no one else has done so.
"I think you're going to see bipartisan support for a number of things increased," Ambassador Strauss said.
Mr. Helms is the ranking Republican member of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Senator Thurmond is the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Subcommittee on Strategic Forces and Nuclear Deterrence.
Many members of Congress say that President Bush is apprehensive about pushing for more aid to the former Soviet republics because of criticism that he has paid too much attention to foreign policy and because of campaign pressures from his Republican opponent in the presidential primaries, Patrick Buchanan.
"This is going to require very aggressive leadership on the part of the President," said Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, who heads the House Subcommittee on Foreign Operations. "I think the White House has been so rattled by Buchanan that they're bobbing and weaving on many issues, including this."
 
Averting a Coup
 Some Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress say the collapse of the East bloc and President Bush's foreign policy successes could be largely nullified if economic suffering brought an anti-Western Government to power in the former Soviet Union. Generous Western aid could go far in preventing a coup, they argue, and a coup could lead to an expensive rearming of the United States.
"If the President doesn't take a lead in this area, a vigorous lead in energizing his own executive branch and advocating these kinds of measures to Congress, he may end up winning the election but losing his place in history," Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said in an interview. "The amount of money we're talking about is very small potatoes compared to what we will have to pay if democracy fails."
Senator Nunn, who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, recently returned from Moscow with Senator Lugar, Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, and Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia. Mr. Bingaman is chairman of the Armed Services Subcommittee on Defense Industry and Technology and Mr. Warner is the ranking Republican member of the full committee.
The four lawmakers sent the President a report urging him to "do more, on a priority basis" in aid for Russia and the other republics.
Administration officials say that President Bush recently proposed $645 million more in aid to the former Soviet Union. This comes on top of $1.5 billion in assistance announced in November.
The Administration officials say that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has repeatedly called on Congress to vote $12 billion to replenish the I.M.F. and that President Bush wrote to several members of Congress last year to seek support for such financing.
"Right now the Administration is looking at the whole aid picture toward Russia and the C.I.S. -- an in-depth look," said an Administration official who has followed the aid debate closely. "It's not being spurred by any criticism or suggestion. It's something that's been done off and on since the late fall of '91."
At a conference last week on foreign affairs sponsored by the Nixon Library, Mr. Bush agreed with the former President that Russia needed more aid, but he did not make the strong public appeal for billions in new aid that Mr. Nixon said was vital.
President Bush said Washington was considering a contribution to a fund to stabilize the ruble, but added that "we're living in a time of constrained resources" and "I don't have a blank check" for foreign aid.
Many liberals and conservatives had hoped that Mr. Bush would be more forthcoming after Mr. Nixon's remarks. "President Bush's remarks were a very weak response to a well-orchestrated effort by President Nixon," said Judy Shelton, an expert on the Soviet economy at the Hoover Institution. "It's urgent that Western nations help Russia have a sound currency."
 
Russia's Application
 A senior Treasury official said the United States was talking with other industrialized nations about setting up a fund to stabilize the ruble, but that Russia must first join the I.M.F. and gain its approval for an economic reform program. He said Russia and several other republics would probably join the fund around April 27, when the fund's spring meeting takes place.
I.M.F. officials suggest that $6 billion might be needed for a ruble stabilization fund. They estimate that Russia needs $12 billion in food aid and other assistance to meet its import requirements this year.
The Treasury official said the Administration wants to be sure that conditions are right before a ruble stabilization fund is set up.
He said that Russia has made substantial progress in reducing its budget deficit and reining in its money supply to meet the conditions for a ruble fund since January. But if the fund fails to stabilize the ruble, the official added, Western nations will lose billions of dollars trying to shore up the currency.
He said such a failure would be a harsh blow to the Russian economy and to future efforts to set up stabilization funds.
Administration officials say the $12 billion contribution to the I.M.F. should be approved soon because the delay is holding up an overall $60 billion funding increase for the organization.
A senior Treasury official said it was Congress that was dragging its feet on the I.M.F. aid. But Democrats, who remember being attacked by conservative Republicans in the 1980's for backing more I.M.F. aid, say they want Mr. Bush to take a visible role.
 
No Solace for Lip Readers
 "We have never heard the phrase 'I.M.F. replenishment' come off the President's lips," said a member of one Democratic Senator's staff.
Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, said: "It's an election year and when we go home, we're facing questions that we're giving too much to foreign aid. We have to go forward regardless of the criticisms and do what can be done to assist the commonwealth."
But not all Republicans supported Mr. Nixon's position. "There is only so many dollars we have and I think we have to take care of our commitments at home before we start sending more billions overseas," said Representative Toby Roth, Republican of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: Coffee Growers Seek Limits

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 15

 BODY:
Central American coffee producers will meet with a trade official of the United States on Monday to push for Washington's support for new international coffee quotas.
The Central Americans will meet in Washington with Myles Frechette, the assistant trade representative for Latin America, the Caribbean and Africa, to discuss negotiating positions in anticipation of the International Coffee Organization meeting in London on April 6. 
 "What we want is for there to be no doubt about what the United States is going to say in London," the president of Nicaragua's coffee commission, David Robleto, said.
The United States, the world's biggest coffee market, has always opposed renewal of export limits, saying the free market should set prices.
The Central Americans, by contrast, want to make it clear that they are unified in their support for new export limits, which would replace the previous pact that collapsed in July 1989. Coffee is a major source of export income throughout the region.
"There should be no doubt that Central American countries and Latin American countries have come out in favor of market regulation," Mr. Robleto said. Brazil last week dropped its opposition to an international coffee accord, removing a big roadblock to a price agreement.
Central American countries have seen their fragile economies battered by falling coffee prices, which dropped to 17-year lows last month for the region's mild Arabica coffee.
