HEADLINE: Dismal Section of Brighton Beach Resists Revival Efforts

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Pat Singer marched down the Brighton Beach side street, her white spangled cowboy boots clicking, her voice tight with frustration as she performing triage on the row of Archie Bunker-style houses.
"There are still drugs over there," she said, throwing a hand toward a cluster of run-down homes. "That one looks much better, but you never know," she said at another. Ms. Singer then stopped at a house at 3053 Brighton Fifth Street. "It's going to go back the way it was," she said. "Just look at it." 
 For the last 15 years, Ms. Singer, director of the Brighton Neighborhood Association, and her tiny band of workers have waged hundreds of housing battles in this ocean side community, fighting crime and inattentive landlords by organizing tenant groups in the tall brick apartment buildings that stand between Brighton Beach Avenue and the Boardwalk.
Crusading on the other side of Brighton Beach Avenue has not been so easy.
There, rows of modest, wood-frame houses -- once homes to well-to-do families -- have been converted into single-room occupancy dwellings as a kind of housing of last resort for unemployed, elderly or mentally handicapped people, most of whom subsist on welfare payments.
 
A Struggle for the Streets
 A few of the estimated 200 to 300 S.R.O.'s here are neatly kept. Many, especially those along Brighton Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Streets, are not. Absentee landlords have let the houses fall apart, leaving them as magnets for crack dealers and prostitutes who slip in and out of the most battered-looking buildings at night.
Ms. Singer and her group have tried repeatedly to reclaim this area, one of the last trouble spots in an otherwise reviving neighborhood. But the defeats keep coming.
"It's like spitting into the wind," she says.
Sitting in her office, surrounded by signs reading "Wonder Woman Works Here" and "Redheads are sexier," Ms. Singer kicks her boots up on her desk and tells of her struggle for those streets.
Almost a decade ago, with the help of $150,000 in loans and grants from private and public agencies, the association began a program to renovate and convert the most dilapidated S.R.O.'s into owner-occupied one-, two- and three-family homes. Promoting ownership would help stabilize the neighborhood, Ms. Singer reasoned. With a portion of the borrowed money, the group bought three crumbling S.R.O.'s.
 
'Through the Back Door'
 The members began with some success: One house was completed in 1985 and sold for $108,000 to Edward Lee, a local restaurant owner. But later that year, during work on the next house, the house went up in flames; a result, Ms. Singer says, of illegal drug activity there.
Mr. Lee weathered five years in the neighborhood, during which he was robbed and barraged by the sound of gunfire in the streets, until he could take no more. He sold the house and moved to Sheepshead Bay. "The house was pretty good," he said, "but there were a lot of problems in the neighborhood."
Meanwhile, discouraged about the prospects of getting more loans, the neighborhood association began trying another tack. This time, Ms. Singer sought to have one of her employees appointed by the city to be the administrator of a house where the landlord had failed to pay utility bills and had let the house fall into shambles.
That was 3053 Brighton Fifth; it was 1989.
"I thought if we can't get in the front door, we'll go in the back door," says Ms. Singer.
 
Tackling Basic Needs
 For months, said Sara Jones, the association's housing worker, the 16 people living in the house, most of them immigrants from Mexico and Puerto Rico, had dipped into their welfare money to pay the house's oil and electric bills. Crack dealers, who had taken over the basement, prompted regular raids by the police.
After more than a year of legal proceedings, Ms. Jones was given control of the house and the rent roll. Using that money, about $1,500 a month, she joined the tenants and began tackling basic needs. First heat and hot water. Then new gas lines for the stove. With the crack dealers run out, progress was being made.
Last September, however, the association's efforts were foiled again. The house's owner had failed to pay property taxes for the third year in a row, so 3053 Brighton Fifth Street was turned over to the city's Department of Housing, Preservation and Development.
Now, the house's tenants said, while they have heat and electricity, their progress has been severely stunted.
Since the city took over six months ago, no repairs have been made, said Monseratte Santiago, a tenant who greets visitors at the bullet-battered door. Using her plastic yellow flashlight to make her way through the halls, she points out the sources of what she says are almost daily complaints to the city.
 
Beyond Essential Services
 In most of the house, where tenants share one- and two-room apartments and hallway bathrooms, paint is falling from the ceiling in large chunks. In the upstairs bathroom, sections of the wall have become waterlogged. When it rains, broken gutters leave water to stream down the inside wall of the house.
"I called them about these things and they said they would be here the next day," Ms. Santiago said. "That was 15 days ago."
Downstairs, Ms. Santiago's sister, Migdalia Alequin, and her 5-year-old nephew live in a tiny two-room apartment where pink toilet tissue is crammed into gaps in the wall to keep cold air out. "Twice a day I have to clean the apartment because of the dust and paint that falls from the ceiling," Ms. Alequin said.
Roz Post, a spokeswoman for the housing department, said the house had 243 pending violations, a quarter of them marked "serious." About $24,000 had been spent on emergency repairs, she said. But she said the city's responsibility was to insure that the house had "essential services" like heat and hot water. As for other problems, "the building has just been in the system too short a time to have been assessed," she said.
But in what could be seen as a small victory for the association, Ms. Santiago and the other tenants have continued renovations on their own, with money from their welfare checks.
In the meantime, the association has picked itself up, brushed itself off and found another house to try to whip into shape: one block over on Brighton Fourth Street.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Migdalia Alequin in her apartment in Brighton Beach, where toilet tissue is crammed into gaps in the wall to keep out cold air and rodents. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Policy;
Debate on Taxes and Trade Grows Intense in Rust Belt

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 15

 BODY:
In their television commercials, debates and stump speeches in Michigan and Illinois, the Democratic Presidential candidates degrade each others' economic platforms as the basis for disaster.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas says Gov. Bill Clinton has no interest in expanding the economic pie, only in distributing increasingly smaller slices more evenly. Mr. Clinton says that Mr. Tsongas is a patsy for Wall Street and that former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. favors higher taxes for the middle class and deep tax cuts for the rich. 
 Mr. Brown, a free-trader during his days as Governor of California, now espouses the protectionist line and says Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas will do nothing about American jobs being shipped overseas.
 
Agreements Are Buried
 No matter that the three Democrats agree on fundamental economic precepts much more than they disagree. On the most critical political-economic principle, whether the Government should aggressively try to guide the nation's economy or take a hands-off approach and rely on the marketplace as President Bush and most other Republicans prefer, the Democrats all support an active Government role.
But in the primary season, the Democratic candidates seem to feel obliged to bury their agreements, especially on the economy and most especially here in the Rust Belt, where the state of the economy is the overarching issue of this year's campaign.
The unemployment rate last month was 9 percent in Michigan and 8.5 percent in Illinois, well above the 7.3 percent national average, and no relief is in sight.
In Michigan, the General Motors Corporation is closing several big automobile plants. The shutdown of the Chevrolet Caprice factory at Willow Run, southwest of Detroit, will alone cost the state nearly 15,000 jobs within three years, according to a study at Eastern Michigan University.
 
'Real Sense of Hopelessness'
 The picture in Illinois is little better. In the last three months of 1991, the state lost 20,000 jobs, including more than 3,000 at Midway Airlines, which folded in December. On a frigid day in January, 9,000 people stood in line for hours to apply for 500 jobs, some paying as little as $5 an hour, being offered at a new Sheraton Hotel in Chicago.
Robert Kahle, a poll taker at Wayne State University here, said he had never before found such pervasive despair. "You get a real sense of hopelessness, of anger," Professor Kahle said. "People are divided. They're unsure. They're disaffected."
What this means for politics generally and for Tuesday's Democratic primaries in particular is uncertain. William Ballenger, the editor of Inside Michigan Politics, a newsletter in Lansing, said many voters might be so disaffected that they simply would not go to the polls.
But the bitterness over the flagging economy could lead people not only to vote but also to do so in unexpected ways. For example, Dave Hannis, a Detroit bus driver, said that he normally voted Republican but that he had switched his registration this year so he could vote for Mr. Brown. He decided to do that, Mr. Hannis said, after a relative's job as a truck driver was jeopardized by the movement of manufacturing companies to Mexico.
"Brown's the only one who says he will stand up to that," Mr. Hannis said.
Until recently, Mr. Brown had said little about trade policy. But then Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the favorite of the United Automobile Workers and most other labor unions here, dropped out of the race, as did Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, the other Democrat who was pushing hard for trade restrictions.
Mr. Brown seized the opportunity and for the first time in the campaign, he began pressing a specific issue and not just relying on his general theme that the whole political system is corrupt. His motto became, "Keep Michigan jobs in Michigan."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, are advocates of free trade. Like almost all mainstream economists, they say trade restrictions would damage the country's economy.
But whatever its advantages for the country as a whole, particular places, like Michigan, are hurt by free trade. The poor economic condition of the state and its main industry, automobiles, is due in large part to Japanese imports. And while no one outside the company knows for sure why G.M. decided to close the Willow Run plant and leave a similar one open in Arlington, Tex., the prevailing view, said Mordechai Kreinin, an economist at Michigan State University, is that the company wants the assembly work done nearer Mexico, where G.M. hopes to take advantage of a cheaper work force.
 
Differences With Labor
 So Mr. Brown became an outspoken opponent of the fast-track authority under which Congress is allowing President Bush to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico. Congress will be able only to vote the final trade pact up or down, not to object to particular items. Otherwise, negotiation of a trade agreement would probably be impossible.
In a state where Democratic politics is dominated by labor unions, Mr. Tsongas has come under fire for opposing legislation that would prohibit companies from hiring permanent replacements for striking workers. Mr. Clinton has been criticized because as Governor of Arkansas he has never really tried to rid his state of its "right-to-work" law, which outlaws labor contracts that require workers to belong to a union.
The emphasis this week on trade and other issues of special interest to organized labor has overshadowed what until now had been the main point of economic dispute: tax policy.
 
New Taxes or Tax Cuts
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Tsongas both favor raising taxes on the rich, usually described as those with incomes above about $200,000 a year. But while Mr. Clinton would use the additional revenue to give a 10 percent tax cut to the middle class, Mr. Tsongas would reduce the tax on capital gains and give several tax breaks to businesses to spur manufacturing.
Mr. Tsongas argues that economic growth is more important than fairness in the tax code and that a favorable climate for business is essential to such growth. Mr. Clinton maintains that the best way to get the economy growing is for the Government to promote better education and training for workers.
Mr. Brown advocates scrapping the current tax system and replacing it with a 13 percent flat tax on the income of all individuals and businesses and a 13 percent value-added tax, a kind of national sales tax prominent in Europe. When questioners observe that such a system would force poor people to pay much more in taxes than they do now, Mr. Brown talks vaguely about credits and other devices to make his plan more equitable.

HEADLINE: The House Bank;
House Bank Overdrafts Add to Voters' Outrage

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 15

 BODY:
Drowning in a sea of overdrawn checks, exhausted members of Congress returned to their home districts this weekend only to be met at the door by a public shouting a giant collective "Gotcha!"
To be sure, not everyone joined the chorus, arguing that the outcry over the checks was much ado about nothing or that it took away from the real issues. But overwhelmingly -- in more than 100 interviews around the nation, in editorials and call-in shows and jokes -- the voices spoke of scorn and outrage. Many took the overdrafts as a personal insult, as a sign that Washington politicians thought they could put one over on the rubes back home. 
 "How could they think they could get away with this?" asked Flo Burkholder, 54, a Republican in Wauconda, about 35 miles west of here. "They think it's just a bunch of little people out in the country who will never know."
 
Smoking Gun
 In Texas, Eunice Alleman, who lives near Houston, said: "It galls people. It just really galls them."
Through the outrage and anger ran a thread of mischievous satisfaction: for Americans who suspected all along that those incumbents in Washington were up to no good, now there was a smoking gun.
"This is more of the same," said Allen Jason, a 42-year-old lawyer in Chicago. "It fits the pattern of voting themselves pay raises in the middle of the night. All they care about is themselves. Now at least they got called on this one. All right!"
Michael Leonard, an art critic and writer in San Francisco, said, "There's a lot of abuse and arrogance and misuse of power and this is just one of the issues."
Labeled as laughingstocks and as disgraces, some members of Congress confronted the issue head on, some said that they had been misunderstood, that they had always been in favor of disclosing the names of the overdraft writers. Really.
 
'Out of Touch'
 Others chose simply to lie low. And there was plenty from which to lie low as a new word took hold in the American political lexicon: "Rubbergate."
A Boston Globe editorial dismissed the affair as "a pocket embarrassment, not really a scandal at all," saying the public leaped on it because it could understand it.
An editorial in The Seattle Times said that the actions of Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, "are disturbingly like those of politicians out of touch with the everyday life of the people they represent."
That was a theme picked up throughout the country, including in a Miami Herald editorial that cited "justified public outrage."
An editorial in The Los Angeles Times said, "Americans are tired of politicians being out of touch with common-sense principles."
On radio call-in shows, the tone was irate. "This issue is really going to open the floodgates on the term limitations thing," said one male caller to KGO radio in San Francisco. A Cincinnati woman who called the Larry King show said, "There should be a special prosecutor."
 
Voter Reaction
 That weather vane of American public opinion, Johnny Carson, could barely contain himself Friday night on "The Tonight Show." "Folks, you've got to hand it to our House of Representatives," he said, just for starters. "They finally passed something: 5,000 bad checks."
A poll for Newsweek magazine, conducted Friday, found that 78 percent of 513 adults interviewed would be unlikely to re-elect their member of Congress if they were among the worst of the overdraft writers. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
With such an outcry, it's no wonder that even members of Congress who say they had no overdrafts -- the full list won't be released until the first week of April -- took to the campaign trail to defend themselves.
A local Republican gathering in the American Legion Hall in Wauconda amounted to a virtual celebration, with Republicans patting themselves on the backs because their party was responsible for few of the overdrafts. "It sure cuts well for the Republicans," said James Eschenbauch, 44, a carpenter.
 
'Here's My Checkbook'
 But the local congressman, Philip M. Crane, knows that the issue could work against all incumbents, including those like him who say they had no overdrafts and who pressed early for disclosure of the full list. At the meeting, Mr. Crane, who faces a challenger in the Republican primary on Tuesday, gives out literature proclaiming, "I am NOT among the congressmen who wrote bad checks."
That hasn't stopped his opponent, Gary Skoien, from milking the issue anyway. At campaign stops, he reaches into his pocket. "Here's my checkbook," he says. "I just brought it along to show you I haven't bounced any checks."
In Lowell, Mass., Michael Conway goes Mr. Skoien one better. Running for the seat of Chester G. Atkins, a Democrat who has admitted to overdrawing his House Bank account, he took to restaurants this weekend, passing out rubber checks.
"Rubbergate isn't only about bouncing checks," Mr. Conway told voters. "It's about greed and abuse of power."
 
'Part of the Coverup'
 In Chicago, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, a Democrat, is facing a primary fight on Tuesday after reapportionment moved an enclave of reform-minded yuppies into his blue-collar district. His opponent, Dick Simpson, campaigned vigorously over the weekend, attacking Mr. Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, as part of a House leadership that sought to block revealing the names of all members of Congress who overdrew their House Bank accounts.
"Rostenkowski is part of the coverup," he said at a rally. "We need a whole new group of congressmen who won't put up with this."
Mr. Rostenkowski has released a letter from Jack Russ, who oversaw the House Bank, saying there was no problem with the Representative's checks. But Mr. Simpson isn't convinced. Indeed, several members of Congress who received such letters and thought they were clear have found out they are not.
In Texas, Representative Jack Fields said he had received such a letter, but realized on Tuesday, when the coding on checks was explained to him, that some of his checks had exceeded the amount of money in his account. He had planned to bring it up at a town meeting he had scheduled for today. But virtually no one turned up. And when Mr. Fields did bring it up, Milton Lusk, a Jacinto City Councilman, said, "I don't want to hear about that," preferring instead to talk about the safety program of a local company.
 
The Bank's Fault
 Other members of Congress were not so lucky. WPLG, the Miami ABC affiliate, led its 6 P.M. newscast Friday with its chief political reporter chasing Representative Lawrence J. Smith, a Democrat from Hollywood, Fla., through an airport concourse. Mr. Smith said last week that he had not overdrawn his account. By Wednesday night he had changed his answer to "no comment." And by Friday he was suggesting that he had overdrawn his account but that it was the bank's fault.
It was not clear how the voter anger will translate at the polls. Voters have a history of complaining in general about Congress yet loyally re-electing their own Representative. For many, angry as they were, the decision seemed to rest on how big the abuse, on how contrite the lawmaker. Sensing that, many politicians issued apologies.
Representative Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat who listed 87 overdrafts and is running for the United States Senate, issued a statement that "in painful retrospect, I clearly should have paid more attention to my account."
She said she had written a check to the Deficit Reduction Fund of the United States Treasury representing the $15 that a regular bank would have charged for each overdraft.
"I'd be willing to accept one or two bounced checks," said Milton Rosen, an architect in Detroit. "And they'd better be pretty sorry about it."
Whether individual members of Congress survive or not, the damage is already done. For many Americans, the check disclosures seemed to be just another step in the decline of faith in government, just another symbol of a government that can't keep its own house in order, let alone the whole nation's.
"They're holding those big offices up there," said Lou Blackshear, who works as a maid in the Houston area. "They should be able to keep their books straight."
Allen Shaffer, a bookstore owner in Birmingham, Ala., said: "It's their playhouse. They're going to run it anyway they want."
George Fenning, a high-school teacher in Cleveland, Ohio, said: "You wonder why we can't get the economy on line, why the country is in debt. Just look at who's running things."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Thinking About De Facto Apartheid

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS rarely reads for enjoyment, but while recovering from diverticulitis last week he graciously selected an Ed McBain novel about legal injustice that was proffered from New York Hospital's library cart. For his next literary indulgence, the Mayor should choose another book about injustice: "Two Nations," Andrew Hacker's unsanitized study of racial division. Unfortunately, it's nonfiction.
Not that Mr. Dinkins, after living in New York, New Jersey and Washington, will learn much more about what it means to be black in America. What he might absorb from this analysis, though, are the emotional and intellectual underpinnings of white prejudice, presented non-judgmentally by a white who shows he can share a black perspective without being patronizing. Most disturbing about Mr. Hacker's book, as demonstrated by the quotations below, is how profoundly black and white perspectives can differ, even when race may be less valid as a characteristic than many people think. 
 America's version of apartheid, while lacking overt legal sanction, comes closest to the system even now being reformed in the land of its invention.
In "Two Nations -- Black and White, Separate, Hostile, Unequal" (Charles Scribner's Sons, 1992), Mr. Hacker, a professor at Queens College of the City University of New York and formerly at Cornell, avoid political convention. He suggests that while black racists abound, too, "no white person can claim to have suffered in such ways because of ideas that may be held about them by some black citizens." He writes that "if more black felons end up in prison cells, not the least reason is that they lacked office-based opportunities" to commit white-collar crimes, but adds, "Through crime, blacks are paying whites back, in the most ominous way they can."
What every black American knows, and whites should try to imagine, is how it feels to have an unfavorable -- and unfair -- identity imposed on you every waking day.
If Mr. Dinkins rarely suggests that he is being treated differently by the media, who doubts that he generally believes it? He would define differently as worse. Few gut responses demonstrate the rift between the races more than that so many whites agree he has been treated differently, but often better than he deserved.
Warring in the minds of Jeffersonians, both in his time and ours, is the hope that blacks are equal -- accompanied by the suspicion that they are not.
Few New Yorkers feel they control their own destiny; whites, shrinking proportionately, are becoming more edgy. White economic and social power is largely unchallenged; political control is up for grabs. That makes next year's mayoral campaign more vulnerable to a divisive racial overlay. Can reasonable people oppose Mr. Dinkins without being branded racists? In 1989, he ran on hope. If he runs in 1993, voters may measure his record against hopes raised by his rivals.
You realize that your presence makes whites uncomfortable; most of them probably wish you were not there at all. But since you are, they want to see you smile, so they can believe that you are being treated well. Not only is an upbeat air expected, but you must never show exasperation or anger, let alone anything that could look like a chip on your shoulder.
Mr. Hacker distills computer-generated statistics to deflate several misconceptions about welfare. He explains that the ratio of black single-parent families to white ones has remained fairly steady. (Half of all black and Hispanic single mothers collect public assistance; so do about a third of white single mothers.)
He mischievously wonders whether anti-abortion groups "wish a steep rise in the black birth rate, which could very well happen were abortions to be made illegal." Also, why "people who criticize middle-class career women because they see little of their children, have no compunctions about insisting that poorer women should leave their youngsters for the day and go off to work."
No white American, including those who insist that opportunities exist for persons of every race, would change places with even the most successful black American. . . . Even when black men reach the same academic level as white men, their incomes stay several steps behind. . . . Perhaps most revealing of all is the small number of black dental hygienists. While white patients seem willing to be cared for by black nurses, they apparently draw the line at having black fingers in their mouths.
A recent New York Times/WCBS-TV News survey found that blacks and whites in the region differed on whether whites would be welcome in black neighborhoods after dark and vice versa. Their assessment of government services also diverged: blacks even rated drinking water worse than whites did.
A politics purposively permeated by race has consolidated enough white Americans as a self-conscious racial majority. This is not to say that they are bigots or reactionaries. It is rather that they feel threatened, not always in ways they understand.
Mr. Dinkins's challenge is to understand himself. Then to help all his constituents overcome.

HEADLINE: Rural New York County Has Unlikely Manufacturing Revival

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HORSEHEADS, N.Y., March 13

 BODY:
Something strange has happened in the lushly forested hills here, 30 miles southwest of Ithaca, where one of the highest concentrations of shuttered factories in the Northeast had come to resemble a rust-laden museum of heavy industry. The museum has come to life.
Inspired first in the mid-1980's by a huge investment from Toshiba Inc., the Japanese conglomerate, plants have reopened, assembly lines have been automated, and machine shops are suddenly abuzz in a manufacturing revival. 
 "It's come through a combination of good luck and hard work, and things have snowballed," said Frank M. Surdey, regional economist for the New York State Department of Labor, who said manufacturing employment in Horseheads, Elmira and elsewhere in Chemung County has increased by more than 20 percent since 1985.
The upturn is perhaps no more than a blip on the rural landscape, while factories in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and the nation continue to fall prey to the recession and foreign competition. And Chemung County is not immune. After robust expansion for four years, many of its factories and machine shops began laying off workers last year, and the downturn has accelerated since January. The showcase Toshiba plant is still operating at a deep loss.
But despite the setbacks, a sense of optimism seems to pervade plant floors and family gatherings, and stems from long historical roots.
 
Incubator of Industrial Muscle
 It was here, beginning early in the century, that American industry established an incubator of manufacturing muscle. Fed by rail lines and waves of skilled immigrant labor, the United States Steel Corporation, the General Electric Company and more than a dozen other industrial concerns built plants.
Almost all were abandoned in cascades of layoffs, financial misery and broken families that culminated in the mid-1980's.
"It was a desperate time," said Donald Loomis, 40 years old, who spent eight months without a job in 1987, nearly losing his house. His employer, a foundry, had followed the valve fabricators, fire hydrant makers and other Chemung County companies it supplied into extinction.
Now Mr. Loomis and his wife, Ronda, both work at Chemung County's largest company, Toshiba Display Devices, Inc. In a plant that had been long abandoned, the Japanese company has invested more than $200 million and now employs 1,300 people. The plant's main product is oversized picture tubes for expensive televisions, a market that is itself being battered by the recession and global competition.
Economists and industry analysts say the mini-revival of Chemung County, fueled in part by business incentives from New York State, may offer a case study for those trying to reinvigorate industry elsewhere.
It also demonstrates how a Japanese conglomerate can become central to the welfare of small American communities, even as complaints about predatory Japanese business practices are a recurrent political theme across the country.
"This recession, like all those that have occurred before it, will pass," said Yoshio Aono, president of Toshiba Display Devices, and one of five executives from Tokyo who run the Horseheads plant with five American managers.
 
Accepts Union Proposal
 The company said its sales were far below its own projections, and last month announced production cuts. But it shocked many people here by accepting a union proposal in which workers are encouraged to take one day each week off without pay, but are not forced to do so. At the same time, no one is being laid off.
"They have always treated us well in times of economic hardship," said Roxanne Barnstead, a jocular mechanic in the Toshiba plant known here as Rocky, who is president of Local 1632 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
When Toshiba made its first investment here in 1985, reopening the Horseheads plant in a joint venture with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, union officials said they feared that the newly arrived Japanese executives would fight any form of union. But the plant was quickly organized without management objections.
Elsewhere in Chemung County, workers have found new options at other manufacturers.
One is ABB Traction Inc., a subsidiary of a Swiss conglomerate that makes railroad cars and equipment. It bought a long-abandoned United States Steel plant last year in Elmira Heights. It has hired 600 workers to fill contracts from New Jersey Transit, the city of Baltimore and other large customers.
 
'Picking Themselves Up'
 Makers of helicopters, athletic equipment and novelty merchandise have also opened or expanded over the last five years.
"I don't think there is any place in the country where people have done such a remarkable job picking themselves up by their own bootstraps," said Robert Bivens, president of Southern Tier Economic Growth, a group of Chemung County boosters.
State business incentives have been distributed generously here. The state provided low-rate loans and job-training grants worth $7 million to Toshiba and Westinghouse for its partnership in 1985, and since then, 44 smaller manufacturers in the county have received incentives worth $9.6 million, according to the state's Urban Development Corporation.
The upturn in Chemung "has enhanced the entire state's ability to attract foreign and domestic manufacturing jobs," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in October when he went to Tokyo. He made it a point to visit senior executives of Toshiba there.
Executives say the resilience of this area as a manufacturing center rests mainly on resources that have been here for more than 50 years, through good times and bad. Abandoned plants still litter the landscape and can be bought cheap, and generations of experienced laborers are still looking for opportunities.
"We found the right production site, a skilled labor force and a high work ethic," said Joyce Baginski, a spokesperson for ABB Traction.
Still, the shadow of the recession is not far away. At the Toshiba plant and other companies, posters at the entrances say no new job applications are being accepted.
And despite their warm relations, the courtship between this rural outpost and the Japanese could sour.
"The Japanese have their limits, and Toshiba is not going to keep that plant open just to employ 1,300 workers," said Schon Beechler, a professor of international management at Columbia Business School. "I would not be all that comfortable if their market does not pick up soon."
The company's biggest investment has been to retool its plant for production of television screens 27 inches to 35 inches in diameter, most of them assembled into finished sets at another of its plants, in Tennessee. Priced at $700 to over $2,000, the televisions have captured a tiny share of the United States market, even though Toshiba is meeting new competition from American plants run by Matsushita Electric and other Japanese concerns.
But analysts said the Toshiba workers here were more secure than they might be under traditional United States corporate practices, because of the long-term planning used by Japanese companies, including Toshiba. They have been willing to invest vast amounts in advanced electronic products for years to serve their strategic purpose of establishing large new markets.
"In a recession, I'd put my chips on a Japanese company," Ms. Beechler said.
Toshiba's venture in Horseheads has never been smooth. After false starts and differences over strategy, Toshiba bought out Westinghouse's interest in the plant in 1987, retooled with automated machinery designed in Japan, and hired 400 more workers. The company is offering no assurances to Chemung County that it can avert layoffs.
But workers here say that, at least for now, life has returned to normal after a brush with economic ruin.
"You can go to work, pay your bills, and live an ordinary life," said Mr. Loomis. "That in itself is big improvement for this area."

HEADLINE: Press Notes;
U.P.I. Seems to Be Nearing A Moment of Truth Again

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Beleaguered United Press International seems once again to be approaching a moment of truth.
Earlier this month, Judge Francis G. Conrad of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan said that U.P.I. seemed to have enough cash to continue operating only through April, and he threw open the legal gates to allow anyone to make a bid to save the news agency. 
 "At a certain price, we believe someone will acquire U.P.I.," said Dennis M. O'Dea, counsel for the creditors committee, who added that if any prospective buyers had been hesitating, the moment to make an offer was at hand. He said U.P.I. needed to find a buyer within 60 days.
U.P.I., once one of the largest and most competitive news-gathering agencies in the world, declared bankruptcy in August for the second time, and since then its management has been frantically trying to find a buyer or investor.
The Bankruptcy Court allowed the management one extension on its allotted 120 days of exclusive right to come up with a reorganization plan, but earlier this month, the court refused a second extension.
Now, anyone is free to file a reorganization plan that would rescue U.P.I., which a decade ago competed around the globe with its archrival, The Associated Press.
While the withering of U.P.I. has diminished what had been one of the principal streams of information flowing to the nation's news organizations, its role has been filled by The Associated Press and a host of supplemental news services that have grown rapidly in the last decade. Among these are the news services of Knight-Ridder, The New York Times, Gannett, and a joint venture of The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. In addition, Reuters, the British news service, has expanded its coverage of the United States.
"We're not trying to compete with The Associated Press anymore, except on certain stories," said Al Rossiter Jr., who has been with U.P.I. for 32 years and has led the news service's news operation since 1987.
Mr. Rossiter said that U.P.I. was losing about $100,000 a month and that the company must find a bridge loan or an investor or face extinction.
In any event, Friday was Mr. Rossiter's last day.
Like many other "Unipressers," as U.P.I. news staff call themselves, he elected to take another job and will become director of the Duke University news service.
Mr. Rossiter said U.P.I.'s news staff now has about half the 850 full-time employees it had in 1987.
But Mr. Rossiter said that the agency was still providing a service and that its network of 80 foreign and domestic bureaus was a franchise too valuable to go under.
"We've been in as precarious a position, if not more so, in the past," Mr. Rossiter said. "And we've survived one way or another."
But Mr. Rossiter, who is 56 years old and had his pension frozen three years ago because of U.P.I.'s desperate financial straits, said he felt he had no choice but to leave.
 
Guild Effort in Los Angeles
 For the first time, the Newspaper Guild has begun a full-scale effort to organize The Los Angeles Times, the nation's largest nonunion newspaper.
Jim Smith, administrative officer of the Los Angeles Newspaper Guild, said that for decades The Times's wages and benefits had been so superior to other area newspapers that the Guild had not made the effort.
Mr. Smith said that last November The Times laid off some part-time employees in the mailroom and that there were complaints about pay cuts and arbitrary transfers.
Citing declines in advertising from a depressed economy in the last 18 months, the paper has reduced its full-time work force by about 1,000, to 7,600, through attrition, a hiring freeze and a voluntary early-retirement program.
The result has been "a surge of interest," Mr. Smith said.
The effort thus far is to get signatures requesting a union election from one-third of the employees in the job categories the Guild is seeking to represent, as required by labor law.
Mr. Smith said that conceivably the Guild could represent roughly 5,500 Times employees in news, advertising, circulation, transportation and the mailroom but could hold an election that involved only one or a combination of them.
Mr. Smith declined to say how many employees had signed cards, but he predicted a vote before the end of the year.
To help make the Guild's case, the union arranged for a visit from Juan Gonzalez, a columnist at The Daily News in New York, who was a prominent leader during the strike that ended a year ago.
In February, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters lost an election to represent mailroom employees by about 4 to 1. Laura Morgan, a Times spokeswoman, said that the paper was making every effort to maintain its nonunion status.
For instance, in January the paper approved a 4 percent wage increase, which is considered quite generous in such tight economic times.
 
A Nonunion Project
 On the flip side of the union record, a longtime adviser and confidant of New York City's newspaper unions has become a newspaper publisher -- of a nonunion daily.
Theodore W. Kheel, who has helped mediate newspaper union strikes and other crises since 1963, is publisher of The Earth Summit Times, which appears five days each week and has a circulation of about 7,000.
But this particular daily, which is provided without charge, is scheduled to cease publication April 3 after 30 issues.
Mr. Kheel said The Earth Summit Times had been created to draw attention to the planning meeting at the United Nations for the United Nations Conference on the Environment, a major environmental summit scheduled for Rio de Janiero in June.
The staff ranges from Don DeMaio, the executive editor, who worked at The National, the defunct sports daily, to Gerard Piel, long associated with Scientific American, who is editor of the opinion pages.
"It's nonunion, but we're willing to be organized," Mr. Kheel said.
 
Alphabet Soup Mix
 The newspaper industry's effort to streamline eight support organizations into one grand association has been a messy job, with false starts, confusion and infighting.
The objective of such a consolidation is to eliminate duplicated work done by the various organizations and also to reduce the costs of papers now paying membership dues for up to eight organizations.
There is little doubt that the merger will take place and that on April 24 the N.A.A. (Newspaper Association of America) will be voted into existence.
But it has not been pretty.
Last year, the N.A.B. (Newspaper Advertising Bureau) announced plans to merge this July 1 with six related marketing associations known within the industry as the alphabet soups: A.N.C.A.M. (Association of Newspaper Classified Advertising Managers), I.C.M.A. (International Circulation Managers Association) and -- similarly -- the I.N.A.M.E., I.N.M.A., N.A.C.N., and N.R.C., all related to marketing and advertising.
This merged creature was to be called N.M.I. (Newspaper Marketing Inc.)
But in January, plans for N.M.I. were scrapped in favor of an even bigger merger that would include the A.N.P.A. (American Newspaper Publishers Association).
The new product of this mega-merger was to have been called the A.N.A. (American Newspaper Association).
But it turned out that there was another A.N.A., so to avoid confusion a new name had to be found. The A.A.N. (Association of American Newspapers) was considered, but rejected.
Finally, N.A.A. (Newspaper Association of America) was settled upon.
Meanwhile, there was another problem.
One reason for the merger was the feeling by many of the major newspaper groups that some chains, mostly of small papers, were not bearing their fair share of the cost of supporting the industry organizations.
For instance, while the Gannett Company, the Times-Mirror Company and other major chains paid membership for each of their papers, some chains might have only one or two papers as paying members but still have all their top executives taking part in conventions and deriving other benefits of membership, like libel insurance.
Many of those planning the new organization wanted to include a rule that membership in the N.A.A. would be an all-or-nothing proposition; either all a chain's papers were members, or the chain would be excluded.
But the small chains made it clear that in an all-or-nothing situation they would choose nothing or maybe the N.N.A. (National Newspaper Association), which mostly has non-dailies as members but includes some dailies.
The planners decided they could not make the all-or-nothing rule stick, and the final plan allows a chain to join on whatever basis it chooses. Peer pressure will be applied to encourage them to make all their papers members.
 
A Buy Recommendation
 Lee Dirks, one of the nation's major newspaper brokers, has provided one more sign that the newspaper business may be improving.
Last week, he sent a letter to clients and prospective clients urging them to buy a newspaper.
Last year, only 18 newspapers were sold, making 1991 the worst year for newspaper sales since Mr. Dirks began keeping records 20 years ago. And 1990 was third worst, with 25 sales.
But Mr. Dirks said he was encouraged by lower interest rates, relaxed lending and tax regulations, a faint improvement in advertising and a lot of pent-up demand from both buyers and sellers.
"We don't foresee a return to the extremely strong prices of the late 1980's anytime soon," Mr. Dirks said, "but we think prices have reached the bottom of the trough and will begin firming very soon. To us, that means one thing: now is the time to buy."

HEADLINE: Second-in-Command at Tenneco

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 15

 BODY:
Struggling to recover from a huge loss last year, Tenneco Inc. has again turned to a senior executive from another big manufacturing company to bolster its top management.
The diversified industrial company said today that Dana G. Mead, an executive vice president of the International Paper Company and a retired Army colonel who wrote several sections of the Pentagon Papers in the late 1960's, would become the chief operating officer and a director at Tenneco on April 1. Mr. Mead, 56 years old, will add the president's title in May. 
 Since September, Tenneco has been led by Michael H. Walsh, a tough-minded chief executive who came to the company after five years as the head of the Union Pacific Railroad.
 
Two Late Starters
 In Mr. Walsh and Mr. Mead, Tenneco, the nation's 38th-largest industrial corporation, has a pair of leaders who got a comparatively late start in their corporate careers.
A Yale-educated lawyer, Mr. Walsh was the United States Attorney for the Southern District of California in San Diego when, at age 38, he was lured into a management post with the Cummins Engine Company. In 1978, Mr. Mead, then 42, resigned from a tenured professorship at the United States Military Academy to join International Paper as a project director.
Mr. Walsh, 49, has pledged a quick turnaround for Tenneco, which lost $732 million last year mainly from restructuring charges at its J. I. Case unit, a maker of farm and construction machinery. He will add the chairman's title when James L. Ketelsen, 60, who has led Tenneco since 1978, steps down at the company's annual meeting on May 12.
In an interview today from his home in Houston, where Tenneco is based, Mr. Walsh said Mr. Mead's main assignment would be to push Tenneco's six operating companies to meet goals for higher productivity, efficiency, quality and profits.
In addition to the troubled Case unit, Tenneco operates a big natural gas pipeline; the world's largest shipyard in Newport News, Va., and three other companies each with more than $1 billion in sales in packaging, chemicals and auto parts.
Explaining why he had switched to the business world, Mr. Mead said in an interview today from Tenneco's headquarters: "The West Point professor's position was appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate, but after a few years, I found that my adrenaline was pumping faster than being a professor. I left it reluctantly, but I just wasn't able to do what I wanted with the cadets."
In his 14 years at International Paper, Mr. Mead contributed to a substantial improvement in the company's performance, analysts said. Costs of fiber used in making paper fell 30 percent and the energy costs dropped 40 percent, while output for each employee rose by a minimum of 3 percent a year.
Mr. Mead negotiated separate deals in which International Paper acquired Zanders, a major producer in Europe of coated papers, and Aussedat-Rey, France's largest maker of copy papers. He also was a frequent spokesman for the domestic paper industry in its frustrated campaign to sell more products in Japan.
International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., improved its profit as a percentage of shareholders' equity in the 1980's, reaching a peak of 17.6 percent in 1989. Its stock price, which closed up $1, to $74.375, on the Big Board on Friday, rebounded from a low of $16.50 in the recession in 1982.
"My leaving I.P. had nothing to do with that company," he said. "I had a great job. But Tenneco represents a challenge, with basic businesses that are excellent. Mike Walsh is one of the top C.E.O.'s in the country, and I subscribe to the kind of things that he's trying to do."
 
A Distinguished Officer
 Mr. Mead spent 21 years in the Army. After graduating from West Point with an engineering degree, he earned a doctorate in political science and economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
After a year as a White House fellow, he rose to deputy director of the Nixon Administration's domestic policy council, under Paul H. O'Neill, now chief executive of Alcoa. He returned to West Point for four years in 1974 as one of two tenured professors at the military academy, teaching government, international relations and economics.
In 1968, he wrote the final four volumes of the Pentagon Papers, covering the history of American ground forces in Vietnam. He also drafted the plans the Marines followed in their withdrawal from Vietnam's demilitarized zone late in 1969. He then headed Army combat operations in the zone for the first half of 1970.
Mr. Mead joined International Paper as a program director in 1978, headed the human resources department for two years and was senior vice president until being named one of two executive vice presidents in 1988.
"When you put it all together, he's got a combination of leadership skills and consistent pattern of success," Mr. Walsh said. "He's a real get-it-done guy."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Indicate Traders Expect Higher Growth

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
With the latest statistics showing surprising economic strength, credit market participants are challenging the view held by most economists that any recovery will be mild at most.
The reports, particularly the spurt in retail sales reported for January and February, have caused many economists to ratchet up their growth forecasts for the first half of the year. It now appears, they say, that the economy is likely to expand slightly in the first quarter instead of contracting. And the boost to consumption provided by the retail sales numbers suggests that second-quarter growth should be around 2 percent or perhaps a bit higher. 
 But if the rise in interest rates this winter is indicative of market expectations, traders see those forecasts as overly pessimistic.
 
Higher Pricing of Debt
 Instead of 1 percent to 2 percent growth, market participants have priced debt securities at levels consistent with an economy expanding at a 3 percent to 4 percent rate, analysts said.
While that higher level would be about half the rate of expansion at the end of earlier post-World War II recessions, most economists say even that sort of pace will not be reached this year, particularly on a sustained basis.
"There is the potential for stronger-than-expected growth," said Gary Schlossberg, a vice president and senior economist at Wells Fargo & Company in San Francisco. "But I think it will be more modest than the bond market currently expects and that interest rates will move back down."
 
Consumers Still Stymied
 Even though the rise in spending pushed retail sales to their highest level in nearly two years on an inflation-adjusted basis in January and February, a now-familiar litany of constraints made it hard to see how much extra push to the recovery consumers can provide.
Outstanding consumer debt and debt service have fallen noticeably from the peaks reached in 1989, but economists note that both measures remain well above historic norms.
Meanwhile, growth in personal income remains sluggish, though analysts said that mortgage refinancings and larger tax refunds might have improved cash flows in January and February and could help explain why spending picked up in those months.
 
Need for More Jobs
 Consumer confidence is showing some improvement as well, but weekly initial unemployment claims continue to run at recession-like levels. And with factories operating at well under peak capacity, employers are more likely to have their existing work force put in longer hours to meet any increase in output for some months before they start hiring again.
"Without an increase in jobs, the recent growth in cash flows will not be sustained," Paul D. Mastroddi, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, wrote in the bank's weekly letter to clients.
Thomas Synnott, chief economist and senior vice president at the United States Trust Company, said, "With initial unemployment claims still running at 450,000 a week, we are not poised for a big turn" in the economy.
"Low inflation, the prospects for a mild recovery and the weakness of private demand for credit all argue for lower interest rates than we have today," Mr. Synnott added, "with the possible exception of the overnight Federal funds rate."
The credit markets usually warm to indications of a weak economy and mild inflation pressures because lower inflation tends to increase the value of fixed-income securities.
 
Little Has Changed of Late
 Little has changed over the last few months to stir expectations of much stimulus from other sectors of the economy, analysts argue.
Prospects that the President and Congress will agree to a substantive fiscal package are dwindling, Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, said.
If no economic growth package is produced, stimulus from the Government will be limited to the increase in unemployment benefits and the reduction in payroll withholding taxes announced in January.
In addition, the financial condition of most state and local governments is still shaky. And the recent rise in the dollar as well as growing weakness in crucial markets in Europe and Asia make it difficult to see American export growth accelerating from current levels.
"Although recovery is taking on a more durable cast, growth is unlikely to exceed 2 percent in the spring quarter and likely will remain muted at 2.5 percent to 3 percent in the second half of 1992," Ms. Hering wrote in Salomon's weekly Comments on Credit.
 
Higher Rates Expected
 While analysts remain convinced that recent sharp gains in areas like retail sales will become much more moderate in months ahead, they said they were almost equally certain that given the gloom currently hanging over the credit markets, interest rates are more likely to move higher in the next few weeks than they are to decline.
The few remaining important reports to be released this month on how the economy fared in February will not do much to shake the market's current conviction that recovery is coming at a much faster pace than forecast, the analysts said.
"There are still some strong economic numbers coming down the pike," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "The rise in interest rates has gone too far, but over the near term it can get worse."

HEADLINE: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week

 BODY:
The tentative schedule of Treasury financings this week includes only the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.
Late in the day on Friday, the three-month bills traded with a yield of 4.04 percent and the six-month bills were at 4.21 percent.

HEADLINE: Savings Rate Falls in Japan

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 15

 BODY:
Japan's savings rate fell to a record low 6.5 percent in 1991, the Government has reported, fueling anxiety that the foundation of the nation's postwar economic boom is eroding.
The Bank of Japan said on Friday that it was the second consecutive year for a record low savings rate -- personal savings as a percentage of disposable income. In 1990, savings grew by 7.7 percent. 
 "Japan's high savings rate has been one of the most important aspects of Japan's postwar economy," said Chiharu Shima, economist at UBS Phillips & Drew International Ltd.
Fears are now mounting that lower savings will constrain investment needed for economic growth. "There is increasing concern about the falling savings rate," Mr. Shima said.
Japan, which saved about 20 percent of disposable income in the mid-1970's, has traditionally had a much higher savings rate than the United States, giving Japanese the capital to build what has become the second most powerful economy in the world.
Economists for years have said that the United States, with a savings rate of 5.3 percent, needs to increase that level if it hopes to have money for future investments in a more competitive world.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Farm Aid: Music Omits Message

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 15

 BODY:
At the Farm Aid V benefit concert at Texas Stadium in Irving on Saturday, the music often spoke louder than the message. Flanking the stage were two enormous banners bearing the Farm Aid logo of a tractor flying an American flag. On the stage itself were enlarged black-and-white photographs of farmland scenes: Richard Avedon-style portraits of wan children's faces, landscapes of silos, homesteads and waves of grain. With these few token references in place, many of the big names from the roster of more than 50 country, rock and folk performers scheduled throughout the 12-hour event took the opportunity to perform some of their big hits.
Paul Simon stood with an acoustic guitar and played Simon and Garfunkel favorites like "The Boxer" and "Homeward Bound." Neil Young gathered together a loose country-rock band for "Heart of Gold" and "Old Man." The Funky Farmer All-Stars, featuring members of Lynyrd Skynyrd, stomped through the Southern rock classic "Sweet Home Alabama." The audience had plenty of anthems to punch its fists to, even if the cause behind the event -- the plight of American family farmers -- was somewhat steamrolled in the process. 
 The Farm Aid benefit, now in its fifth year, with past concerts taking place in 1985, 1986, 1987 and 1990, has become a forum for top entertainers to provide some great music and simultaneously raise consciousness about the situation in the farm industry, with farmers' being forced off the land because of economic restraints that make profitable independent farming difficult. Money raised from pledges and ticket sales goes to Farm Aid Inc., a nonprofit organization that offers relief to farmers in various forms, from crisis hot lines to job training to legal support. Since 1985, Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp and Mr. Young, the three driving forces behind the event, have shown a stalwart long-term commitment to the cause that is unusual among celebrity charity endorsements.
On Saturday, a few artists made explicit reference in their music to the issues at hand. The country-rock singer Steve Earle performed a solo acoustic version of his song "The Rain Came Down," which he wrote after appearing at Farm Aid II in 1986; James McMurtry's dusty tales of the heartland spoke directly to the rural condition. Mr. Nelson invoked traditional values with songs like "This Land Is Your Land" and "Amazing Grace."
Other bands roused the crowd on a purely musical level. Little Village, a roots-rock supergroup featuring Nick Lowe, Ry Cooder and John Hiatt, succeeded in "reducing this home of the Dallas Cowboys to a smoky little night club" with its nuevo-rockabilly rave-ups. Also performing were the Texas Tornadoes, Michelle Shocked, Mary Chapin-Carpenter and Tracy Chapman, who sang somber if soulful adult-rock ballads.
Mr. Mellencamp was the one performer who gracefully integrated music and message. His three-song set combined the muscled bravura of rock-and-roll with concerns that lie deep at the heart of Americana: "Rain on the Scarecrow" looked specifically at the social and economic disintegration in the Midwest, while "The Authority Song" reaffirmed the need to fight the Establishment continually, no matter how many times the Establishment wins. When he performed his hit "Pink Houses," the myth of American freedom seemed to grow as big as the stadium itself.
But a bad omen occurred mid-afternoon, when the Rev. Jesse Jackson came out onstage to address the crowd about family farmers' issues. He was greeted by a display of Southern inhospitality when the predominantly white crowd booed him. The reaction underscores a persistent problem with the Farm Aid concerts: whether the message itself is actually reaching a wide enough audience, both inside and outside the walls of the stadium.
Since the first concert in 1985, Farm Aid has been plagued by both financial and organizational problems. Mr. Nelson organized the initial Farm Aid concert in the wake of Live Aid, the high-profile American and European shows to raise money for Ethiopian famine relief. "When Bob Dylan was on Live Aid," Mr. Nelson said in an interview last week, "he said, 'Wouldn't it be nice if some of this money we're sending overseas stayed here for our farmers?' " At the time, Farm Aid officials said they hoped to raise around $40 million for the cause, but the actual pledges after the show came to only $7 million.
Subsequent events fell further from the original goals. Farm Aid II raised $1.5 million; Farm Aid III $1.6 million; and Farm Aid IV $1.2 million. An estimate of pledges from Saturday's show was not yet available. The stadium, which as modified for the concert held about 40,000, did not sell out.
"The same people that we're asking today are the people we asked back in 1985," said Mr. Nelson. "It's like, 'We gave already.' We're trying to find another audience that didn't give."
Last week Mr. Mellencamp expressed concern over whether the current economic recession would further hinder the audience's ability to donate. "I could tell you something that might make everything seem rosy, but I find that a lot of people are having a hard enough time paying their own bills," he said. "They're questioning: I can't even make my own payments anymore, you really expect me to donate money? It's tough out there."
Other problems may have to do with the way the show is organized.
Lloyd Werner, the senior vice president for marketing and sales at the Nashville Network, the cable channel that has broadcast every Farm Aid but the second (the music-video cable channel VH-1 carried that), said the organizers don't plan the show far enough in advance. "One of the problems is when Willie decides to do the concert," he said. "One day he gets up and says it would be a good idea to hold a concert. He calls up all his friends and all his friends say sure, we'll be there. Then he seeks a television outlet."
Mr. Nelson announced Saturday's benefit in January. Mr. Werner said that TNN signed the contracts to broadcast the event only three weeks ago. By then, he said, "we had already planned programming.
"We had to take that programming off the air, and all the advertising that's in it. Without preplanning you can't market it, you can't sell it, you can't get the advertisers involved and your ratings tend to be lower."
Farm Aid has also never been based in a particular city or at a particular time of the year. The first concert was held in Champaign, Ill., on Sept. 4, 1985; the second in Austin on July 4, 1986; the third in Lincoln, Neb., on Sept. 19, 1987; the fourth in Indianapolis on April 7, 1990. No Farm Aid was scheduled for 1991, although Carolyn Mugar, the executive director of Farm Aid, said "we were trying to get one together for the fall but it didn't work out." Last year, Mr. Nelson was involved in raising $15 million that he owed to the Internal Revenue Service.
Mr. Nelson's personal commitment to the cause of Farm Aid, however, is unquestionable. "I got into it because I'm an ex-farm worker," he said. "I'm stubborn by birth. I can't believe that people don't care; I believe they don't know yet. So that's the purpose of all these other Farm Aids: to try and get the word out."

HEADLINE: The New Faces of Wall Street '92

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
A fresh crop of recruits has arrived on Wall Street, one of the few areas in the New York region that is hiring after years of retrenchment. The new faces are older and more experienced than those hired in the past, and, if David Nelson is any example, they bring a more lucrative list of potential clients with them.
Mr. Nelson, 43 years old, was once lead guitarist for the Turtles, one of the mop-top rock groups that characterized the rebellious flavor of the late 1960's. Last year, he became a broker at Merrill Lynch & Company, and by tapping his acquaintances in the music business, he is likely to develop a fuller book of clients than most first-year brokers.
 
Opportunity Knocking Again
 "I've already been able to make inroads with record companies that need business and financial advice," said Mr. Nelson, who talks about cash-flow, pension and insurance issues with the assurance of a knowledgeable insider. "I don't want to limit myself to the music business, but that is obviously my area of expertise. 
 "I wanted to make this move back in 1987," added Mr. Nelson, who worked most recently as a record producer. "But the opportunity wasn't there," he said, after the stock market crashed in October of that year.
It is now. Several brokerage firms are hiring more entry-level brokers than they did a year ago. While limited, this expansion is one of the few economic bright spots in the New York region, where 40,000 jobs are expected to evaporate in the next few years.
If a silver lining to a recession is that the quality and size of job-applicant pools swell, Wall Street firms are in the enviable position of being able to take advantage of the talent fleeing hard times in other businesses. It is not so much that the rash of new applicants are unemployed, recruiting executives say, but rather that many are finding their careers stalled in depressed areas like banking and financial consulting.
Richard A. Ferdinand also joined Merrill recently, 12 years after he left the securities industry. Mr. Ferdinand enjoyed the independence of working alone at the investment banking firm he set up in New Jersey, he said, but found that the recession and growing service requirements eventually limited what he could do.
"As the business cycle changes, here I am back on the Street," Mr. Ferdinand, 48, said.
Working as a broker at a larger firm, he explained, allows him the resources to provide financial planning for a wider scope of companies, while his experience running his own business gives him a quick rapport with clients, whose concerns he can readily understand.
"I have enough breadth to go to someone and say, 'Here's what I would do,' " he said.
 
A Growing Pool
 Paradoxically, Wall Street's recent success -- reflected in record profits at brokerage houses and in new stock market highs -- is drawing so many job seekers that despite the hiring, some firms are turning away many more applicants than they did a year ago. For Wall Street's big firms, the result is a richer choice of applicants for each available position.
"We've seen a dramatic change in the people coming in," said Robert J. Dwyer, who oversees recruitment at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. In 1991, Mr. Dwyer said, the average broker recruited by Dean Witter was 36 years old, with six years of related experience. Only a year earlier, Dean Witter's average new broker was 26 years old, with a year of experience.
Dean Witter expects to hire 1,000 account executives this year, compared with 600 in 1991. Shearson Lehman Brothers expects to hire between 600 and 1,000 brokers, compared with 400 last year. Prudential Securities' training program has accepted more than 400 brokers this year, compared with just 97 last year.
 
Concentrated in Retail Area
 This expansion, while limited mostly to the retail side of the business, is giving the securities industry its first boost in employment in three years. According to the Securities Industry Association, employment in the industry totaled about 214,000 at the end of 1991, compared with 210,000 a year before. Figures for early 1992 are not yet available.
From its peak just before the stock market crash in 1987, employment on Wall Street is still down by 50,000, and in the narrow streets of lower Manhattan, lunchtime crowds are still palpably smaller than they were a few years ago.
Part of the focus at firms in this slimmer, sleeker environment is to accumulate assets under management from individuals as a financial ballast to the unpredictable, volatile nature of trading securities.
Several brokerage firms are both expanding the training of their own retail brokers and stressing the value of building a long-term relationship with each client instead of relying on quick trading commissions.
"It's no longer 'get a hunch and sell a bunch,' " said Linda Marcelli, branch manager of Merrill Lynch's main New York office. She supervises more than 160 financial advisers, including Mr. Nelson. "It's long-term planning that we're looking for."
Prudential Securities recently hired a new executive vice president, A. Laurence Norton, to oversee recruitment, training and retention of the firm's financial advisers.
One of the advantages of the older, more seasoned crop of new brokers coming into Prudential, Mr. Norton said, is that they generally are people with some financial experience, people who have some understanding of the securities business.
"These are the kind of people who can make an impact a little quicker," Mr. Norton said. Some customers are more comfortable entrusting their investments to an older broker, he added, although more sophisticated customers tend to judge a financial consultant by rate of success and not by age.
For brokerage houses, another bonus of the higher caliber of fresh recruits is that instead of starting from scratch, new brokers often come to their jobs with a list of potential clients from their previous work.
With the ability of Mr. Nelson to tap his contacts in the music and film businesses, which are traditionally not known for their sophisticated money management, he can parlay them into a promising list of clients.
"The amounts of money coming in were astonishing," said Mr. Nelson of what he saw in his years in the music industry. "And there was no money management at all."
Sam Masucci, a colleague of Mr. Nelson, arrived at Merrill after three years at Metropolitan Life, where he sold insurance but felt constricted by his limited ability there to provide clients with comprehensive financial planning.
On his first day at Merrill, he said, he landed 18 clients that he had known from Metropolitan Life.
"Not bad for a first day," joked Ms. Marcelli, his boss at Merrill.
"Let's see if he can keep it up."

HEADLINE: Caller, Identify Yourself

 BODY:
The same technology that lets telephone users identify their callers also exposes callers to identification they may not want. An obvious case is the rape victim who wishes to call a counseling service without first divulging her name. This technology now advances from state to state, raising privacy problems that cut in all directions.
New York, the latest state to approve a service named Caller ID, has adopted some wise safeguards for privacy that might serve as a guide to others. 
 Nearly half the states let phone companies give customers the means to trace or deal with an objectionable call. Some systems can instantly switch heavy-breathers to a police operator, or let a person who receives an obscene call press a few buttons and make it impossible for the caller to phone again.
By far the best-known and most controversial system is "caller identification." An attachment costing $60 to $120 lets the customer see the caller's number on a small screen. Some of the gadgets maintain a record of calling numbers and others can even summon the caller's name along with other personal information. The main worries about privacy involve people who don't want to divulge their numbers merely by calling out.
In New York, the state Public Service Commission has just approved the New York Telephone Company's version of Caller ID, which soon will start operating in Poughkeepsie and other mid-Hudson areas. It's a system that meets evolving Federal standards for interstate phoning and seems to offer high privacy protection.
Customers will receive at no extra charge a service called per-call blocking: press a couple of digits before dialing the number and the party called receives no identification -- only a symbol "P" for private. Or the customer may elect free per-line blocking, a system that allows the caller to remain anonymous on every call unless he or she elects to remove the block by hitting another few digits.
This should give the dialer maximum power to choose whether to be identified. A counselor can feel more at ease calling the home of a battered spouse, for example, or a rape victim can feel freer to phone a counseling service.
Will so many customers choose total identification blocking that Caller ID won't work economically? That hasn't happened yet, but more experience is needed. Meanwhile, New York has made a promising start on coping with a new and, to some, scary technology.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Trading Trade for Votes, Fearfully

 BODY:
"Yeah, they'll create jobs. In Mexico." That sarcastic remark from a Detroit auto worker captured the anger directed last week at candidates Bill Clinton and Paul Tsongas for supporting the North American Free Trade Agreement. The anger is undeserved.
The proposed agreement would eliminate most trade barriers between the U.S. and its neighbors. The U.S. would benefit because the treaty would create more jobs than it would destroy, and lower consumer prices for everyone. 
 Not everyone will come out ahead. Indeed, auto workers in the Midwest would be threatened, notably in Michigan and Illinois, which hold primary elections tomorrow. That explains why candidates willing to pander to protectionism -- Democrat Jerry Brown and Republican Patrick Buchanan -- are suddenly finding friends.
Neither is likely to win nomination. Yet in the battle for votes, they might pressure their opponents to back away from supporting the trade agreement. The danger is not merely hypothetical. In a recent debate, Mr. Clinton soft-pedaled his support. And Mr. Tsongas, after repeating his allegiance to free trade, quickly added a list of difficult conditions.
Mr. Buchanan's protectionist calls pose graver problems. President Bush has already shown he is quick to cave in when Mr. Buchanan spouts off with right-wing broadsides. These capitulations invite fear that he will backtrack on trade, too. Getting lost in the debate is the value of freer trade. According to estimates by the respected Institute for International Economics, the agreement would create on balance about 130,000 U.S. jobs, and raise net exports by about $10 billion annually. Those aren't whopping numbers, but they are in the right direction.
The pact is more important to Mexico. Its Government has embarked on radical market reforms, overturning decades of stifling bureaucracy. By guaranteeing access to the huge U.S. market, the trade pact is the best signal the U.S. can send that it stands behind the Mexican reforms.
Freer trade with Mexico can't hurt the U.S., whose economy is 20 times larger. But not everyone wins. About 100,000 U.S. workers, mainly in autos and apparel, are expected to lose their jobs. The compassionate remedy would be generous dislocation assistance. Washington can also reassure environmental and labor organizations that the agreement will protect the environment and U.S. workplace safety.
What would be truly costly is for Government to cave in to election-year expediency. To maintain trade barriers would penalize hundreds of thousands of workers in industries, notably computers, pharmaceuticals and agriculture, that could pick up export sales and millions of consumers -- in other words, a greater bad for a much greater number.
